title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["Beyoncé Giselle Knowles-Carter (/biː'jɒnseɪ/ bee-YON-say) (born September 4, 1981) is an American singer, songwriter, record producer and actress. Born and raised in Houston, Texas, she performed in various singing and dancing competitions as a child, and rose to fame in the late 1990s as ••lead singer•• of R&B girl-group Destiny's Child. Managed by her father, Mathew Knowles, the group became one of the world's best-selling girl groups of all time. Their hiatus saw the release of Beyoncé's debut album, Dangerously in Love (2003), which established her as a solo artist worldwide, earned five Grammy Awards and featured the Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles Crazy in Love and Baby Boy."]
altered_context: ["Beyoncé Giselle Knowles-Carter (/biː'jɒnseɪ/ bee-YON-say) (born on September 4, 1981) is an American vocalist, composer, record producer, and actress. Raised in Houston, Texas, she took part in various singing and dancing contests during her childhood and gained prominence in the late 1990s as the ••leading vocalist•• of the R&B girl group Destiny's Child. The group, managed by her father, Mathew Knowles, became one of the most successful girl groups globally. Their break led to the release of Beyoncé's first album, Dangerously in Love (2003), which solidified her status as a solo performer internationally, won five Grammy Awards, and included the Billboard Hot 100 number-one hits Crazy in Love and Baby Boy."]
original_question: What role did Beyoncé have in Destiny's Child?
altered_question: What position did Beyoncé hold in Destiny's Child?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["Following the disbandment of Destiny's Child in June 2005, she released her second solo album, B'Day (2006), which contained hits Déjà Vu, Irreplaceable, and Beautiful Liar. Beyoncé also ventured into acting, with a Golden Globe-nominated performance in Dreamgirls (2006), and starring roles in The Pink Panther (2006) and Obsessed (2009). ", 'Her marriage to rapper Jay Z and portrayal of Etta James in Cadillac Records (2008) influenced her third album, I Am... Sasha Fierce (2008), which saw the birth of her alter-ego Sasha Fierce and earned a record-setting six Grammy Awards in ••2010••, including Song of the Year for Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It). Beyoncé took a hiatus from music in 2010 and took over management of her career؛ her fourth album 4 (2011) was subsequently mellower in tone, exploring 1970s funk, 1980s pop, and 1990s soul. Her critically acclaimed fifth studio album, Beyoncé (2013), was distinguished from previous releases by its experimental production and exploration of darker themes.']
altered_context: ["After the dissolution of Destiny's Child in June 2005, she issued her second solo record, B'Day (2006), which featured hits Déjà Vu, Irreplaceable, and Beautiful Liar. Beyoncé also embarked on an acting career, highlighted by a Golden Globe-nominated role in Dreamgirls (2006), along with prominent appearances in The Pink Panther (2006) and Obsessed (2009).", 'Her union with rapper Jay Z and her depiction of Etta James in Cadillac Records (2008) shaped her third album, I Am... Sasha Fierce (2008), which introduced her alter-ego Sasha Fierce and achieved a record-breaking six Grammy Awards in ••2010••, including the prestigious Song of the Year for Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It). Beyoncé took a break from music in 2010 and assumed full control of her career; her fourth album 4 (2011) was subsequently more subdued in tone, delving into the realms of 1970s funk, 1980s pop, and 1990s soul. Her widely praised fifth studio record, Beyoncé (2013), was characterized by its innovative production and examination of more somber themes.']
original_question: When did Beyonce take a hiatus in her career and take control of her management?
altered_question: In which year did Beyonce pause her career and assume management responsibility?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["A self-described modern-day feminist, Beyoncé creates songs that are often characterized by themes of love, relationships, and monogamy, as well as female sexuality and empowerment. On stage, her dynamic, highly choreographed performances have led to critics hailing her as one of the best entertainers in contemporary popular music. Throughout a career spanning 19 years, she has sold over 118 million records as a solo artist, and a further 60 million with Destiny's Child, making her one of the best-selling music artists of all time. ", "She has won 20 Grammy Awards and is the most nominated woman in the award's history. The Recording Industry Association of America recognized her as the Top Certified Artist in America during the 2000s decade. In 2009, Billboard named her the Top Radio Songs Artist of the Decade, the Top Female Artist of the 2000s and their Artist of the Millennium in 2011. Time listed her among the 100 most influential people in the world in 2013 and 2014. ••Forbes•• magazine also listed her as the most powerful female musician of 2015."]
altered_context: ["Beyoncé, who identifies as a contemporary feminist, produces music that frequently explores topics such as affection, partnerships, and exclusivity, alongside themes of female sexuality and empowerment. On stage, her vibrant and meticulously choreographed shows have led reviewers to acclaim her as one of the finest performers in modern popular music. Over a career that spans 19 years, she has sold more than 118 million records as a solo artist, in addition to another 60 million with Destiny's Child, solidifying her status as one of the top-selling music performers in history.", 'She has received 20 Grammy Awards and is recognized as the most nominated female in the history of the honors. The Recording Industry Association of America acknowledged her as the Top Certified Artist in the United States throughout the 2000s. In 2009, Billboard designated her as the Top Radio Songs Artist of the Decade, the Top Female Artist of the 2000s, and in 2011, they honored her as their Artist of the Millennium. Time featured her in the list of the 100 most influential individuals globally in both 2013 and 2014. ••Forbes•• magazine also recognized her as the most influential female music artist of 2015.']
original_question: What magazine named Beyoncé as the most powerful female musician for 2015?
altered_question: Which publication recognized Beyoncé as the most influential female musician for the year 2015?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["Beyoncé attended St. Mary's Elementary School in Fredericksburg, Texas, where she enrolled in dance classes. Her singing talent was discovered when dance instructor Darlette Johnson began humming a song and she finished it, able to hit the high-pitched notes. Beyoncé's interest in music and performing continued after winning a school talent show at age seven, singing John Lennon's Imagine to beat 15/16-year-olds. In fall of 1990, Beyoncé enrolled in Parker Elementary School, a music magnet school in ••Houston••, where she would perform with the school's choir. She also attended the High School for the Performing and Visual Arts and later Alief Elsik High School. Beyoncé was also a member of the choir at St. John's United Methodist Church as a soloist for two years."]
altered_context: ["Beyoncé attended St. Mary's Elementary School located in Fredericksburg, Texas, where she participated in dance lessons. Her vocal ability was recognized when dance teacher Darlette Johnson started humming a melody and she completed it, capable of reaching the high notes. Beyoncé's passion for music and performance persisted after winning a talent competition at school at the age of seven, singing John Lennon's Imagine to outperform individuals aged 15 and 16. In the autumn of 1990, Beyoncé enrolled in Parker Elementary School, a music-focused institution in ••Houston••, where she would sing with the school's choir. She also went to the High School for the Performing and Visual Arts and subsequently attended Alief Elsik High School. Additionally, Beyoncé was part of the choir at St. John's United Methodist Church, serving as a soloist for two years."]
original_question: Beyonce moved to which town after she left her first elementary school?
altered_question: In which city did Beyonce relocate after leaving her initial elementary school?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["At age eight, Beyoncé and childhood friend Kelly Rowland met LaTavia Roberson while in an audition for an all-girl entertainment group. They were placed into a group with three other girls as ••Girl's Tyme••, and rapped and danced on the talent show circuit in Houston. After seeing the group, R&B producer Arne Frager brought them to his Northern California studio and placed them in Star Search, the largest talent show on national TV at the time. Girl's Tyme failed to win, and Beyoncé later said the song they performed was not good. ", "In 1995 Beyoncé's father resigned from his job to manage the group. The move reduced Beyoncé's family's income by half, and her parents were forced to move into separated apartments. Mathew cut the original line-up to four and the group continued performing as an opening act for other established R&B girl groups. The girls auditioned before record labels and were finally signed to Elektra Records, moving to Atlanta Records briefly to work on their first recording, only to be cut by the company. This put further strain on the family, and Beyoncé's parents separated. On October 5, 1995, Dwayne Wiggins's Grass Roots Entertainment signed the group. In 1996, the girls began recording their debut album under an agreement with Sony Music, the Knowles family reunited, and shortly after, the group got a contract with Columbia Records."]
altered_context: ["At the age of eight, Beyoncé and her childhood companion Kelly Rowland encountered LaTavia Roberson during an audition for an all-female entertainment ensemble. They were placed into a collective with three additional girls named ••Girl's Tyme••, and they performed rap and dance routines on the talent show circuit in Houston. After witnessing the group, R&B producer Arne Frager invited them to his studio in Northern California and entered them into Star Search, the largest talent competition on national television at that time. Girl's Tyme did not succeed in winning, and Beyoncé later remarked that the song they showcased was subpar.", "In 1995, Beyoncé's father stepped down from his position to oversee the group. This decision halved Beyoncé's family's earnings, prompting her parents to move into separate residences. Mathew reduced the initial line-up to four members, and the group continued to perform as an opening act for other notable R&B girl groups. The girls auditioned in front of record labels and ultimately signed with Elektra Records, briefly shifting to Atlanta Records to work on their initial recording, only to be dropped by the label. This created additional pressure on the family, leading to Beyoncé's parents' separation. On October 5, 1995, Dwayne Wiggins's Grass Roots Entertainment signed the ensemble. By 1996, the girls started recording their first album under a contract with Sony Music, the Knowles family reconciled, and soon thereafter, the group secured a deal with Columbia Records."]
original_question: What was the name of the first group Beyoncé was a part of?
altered_question: What was the title of the initial group that Beyoncé joined?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["The group changed their name to Destiny's Child in 1996, based upon a passage in the Book of Isaiah. In 1997, Destiny's Child released their major label debut song Killing Time on the soundtrack to the 1997 film, Men in Black. The following year, the group released their self-titled debut album, scoring their first major hit No, No, No. The album established the group as a viable act in the music industry, with moderate sales and winning the group three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Best R&B/Soul or Rap New Artist, and Best R&B/Soul Single for No, No, No. ", "The group released their multi-platinum second album The Writing's on the Wall in 1999. The record features some of the group's most widely known songs such as Bills, Bills, Bills, the group's first number-one single, Jumpin' Jumpin' and Say My Name, which became their most successful song at the time, and would remain one of their signature songs. Say My Name won the Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and the Best R&B Song at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards. The Writing's on the Wall sold more than eight million copies worldwide. During this time, Beyoncé recorded a duet with ••Marc Nelson••, an original member of Boyz II Men, on the song After All Is Said and Done for the soundtrack to the 1999 film, The Best Man."]
altered_context: ["The ensemble altered their name to Destiny's Child in 1996, derived from a verse in the Book of Isaiah. In 1997, Destiny's Child launched their significant label debut track Killing Time as part of the soundtrack for the 1997 movie, Men in Black. The subsequent year, the ensemble released their self-titled debut album, achieving their initial major success with No, No, No. This album solidified the group as a credible act in the music scene, enjoying moderate sales and earning them three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Best R&B/Soul or Rap New Artist, and Best R&B/Soul Single for No, No, No.", "The ensemble debuted their multi-platinum second album The Writing's on the Wall in 1999. The album includes some of the group's most famous tracks like Bills, Bills, Bills, which was their first number-one hit, along with Jumpin' Jumpin' and Say My Name, which turned out to be their most prosperous track at that time, and would remain one of their iconic songs. Say My Name earned the accolades for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and Best R&B Song at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards. The Writing's on the Wall achieved sales of over eight million copies globally. During this period, Beyoncé collaborated on a duet with Marc Nelson, an original member of Boyz II Men, performing the track After All Is Said and Done for the soundtrack to the 1999 movie, The Best Man."]
original_question: Who did Beyoncé sing a duet with for "The Best Man" film?
altered_question: With whom did Beyoncé collaborate on a duet for the film 'The Best Man'?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["The remaining band members recorded ••Independent Women Part I••, which appeared on the soundtrack to the 2000 film, Charlie's Angels. It became their best-charting single, topping the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart for eleven consecutive weeks. In early 2001, while Destiny's Child was completing their third album, Beyoncé landed a major role in the MTV made-for-television film, Carmen: A Hip Hopera, starring alongside American actor Mekhi Phifer. Set in Philadelphia, the film is a modern interpretation of the 19th century opera Carmen by French composer Georges Bizet. When the third album Survivor was released in May 2001, Luckett and Roberson filed a lawsuit claiming that the songs were aimed at them. ", 'The album debuted at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200, with first-week sales of 663,000 copies sold. The album spawned other number-one hits, Bootylicious and the title track, Survivor, the latter of which earned the group a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals. After releasing their holiday album 8 Days of Christmas in October 2001, the group announced a hiatus to further pursue solo careers.']
altered_context: ["The other members of the band recorded ••Independent Women Part I••, which was included in the soundtrack of the 2000 movie, Charlie's Angels. It became their most successful single, reaching the top of the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart for eleven straight weeks. In the beginning of 2001, while Destiny's Child was finalizing their third album, Beyoncé secured a significant role in the MTV film made for TV, Carmen: A Hip Hopera, performing alongside American actor Mekhi Phifer. Set in Philadelphia, the film is a contemporary version of the 19th century opera Carmen by French composer Georges Bizet. When the third album Survivor was launched in May 2001, Luckett and Roberson initiated a lawsuit asserting that the songs were directed at them.", 'The album premiered at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200, with first-week sales of 663,000 units. The album also produced other chart-topping hits, Bootylicious and the title song, Survivor, the latter of which granted the group a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals. After launching their festive album 8 Days of Christmas in October 2001, the group declared a break to pursue individual careers more extensively.']
original_question: "Charlie's Angels" featured which single from the band members?
altered_question: Which single from the band members was part of the soundtrack for 'Charlie's Angels'?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ['In ••November 2003••, she embarked on the Dangerously in Love Tour in Europe and later toured alongside Missy Elliott and Alicia Keys for the Verizon Ladies First Tour in North America. On February 1, 2004, Beyoncé performed the American national anthem at Super Bowl XXXVIII, at the Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas. After the release of Dangerously in Love, Beyoncé had planned to produce a follow-up album using several of the left-over tracks. ', "However, this was put on hold so she could concentrate on recording Destiny Fulfilled, the final studio album by Destiny's Child. Released on November 15, 2004, in the US and peaking at number two on the Billboard 200, Destiny Fulfilled included the singles Lose My Breath and Soldier, which reached the top five on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Destiny's Child embarked on a worldwide concert tour, Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It and during the last stop of their European tour, in Barcelona on June 11, 2005, Rowland announced that Destiny's Child would disband following the North American leg of the tour. The group released their first compilation album Number 1's on October 25, 2005, in the US and accepted a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in March 2006."]
altered_context: ['In ••November 2003••, she initiated the Dangerously in Love Tour across Europe and subsequently performed alongside Missy Elliott and Alicia Keys for the Verizon Ladies First Tour in North America. On February 1, 2004, Beyoncé sang the American national anthem at Super Bowl XXXVIII, held at the Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas. Following the launch of Dangerously in Love, Beyoncé intended to create a subsequent album with several unused tracks. ', "However, this was postponed so she could focus on recording Destiny Fulfilled, the ultimate studio album by Destiny's Child. Released on November 15, 2004, in the US and achieving a peak position of number two on the Billboard 200, Destiny Fulfilled featured the singles Lose My Breath and Soldier, which climbed into the top five on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Destiny's Child kicked off a global concert tour, Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It, and during the final stop of their European tour, in Barcelona on June 11, 2005, Rowland revealed that Destiny's Child would dissolve following the North American leg of the tour. The group launched their inaugural compilation album Number 1's on October 25, 2005, in the US and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in March 2006."]
original_question: In what year did Beyonce embark on her Dangerously in Love tour of Europe?
altered_question: In which year did Beyoncé start her Dangerously in Love tour in Europe?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States. The album formally introduces Beyoncé's alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single Crazy in Love, selling 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting atop the Billboard 200, and giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US. ", "The album featured the number-one song Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It) and the top-five songs If I Were a Boy and Halo. Achieving the accomplishment of becoming her longest-running Hot 100 single in her career, Halo's success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top-ten singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s. It also included the successful Sweet Dreams, and singles Diva, Ego, Broken-Hearted Girl and Video Phone. The music video for Single Ladies has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the first major dance craze of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. The video has won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year. ", "Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American country pop singer ••Taylor Swift••'s You Belong with Me, led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance speech. In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5 million."]
altered_context: ["On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé entered into matrimony with Jay Z. She made their union public in a video compilation at the release event for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, held at Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce debuted in the United States on November 18, 2008. The album formally introduces Beyoncé's alter persona Sasha Fierce, which was developed during the production of her 2003 hit Crazy in Love, selling 482,000 copies in its opening week, debuting at the top of the Billboard 200, and marking Beyoncé's third consecutive number-one album in the US. ", "The album included the chart-topping track Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It) as well as the top-five hits If I Were a Boy and Halo. Achieving the distinction of being her longest-lasting Hot 100 single throughout her career, Halo's success in the US enabled Beyoncé to secure more top-ten singles on the chart than any other female artist during the 2000s. Additionally, it featured the popular Sweet Dreams, along with singles Diva, Ego, Broken-Hearted Girl, and Video Phone. The music video for Single Ladies has been spoofed and replicated worldwide, initiating the first significant dance trend of the Internet era, as noted by the Toronto Star. The video earned multiple accolades, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. During the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video received nine nominations, ultimately winning three, including Video of the Year. ", "Its inability to secure the Best Female Video award, which was won by American country pop artist ••Taylor Swift•• for her song You Belong with Me, resulted in Kanye West disrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance address. In March 2009, Beyoncé kicked off the I Am... World Tour, her second global concert series, consisting of 108 performances and generating $119.5 million in revenue."]
original_question: Which singer beat out Beyonce for best video performance?
altered_question: Which artist outperformed Beyonce for the best video accolade?

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["At age eight, Beyoncé and childhood friend Kelly Rowland met LaTavia Roberson while in an audition for an all-girl entertainment group. They were placed into a group with three other girls as ••Girl's Tyme••, and rapped and danced on the talent show circuit in Houston. After seeing the group, R&B producer Arne Frager brought them to his Northern California studio and placed them in Star Search, the largest talent show on national TV at the time. Girl's Tyme failed to win, and Beyoncé later said the song they performed was not good. ", "In 1995 Beyoncé's father resigned from his job to manage the group. The move reduced Beyoncé's family's income by half, and her parents were forced to move into separated apartments. Mathew cut the original line-up to four and the group continued performing as an opening act for other established R&B girl groups. The girls auditioned before record labels and were finally signed to Elektra Records, moving to Atlanta Records briefly to work on their first recording, only to be cut by the company. This put further strain on the family, and Beyoncé's parents separated. On October 5, 1995, Dwayne Wiggins's Grass Roots Entertainment signed the group. In 1996, the girls began recording their debut album under an agreement with Sony Music, the Knowles family reunited, and shortly after, the group got a contract with Columbia Records."]

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["The group changed their name to Destiny's Child in 1996, based upon a passage in the Book of Isaiah. In 1997, Destiny's Child released their major label debut song Killing Time on the soundtrack to the 1997 film, Men in Black. The following year, the group released their self-titled debut album, scoring their first major hit No, No, No. The album established the group as a viable act in the music industry, with moderate sales and winning the group three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Best R&B/Soul or Rap New Artist, and Best R&B/Soul Single for No, No, No. ", "The group released their multi-platinum second album The Writing's on the Wall in 1999. The record features some of the group's most widely known songs such as Bills, Bills, Bills, the group's first number-one single, Jumpin' Jumpin' and Say My Name, which became their most successful song at the time, and would remain one of their signature songs. Say My Name won the Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and the Best R&B Song at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards. The Writing's on the Wall sold more than eight million copies worldwide. During this time, Beyoncé recorded a duet with ••Marc Nelson••, an original member of Boyz II Men, on the song After All Is Said and Done for the soundtrack to the 1999 film, The Best Man."]

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ['In ••November 2003••, she embarked on the Dangerously in Love Tour in Europe and later toured alongside Missy Elliott and Alicia Keys for the Verizon Ladies First Tour in North America. On February 1, 2004, Beyoncé performed the American national anthem at Super Bowl XXXVIII, at the Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas. After the release of Dangerously in Love, Beyoncé had planned to produce a follow-up album using several of the left-over tracks. ', "However, this was put on hold so she could concentrate on recording Destiny Fulfilled, the final studio album by Destiny's Child. Released on November 15, 2004, in the US and peaking at number two on the Billboard 200, Destiny Fulfilled included the singles Lose My Breath and Soldier, which reached the top five on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Destiny's Child embarked on a worldwide concert tour, Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It and during the last stop of their European tour, in Barcelona on June 11, 2005, Rowland announced that Destiny's Child would disband following the North American leg of the tour. The group released their first compilation album Number 1's on October 25, 2005, in the US and accepted a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in March 2006."]

title: Beyoncé
original_context: ["On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States. The album formally introduces Beyoncé's alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single Crazy in Love, selling 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting atop the Billboard 200, and giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US. ", "The album featured the number-one song Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It) and the top-five songs If I Were a Boy and Halo. Achieving the accomplishment of becoming her longest-running Hot 100 single in her career, Halo's success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top-ten singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s. It also included the successful Sweet Dreams, and singles Diva, Ego, Broken-Hearted Girl and Video Phone. The music video for Single Ladies has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the first major dance craze of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. The video has won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year. ", "Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American country pop singer ••Taylor Swift••'s You Belong with Me, led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance speech. In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5 million."]

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ['At the age of 21 he settled in Paris. Thereafter, during the last 18 years of his life, he gave only some 30 public performances, preferring the more intimate atmosphere of the salon. He supported himself by selling his compositions and teaching piano, for which he was in high demand. Chopin formed a friendship with Franz Liszt and was admired by many of his musical contemporaries, including Robert Schumann. In ••1835•• he obtained French citizenship. After a failed engagement to Maria Wodzińska, from 1837 to 1847 he maintained an often troubled relationship with the French writer George Sand. A brief and unhappy visit to Majorca with Sand in 1838--39 was one of his most productive periods of composition. In his last years, he was financially supported by his admirer Jane Stirling, who also arranged for him to visit Scotland in 1848. Through most of his life, Chopin suffered from poor health. He died in Paris in 1849, probably of tuberculosis.']
altered_context: ['At the age of 21, he established his residence in Paris. Following that, over the next 18 years of his existence, he participated in merely around 30 public performances, favoring the more personal setting of the salon. He earned a living by marketing his musical works and instructing piano, for which there was considerable demand. Chopin developed a friendship with Franz Liszt and was respected by numerous of his musical peers, such as Robert Schumann. In ••1835••, he acquired French citizenship. After an unsuccessful engagement to Maria Wodzińska, from 1837 to 1847 he experienced a frequently tumultuous relationship with the French author George Sand. A short and disappointing trip to Majorca with Sand in 1838--39 turned out to be one of his most fruitful phases of composition. During his final years, he received financial assistance from his supporter Jane Stirling, who also organized a visit for him to Scotland in 1848. Throughout most of his lifetime, Chopin endured poor health. He passed away in Paris in 1849, likely due to tuberculosis.']
original_question: In what year did Chopin become a French citizen?
altered_question: Which year did Chopin acquire citizenship in France?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["All of Chopin's compositions include the piano. Most are for solo piano, though he also wrote two piano concertos, a few chamber pieces, and some songs to Polish lyrics. His keyboard style is highly individual and often technically demanding؛ his own performances were noted for their nuance and sensitivity. Chopin invented the concept of instrumental ballade. His major piano works also include mazurkas, waltzes, nocturnes, polonaises, études, impromptus, scherzos, preludes and sonatas, some published only after his death. Influences on his compositional style include Polish folk music, the classical tradition of ••J. S. Bach, Mozart and Schubert••, the music of all of whom he admired, as well as the Paris salons where he was a frequent guest. His innovations in style, musical form, and harmony, and his association of music with nationalism, were influential throughout and after the late Romantic period."]
altered_context: ['Every composition by Chopin incorporates the piano. The majority are intended for solo piano, although he also created two piano concertos, several chamber works, and some melodies with Polish lyrics. His approach to the keyboard is uniquely personal and frequently technically challenging; his own performances were recognized for their subtlety and expressiveness. Chopin was the pioneer of the instrumental ballade concept. His significant piano pieces also encompass mazurkas, waltzes, nocturnes, polonaises, études, impromptus, scherzos, preludes, and sonatas, with some being released only after his passing. His compositional style drew inspiration from Polish folk tunes, the classical legacies of J. S. Bach, Mozart, and Schubert, whose music he held in high esteem, along with the Paris salons where he was a regular visitor. His stylistic innovations, musical structures, and harmonic concepts, along with his linking of music to nationalism, greatly influenced the late Romantic era and beyond.']
original_question: What three composers did Chopin take inspiration from?
altered_question: Which three composers inspired Chopin?
answer: J. S. Bach, Mozart and Schubert

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ['Fryderyk Chopin was born in ••Żelazowa Wola••, 46 kilometres (29 miles) west of Warsaw, in what was then the Duchy of Warsaw, a Polish state established by Napoleon. The parish baptismal record gives his birthday as 22 February 1810, and cites his given names in the Latin form Fridericus Franciscus (in Polish, he was Fryderyk Franciszek). However, the composer and his family used the birthdate 1 March,[n 2] which is now generally accepted as the correct date.']

For the prince and his pianist daughter Wanda, he composed his Introduction and Polonaise brillante in C major for cello and piano, Op. 3.']

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Chopin's successes as a composer and performer opened the door to western Europe for him, and on 2 November 1830, he set out, in the words of Zdzisław Jachimecki, into the wide world, with no very clearly defined aim, forever. With Woyciechowski, he headed for Austria, intending to go on to Italy. Later that month, in Warsaw, the November 1830 Uprising broke out, and Woyciechowski returned to Poland to enlist. Chopin, now alone in Vienna, was nostalgic for his homeland, and wrote to a friend, I curse the moment of my departure. When in September ••1831•• he learned, while travelling from Vienna to Paris, that the uprising had been crushed, he expressed his anguish in the pages of his private journal: Oh God! ... You are there, and yet you do not take vengeance! Jachimecki ascribes to these events the composer's maturing into an inspired national bard who intuited the past, present and future of his native Poland."]
altered_context: ["Chopin's achievements as both a composer and a performer facilitated his entry into Western Europe, and on 2 November 1830, he embarked, in the words of Zdzisław Jachimecki, into the vast world, without any particularly well-defined objective, for eternity. Accompanied by Woyciechowski, he traveled toward Austria, with plans to continue on to Italy. Later that month, in Warsaw, the November 1830 Uprising erupted, prompting Woyciechowski to return to Poland to enlist. Left by himself in Vienna, Chopin felt a deep sorrow for his homeland and penned a letter to a friend, lamenting the moment he left. When in September 1831 he discovered, while journeying from Vienna to Paris, that the uprising had been quelled, he conveyed his despair in his personal journal: Oh God! ... You are present, yet You do not take retribution! Jachimecki attributes these occurrences to the composer's evolution into an inspired national bard who sensed the past, present, and future of his beloved Poland."]
original_question: What year did Chopin learn that the uprising in Warsaw was crushed?
altered_question: In which year did Chopin find out that the uprising in Warsaw had been suppressed?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ['In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, and it was there that Chopin met Felix Mendelssohn. After the festival, the three visited Düsseldorf, where Mendelssohn had been appointed musical director. They spent what Mendelssohn described as a very agreeable day, playing and discussing music at his piano, and met ••Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow••, director of the Academy of Art, and some of his eminent pupils such as Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt and Sohn. In 1835 Chopin went to Carlsbad, where he spent time with his parents؛ it was the last time he would see them. On his way back to Paris, he met old friends from Warsaw, the Wodzińskis. He had made the acquaintance of their daughter Maria in Poland five years earlier, when she was eleven. This meeting prompted him to stay for two weeks in Dresden, when he had previously intended to return to Paris via Leipzig. ', "The sixteen-year-old girl's portrait of the composer is considered, along with Delacroix's, as among Chopin's best likenesses. In October he finally reached Leipzig, where he met Schumann, Clara Wieck and Felix Mendelssohn, who organised for him a performance of his own oratorio St. Paul, and who considered him a perfect musician. In July 1836 Chopin travelled to Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family, and in September he proposed to Maria, whose mother Countess Wodzińska approved in principle. Chopin went on to Leipzig, where he presented Schumann with his G minor Ballade. At the end of 1836 he sent Maria an album in which his sister Ludwika had inscribed seven of his songs, and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. The anodyne thanks he received from Maria proved to be the last letter he was to have from her."]
altered_context: ['During the spring of 1834, Chopin participated in the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle alongside Hiller, where he encountered Felix Mendelssohn. Following the festival, the trio traveled to Düsseldorf, where Mendelssohn had been named musical director. They enjoyed what Mendelssohn referred to as a most pleasant day, engaging in music and discussions at his piano, and met ••Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow••, head of the Academy of Art, along with several of his distinguished students including Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt, and Sohn. In 1835, Chopin visited Carlsbad, spending time with his parents; it was the final occasion he would see them. On his return to Paris, he reunited with old friends from Warsaw, the Wodzińskis. He had become acquainted with their daughter Maria in Poland five years prior, when she was just eleven. This reunion led him to linger in Dresden for two weeks, a change from his original plan to return to Paris through Leipzig.', "The portrait of the composer created by the sixteen-year-old girl is regarded, alongside Delacroix's, as one of the finest representations of Chopin. By October, he had finally arrived in Leipzig, where he met Schumann, Clara Wieck, and Felix Mendelssohn, who arranged for a performance of his own oratorio St. Paul, and deemed him a flawless musician. In July 1836, Chopin journeyed to Marienbad and Dresden to spend time with the Wodziński family, and in September, he proposed to Maria, whose mother Countess Wodzińska gave preliminary approval. Chopin then traveled to Leipzig, where he gifted Schumann his G minor Ballade. By the end of 1836, he sent Maria an album containing seven of his songs inscribed by his sister Ludwika, as well as his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. The bland gratitude he received from Maria turned out to be the last correspondence he would receive from her."]
original_question: Who was the director of the Academy of Art that Frédéric met while in Düsseldorf?
altered_question: Who held the position of director at the Academy of Art that Frédéric encountered while in Düsseldorf?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["The two became friends, and for many years lived in close proximity in Paris, Chopin at 38 Rue de la Chaussée-d'Antin, and Liszt at the Hôtel de France on the Rue Lafitte, a few blocks away. They performed together on seven occasions between 1833 and 1841. The first, on 2 April 1833, was at a benefit concert organized by Hector Berlioz for his bankrupt Shakespearean actress wife ••Harriet Smithson••, during which they played George Onslow's Sonata in F minor for piano duet. Later joint appearances included a benefit concert for the Benevolent Association of Polish Ladies in Paris. Their last appearance together in public was for a charity concert conducted for the Beethoven Memorial in Bonn, held at the Salle Pleyel and the Paris Conservatory on 25 and 26 April 1841."]
altered_context: ["The two developed a friendship, and for numerous years resided in close quarters in Paris, Chopin at 38 Rue de la Chaussée-d'Antin, and Liszt at the Hôtel de France situated on the Rue Lafitte, just a few blocks apart. The initial occasion, on 2 April 1833, took place at a charity concert organized by Hector Berlioz for his financially troubled Shakespearean actress spouse ••Harriet Smithson••, during which they performed George Onslow's Sonata in F minor for piano duet. Subsequent joint performances included a fundraising concert for the Benevolent Association of Polish Ladies in Paris. Their final public performance together occurred at a charity concert conducted for the Beethoven Memorial in Bonn, which took place at the Salle Pleyel and the Paris Conservatory on 25 and 26 April 1841."]

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["At the funeral of the tenor Adolphe Nourrit in Paris in 1839, Chopin made a rare appearance at the organ, playing a transcription of Franz Schubert's lied Die Gestirne. On 26 July 1840 Chopin and Sand were present at the dress rehearsal of ••Berlioz's Grande symphonie funèbre et triomphale••, composed to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the July Revolution. Chopin was reportedly unimpressed with the composition."]

It was reported that Chopin was not particularly impressed with the piece."]

title: Frédéric_Chopin

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Chopin also endowed popular dance forms with a greater range of melody and expression. Chopin's mazurkas, while originating in the traditional Polish dance (the mazurek), differed from the traditional variety in that they were written for the concert hall rather than the dance hall؛ it was Chopin who put the mazurka on the European musical map. The series of seven polonaises published in his lifetime (another ••nine•• were published posthumously), beginning with the Op. 26 pair (published 1836), set a new standard for music in the form. His waltzes were also written specifically for the salon recital rather than the ballroom and are frequently at rather faster tempos than their dance-floor equivalents."]
altered_context: ['Chopin additionally infused well-known dance styles with an expanded variety of melody and emotional depth. While the mazurkas by Chopin were derived from the classic Polish dance known as the mazurek, they were distinct from the traditional type as they were composed for concert performances instead of for social dances; it was Chopin who brought the mazurka to the forefront of European music. The collection of seven polonaises that were released during his lifetime (with another nine being published after his death), starting with the pair from Op. 26 (released in 1836), established a new benchmark for music in this genre. His waltzes were likewise crafted specifically for salon performances rather than ballroom events and are often played at considerably quicker tempos compared to typical dance music.']
original_question: How many polonaises were published after Chopin died?
altered_question: What is the number of polonaises that were released following Chopin's passing?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Some of Chopin's well-known pieces have acquired descriptive titles, such as ••the Revolutionary Étude•• (Op. 10, No. 12), and the Minute Waltz (Op. 64, No. 1). However, with the exception of his Funeral March, the composer never named an instrumental work beyond genre and number, leaving all potential extramusical associations to the listener؛ the names by which many of his pieces are known were invented by others. There is no evidence to suggest that the Revolutionary Étude was written with the failed Polish uprising against Russia in mind؛ it merely appeared at that time. The Funeral March, the third movement of his Sonata No. 2 (Op. 35), the one case where he did give a title, was written before the rest of the sonata, but no specific event or death is known to have inspired it."]
altered_context: ["Several of Chopin's famous compositions have taken on descriptive names, such as ••the Revolutionary Étude•• (Op. 10, No. 12), along with the Minute Waltz (Op. 64, No. 1). Nonetheless, apart from his Funeral March, the composer did not assign a title to any instrumental piece beyond its genre and numerical designation, allowing all possible associations outside of the music to the audience; the titles by which many of his works are recognized were created by others. There are no indications to imply that the Revolutionary Étude was composed with the unsuccessful Polish revolt against Russia in consideration; it simply surfaced during that period. The Funeral March, which is the third movement of his Sonata No. 2 (Op. 35) and the sole instance where he provided a title, was composed prior to the completion of the rest of the sonata, yet no particular incident or death is recognized to have influenced it."]
original_question: What is another title Op. 10, No. 12 has garnered?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Improvisation stands at the centre of Chopin's creative processes. However, this does not imply impulsive rambling: Nicholas Temperley writes that improvisation is designed for an audience, and its starting-point is that audience's expectations, which include the current conventions of musical form. The works for piano and orchestra, including the two concertos, are held by Temperley to be merely vehicles for brilliant piano playing ... formally longwinded and extremely conservative. After the piano concertos (which are both early, dating from 1830), Chopin made no attempts at large-scale multi-movement forms, save for his late sonatas for piano and for cello؛ instead he achieved near-perfection in pieces of simple general design but subtle and complex cell-structure. Rosen suggests that an important aspect of Chopin's individuality is his flexible handling of ••the four-bar phrase•• as a structural unit."]
altered_context: ["Improvisation is pivotal in Chopin's artistic practices. Nevertheless, this does not suggest reckless drivel: Nicholas Temperley notes that improvisation is intended for an audience, and its foundation lies in that audience's anticipations, which encompass the existing norms of musical structure. The compositions for piano and orchestra, encompassing the two concertos, are considered by Temperley to be merely instruments for showcasing exceptional piano performance ... structurally protracted and exceedingly traditional. Following the piano concertos (which are both early, originating from 1830), Chopin did not pursue expansive multi-movement forms, except for his later sonatas for piano and cello; instead, he reached near-perfection in pieces of straightforward overall design yet intricate and sophisticated cell-architecture. Rosen proposes that a significant element of Chopin's distinctiveness is his adaptable approach to ••the four-bar phrase•• as a foundational component."]
original_question: Rosen suggests that a central part of Chopin's uniqueness is how he handles what?
altered_question: Rosen proposes that a key element of Chopin's distinctiveness is his method of handling what?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Chopin's harmonic innovations may have arisen partly from his keyboard improvisation technique. ••Temperley•• says that in his works novel harmonic effects frequently result from the combination of ordinary appoggiaturas or passing notes with melodic figures of accompaniment, and cadences are delayed by the use of chords outside the home key (neapolitan sixths and diminished sevenths), or by sudden shifts to remote keys. Chord progressions sometimes anticipate the shifting tonality of later composers such as Claude Debussy, as does Chopin's use of modal harmony."]
altered_context: ["Chopin's harmonic breakthroughs might have originated in part from his piano improvisational methods. ••Temperley•• states that in his compositions, new harmonic effects often emerge from the blend of typical appoggiaturas or passing tones combined with accompanying melodic figures, with cadences postponed through the inclusion of chords beyond the principal key (neapolitan sixths and diminished sevenths), or by abrupt transitions to distant keys. Chord sequences occasionally foreshadow the changing tonality found in later composers like Claude Debussy, similar to Chopin's application of modal harmony."]
original_question: Who wrote about Chopin's "novel harmonic effects"?
altered_question: Who discussed Chopin's 'new harmonic effects'?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["••Friederike Müller••, a pupil of Chopin, wrote: [His] playing was always noble and beautiful؛ his tones sang, whether in full forte or softest piano. He took infinite pains to teach his pupils this legato, cantabile style of playing. His most severe criticism was 'He--or she--does not know how to join two notes together.' He also demanded the strictest adherence to rhythm. He hated all lingering and dragging, misplaced rubatos, as well as exaggerated ritardandos ... and it is precisely in this respect that people make such terrible errors in playing his works."]
altered_context: ["••Friederike Müller••, a disciple of Chopin, noted: [His] performance was invariably noble and exquisite; his tones resonated, whether at full crescendo or the softest pianissimo. He expended tremendous effort to instruct his students in this legato, cantabile technique of playing. His most harsh critique was 'He--or she--does not understand how to connect two notes together.' He also insisted on the utmost precision to rhythm. He despised any delay and dragging, improper rubatos, as well as exaggerated slowing ... and it is particularly in this aspect that individuals commit such grave mistakes in interpreting his compositions."]
original_question: Which student said Chopin made sure his students knew his legato, cantabile style of playing?
altered_question: Which pupil mentioned that Chopin ensured his students grasped his legato, cantabile technique of playing?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Jones comments that Chopin's unique position as a composer, despite the fact that virtually everything he wrote was for the piano, has rarely been questioned. He also notes that Chopin was fortunate to arrive in Paris in 1831--the artistic environment, the publishers who were willing to print his music, the wealthy and aristocratic who paid what Chopin asked for their lessons--and these factors, as well as his musical genius, also fuelled his contemporary and later reputation. While his illness and his love-affairs conform to some of the stereotypes of romanticism, the rarity of his public recitals (as opposed to performances at fashionable Paris soirées) led Arthur Hutchings to suggest that his lack of ••Byronic flamboyance•• [and] his aristocratic reclusiveness make him exceptional among his romantic contemporaries, such as Liszt and Henri Herz."]
altered_context: ["Jones observes that Chopin's distinctive role as a composer, even though nearly all his compositions were for the piano, has seldom been challenged. He also remarks that Chopin was lucky to reach Paris in 1831--the cultural scene, the publishers eager to disseminate his music, the affluent and noble individuals who compensated Chopin according to his requests for their lessons--and these elements, along with his musical brilliance, also contributed to his reputation during his time and beyond. While his health issues and romantic entanglements align with certain clichés of romanticism, the infrequency of his public performances (in contrast to appearances at stylish Parisian soirées) led Arthur Hutchings to propose that his absence of ••Byronic flamboyance•• [and] his noble seclusion distinguishes him among his romantic peers, such as Liszt and Henri Herz."]
original_question: Arthur Hutchings stated that Chopin's lack of what made him special?
altered_question: Arthur Hutchings indicated that Chopin's absence of what attribute made him distinctive?

title: Frédéric_Chopin
original_context: ["Jones comments that Chopin's unique position as a composer, despite the fact that virtually everything he wrote was for the piano, has rarely been questioned. He also notes that Chopin was fortunate to arrive in Paris in 1831--the artistic environment, the publishers who were willing to print his music, the wealthy and aristocratic who paid what Chopin asked for their lessons--and these factors, as well as his musical genius, also fuelled his contemporary and later reputation. While his illness and his love-affairs conform to some of the stereotypes of romanticism, the rarity of his public recitals (as opposed to performances at fashionable Paris soirées) led ••Arthur Hutchings•• to suggest that his lack of Byronic flamboyance [and] his aristocratic reclusiveness make him exceptional among his romantic contemporaries, such as Liszt and Henri Herz."]
altered_context: ["Jones remarks that Chopin's distinct status as a composer, even though nearly all of his works were composed for the piano, has seldom been questioned. He also mentions that Chopin was fortunate to arrive in Paris in 1831--the artistic atmosphere, the publishers ready to print his compositions, and the affluent and noble who consented to his fees for lessons--and these aspects, along with his musical talent, contributed to his reputation both during his lifetime and afterward. Although his health issues and romantic involvements fit some common stereotypes of romanticism, the infrequency of his public performances (as opposed to appearances at stylish Parisian soirées) led ••Arthur Hutchings•• to propose that his absence of Byronic flamboyance [and] his high-born seclusion render him extraordinary among his romantic peers, such as Liszt and Henri Herz."]
original_question: Who said Chopin was unlike his romantic contemporaries Liszt and Henri Herz?
altered_question: Who proposed that Chopin was distinct from his romantic peers Liszt and Henri Herz?

title: Sino-Tibetan_relations_during_the_Ming_dynasty
original_context: ['According to Tibetologist ••John Powers••, Tibetan sources counter this narrative of titles granted by the Chinese to Tibetans with various titles which the Tibetans gave to the Chinese emperors and their officials. Tribute missions from Tibetan monasteries to the Chinese court brought back not only titles, but large, commercially valuable gifts which could subsequently be sold. The Ming emperors sent invitations to ruling lamas, but the lamas sent subordinates rather than coming themselves, and no Tibetan ruler ever explicitly accepted the role of being a vassal of the Ming.']

title: Sino-Tibetan_relations_during_the_Ming_dynasty
original_context: ["Throughout the following month, the Yongle Emperor and his court showered the Karmapa with presents. At ••Linggu Temple•• in Nanjing, he presided over the religious ceremonies for the Yongle Emperor's deceased parents, while twenty-two days of his stay were marked by religious miracles that were recorded in five languages on a gigantic scroll that bore the Emperor's seal. During his stay in Nanjing, Deshin Shekpa was bestowed the title Great Treasure Prince of Dharma by the Yongle Emperor. Elliot Sperling asserts that the Yongle Emperor, in bestowing Deshin Shekpa with the title of King and praising his mystical abilities and miracles, was trying to build an alliance with the Karmapa as the Mongols had with the Sakya lamas, but Deshin Shekpa rejected the Yongle Emperor's offer. In fact, this was the same title that Kublai Khan had offered the Sakya Phagpa lama, but Deshin Shekpa persuaded the Yongle Emperor to grant the title to religious leaders of other Tibetan Buddhist sects."]
altered_context: Throughout the subsequent month, the Yongle Emperor and his entourage lavished the Karmapa with gifts. At ••Linggu Temple•• in Nanjing, he officiated the religious rituals for the Yongle Emperor's late parents, while twenty-two days of his visit were highlighted by spiritual miracles that were documented in five different languages on a massive scroll that carried the Emperor's insignia. During his time in Nanjing, Deshin Shekpa was granted the title Great Treasure Prince of Dharma by the Yongle Emperor. Elliot Sperling claims that the Yongle Emperor, by bestowing Deshin Shekpa with the title of King and commending his mystical talents and phenomena, was attempting to cultivate an alliance with the Karmapa similar to the one the Mongols had with the Sakya lamas, but Deshin Shekpa declined the Yongle Emperor's proposition. Indeed, this was the identical title that Kublai Khan had offered the Sakya Phagpa lama, yet Deshin Shekpa convinced the Yongle Emperor to award the title to spiritual leaders from other Tibetan Buddhist traditions.

title: Sino-Tibetan_relations_during_the_Ming_dynasty
original_context: ['Tsai writes that shortly after the visit by Deshin Shekpa, the Yongle Emperor ordered the construction of a road and of trading posts in the upper reaches of the Yangzi and Mekong Rivers in order to facilitate trade with Tibet in tea, horses, and salt. The trade route passed ••through Sichuan and crossed Shangri-La County in Yunnan••. Wang and Nyima assert that this tribute-related trade of the Ming exchanging Chinese tea for Tibetan horses--while granting Tibetan envoys and Tibetan merchants explicit permission to trade with Han Chinese merchants--furthered the rule of the Ming dynasty court over Tibet. ', "Rossabi and Sperling note that this trade in Tibetan horses for Chinese tea existed long before the Ming. Peter C. Perdue says that Wang Anshi (1021--1086), realizing that China could not produce enough militarily capable steeds, had also aimed to obtain horses from Inner Asia in exchange for Chinese tea. The Chinese needed horses not only for cavalry but also as draft animals for the army's supply wagons. The Tibetans required Chinese tea not only as a common beverage but also as a religious ceremonial supplement. The Ming government imposed a monopoly on tea production and attempted to regulate this trade with state-supervised markets, but these collapsed in 1449 due to military failures and internal ecological and commercial pressures on the tea-producing regions."]

Wang and Nyima maintain that this tribute-related commerce of the Ming, which involved exchanging Chinese tea for Tibetan horses—while granting clear authorization to Tibetan envoys and merchants to engage with Han Chinese traders—strengthened the authority of the Ming dynasty court over Tibet.', "Rossabi and Sperling observe that this exchange of Tibetan horses for Chinese tea had been established long before the Ming period. Peter C. Perdue mentions that Wang Anshi (1021–1086), upon realizing that China was unable to generate a sufficient number of militarily effective horses, sought to procure horses from Inner Asia in return for Chinese tea. The Chinese needed horses not just for cavalry purposes but also as work animals for the army's supply carts. Meanwhile, the Tibetans sought Chinese tea, not only as a popular drink but also as a component of religious ceremonies. The Ming administration enforced a monopoly over tea production and made attempts to oversee this trade through state-regulated markets, which ultimately failed in 1449 due to military setbacks and internal environmental and commercial stressors affecting the tea-producing areas."]

title: Sino-Tibetan_relations_during_the_Ming_dynasty
original_context: ['During the reign of the Jiajing Emperor (r. 1521--1567), the native Chinese ideology of Daoism was fully sponsored at the Ming court, while Tibetan Vajrayana and even Chinese Buddhism were ignored or suppressed. Even the History of Ming states that the Tibetan lamas discontinued their trips to Ming China and its court at this point. Grand Secretary ••Yang Tinghe•• under Jiajing was determined to break the eunuch influence at court which typified the Zhengde era, an example being the costly escort of the eunuch Liu Yun as described above in his failed mission to Tibet. The court eunuchs were in favor of expanding and building new commercial ties with foreign countries such as Portugal, which Zhengde deemed permissible since he had an affinity for foreign and exotic people.']

Grand Secretary ••Yang Tinghe••, serving under Jiajing, was resolute in diminishing the eunuch dominion at court, which characterized the Zhengde period, as exemplified by the extravagant escort of the eunuch Liu Yun in his unsuccessful mission to Tibet. title: IPod
original_context: ["Apple did not develop the iPod software entirely in-house, instead using ••PortalPlayer••'s reference platform based on two ARM cores. The platform had rudimentary software running on a commercial microkernel embedded operating system. PortalPlayer had previously been working on an IBM-branded MP3 player with Bluetooth headphones. Apple contracted another company, Pixo, to help design and implement the user interface under the direct supervision of Steve Jobs. As development progressed, Apple continued to refine the software's look and feel. ", "Starting with the iPod Mini, the Chicago font was replaced with Espy Sans. Later iPods switched fonts again to Podium Sans--a font similar to Apple's corporate font, Myriad. iPods with color displays then adopted some Mac OS X themes like Aqua progress bars, and brushed metal meant to evoke a combination lock. In 2007, Apple modified the iPod interface again with the introduction of the sixth-generation iPod Classic and third-generation iPod Nano by changing the font to Helvetica and, in most cases, splitting the screen in half by displaying the menus on the left and album artwork, photos, or videos on the right (whichever was appropriate for the selected item)."]
altered_context: ["Apple did not create the iPod software entirely within its own facilities, instead utilizing ••PortalPlayer••'s reference framework based on two ARM processors. The framework featured basic software operating on a commercial microkernel embedded operating system. Prior to this, PortalPlayer had been engaged in the development of an IBM-branded MP3 device with Bluetooth headphones. Apple enlisted the assistance of another firm, Pixo, to help design and implement the user interface under the close oversight of Steve Jobs. As the project progressed, Apple kept refining the software's aesthetics and functionality.", "Beginning with the iPod Mini, the Chicago font was exchanged for Espy Sans. Subsequent iPods changed fonts yet again to Podium Sans—a typeface reminiscent of Apple's corporate font, Myriad. iPods equipped with color displays then adopted certain Mac OS X themes like Aqua progress bars, and a brushed metal finish intended to evoke the look of a combination lock. In 2007, Apple revised the iPod interface once more with the launch of the sixth-generation iPod Classic and third-generation iPod Nano by altering the font to Helvetica and, in most instances, dividing the screen in two by presenting menus on the left and album artwork, photos, or videos on the right (depending on what was selected)."]

title: IPod
original_context: ['The third generation began including a 30-pin dock connector, allowing for FireWire or USB connectivity. This provided better compatibility with non-Apple machines, as most of them did not have FireWire ports at the time. Eventually Apple began shipping iPods with USB cables instead of FireWire, although the latter was available separately. As of the first-generation iPod Nano and the fifth-generation iPod Classic, Apple discontinued using FireWire for data transfer (while still allowing for use of FireWire to charge the device) in an attempt to reduce cost and form factor. As of the second-generation iPod Touch and the fourth-generation iPod Nano, FireWire charging ability has been removed. The second-, third-, and fourth-generation iPod ••Shuffle•• uses a single 3.5 mm minijack phone connector which acts as both a headphone jack and a data port for the dock.']
altered_context: The third iteration started featuring a 30-pin docking connector, enabling FireWire or USB connections. This enhancement offered improved compatibility with non-Apple devices, since most lacked FireWire ports during that period. Ultimately, Apple started providing iPods with USB cables instead of FireWire, even though the latter remained available separately. With the introduction of the first-generation iPod Nano and the fifth-generation iPod Classic, Apple ceased utilizing FireWire for data transfers (though it continued to permit the use of FireWire for charging the device) as a means to cut expenses and reduce size. As observed with the second-generation iPod Touch and the fourth-generation iPod Nano, the ability to charge via FireWire has been eliminated. The second-, third-, and fourth-generation iPod Shuffle employs a singular 3.5 mm minijack phone connector which serves the dual purpose of a headphone jack and a data port for the dock.

For the iPod Nano, soldering tools are needed because the battery is soldered onto the main board. Fifth generation iPods have their battery attached to the backplate with adhesive.']
altered_context: On November 14, 2003, Apple revealed a ••battery substitution initiative••, shortly before a highly publicized event and website created by the Neistat Brothers. The original price was US$99, which was decreased to US$59 in 2005. Just one week later, Apple introduced an enhanced iPod warranty for US$59. For the iPod Nano, soldering tools are required since the battery is fixed onto the main circuit board. Fifth generation iPods have their battery secured to the backplate using adhesive.
original_question: What did Apple launch on November 14, 2003?
altered_question: What did Apple introduce on November 14, 2003?

title: The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Twilight_Princess
original_context: ['At the time of its release, Twilight Princess was considered the greatest entry in the Zelda series by many critics, including writers for 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN, and The Washington Post. It received several Game of the Year awards, and was the most critically acclaimed game of 2006. In 2011, the Wii version was rereleased under the Nintendo Selects label. A high-definition port for the Wii U, The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD, will be released in ••March 2016••.']
altered_context: ['At the moment of its debut, Twilight Princess was regarded as the finest installment in the Zelda franchise by numerous critics, including contributors for 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN, and The Washington Post. It was awarded several Game of the Year honors and was the most critically lauded game of 2006. In 2011, the Wii edition was re-released under the Nintendo Selects label. A high-definition adaptation for the Wii U, The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD, is scheduled for launch in March 2016.']

title: The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Twilight_Princess
original_context: ['There is very little voice acting in the game, as is the case in most Zelda titles to date. Link remains silent in conversation, but grunts when attacking or injured and gasps when surprised. His emotions and responses are largely indicated visually by nods and facial expressions. Other characters have similar language-independent verbalizations, including laughter, surprised or fearful exclamations, and screams. The character of ••Midna•• has the most voice acting--her on-screen dialog is often accompanied by a babble of pseudo-speech, which was produced by scrambling the phonemes of English phrases[better source needed] sampled by Japanese voice actress Akiko Kōmoto.']
altered_context: There is minimal vocal performance in the game, similar to most Zelda installments up to now. Link remains mute in dialogues, but makes sounds when attacking or hurt, and gasps in moments of surprise. His feelings and reactions are primarily shown through visual cues like nods and facial expressions. Other characters produce similar non-verbal vocalizations, such as laughter, exclamations of shock or fear, and screams. The character of ••Midna•• possesses the highest amount of voice acting--her on-screen dialogues are frequently paired with a mix of nonsensical speech, which was created by mixing up the phonemes from English sentences[better source needed] recorded by Japanese voice actress Akiko Kōmoto.
original_question: Which person has the most spoken dialogue in the game?
altered_question: Which character has the greatest amount of spoken lines in the game?

title: The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Twilight_Princess
original_context: ["Twilight Princess takes place several centuries after Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask, and begins with a youth named Link who is working as a ••ranch hand•• in Ordon Village. One day, the village is attacked by Bulblins, who carry off the village's children with Link in pursuit before he encounters a wall of Twilight. A Shadow Beast pulls him beyond the wall into the Realm of Twilight, where he is transformed into a wolf and imprisoned. Link is soon freed by an imp-like Twilight being named Midna, who dislikes Link but agrees to help him if he obeys her unconditionally. ", "She guides him to Princess Zelda. Zelda explains that Zant, the King of the Twilight, has stolen the light from three of the four Light Spirits and conquered Hyrule. In order to save Hyrule, Link must first restore the Light Spirits by entering the Twilight-covered areas and, as a wolf, recover the Spirits' lost light. He must do this by collecting the multiple Tears of Light؛ once all the Tears of Light are collected for one area, he restores that area's Light Spirit. As he restores them, the Light Spirits return Link to his Hylian form."]
altered_context: ["Twilight Princess occurs many centuries following Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask, and starts with a young man named Link who works as a ••farm worker•• in Ordon Village. One day, the settlement is assaulted by Bulblins, who abduct the village's children with Link chasing after them until he confronts a barrier of Twilight. A Shadow Beast drags him across the barrier into the Twilight Realm, where he is altered into a wolf and confined. Link is quickly liberated by a sprite-like being from Twilight named Midna, who has an aversion to Link but consents to assist him if he follows her orders without question.", "She leads him to Princess Zelda. Zelda reveals that Zant, the Monarch of Twilight, has taken the light from three of the four Light Spirits and taken control of Hyrule. To rescue Hyrule, Link must first revive the Light Spirits by entering the areas shrouded in Twilight and, as a wolf, retrieve the Spirits' stolen light. He needs to achieve this by gathering the various Tears of Light; when all the Tears of Light are amassed for a particular area, he restores that region's Light Spirit. Each time he revives them, the Light Spirits revert Link back to his Hylian form."]
original_question: What is the Light Spirits job at the start of Twilight Princess?
altered_question: What role do the Light Spirits play at the beginning of Twilight Princess?

title: The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Twilight_Princess
original_context: ['After gaining the Master Sword, Link is cleansed of the magic that kept him in wolf form, obtaining the Shadow Crystal. Now able to use it to switch between both forms at will, Link is led by Midna to the ••Mirror of Twilight•• located deep within the Gerudo Desert, the only known gateway between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule. However, they discover that the mirror is broken. The Sages there explain that Zant tried to destroy it, but he was only able to shatter it into fragments؛ only the true ruler of the Twili can completely destroy the Mirror of Twilight. They also reveal that they used it a century ago to banish Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who attempted to steal the Triforce, to the Twilight Realm when executing him failed. Assisted by an underground resistance group they meet in Castle Town, Link and Midna set out to retrieve the missing shards of the Mirror, defeating those they infected. ', "Once the portal has been restored, Midna is revealed to be the true ruler of the Twilight Realm, usurped by Zant when he cursed her into her current form. Confronting Zant, Link and Midna learn that Zant's coup was made possible when he forged a pact with Ganondorf, who asked for Zant's assistance in conquering Hyrule. After Link defeats Zant, Midna recovers the Fused Shadows, but destroys Zant after learning that only Ganondorf's death can release her from her curse. Returning to Hyrule, Link and Midna find Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle, with a lifeless Zelda suspended above his head. Ganondorf fights Link by possessing Zelda's body and eventually by transforming into a beast, but Link defeats him and Midna is able to resurrect Zelda."]
altered_context: After obtaining the Master Sword, Link is freed from the enchantment that kept him in wolf shape, acquiring the Shadow Crystal. Now capable of using it to transition between both forms at his discretion, Link is guided by Midna to the ••Mirror of Twilight•• situated deep within the Gerudo Desert, the sole recognized entryway between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule. However, they find that the mirror is damaged. The Sages present explain that Zant attempted to ruin it, but he only managed to break it into pieces; only the genuine leader of the Twili can thoroughly annihilate the Mirror of Twilight. They also disclose that they utilized it a century prior to exile Ganondorf, the Gerudo chief who sought to steal the Triforce, to the Twilight Realm when executing him failed. Aided by an underground resistance group they encounter in Castle Town, Link and Midna embark on a mission to recover the lost fragments of the Mirror, overcoming those they infected. Once the portal is repaired, Midna is disclosed to be the true sovereign of the Twilight Realm, usurped by Zant when he cursed her into her existing form. Confronting Zant, Link and Midna discover that Zant's rebellion was enabled when he made a pact with Ganondorf, who sought Zant's help in conquering Hyrule. After Link vanquishes Zant, Midna regains the Fused Shadows but destroys Zant after learning that only Ganondorf's demise can liberate her from her enchantment. Upon returning to Hyrule, Link and Midna locate Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle, with a lifeless Zelda hovering above him. Ganondorf battles Link by possessing Zelda's body and eventually by metamorphosing into a beast, but Link overcomes him, allowing Midna to bring Zelda back to life.
original_question: Where does Midna take Link after he acquires the Master Sword?
altered_question: Where does Midna guide Link after he obtains the Master Sword?
