title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["Bond travels to Austria to find White, who is dying of thallium poisoning. He admits to growing disenchanted with Quantum and tells Bond to find and protect his daughter, ••Dr. Madeline Swann••, who will take him to L'Américain؛ this will in turn lead him to Spectre. White then commits suicide. Bond locates Swann at the Hoffler Klinik, but she is abducted by Hinx. Bond rescues her and the two meet Q, who discovers that Sciarra's ring links Oberhauser to Bond's previous missions, identifying Le Chiffre, Dominic Greene and Raoul Silva as Spectre agents. Swann reveals that L'Américain is a hotel in Tangier."]
altered_context: Bond journeys to Austria in search of White, who is succumbing to thallium toxicity. He confesses to becoming disillusioned with Quantum and urges Bond to locate and safeguard his daughter, ••Dr. Madeline Swann••, who will guide him to L'Américain; this will subsequently lead him to Spectre. White then takes his own life. Bond finds Swann at the Hoffler Klinik, but she is kidnapped by Hinx. Bond saves her and the two encounter Q, who uncovers that Sciarra's ring connects Oberhauser to Bond's earlier missions, pinpointing Le Chiffre, Dominic Greene, and Raoul Silva as Spectre operatives. Swann discloses that L'Américain is a lodging in Tangier.
original_question: Who is White's daughter?
altered_question: What is the name of White's daughter?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["In November 2014, Sony Pictures Entertainment was targeted by hackers who released details of confidential e-mails between Sony executives regarding several high-profile film projects. Included within these were several memos relating to the production of Spectre, claiming that the film was over budget, detailing early drafts of the script written by ••John Logan••, and expressing Sony's frustration with the project. Eon Productions later issued a statement confirming the leak of what they called an early version of the screenplay."]
altered_context: ["In November 2014, Sony Pictures Entertainment fell prey to cyber attackers who disclosed details of private e-mails exchanged among Sony executives concerning various prominent film ventures. Among these were several communications pertaining to the production of Spectre, asserting that the film had exceeded its budget, outlining initial drafts of the screenplay composed by ••John Logan••, and voicing Sony's dissatisfaction with the endeavor. Eon Productions subsequently released a statement acknowledging the disclosure of what they referred to as a preliminary version of the script."]
original_question: Who wrote the early drafts of the script for Spectre?
altered_question: Who was the author of the initial drafts of the screenplay for Spectre?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["Despite being an original story, Spectre draws on Ian Fleming's source material, most notably in the character of Franz Oberhauser, played by Christoph Waltz. Oberhauser shares his name with ••Hannes Oberhauser••, a background character in the short story Octopussy from the Octopussy and The Living Daylights collection, and who is named in the film as having been a temporary legal guardian of a young Bond in 1983. Similarly, Charmian Bond is shown to have been his full-time guardian, observing the back story established by Fleming. With the acquisition of the rights to Spectre and its associated characters, screenwriters Neal Purvis and Robert Wade revealed that the film would provide a minor retcon to the continuity of the previous films, with the Quantum organisation alluded to in Casino Royale and introduced in Quantum of Solace reimagined as a division within Spectre rather than an independent organisation."]
altered_context: ["Although it is an original tale, Spectre is influenced by Ian Fleming's foundational works, particularly regarding the figure of Franz Oberhauser, portrayed by Christoph Waltz. Oberhauser has the same name as ••Hannes Oberhauser••, a minor character from the short story Octopussy included in the Octopussy and The Living Daylights anthology, who is mentioned in the movie as having served as a temporary guardian to a young Bond in 1983. Likewise, Charmian Bond is depicted as having been his primary guardian, reflecting the backstory crafted by Fleming. Following the acquisition of the rights to Spectre and its related characters, screenwriters Neal Purvis and Robert Wade disclosed that the film would create a subtle alteration to the continuity of the earlier films, presenting the Quantum organization mentioned in Casino Royale and introduced in Quantum of Solace as a subset of Spectre instead of a separate entity."]
original_question: Who has permanent legal custody of Bond in 1983?
altered_question: Who has full-time legal guardianship of Bond in 1983?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["In March 2013 Mendes said he would not return to direct the next film in the series, then known as Bond 24؛ he later recanted and announced that he would return, as he found the script and the plans for the long-term future of the franchise appealing. In directing Skyfall and Spectre, Mendes became the first director to oversee two consecutive Bond films since John Glen directed The Living Daylights and Licence to Kill in 1987 and 1989. Skyfall writer John Logan resumed his role of scriptwriter, collaborating with Neal Purvis and Robert Wade, who returned for their ••six••th Bond film.[N 4] The writer Jez Butterworth also worked on the script, alongside Mendes and Craig. Dennis Gassner returned as the film's production designer, while cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema took over from Roger Deakins. In July 2015 Mendes noted that the combined crew of Spectre numbered over one thousand, making it a larger production than Skyfall. Craig is listed as co-producer."]
altered_context: In March 2013, Mendes declared he would not return to helm the upcoming installment in the series, then referred to as Bond 24; he subsequently changed his mind and confirmed that he would come back, as he found the screenplay and the future plans for the franchise attractive. By directing Skyfall and Spectre, Mendes became the initial director to manage two consecutive Bond movies since John Glen directed The Living Daylights and Licence to Kill in 1987 and 1989. John Logan, the writer of Skyfall, returned to his role as screenwriter, teaming up with Neal Purvis and Robert Wade, who also came back for their sixth Bond film. The script also saw contributions from writer Jez Butterworth, alongside Mendes and Craig. Dennis Gassner was back on as the film's production designer, while Hoyte van Hoytema took over cinematography duties from Roger Deakins. In July 2015, Mendes remarked that the total crew of Spectre exceeded one thousand, designating it a larger production than Skyfall. Craig is credited as co-producer.
original_question: Neal Purvis and Robert Wade have worked on how many Bond films?
altered_question: How many Bond films have Neal Purvis and Robert Wade collaborated on?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ['Filming temporarily returned to England to shoot scenes at Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire, which stood in for a location in Rome, before moving on to the city itself for a five-week shoot across the city, with locations including the Ponte Sisto bridge and the Roman Forum. The production faced opposition from a variety of special interest groups and city authorities, who were concerned about the potential for damage to historical sites around the city, and problems with graffiti and rubbish appearing in the film. ', 'A car chase scene set along the banks of the Tiber River and through the streets of Rome featured an Aston Martin DB10 and a ••Jaguar•• C-X75. The C-X75 was originally developed as a hybrid electric vehicle with four independent electric engines powered by two jet turbines, before the project was cancelled. The version used for filming was converted to use a conventional internal combustion engine, to minimise the potential for disruption from mechanical problems with the complex hybrid system. The C-X75s used for filming were developed by the engineering division of Formula One racing team Williams, who built the original C-X75 prototype for Jaguar.']
altered_context: Filming temporarily returned to England to capture scenes at Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire, which represented a location in Rome, before proceeding to the city itself for a five-week shoot throughout the area, featuring sites such as the Ponte Sisto bridge and the Roman Forum. The production encountered resistance from various special interest groups and municipal authorities, who expressed concerns regarding possible damage to historic sites within the city, as well as issues with graffiti and litter appearing in the film. A car chase sequence filmed alongside the banks of the Tiber River and through the streets of Rome included an Aston Martin DB10 and a Jaguar C-X75. The C-X75 was initially created as a hybrid electric vehicle with four distinct electric motors driven by two jet turbines, prior to the project's cancellation. The version utilized for filming was modified to operate with a traditional internal combustion engine, to reduce the likelihood of disruption from mechanical issues stemming from the intricate hybrid system. The C-X75s employed during production were designed by the engineering division of the Formula One racing team Williams, which constructed the original C-X75 prototype for Jaguar.
original_question: For which auto maker did Williams first develop the C-X75?
altered_question: Which automobile manufacturer did Williams first create the C-X75 for?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["During the December 2014 press conference announcing the start of filming, Aston Martin and Eon unveiled the new DB10 as the official car for the ••film••. The DB10 was designed in collaboration between Aston Martin and the filmmakers, with only 10 being produced especially for Spectre as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the company's association with the franchise. Only eight of those 10 were used for the film, however؛ the remaining two were used for promotional work. After modifying the Jaguar C-X75 for the film, Williams F1 carried the 007 logo on their cars at the 2015 Mexican Grand Prix, with the team playing host to the cast and crew ahead of the Mexican premiere of the film."]
altered_context: In the press conference held in December 2014 to announce the commencement of filming, Aston Martin along with Eon revealed the latest DB10 as the designated vehicle for the movie. The DB10 was crafted through a collaboration between Aston Martin and the movie producers, with only 10 units being created specifically for Spectre to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the company's partnership with the series. Nevertheless, merely eight of those 10 were utilized in the film; the other two were allocated for promotional activities. After adapting the Jaguar C-X75 for the film, Williams F1 sported the 007 emblem on their vehicles during the 2015 Mexican Grand Prix, with the team hosting the cast and crew prior to the Mexican release of the movie.
original_question: Honda was the official car of what?
altered_question: What was the official vehicle for the film?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["Spectre had its world premiere in London on 26 October 2015 at the Royal Albert Hall, the same day as its general release in the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland. Following the announcement of the start of filming, Paramount Pictures brought forward the release of Mission: Impossible -- Rogue Nation to avoid competing with Spectre. In March ••2015•• IMAX corporation announced that Spectre would be screened in its cinemas, following Skyfall's success with the company. In the UK it received a wider release than Skyfall, with a minimum of 647 cinemas including 40 IMAX screens, compared to Skyfall's 587 locations and 21 IMAX screens."]
altered_context: ["Spectre had its world debut in London on 26 October 2015 at the Royal Albert Hall, coinciding with its general release in the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland. After the filming commencement announcement, Paramount Pictures advanced the release of Mission: Impossible -- Rogue Nation to prevent competition with Spectre. In March 2015, IMAX Corporation revealed that Spectre would be presented in its theaters, following the successful run of Skyfall with the company. In the UK, it had a more extensive release compared to Skyfall, with at least 647 theaters, which included 40 IMAX venues, in contrast to Skyfall's 587 locations and 21 IMAX screens."]
original_question: IMAX announced that Spectre would be screened in its cinemas in January of what year?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["In the United Kingdom, the film grossed £4.1 million ($6.4 million) from its Monday preview screenings. It grossed £6.3 million ($9.2 million) on its opening day and then £5.7 million ($8.8 million) on Wednesday, setting UK records for both days. In the film's first seven days it grossed £41.7 million ($63.8 million), breaking the UK record for highest first-week opening, set by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban's £23.88 million ($36.9 million) in 2004. Its Friday--Saturday gross was £20.4 million ($31.2 million) compared to Skyfall's £20.1 million ($31 million). The film also broke the record for the best per-screen opening average with $110,000, a record previously held by ••The Dark Knight•• with $100,200. It has grossed a total of $136.3 million there. In the U.K., it surpassed Avatar to become the country's highest-grossing IMAX release ever with $10.09 million."]
altered_context: ["In the United Kingdom, the movie earned £4.1 million ($6.4 million) from its Monday preview showings. It secured £6.3 million ($9.2 million) on its first day and then £5.7 million ($8.8 million) on Wednesday, establishing UK records for both days. In the film's initial seven days, it accumulated £41.7 million ($63.8 million), surpassing the UK record for the highest first-week opening, previously set by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban with £23.88 million ($36.9 million) in 2004. Its gross for Friday and Saturday was £20.4 million ($31.2 million) compared to Skyfall's £20.1 million ($31 million). The film also established the record for the highest average earnings per screen at $110,000, a title previously held by The Dark Knight at $100,200. It has garnered a total of $136.3 million in that market. In the U.K., it overtook Avatar to claim the title of the country's highest-grossing IMAX release ever with $10.09 million."]
original_question: Spectre passed which movie to have the largest per screen opening average?
altered_question: Which film did Spectre surpass to obtain the largest average opening per screen?

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ['Spectre opened in Germany with $22.45 million (including previews), which included a new record for the biggest Saturday of all time, Australia with $8.7 million (including previews) and South Korea opened to $8.2 million (including previews). Despite the 13 November Paris attacks, which led to numerous theaters being closed down, the film opened with $14.6 million (including $2 million in previews) in France. In Mexico, where part of the film was shot, it debuted with more than double that of Skyfall with $4.5 million. ', "It also bested its predecessor's opening in various Nordic regions where MGM is distributing, such as in Finland ($2.66 million) and Norway ($2.91 million), and in other markets like Denmark ($4.2 million), the Netherlands ($3.38 million), and Sweden ($3.1 million). In India, it opened at No. 1 with $4.8 million which is 4% above the opening of Skyfall. It topped the German-speaking Switzerland box office for four weeks and in the Netherlands, it has held the No. 1 spot for seven weeks straight where it has topped Minions to become the top movie of the year. The top earning markets are Germany ($70.3 million) and France ($38.8 million). In Paris, it has the second highest ticket sales of all time with $4.1 million tickets sold only behind ••Spider-Man 3•• which sold over $6.32 million tickets in 2007."]
altered_context: ["Spectre launched in Germany with $22.45 million (inclusive of previews), setting a new record for the largest Saturday opening ever; in Australia, it achieved $8.7 million (including previews), while South Korea recorded an opening of $8.2 million (including previews). In spite of the Paris attacks on 13 November, which resulted in many cinemas being shuttered, the film still debuted in France with $14.6 million (including $2 million from previews). In Mexico, where parts of the film were filmed, it made a strong debut, outperforming Skyfall with $4.5 million. It also surpassed its predecessor's opening in several Nordic regions where MGM is handling distribution, such as Finland ($2.66 million) and Norway ($2.91 million), along with other markets including Denmark ($4.2 million), the Netherlands ($3.38 million), and Sweden ($3.1 million). In India, the film opened at the top spot with $4.8 million, which reflects a 4% increase over the opening of Skyfall. It dominated the German-speaking Switzerland box office for four consecutive weeks and maintained the number one position in the Netherlands for seven weeks, surpassing Minions to become the top film of the year. The highest earning markets include Germany ($70.3 million) and France ($38.8 million). In Paris, it has achieved the second highest ticket sales record of all time with $4.1 million tickets sold, trailing only behind ••Spider-Man 3•• which sold more than $6.32 million tickets back in 2007."]

title: Spectre_(2015_film)
original_context: ["In the United States and Canada, the film opened on 6 November 2015, and in its opening weekend, was originally projected to gross $70--75 million from 3,927 screens, the widest release for a Bond film. However, after grossing $5.25 million from its early Thursday night showings and $28 million on its opening day, weekend projections were increased to $75--80 million. The film ended up grossing $70.4 million in its opening weekend (about $20 million less than Skyfall's $90.6 million debut, including IMAX previews), but nevertheless finished first at the box office. IMAX generated $9.1 million for Spectre at ••374•• screens, premium large format made $8 million from 429 cinemas, reaping 11% of the film's opening, which means that Spectre earned $17.1 million (23%) of its opening weekend total in large-format venues. Cinemark XD generated $1.85 million in 112 XD locations."]
altered_context: In Canada and the United States, the movie debuted on November 6, 2015, and during its initial weekend, it was initially estimated to earn between $70 and $75 million from 3,927 theaters, marking the widest distribution for a Bond movie. Ultimately, the film grossed $70.4 million in its opening weekend (approximately $20 million lower than Skyfall's $90.6 million launch, including IMAX previews), but it still ranked top at the box office. IMAX accounted for $9.1 million for Spectre across 374 screens, while premium large format contributed $8 million from 429 theaters, yielding 11% of the film’s introductory earnings, indicating that Spectre made $17.1 million (23%) of its opening weekend total from large-format locations. title: 2008_Sichuan_earthquake
original_context: ["Office buildings in Shanghai's financial district, including the Jin Mao Tower and the Hong Kong New World Tower, were evacuated. A receptionist at the Tibet Hotel in Chengdu said things were calm after the hotel evacuated its guests. Meanwhile, workers at a Ford plant in Sichuan were evacuated for about 10 minutes. Chengdu Shuangliu International Airport was shut down, and the control tower and regional radar control evacuated. One SilkAir flight was diverted and landed in Kunming as a result. Cathay Pacific delayed both legs of its quadruple daily Hong Kong to London route due to this disruption in air traffic services. Chengdu Shuangliu Airport reopened later on the evening of May 12, offering limited service as the airport began to be used as a staging area for ••relief operations••."]
altered_context: ["Office structures in Shanghai's financial sector, such as the Jin Mao Tower and the Hong Kong New World Tower, were evacuated. A front desk employee at the Tibet Hotel in Chengdu reported that the situation was tranquil after the hotel had cleared out its patrons. In addition, employees at a Ford facility in Sichuan were removed for roughly 10 minutes. Chengdu Shuangliu International Airport was closed, and both the control tower and regional radar control were evacuated. Consequently, one SilkAir flight was redirected and landed in Kunming. Cathay Pacific postponed both legs of its four-times-daily Hong Kong to London service because of this interference in aviation services. Chengdu Shuangliu Airport resumed operations later that evening on May 12, providing limited service as the airport commenced functioning as a staging ground for ••relief operations••."]
original_question: What were they using the airport to stage for?
altered_question: What purpose was the airport being used for?

title: 2008_Sichuan_earthquake
original_context: ["All of the highways into Wenchuan, and others throughout the province, were damaged, resulting in ••delayed arrival•• of the rescue troops. In Beichuan County, 80% of the buildings collapsed according to Xinhua News. In the city of Shifang, the collapse of two chemical plants led to leakage of some 80 tons of liquid ammonia, with hundreds of people reported buried. In the city of Dujiangyan, south-east of the epicenter, a whole school collapsed with 900 students buried and fewer than 60 survived. The Juyuan Middle School, where many teenagers were buried, was excavated by civilians and cranes. Dujiangyan is home of the Dujiangyan Irrigation System, an ancient water diversion project which is still in use and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The project's famous Fish Mouth was cracked but not severely damaged otherwise."]

In the city of Shifang, the collapse of two chemical facilities resulted in the leakage of around 80 tons of liquid ammonia, with hundreds of individuals reported trapped. In the city of Dujiangyan, located to the southeast of the epicenter, an entire school crumbled with 900 students trapped and fewer than 60 managing to survive. The Juyuan Middle School, where numerous teenagers were buried, was excavated by local residents and cranes. Dujiangyan is known for the Dujiangyan Irrigation System, an ancient water diversion project which remains operational and is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The project's notable Fish Mouth was fractured but otherwise not severely affected."]
original_question: What did the damaged roadways cause to the rescue operations?
altered_question: How did the compromised roadways impact the rescue efforts?

title: 2008_Sichuan_earthquake
original_context: ['Many rescue teams, including that of the Taipei Fire Department from Taiwan, were reported ready to join the rescue effort in Sichuan as early as Wednesday. However, the Red Cross Society of China said that (on May 13) it was inconvenient currently due to ••the traffic problem•• to the hardest hit areas closest to the epicenter. The Red Cross Society of China also stated that the disaster areas need tents, medical supplies, drinking water and food؛ however it recommended donating cash instead of other items, as it had not been possible to reach roads that were completely damaged or places that were blocked off by landslides. ', 'Landslides continuously threatened the progress of a search and rescue group of 80 men, each carrying about 40 kg of relief supplies, from a motorized infantry brigade under commander Yang Wenyao, as they tried to reach the ethnically Tibetan village of Sier at a height of 4000 m above sea level in Pingwu county. The extreme terrain conditions precluded the use of helicopter evacuation, and over 300 of the Tibetan villagers were stranded in their demolished village for five days without food and water before the rescue group finally arrived to help the injured and stranded villagers down the mountain.']
altered_context: Numerous rescue squads, including the contingent from the Taipei Fire Department in Taiwan, were reported prepared to participate in the relief operations in Sichuan as early as Wednesday. Nonetheless, the Red Cross Society of China indicated that (on May 13) it was presently impractical due to ••the traffic issue•• affecting access to the areas most impacted that were nearest to the epicenter. The Red Cross Society of China also mentioned that the disaster-affected zones required tents, medical resources, potable water, and food; however, it suggested making cash donations instead of other items, as accessing thoroughly damaged roads or areas obstructed by landslides had proven impossible. Landslides persistently endangered the efforts of a search and rescue team comprising 80 individuals, each bearing approximately 40 kg of aid supplies, from a motorized infantry brigade led by Commander Yang Wenyao, as they attempted to reach the ethnically Tibetan community of Sier at an elevation of 4000 m above sea level in Pingwu county. The severe terrain conditions ruled out the possibility of helicopter rescues, and more than 300 Tibetan inhabitants were stranded in their ravaged village for five days without food and water before the rescue team eventually arrived to assist the wounded and trapped villagers down the mountain.

At the start of rescue operations on May 12, 20 helicopters were deployed for the delivery of food, water, and emergency aid, and also the evacuation of the injured and reconnaissance of quake-stricken areas. By 17:37 CST on May 13, a total of over ••15,600•• troops and militia reservists from the Chengdu Military Region had joined the rescue force in the heavily affected areas. ', 'A commander reported from Yingxiu Town, Wenchuan, that around 3,000 survivors were found, while the status of the other inhabitants (around 9,000) remained unclear. The 1,300 rescuers reached the epicenter, and 300 pioneer troops reached the seat of Wenchuan at about 23:30 CST. By 12:17 CST, May 14, 2008, communication in the seat of Wenchuan was partly revived. On the afternoon of May 14, 15 Special Operations Troops, along with relief supplies and communications gear, parachuted into inaccessible Mao County, northeast of Wenchuan.']

A commander reported from Yingxiu Town, Wenchuan, that approximately 3,000 survivors were located, while the condition of the remaining residents (approximately 9,000) was uncertain. By 12:17 CST on May 14, 2008, communication in the center of Wenchuan was partially restored. title: To_Kill_a_Mockingbird
original_context: ["Scholars have characterized To Kill a Mockingbird as both a Southern ••Gothic•• and coming-of-age or Bildungsroman novel. The grotesque and near-supernatural qualities of Boo Radley and his house, and the element of racial injustice involving Tom Robinson contribute to the aura of the Gothic in the novel. Lee used the term Gothic to describe the architecture of Maycomb's courthouse and in regard to Dill's exaggeratedly morbid performances as Boo Radley. Outsiders are also an important element of Southern Gothic texts and Scout and Jem's questions about the hierarchy in the town cause scholars to compare the novel to Catcher in the Rye and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. ", "Despite challenging the town's systems, Scout reveres Atticus as an authority above all others, because he believes that following one's conscience is the highest priority, even when the result is social ostracism. However, scholars debate about the Southern Gothic classification, noting that Boo Radley is in fact human, protective, and benevolent. Furthermore, in addressing themes such as alcoholism, incest, rape, and racial violence, Lee wrote about her small town realistically rather than melodramatically. She portrays the problems of individual characters as universal underlying issues in every society."]
altered_context: ["Academics have described To Kill a Mockingbird as both a Southern ••Gothic•• and coming-of-age or Bildungsroman narrative. The bizarre and almost otherworldly traits of Boo Radley and his residence, along with the aspect of racial injustice concerning Tom Robinson, enhance the Gothic atmosphere in the story. Lee utilized the term Gothic to depict the design of Maycomb's courthouse and with respect to Dill's dramatically macabre performances as Boo Radley. Outsiders also play a significant role in Southern Gothic literature, and Scout and Jem's inquiries regarding the social hierarchy in the town lead scholars to liken the novel to Catcher in the Rye and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.", "Even though she confronts the town's structures, Scout holds Atticus in high esteem as an authority figure above all others, since he maintains that adhering to one's principles is the utmost priority, even when it leads to social exclusion. Nonetheless, academics discuss the classification of Southern Gothic, observing that Boo Radley is, in reality, a human being who is protective and kind-hearted. Additionally, in tackling subjects like alcoholism, incest, rape, and racial violence, Lee depicted her small town in a realistic way instead of melodramatically. She illustrates the dilemmas of individual characters as universal fundamental issues present in every community."]

title: To_Kill_a_Mockingbird
original_context: ["Songbirds and their associated symbolism appear throughout the novel. The family's last name of ••Finch•• also shares Lee's mother's maiden name. The titular mockingbird is a key motif of this theme, which first appears when Atticus, having given his children air-rifles for Christmas, allows their Uncle Jack to teach them to shoot. Atticus warns them that, although they can shoot all the bluejays they want, they must remember that it's a sin to kill a mockingbird. Confused, Scout approaches her neighbor Miss Maudie, who explains that mockingbirds never harm other living creatures. She points out that mockingbirds simply provide pleasure with their songs, saying, They don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. Writer Edwin Bruell summarized the symbolism when he wrote in 1964, 'To kill a mockingbird' is to kill that which is innocent and harmless--like Tom Robinson. Scholars have noted that Lee often returns to the mockingbird theme when trying to make a moral point."]
altered_context: ["Throughout the novel, songbirds and their corresponding symbolism are prevalent. The family's surname, ••Finch••, also coincidentally matches Lee's mother's maiden name. The titular mockingbird serves as a crucial motif within this theme, first introduced when Atticus, having gifted his children air-rifles for Christmas, permits their Uncle Jack to instruct them in shooting. Atticus cautions them that, although they can aim at as many bluejays as they wish, they must bear in mind that it is a sin to kill a mockingbird. Perplexed, Scout seeks clarification from her neighbor Miss Maudie, who clarifies that mockingbirds do not harm other living beings. She emphasizes that mockingbirds merely bring joy with their melodies, stating, They don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. Writer Edwin Bruell encapsulated the symbolism when he penned in 1964, 'To kill a mockingbird' signifies the destruction of innocence and harmlessness--similar to Tom Robinson. Scholars have observed that Lee frequently revisits the mockingbird motif when aiming to convey a moral lesson."]

altered_question: What was Harper Lee's mother's maiden surname?

title: To_Kill_a_Mockingbird

Upon learning the school administrators were holding hearings to decide the book's appropriateness for the classroom, Harper Lee sent $10 to The Richmond News Leader suggesting it to be used toward the enrollment of the Hanover County School Board in any first grade of its choice. The National Education Association in 1968 placed the novel second on a list of books receiving the most complaints from private organizations--after Little Black Sambo."]

David Kipen of the National Endowment of the Arts, who supervised The Big Read, states people just seem to connect with it. title: To_Kill_a_Mockingbird
original_context: ["An earlier draft of To Kill a Mockingbird, titled Go Set a Watchman, was controversially released on July 14, 2015. This draft, which was completed in ••1957••, is set 20 years after the time period depicted in To Kill a Mockingbird but is not a continuation of the narrative. This earlier version of the story follows an adult Scout Finch who travels from New York to visit her father, Atticus Finch, in Maycomb, Alabama, where she is confronted by the intolerance in her community. The Watchman manuscript was believed to have been lost until Lee's lawyer Tonja Carter discovered it؛ although this claim has been widely disputed. Watchman contains early versions of many of the characters from To Kill a Mockingbird. ", "According to Lee's agent Andrew Nurnberg, Mockingbird was originally intended to be the first book of a trilogy: They discussed publishing Mockingbird first, Watchman last, and a shorter connecting novel between the two. This assertion has been discredited however by the rare books expert James S. Jaffe, who reviewed the pages at the request of Lee's attorney and found them to be only another draft of To Kill a Mockingbird. The statement was also contrary to Jonathan Mahler's description of how Watchman was seen as just the first draft of Mockingbird. Instances where many passages overlap between the two books, in some case word for word, also refutes this assertion."]
altered_context: ["A prior version of To Kill a Mockingbird, named Go Set a Watchman, was controversially released on July 14, 2015. This manuscript, which was completed in ••1957••, occurs two decades after the timeframe depicted in To Kill a Mockingbird but does not serve as a continuation of the plot. This earlier adaptation of the tale features an adult Scout Finch who travels from New York to visit her father, Atticus Finch, in Maycomb, Alabama, where she faces the bigotry present in her community. The Watchman manuscript was thought to have been lost until it was uncovered by Lee's attorney Tonja Carter; although this assertion has been widely challenged. Watchman includes preliminary versions of many characters from To Kill a Mockingbird.", "As per Lee's agent Andrew Nurnberg, Mockingbird was initially meant to be the first part of a trilogy: They considered publishing Mockingbird first, Watchman last, and a shorter novel bridging the two. However, this claim has been dismissed by the rare books specialist James S. Jaffe, who examined the pages at the request of Lee's lawyer and concluded that they are merely another draft of To Kill a Mockingbird. This statement also contradicts Jonathan Mahler's explanation of how Watchman was perceived as just the initial draft of Mockingbird. Numerous instances where many sections overlap between the two books, in some cases verbatim, also dispute this claim."]

title: To_Kill_a_Mockingbird
original_context: ["Native Alabamian Allen Barra sharply criticized Lee and the novel in The Wall Street Journal calling Atticus a repository of cracker-barrel epigrams and the novel represents a sugar-coated myth of Alabama history. Barra writes, It's time to stop pretending that To Kill a Mockingbird is some kind of timeless classic that ranks with the great works of American literature. Its bloodless liberal humanism is sadly dated. Thomas Mallon in The New Yorker criticizes Atticus' stiff and self-righteous demeanor, and calls Scout a kind of highly constructed doll whose speech and actions are improbable. ", "Although acknowledging that the novel works, Mallon blasts Lee's wildly unstable narrative voice for developing a story about a content neighborhood until it begins to impart morals in the courtroom drama, following with his observation that the book has begun to cherish its own goodness by the time the case is over.[note 2] Defending the book, ••Akin Ajayi•• writes that justice is often complicated, but must always be founded upon the notion of equality and fairness for all. Ajayi states that the book forces readers to question issues about race, class, and society, but that it was not written to resolve them."]
altered_context: ["Local Alabamian Allen Barra harshly criticized Lee and the novel in The Wall Street Journal, labeling Atticus as a repository of cracker-barrel sayings and asserting that the novel portrays a sugar-coated representation of Alabama's history. Its detached liberal humanism is regrettably outdated. Thomas Mallon in The New Yorker critiques Atticus' rigid and self-satisfied behavior, describing Scout as a type of meticulously crafted doll whose dialogue and actions are implausible.", "While admitting that the novel functions, Mallon condemns Lee's erratically fluctuating narrative voice for crafting a tale about a complacent community until it starts imparting morals during the courtroom scenes, following up with his remark that the book has begun to value its own virtue by the conclusion of the case. Defending the novel, ••Akin Ajayi•• argues that justice is often intricate, but must invariably be based on the principles of equality and fairness for everyone. Ajayi contends that the book compels readers to examine matters of race, class, and society, although it was not intended to provide solutions."]

title: Solar_energy
original_context: ['Hydrogen production technologies been a significant area of solar chemical research since the 1970s. Aside from electrolysis driven by photovoltaic or photochemical cells, several thermochemical processes have also been explored. One such route ••uses concentrators to split water into oxygen and hydrogen at high temperatures•• (2,300--2,600 °C or 4,200--4,700 °F). Another approach uses the heat from solar concentrators to drive the steam reformation of natural gas thereby increasing the overall hydrogen yield compared to conventional reforming methods. Thermochemical cycles characterized by the decomposition and regeneration of reactants present another avenue for hydrogen production. The Solzinc process under development at the Weizmann Institute uses a 1 MW solar furnace to decompose zinc oxide (ZnO) at temperatures above 1,200 °C (2,200 °F). This initial reaction produces pure zinc, which can subsequently be reacted with water to produce hydrogen.']
altered_context: Hydrogen generation technologies have been a crucial field of solar chemical investigation since the 1970s. In addition to electrolysis powered by photovoltaic or photochemical cells, numerous thermochemical methods have been examined. One such method utilizes concentrators to separate water into oxygen and hydrogen at elevated temperatures (2,300--2,600 °C or 4,200--4,700 °F). Another technique employs the heat from solar concentrators to facilitate the steam reforming of natural gas, thus enhancing the total hydrogen output compared to traditional reforming techniques. Thermochemical cycles defined by the breakdown and reconstitution of reactants offer another pathway for hydrogen creation. The Solzinc process, currently in development at the Weizmann Institute, employs a 1 MW solar furnace to decompose zinc oxide (ZnO) at temperatures exceeding 1,200 °C (2,200 °F). This initial reaction yields pure zinc, which can then be reacted with water to generate hydrogen.

title: Kanye_West
original_context: ["Kanye West began his early production career in the mid-1990s, making beats primarily for burgeoning local artists, eventually developing a style that involved speeding up vocal samples from classic soul records. His first official production credits came at the age of nineteen when he produced eight tracks on Down to Earth, the 1996 debut album of a Chicago rapper named Grav. For a time, West acted as a ghost producer for ••Deric D-Dot Angelettie••. Because of his association with D-Dot, West wasn't able to release a solo album, so he formed and became a member and producer of the Go-Getters, a late-1990s Chicago rap group composed of him, GLC, Timmy G, Really Doe, and Arrowstar. ", 'His group was managed by John Monopoly Johnson, Don Crowley, and Happy Lewis under the management firm Hustle Period. After attending a series of promotional photo shoots and making some radio appearances, The Go-Getters released their first and only studio album World Record Holders in 1999. The album featured other Chicago-based rappers such as Rhymefest, Mikkey Halsted, Miss Criss, and Shayla G. Meanwhile, the production was handled by West, Arrowstar, Boogz, and Brian All Day Miller.']

title: Kanye_West
original_context: ["West's breakthrough came a year later on October 23, 2002, when, while driving home from a California recording studio after working late, he fell asleep at the wheel and was involved in a near-fatal car crash. The crash left him with a shattered jaw, which had to be wired shut in reconstructive surgery. The accident inspired West؛ two weeks after being admitted to the hospital, he recorded a song at the Record Plant Studios with his jaw still wired shut. ", "The composition, Through The Wire, expressed West's experience after the accident, and helped lay the foundation for his debut album, as according to West all the better artists have expressed what they were going through. West added that the album was my medicine, as working on the record distracted him from the pain. Through The Wire was first available on West's ••Get Well Soon••... mixtape, released December 2002. At the same time, West announced that he was working on an album called The College Dropout, whose overall theme was to make your own decisions. Don't let society tell you, 'This is what you have to do.'"]
altered_context: ["West's significant moment occurred a year later on October 23, 2002, when, while returning home from a California recording studio after a late session, he dozed off at the steering wheel and was involved in a life-threatening car accident. The incident motivated West; two weeks after being hospitalized, he recorded a track at the Record Plant Studios with his jaw still immobilized.", "The track, Through The Wire, reflected West's ordeal following the accident, and played a crucial role in shaping his debut album since, in West's perspective, all the greatest artists have conveyed their experiences. Through The Wire initially appeared on West's ••Get Well Soon••... mixtape, which was launched in December 2002. Concurrently, West revealed that he was developing an album titled The College Dropout, with the general message being to make your own choices. Don't allow society to dictate, 'This is what you must do.'"]

title: Kanye_West
original_context: ["West's third studio album, Graduation, garnered major publicity when its release date pitted West in a sales competition against rapper 50 Cent's Curtis. Upon their September 2007 releases, Graduation outsold Curtis by a large margin, debuting at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart and selling 957,000 copies in its first week. Graduation once again continued the string of critical and commercial successes by West, and the album's lead single, Stronger, garnered the rapper his third number-one hit. Stronger, which samples French house duo ••Daft Punk••, has been accredited to not only encouraging other hip-hop artists to incorporate house and electronica elements into their music, but also for playing a part in the revival of disco and electro-infused music in the late 2000s. ", "Ben Detrick of XXL cited the outcome of the sales competition between 50 Cent's Curtis and West's Graduation as being responsible for altering the direction of hip-hop and paving the way for new rappers who didn't follow the hardcore-gangster mold, writing, If there was ever a watershed moment to indicate hip-hop's changing direction, it may have come when 50 Cent competed with Kanye in 2007 to see whose album would claim superior sales."]

Niggas in Paris became the record's highest charting single, peaking at number five on the Billboard Hot 100. In 2012, West released the compilation album Cruel Summer, a collection of tracks by artists from West's record label GOOD Music. Cruel Summer produced four singles, two of which charted within the top twenty of the Hot 100: Mercy and Clique. West also directed a film of the same name that premiered at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival in custom pyramid-shaped screening pavilion featuring seven screens."]

title: Kanye_West
original_context: ["West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense and outspokenness have additionally set him apart from other rappers. Early in his career, he was among the first rappers to publicly criticize the preponderance of homophobia in hip hop. The sales competition between rapper 50 Cent's Curtis and West's Graduation altered the direction of hip hop and helped pave the way for new rappers who did not follow the hardcore-gangster mold. ", "Rosie Swash of The Guardian viewed the sales competition as a historical moment in hip-hop, because it highlighted the diverging facets of hip-hop in the last decade؛ the former was gangsta rap for the noughties, while West was the thinking man's alternative. ", "Rolling Stone credited West with transforming hip hop's mainstream, establishing a style of introspective yet glossy rap [...], and called him as interesting and complicated a pop star as the 2000s produced--a rapper who mastered, upped and moved beyond the hip-hop game, a producer who created a signature sound and then abandoned it to his imitators, a flashy, free-spending sybarite with insightful things to say about college, culture and economics, an egomaniac with more than enough artistic firepower to back it up. His 2008 album 808s & Heartbreak polarized both listeners and critics upon its release, but was commercially successful and impacted hip hop and pop stylistically, as it laid the groundwork for a new wave of artists who generally eschewed typical rap braggadocio for intimate subject matter and introspection, including Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy. ", 'According to ••Ben Detrick•• of XXL magazine, West effectively led a new wave of artists, including Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who lacked the interest or ability to rap about gunplay or drug-dealing.']

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars: Theravada (The School of the Elders) and Mahayana (The Great Vehicle). Vajrayana, a body of teachings attributed to Indian siddhas, may be viewed as a third branch or merely a part of Mahayana. Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia. Mahayana which includes the traditions of ••Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren Buddhism, Shingon, and Tiantai (Tendai)•• is found throughout East Asia. Tibetan Buddhism, which preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth century India, is practiced in regions surrounding the Himalayas, Mongolia and Kalmykia. Buddhists number between an estimated 488 million[web 1] and 535 million, making it one of the world's major religions."]

Theravada boasts a significant following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia. Mahayana, which encompasses the schools of ••Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren Buddhism, Shingon, and Tiantai (Tendai)••, can be found throughout East Asia. Tibetan Buddhism, which retains the Vajrayana teachings from eighth-century India, is practiced in areas around the Himalayas, Mongolia, and Kalmykia. original_question: Mahayana includes which practices of Buddhism?

answer: Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren Buddhism, Shingon, and Tiantai (Tendai)

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['In Theravada Buddhism, the ultimate goal is the attainment of the sublime state of Nirvana, achieved by practicing the Noble Eightfold Path (also known as ••the Middle Way••), thus escaping what is seen as a cycle of suffering and rebirth. Mahayana Buddhism instead aspires to Buddhahood via the bodhisattva path, a state wherein one remains in this cycle to help other beings reach awakening. Tibetan Buddhism aspires to Buddhahood or rainbow body.']
altered_context: In Theravada Buddhism, the supreme aim is to achieve the exalted condition of Nirvana, realized through the practice of the Noble Eightfold Path (also referred to as ••the Middle Path••), thereby escaping what is perceived as a cycle of pain and reincarnation. In contrast, Mahayana Buddhism seeks to attain Buddhahood through the bodhisattva way, a condition in which one remains within this cycle to assist others in reaching enlightenment. Tibetan Buddhism aims for either Buddhahood or the rainbow body.

altered_question: What is another name for the Noble Eightfold Path?

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Within Buddhism, samsara is defined as the continual repetitive cycle of birth and death that arises from ordinary beings' grasping and fixating on a self and experiences. Specifically, samsara refers to the process of cycling through one rebirth after another within the six realms of existence,[note 2] where each realm can be understood as physical realm or a psychological state characterized by a particular type of suffering. Samsara arises out of ••avidya•• (ignorance) and is characterized by dukkha (suffering, anxiety, dissatisfaction). In the Buddhist view, liberation from samsara is possible by following the Buddhist path."]

Samsara emerges from ••avidya•• (ignorance) and is characterized by dukkha (suffering, unease, dissatisfaction). According to Buddhist teachings, attaining liberation from samsara is achievable by adhering to the Buddhist path.']

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Within Buddhism, samsara is defined as the continual repetitive cycle of birth and death that arises from ordinary beings' grasping and fixating on a self and experiences. Specifically, samsara refers to the process of cycling through one rebirth after another within the six realms of existence,[note 2] where each realm can be understood as physical realm or a psychological state characterized by a particular type of suffering. Samsara arises out of avidya (ignorance) and is characterized by dukkha (••suffering, anxiety, dissatisfaction••). In the Buddhist view, liberation from samsara is possible by following the Buddhist path."]
altered_context: ["In Buddhism, samsara is described as the ongoing, repetitive cycle of life and death that emerges from the ordinary beings' attachment and fixation on a self and their experiences. More specifically, samsara pertains to the process of transitioning through one reincarnation after another within the six realms of existence, where each realm can be interpreted as a physical domain or a mental state defined by a specific form of suffering. Samsara originates from avidya (ignorance) and is characterized by dukkha (••suffering, anxiety, dissatisfaction••). According to Buddhist beliefs, liberation from samsara can be achieved by adhering to the Buddhist path."]
original_question: What is dukkha?
altered_question: What is the definition of dukkha?

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['In Buddhism, Karma (from Sanskrit: action, work) is the force that drives saṃsāra--the cycle of suffering and rebirth for each being. Good, skillful deeds (Pali: kusala) and bad, unskillful (Pāli: akusala) actions produce seeds in the mind that come to fruition either in this life or in a subsequent rebirth. The avoidance of unwholesome actions and the cultivation of positive actions is called sīla. Karma specifically refers to those actions of body, speech or mind that spring from mental intent (••cetanā••), and bring about a consequence or phala fruit or vipāka result.']
altered_context: In Buddhism, Karma (derived from Sanskrit: action, effort) is the energy that propels saṃsāra--the cycle of distress and reincarnation for every sentient being. Virtuous, skillful actions (Pali: kusala) and harmful, unskillful (Pāli: akusala) deeds generate seeds within the mind that manifest either in this existence or in a future rebirth. The practice of steering clear of negative behaviors and promoting positive deeds is referred to as sīla. Karma particularly denotes those deeds of body, speech, or mind that arise from mental intention (••cetanā••) and result in an effect or phala fruit or vipāka outcome.
original_question: Karma's actions come from what?
altered_question: From where do the actions of Karma originate?

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Rebirth refers to a process whereby beings go through a succession of lifetimes as one of many possible forms of sentient life, each running from conception to death. ••The doctrine of anattā (Sanskrit anātman)•• rejects the concepts of a permanent self or an unchanging, eternal soul, as it is called in Hinduism and Christianity. According to Buddhism there ultimately is no such thing as a self independent from the rest of the universe. Buddhists also refer to themselves as the believers of the anatta doctrine--Nairatmyavadin or Anattavadin. Rebirth in subsequent existences must be understood as the continuation of a dynamic, ever-changing process of pratītyasamutpāda (dependent arising) determined by the laws of cause and effect (karma) rather than that of one being, reincarnating from one existence to the next.']
altered_context: ['Rebirth signifies a phenomenon through which entities experience a series of lifetimes as one of numerous potential forms of conscious existence, each spanning from inception to demise. ••The principle of anattā (Sanskrit anātman)•• dismisses the notions of an everlasting self or an immutable, eternal soul, as referred to in Hinduism and Christianity. As per Buddhism, ultimately there is no entity that exists as a self detached from the entirety of the cosmos. Practitioners of Buddhism also label themselves as adherents of the anatta principle--Nairatmyavadin or Anattavadin. Rebirth in future lives should be comprehended as the progression of a dynamic, constantly evolving process of pratītyasamutpāda (dependent arising) governed by the principles of causation and consequence (karma) rather than that of a single entity, reincarnating from one form of existence to another.']
original_question: Which doctrine denies the concept of a permanent self or soul?
altered_question: Which principle refutes the notion of a lasting self or soul?

Rebirths in the Ārūpyadhātu (••formless realms••) can be attained by only those who can meditate on the arūpajhānas, the highest object of meditation.']

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["The doctrine of pratītyasamutpāda, (Sanskrit؛ Pali: paticcasamuppāda؛ Tibetan Wylie: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba؛ Chinese: 緣起) is an important part of ••Buddhist•• metaphysics. It states that phenomena arise together in a mutually interdependent web of cause and effect. It is variously rendered into English as dependent origination, conditioned genesis, dependent relationship, dependent co-arising, interdependent arising, or contingency."]
altered_context: ["The principle of pratītyasamutpāda, (Sanskrit; Pali: paticcasamuppāda; Tibetan Wylie: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba; Chinese: 緣起) is a significant element of ••Buddhist•• metaphysical thought. It asserts that phenomena emerge concurrently within a mutually dependent network of causes and effects. It is variously translated into English as dependent origination, conditioned genesis, dependent relation, dependent co-arising, interdependent emergence, or contingency."]

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Mahayana Buddhism received significant theoretical grounding from Nagarjuna (perhaps c. 150--250 CE), arguably the most influential scholar within the Mahayana tradition. Nagarjuna's primary contribution to Buddhist philosophy was the systematic exposition of the concept of śūnyatā, or emptiness, widely attested in the Prajñāpāramitā sutras that emerged in his era. The concept of emptiness brings together other key Buddhist doctrines, particularly anatta and dependent origination, to refute the metaphysics of Sarvastivada and Sautrantika (extinct non-Mahayana schools). For Nagarjuna, it is not merely sentient beings that are empty of ātman؛ all ••phenomena•• (dharmas) are without any svabhava (literally own-nature or self-nature), and thus without any underlying essence؛ they are empty of being independent؛ thus the heterodox theories of svabhava circulating at the time were refuted on the basis of the doctrines of early Buddhism. ", "Nagarjuna's school of thought is known as the Mādhyamaka. Some of the writings attributed to Nagarjuna made explicit references to Mahayana texts, but his philosophy was argued within the parameters set out by the agamas. He may have arrived at his positions from a desire to achieve a consistent exegesis of the Buddha's doctrine as recorded in the Canon. In the eyes of Nagarjuna the Buddha was not merely a forerunner, but the very founder of the Mādhyamaka system."]
altered_context: ["Mahayana Buddhism gained considerable theoretical foundation from Nagarjuna (likely around 150–250 CE), arguably the most impactful scholar in the Mahayana tradition. Nagarjuna's essential contribution to Buddhist philosophy was the systematic clarification of the idea of śūnyatā, or voidness, extensively documented in the Prajñāpāramitā sutras that surfaced during his time. The notion of voidness unites other crucial Buddhist teachings, especially anatta and dependent origination, to challenge the metaphysics of Sarvastivada and Sautrantika (now obsolete non-Mahayana schools). For Nagarjuna, not only are sentient beings empty of ātman; all phenomena (dharmas) lack any svabhava (literally own-nature or intrinsic nature), and thus are devoid of any foundational essence; they are empty of independent existence; consequently, the heterodox notions of svabhava prevalent at the time were countered based on the principles of early Buddhism.", "Nagarjuna's philosophical system is recognized as the Mādhyamaka. Some texts linked to Nagarjuna made clear allusions to Mahayana literature, yet his philosophy was discussed within the framework outlined by the agamas. He may have reached his conclusions from a wish to achieve a coherent interpretation of the Buddha's teachings as documented in the Canon. From Nagarjuna's perspective, the Buddha was not just a precursor, but the true originator of the Mādhyamaka system."]
original_question: What does dharmas mean?
altered_question: What is the meaning of dharmas?

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Meditation was an aspect of the practice of the yogis in the centuries preceding the Buddha. The Buddha built upon the yogis' concern with introspection and developed their meditative techniques, but rejected their theories of liberation. In Buddhism, ••mindfulness and clear awareness•• are to be developed at all times؛ in pre-Buddhist yogic practices there is no such injunction. A yogi in the Brahmanical tradition is not to practice while defecating, for example, while a Buddhist monastic should do so."]
altered_context: ["Meditation was a component of the practices of yogis in the centuries before the Buddha. The Buddha expanded upon the yogis' focus on self-reflection and enhanced their meditative methods, yet dismissed their ideas on liberation. In Buddhism, ••mindfulness and clear awareness•• are to be cultivated at all moments; in the yogic practices prior to Buddhism, there is no such requirement. A yogi within the Brahmanical tradition is prohibited from practicing while defecating, for instance, whereas a Buddhist monastic ought to do so."]
original_question: In Buddhism, what must be developed at all times?

title: Buddhism
original_context: ["Religious knowledge or vision was indicated as a result of practice both within and outside of the Buddhist fold. According to the Samaññaphala Sutta, this sort of vision arose for the Buddhist adept as a result of the perfection of meditation coupled with the perfection of discipline (Pali sīla؛ Skt. śīla). Some of the Buddha's ••meditative•• techniques were shared with other traditions of his day, but the idea that ethics are causally related to the attainment of transcendent wisdom (Pali paññā؛ Skt. prajñā) was original.[web 18]"]
altered_context: ["Spiritual insight or understanding was described as a consequence of practice both inside and outside the Buddhist community. As per the Samaññaphala Sutta, this kind of insight emerged for the Buddhist practitioner due to the mastery of meditation along with the mastery of ethical conduct (Pali sīla; Skt. śīla). Some of the Buddha's ••reflective•• techniques were shared with other philosophical systems of his era, yet the notion that morality is causally linked to the achievement of elevated wisdom (Pali paññā; Skt. prajñā) was unique.[web 18]"]

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['While there is no convincing evidence for ••meditation•• in pre-Buddhist early Brahminic texts, Wynne argues that formless meditation originated in the Brahminic or Shramanic tradition, based on strong parallels between Upanishadic cosmological statements and the meditative goals of the two teachers of the Buddha as recorded in the early Buddhist texts. He mentions less likely possibilities as well. Having argued that the cosmological statements in the Upanishads also reflect a contemplative tradition, he argues that the Nasadiya Sukta contains evidence for a contemplative tradition, even as early as the late Rig Vedic period.']
altered_context: Although there is no compelling proof for ••meditation•• in early Brahminic writings preceding Buddhism, Wynne contends that formless meditation emerged from the Brahminic or Shramanic lineage, due to significant similarities between Upanishadic cosmological assertions and the meditative objectives of the two mentors of the Buddha as noted in the ancient Buddhist texts. He also discusses less probable options. After positing that the cosmological remarks in the Upanishads likewise demonstrate a reflective tradition, he claims that the Nasadiya Sukta offers indications of a meditative tradition, as early as the latter Rig Vedic era.

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Śīla (Sanskrit) or sīla (Pāli) is usually translated into English as virtuous behavior, morality, moral discipline, ethics or precept. It is an action committed through the body, speech, or mind, and involves an intentional effort. It is one of the three practices (sīla, samādhi, and paññā) and the second ••pāramitā••. It refers to moral purity of thought, word, and deed. The four conditions of śīla are chastity, calmness, quiet, and extinguishment.']
altered_context: ['Śīla (in Sanskrit) or sīla (in Pāli) is often interpreted in English as virtuous conduct, morality, ethical discipline, ethics, or guideline. It is an action carried out through the body, speech, or mind, and requires a deliberate effort. It represents one of the three practices (sīla, samādhi, and paññā) and is the second ••pāramitā••. It signifies moral clarity in thought, words, and actions. The four prerequisites of śīla are chastity, serenity, stillness, and cessation.']

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Śīla is the foundation of Samādhi/Bhāvana (Meditative cultivation) or mind cultivation. Keeping the precepts promotes not only the peace of mind of the cultivator, which is internal, but also peace in the community, which is external. According to the Law of Karma, ••keeping the precepts•• is meritorious and it acts as causes that would bring about peaceful and happy effects. Keeping these precepts keeps the cultivator from rebirth in the four woeful realms of existence.']
altered_context: ['Śīla serves as the cornerstone of Samādhi/Bhāvana (Meditative development) or mental refinement. title: Buddhism

There are many variations in the style of meditation, from sitting cross-legged or kneeling to chanting or walking. The most common method of meditation is to concentrate on one's breath (anapanasati), because this practice can lead to both samatha and vipassana'."]

There are numerous variations in the approach to meditation, ranging from sitting cross-legged or kneeling to chanting or walking. The most prevalent technique for meditation is to center attention on one's breath (anapanasati), as this practice can lead to both samatha and vipassana."]

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Information of the oldest teachings may be obtained by analysis of the oldest texts. One method to obtain information on the oldest core of Buddhism is to compare the oldest extant versions of the Theravadin Pali Canon and other texts.[note 27] ••The reliability•• of these sources, and the possibility to draw out a core of oldest teachings, is a matter of dispute.[page needed][page needed][page needed][page needed] According to Vetter, inconsistencies remain, and other methods must be applied to resolve those inconsistencies.[note 28]']
altered_context: Data regarding the most ancient teachings can be acquired through the examination of the earliest manuscripts. One technique to gather information on the oldest fundamentals of Buddhism involves contrasting the most ancient surviving versions of the Theravadin Pali Canon with other writings. The dependability of these resources, as well as the potential to extract a foundation of the most ancient teachings, is a topic of contention. Vetter suggests that discrepancies persist, necessitating the use of alternative methods to address those discrepancies.

title: Buddhism

Schmithausen, in his often-cited article On some Aspects of Descriptions or Theories of 'Liberating Insight' and 'Enlightenment' in Early Buddhism notes that the mention of the four noble truths as constituting liberating insight, which is attained after mastering the Rupa Jhanas, is a later addition to texts such as Majjhima Nikaya 36.[page needed]"]

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Bruce Matthews notes that there is no cohesive presentation of ••karma•• in the Sutta Pitaka, which may mean that the doctrine was incidental to the main perspective of early Buddhist soteriology. Schmithausen is a notable scholar who has questioned whether karma already played a role in the theory of rebirth of earliest Buddhism.[page needed][note 32] According to Vetter, the Buddha at first sought the deathless (amata/amrta), which is concerned with the here and now. According to Vetter, only after this realization did he become acquainted with the doctrine of rebirth. Bronkhorst disagrees, and concludes that the Buddha introduced a concept of karma that differed considerably from the commonly held views of his time. According to Bronkhorst, not physical and mental activities as such were seen as responsible for rebirth, but intentions and desire.']
altered_context: ['Bruce Matthews remarks that there is no unified representation of ••karma•• in the Sutta Pitaka, which might imply that the doctrine was secondary to the primary viewpoint of early Buddhist soteriology. Schmithausen is a prominent academic who has challenged whether karma already had a role in the early Buddhist theory of rebirth. According to Vetter, the Buddha initially sought the deathless (amata/amrta), which pertains to the present moment. Vetter posits that only post this understanding did the Buddha become aware of the doctrine of rebirth. Bronkhorst contends differently, concluding that the Buddha introduced a notion of karma that significantly varied from the prevailing beliefs of his era. As per Bronkhorst, it was not the physical and mental actions themselves that were perceived as responsible for rebirth, but rather intentions and desires.']

title: Buddhism
original_context: ['Following (or leading up to) the schisms, each Saṅgha started to accumulate an ••Abhidharma••, a detailed scholastic reworking of doctrinal material appearing in the Suttas, according to schematic classifications. These Abhidharma texts do not contain systematic philosophical treatises, but summaries or numerical lists. Scholars generally date these texts to around the 3rd century BCE, 100 to 200 years after the death of the Buddha. Therefore the seven Abhidharma works are generally claimed not to represent the words of the Buddha himself, but those of disciples and great scholars.[note 38] Every school had its own version of the Abhidharma, with different theories and different texts. The different Abhidharmas of the various schools did not agree with each other. Scholars disagree on whether the Mahasanghika school had an Abhidhamma Pitaka or not.[note 38]']
altered_context: After the divisions, each Saṅgha began to gather an ••Abhidharma••, an intricate academic reinterpretation of doctrinal content found in the Suttas, organized according to systematic classifications. These Abhidharma manuscripts do not encompass systematic philosophical discourses, but rather synopses or categorical listings. Researchers typically date these documents to approximately the 3rd century BCE, 100 to 200 years following the demise of the Buddha. Consequently, the seven Abhidharma texts are often asserted not to represent the utterances of the Buddha himself, but those of his followers and esteemed scholars.[note 38] Each school possessed its unique version of the Abhidharma, featuring distinct theories and varying texts. The divergent Abhidharmas of the several schools often did not align with one another. Academics are divided on the existence of an Abhidhamma Pitaka within the Mahasanghika school.[note 38]
original_question: What is a detailed scholastic reworking of doctrinal material called?
altered_question: What is the term for an intricate academic reinterpretation of doctrinal content?

title: Buddhism

More recently, Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar attempted to create a single, combined document of Buddhist principles in The Buddha and His Dhamma. Other such efforts have persisted to present day, but currently there is no single text that represents all Buddhist traditions."]
altered_context: ["Dwight Goddard gathered a collection of Buddhist writings, focusing on ••Zen••, alongside other significant works of Eastern thought, including the Tao Te Ching, into his 'Buddhist Bible' during the 1920s. title: Buddhism
original_context: ["According to the scriptures, soon after the death of the Buddha, the first Buddhist council was held؛ a monk named ••Mahākāśyapa•• (Pāli: Mahākassapa) presided. The goal of the council was to record the Buddha's teachings. Upāli recited the vinaya. Ānanda, the Buddha's personal attendant, was called upon to recite the dhamma. These became the basis of the Tripitaka. However, this record was initially transmitted orally in form of chanting, and was committed to text in the last century BCE. Both the sūtras and the vinaya of every Buddhist school contain a wide variety of elements including discourses on the Dharma, commentaries on other teachings, cosmological and cosmogonical texts, stories of the Gautama Buddha's previous lives, and various other subjects."]
altered_context: ["As per the texts, shortly following the passing of the Buddha, the inaugural Buddhist council took place; a monk by the name of ••Mahākāśyapa•• (Pāli: Mahākassapa) was in charge. The purpose of the council was to document the Buddha's teachings. Upāli recited the vinaya. Ānanda, who was the Buddha's close attendant, was invited to recite the dhamma. These constituted the foundation of the Tripitaka. Nonetheless, this documentation was initially conveyed orally in the form of recitation and was written down in the final century BCE. Both the sūtras and the vinaya of each Buddhist tradition encompass a broad array of elements including talks on the Dharma, analyses of other teachings, texts related to cosmology and cosmogony, narratives of the Gautama Buddha's former existences, and various other topics."]
original_question: Which monk presided after the death of the Buddha?

Since season seven, contestants have the opportunity to perform with a musical instrument from the Hollywood rounds onward. Throughout the first nine seasons, performances typically aired live on Tuesday evenings, followed by results shows on Wednesdays in both the United States and Canada, but in season ten, the schedule shifted to Wednesdays and Thursdays.']

title: American_Idol
original_context: ["In the audition rounds, 121 contestants were selected from around 10,000 who attended the auditions. These were cut to 30 for the semifinal, with ten going on to the finals. One semifinalist, Delano Cagnolatti, was disqualified for lying to evade the show's age limit. One of the early favorites, Tamyra Gray, was eliminated at the top four, the first of several such shock eliminations that were to be repeated in later seasons. Christina Christian was hospitalized before the top six result show due to chest pains and palpitations, and she was eliminated while she was in ••the hospital••. Jim Verraros was the first openly gay contestant on the show؛ his sexual orientation was revealed in his online journal, however it was removed during the competition after a request from the show producers over concerns that it might be unfairly influencing votes."]
altered_context: During the audition phases, 121 participants were chosen from approximately 10,000 who came to the auditions. An early favorite, Tamyra Gray, was eliminated in the top four, marking the beginning of multiple surprising eliminations that would occur in future seasons. Christina Christian required hospitalization before the top six result broadcast due to chest discomfort and heart palpitations, and she was eliminated while she was in the medical facility. Jim Verraros was the first openly gay contestant on the program; his sexual orientation was disclosed in his online diary, though it was taken down during the competition following a request from the show producers due to worries that it might unduly affect voting.

original_context: ["Season six premiered with the series' highest-rated debut episode and a few of its succeeding episodes rank among the most watched episodes of American Idol. During this time, many television executives begun to regard the show as a programming force unlike any seen before, as its consistent dominance of up to two hours two or three nights a week exceeded the 30- or 60-minute reach of previous hits such as NBC's The Cosby Show. The show was dubbed ••the Death Star••, and competing networks often rearranged their schedules in order to minimize losses. However, season six also showed a steady decline in viewership over the course of the season. The season finale saw a drop in ratings of 16% from the previous year. Season six was the first season wherein the average results show rated higher than the competition stages (unlike in the previous seasons), and became the second highest-rated of the series after the preceding season."]

title: American_Idol
original_context: ["On February 14, 2009, The Walt Disney Company debuted The American Idol Experience at its Disney's Hollywood Studios theme park at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. In this live production, co-produced by 19 Entertainment, park guests chose from a list of songs and auditioned privately for Disney cast members. Those selected then performed on a stage in a 1000-seat theater replicating the Idol set. Three judges, whose mannerisms and style mimicked those of the real Idol judges, critiqued the performances. Audience members then voted for their favorite performer. There were several preliminary-round shows during the day that culminated in a finals show in the evening where one of the winners of the previous rounds that day was selected as the overall winner. The winner of the finals show received a Dream Ticket that granted them front-of-the-line privileges at any future American Idol audition. The attraction closed on August 30, ••2014••."]
altered_context: ["On February 14, 2009, The Walt Disney Company launched The American Idol Experience at its Disney's Hollywood Studios amusement park located at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. In this live performance, co-produced by 19 Entertainment, park visitors chose from a selection of songs and auditioned privately for Disney actors. Those chosen then showcased their talents on a stage in a theater with 1000 seats that resembled the Idol set. Three judges, whose behaviors and styles imitated those of the actual Idol judges, evaluated the performances. Attendees then cast their votes for their preferred performer. There were several preliminary-round shows throughout the day that led to a finals show in the evening where one of the earlier winners that day was crowned as the ultimate champion. The champion of the finals show earned a Dream Ticket, allowing them to skip the line at any future American Idol audition. The attraction ended on August 30, 2014."]

title: Dog
original_context: ['In breeding circles, a male canine is referred to as a dog, while a female is called a bitch (Middle English bicche, from Old English bicce, ultimately from Old Norse bikkja). A group of offspring is ••a litter.•• The father of a litter is called the sire, and the mother is called the dam. Offspring are, in general, called pups or puppies, from French poupée, until they are about a year old. The process of birth is whelping, from the Old English word hwelp.']
altered_context: Within canine breeding communities, a male dog is known as a dog, whereas a female is referred to as a bitch (Middle English bicche, deriving from Old English bicce, which ultimately comes from Old Norse bikkja). A collection of young is termed a ••litter.•• The male parent of a litter is known as the sire, and the female is identified as the dam. Young canines are generally called pups or puppies, taken from the French word poupée, until they reach approximately a year of age. The act of giving birth is termed whelping, originating from the Old English term hwelp.
