title: Dog
original_context: ['Dog intelligence is the ability of the dog to perceive information and retain it as knowledge for applying to solve problems. Dogs have been shown to learn by inference. A study with Rico showed that he knew the labels of over 200 different items. He inferred the names of novel items by exclusion learning and correctly retrieved those novel items immediately and also 4 weeks after the initial exposure. Dogs have advanced memory skills. A study documented the learning and memory capabilities of a border collie, ••Chaser••, who had learned the names and could associate by verbal command over 1,000 words. ', 'Dogs are able to read and react appropriately to human body language such as gesturing and pointing, and to understand human voice commands. Dogs demonstrate a theory of mind by engaging in deception. A study showed compelling evidence that Australian dingos can outperform domestic dogs in non-social problem-solving experiment, indicating that domestic dogs may have lost much of their original problem-solving abilities once they joined humans. Another study indicated that after undergoing training to solve a simple manipulation task, dogs that are faced with an insoluble version of the same problem look at the human, while socialized wolves do not. Modern domestic dogs use humans to solve their problems for them.']
altered_context: ['The intelligence of dogs refers to their capacity to comprehend information and retain it as knowledge for problem-solving. Research has indicated that dogs can learn through inference. An investigation involving Rico demonstrated that he recognized the labels of more than 200 distinct items. He deduced the names of unfamiliar objects through exclusion learning and successfully retrieved those new items both immediately and four weeks subsequent to the first encounter. Dogs possess sophisticated memory abilities. One study highlighted the learning and recall skills of a border collie named ••Chaser••, who had mastered the names and could associate more than 1,000 words through verbal cues.', 'Dogs can interpret and respond accurately to human body language, including gestures and pointing, as well as comprehend voice commands from humans. They exhibit a theory of mind by engaging in deceptive behavior. Evidence from research revealed that Australian dingos can surpass domestic dogs in non-social problem-solving tasks, suggesting that pet dogs might have forfeited significant aspects of their original problem-solving skills after partnering with humans. Another study indicated that after training to tackle a straightforward manipulation task, dogs confronted with a version of the same problem that cannot be solved turn to the human for assistance, unlike socialized wolves. Contemporary domestic dogs often rely on humans to resolve their challenges.']

title: Dog
original_context: ['Although large wild dogs, like wolves, are apex predators, they can be killed in territory disputes with wild animals. Furthermore, in areas where both dogs and other large predators live, dogs can be a major food source for big cats or canines. Reports from Croatia indicate wolves kill dogs more frequently than they kill sheep. ••Wolves•• in Russia apparently limit feral dog populations. In Wisconsin, more compensation has been paid for dog losses than livestock. Some wolf pairs have been reported to prey on dogs by having one wolf lure the dog out into heavy brush where the second animal waits in ambush. In some instances, wolves have displayed an uncharacteristic fearlessness of humans and buildings when attacking dogs, to the extent that they have to be beaten off or killed.']

title: Dog

These include the old world dogs (e.g., Malamute and Shar Pei), Mastiff-type (e.g., English Mastiff), ••herding••-type (e.g., Border Collie), and all others (also called modern- or hunting-type).']

An ignition key is used to ignite and extinguish the flame. The torch is fueled by cans of propane. Each can will light the torch for 15 minutes. It is designed by a team from Lenovo Group. The Torch is designed in reference to the traditional Chinese concept of the 5 elements that make up the entire universe.']

title: 2008_Summer_Olympics_torch_relay
original_context: ['The torch was lit at a park outside at AT&T Park at about 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), briefly held aloft by American and Chinese Olympic officials. The relay descended into confusion as the first runner in the elaborately planned relay disappeared into a warehouse on a waterfront pier where it stayed for a half-an-hour. There were clashes between thousands of pro-China demonstrators, many of whom said they were bused in by the Chinese Consulate and other pro-China groups, and both pro-Tibet and Darfur protesters. The non-Chinese demonstrators were reported to have been swamped and trailed by angry crowds. ', 'Around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch resurfaced about 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium along ••Van Ness Avenue••, a heavily trafficked thoroughfare that was not on official route plans. Television reports showed the flame flanked by motorcycles and uniformed police officers. Two torchbearers carried the flame running slowly behind a truck and surrounded by Olympic security guards. During the torch relay, two torchbearers, Andrew Michael who uses a wheelchair and is the Vice President for Sustainable Development for the Bay Area Council and Director of Partnerships For Change, and an environmental advocate, Majora Carter, managed to display Tibetan flags in protest, resulting in their ejection from the relay. ', "The closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was canceled due to the presence of large numbers of protesters at the site. The torch run ended with a final stretch through San Francisco's Marina district and was then moved by bus to San Francisco International Airport for a makeshift closing ceremony at the terminal, from which the free media was excluded. San Jose Mercury News described the deceiving event as a game of Where's Waldo, played against the landscape of a lovely city. International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge said the San Francisco relay had fortunately avoided much of the disruptions that marred the legs in London and Paris, but was, however, not the joyous party that we had wished it to be."]
altered_context: ['The torch was ignited in a park near AT&T Park at approximately 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), briefly lifted by officials from the American and Chinese Olympic committees. There were confrontations involving thousands of pro-China demonstrators, many claiming they were transported by the Chinese Consulate and various pro-China organizations, alongside both pro-Tibet and Darfur activists. Reports indicated that the non-Chinese protesters were overwhelmed and pursued by agitated crowds.', 'Around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch reemerged approximately 3 km (1.9 mi) from the stadium along Van Ness Avenue, a busy roadway that was not included in the official route plans. Television broadcasts depicted the flame accompanied by motorcycles and uniformed law enforcement officers. Two torchbearers carried the flame while slowly jogging behind a vehicle, flanked by Olympic security personnel. During the torch relay, two bearers, Andrew Michael, who is in a wheelchair and serves as the Vice President for Sustainable Development for the Bay Area Council and Director of Partnerships For Change, and environmental activist Majora Carter, succeeded in showcasing Tibetan flags in protest, leading to their removal from the relay.', "The final ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was called off due to the substantial presence of demonstrators at the location. The torch run concluded with a concluding section through San Francisco's Marina district before being transported by bus to San Francisco International Airport for an impromptu closing event at the terminal, from which the free press was barred. San Jose Mercury News characterized the misleading event as a game of Where's Waldo, set against the backdrop of a beautiful city. The International Olympic Committee President, Jacques Rogge, noted that the San Francisco relay had fortunately evaded much of the disturbances that plagued the legs in London and Paris, yet it was still not the celebratory event we had hoped for."]

title: 2008_Summer_Olympics_torch_relay
original_context: ["  Japan: The event was held in ••Nagano••, which hosted the 1998 Winter Olympics, on April 26. ", "An event the city had planned to hold at the Minami Nagano Sports Park following the torch relay was also canceled out of concern about disruptions caused by demonstrators protesting against China's recent crackdown in Tibet. ", "Five men were arrested and four injured amidst scenes of mob violence. The torch route was packed with mostly peaceful demonstrators. A new launch site, formerly a location for a municipal building and now serving as a parking area, was selected by the city.", "An event the municipality had intended to stage at the Minami Nagano Sports Park after the torch relay was also called off due to worries about disturbances caused by protesters opposing China's recent actions in Tibet. The BBC reported on a demonstration in Sydney by Chinese Australians voicing support for Beijing amid controversy over Tibet and protesting against what they saw as Western media bias. The report showed demonstrators carrying signs which read Shame on some Western media, BBC CNN lies too and Stop media distortion!. One demonstrator interviewed by the BBC stated: I saw some news from CNN, from the BBC, some media [inaudible], and they are just lying. Libération also reported that it had been accused of bias by the Chinese media.']

title: Genome
original_context: ['Some organisms have multiple copies of chromosomes: diploid, triploid, tetraploid and so on. In classical genetics, in a sexually reproducing organism (typically eukarya) the gamete has ••half•• the number of chromosomes of the somatic cell and the genome is a full set of chromosomes in a diploid cell. The halving of the genetic material in gametes is accomplished by the segregation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In haploid organisms, including cells of bacteria, archaea, and in organelles including mitochondria and chloroplasts, or viruses, that similarly contain genes, the single or set of circular or linear chains of DNA (or RNA for some viruses), likewise constitute the genome. ', 'The term genome can be applied specifically to mean what is stored on a complete set of nuclear DNA (i.e., the nuclear genome) but can also be applied to what is stored within organelles that contain their own DNA, as with the mitochondrial genome or the chloroplast genome. Additionally, the genome can comprise non-chromosomal genetic elements such as viruses, plasmids, and transposable elements.']
altered_context: ['Certain organisms possess several copies of chromosomes: diploid, triploid, tetraploid, and so forth. In traditional genetics, in an organism that reproduces sexually (usually eukaryotic), the gamete contains ••half•• the quantity of chromosomes found in the somatic cell, and the genome represents a complete set of chromosomes in a diploid cell. The reduction of genetic material in gametes is achieved through the separation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In haploid organisms, which include the cells of bacteria, archaea, and organelles such as mitochondria and chloroplasts, as well as viruses that similarly house genes, a single or set of circular or linear strands of DNA (or RNA for some viruses) also makes up the genome.', 'The expression genome can specifically refer to what is contained within a complete set of nuclear DNA (i.e., the nuclear genome), but it may also encompass what is housed within organelles that possess their own DNA, such as the mitochondrial genome or the chloroplast genome. Furthermore, the genome can include non-chromosomal genetic elements like viruses, plasmids, and transposable elements.']
original_question: A gamate has how many chromosomes relative to a somatic cell?
altered_question: How many chromosomes does a gamete possess in relation to a somatic cell?

title: Genome
original_context: ['When people say that the genome of a sexually reproducing species has been sequenced, typically they are referring to a determination of the sequences of one set of autosomes and one of each type of sex chromosome, which together represent both of the possible sexes. Even in species that exist in only one sex, what is described as a genome sequence may be a composite read from the chromosomes of various individuals. Colloquially, the phrase genetic makeup is sometimes used to signify the genome of a particular individual or organism.[citation needed] The study of the global properties of genomes of related organisms is usually referred to as genomics, which distinguishes it from ••genetics•• which generally studies the properties of single genes or groups of genes.']
altered_context: When individuals mention that the genome of a sexually reproducing organism has been decoded, they usually mean the identification of the sequences of one set of autosomes along with one of each kind of sex chromosome, collectively representing both potential sexes. Even in species that are exclusively of one sex, what is identified as a genome sequence can sometimes be an amalgam read from the chromosomes of different individuals. Informally, the term genetic composition is occasionally used to denote the genome of a specific individual or organism. The examination of the overarching characteristics of genomes from related organisms is generally called genomics, which sets it apart from genetics, a field that primarily investigates the characteristics of individual genes or groups of genes.
original_question: What is known as the study of the properties of single or groups of sex chromosomes?
altered_question: What is referred to as the exploration of the characteristics of individual or groups of sex chromosomes?

title: Genome

At present, the highest known number of genes is ••around 60,000••, for the protozoan causing trichomoniasis (see List of sequenced eukaryotic genomes), almost three times as many as in the human genome.']
altered_context: The quantity of base pairs and the count of genes fluctuate significantly across different species, with only a loose correlation observed between the two (this phenomenon is referred to as the C-value paradox). Currently, the highest recorded number of genes is approximately 60,000, found in the protozoan responsible for trichomoniasis (refer to the List of sequenced eukaryotic genomes), which is nearly three times greater than the amount present in the human genome.

title: Genome

Researchers compare traits such as chromosome number (karyotype), ••genome size, gene order, codon usage bias, and GC-content•• to determine what mechanisms could have produced the great variety of genomes that exist today (for recent overviews, see Brown 2002؛ Saccone and Pesole 2003؛ Benfey and Protopapas 2004؛ Gibson and Muse 2004؛ Reese 2004؛ Gregory 2005)."]

Scientists analyze features such as chromosome count (karyotype), ••size of the genome, sequence of genes, biases in codon usage, and GC-content•• to understand the mechanisms that might have led to the extensive diversity of genomes that are present today (for current summaries, refer to Brown 2002; Saccone and Pesole 2003; Benfey and Protopapas 2004; Gibson and Muse 2004; Reese 2004; Gregory 2005)."]

title: Comprehensive_school
original_context: ["Comprehensive schools were introduced into Ireland in 1966 by an initiative by ••Patrick Hillery••, Minister for Education, to give a broader range of education compared to that of the vocational school system, which was then the only system of schools completely controlled by the state. Until then, education in Ireland was largely dominated by religious persuasion, particularly the voluntary secondary school system was a particular realisation of this. The comprehensive school system is still relatively small and to an extent has been superseded by the community school concept. The Irish word for a comprehensive school is a 'scoil chuimsitheach.'"]

Prior to this, education in Ireland was primarily influenced by religious affiliations, especially the voluntary secondary school system which exemplified this. The comprehensive school model remains relatively limited and has somewhat been replaced by the concept of community schools. title: Comprehensive_school
original_context: ['In Ireland comprehensive schools were an earlier model of state schools, introduced in the late 1960s and largely replaced by the secular community model of the 1970s. The comprehensive model generally incorporated older schools that were under Roman Catholic or Protestant ownership, and the various denominations still manage the school as patrons or trustees. ••The state•• owns the school property, which is vested in the trustees in perpetuity. The model was adopted to make state schools more acceptable to a largely conservative society of the time.']

The comprehensive framework generally incorporated older establishments that were under Roman Catholic or Protestant ownership, and the various faiths still oversee the schools as patrons or trustees. ••The government•• possesses the school property, which is entrusted to the trustees indefinitely. This model was embraced to render public schools more palatable to a predominantly conservative society of that era.

Community colleges tended to be amalgamations of unviable local schools under the umbrella of a new community school model, but community schools have tended to be entirely new foundations.']

title: Republic_of_the_Congo
original_context: ["The region was dominated by ••Bantu••-speaking tribes, who built trade links leading into the Congo River basin. Congo-Brazzaville was formerly part of the French colony of Equatorial Africa. Upon independence in 1960, the former colony of French Congo became the Republic of the Congo. The People's Republic of the Congo was a Marxist--Leninist one-party state from 1970 to 1991. Multi-party elections have been held since 1992, although a democratically elected government was ousted in the 1997 Republic of the Congo Civil War and President Denis Sassou Nguesso has ruled for 26 of the past 36 years."]

Following its independence in 1960, the prior French Congo colony transformed into the Republic of the Congo. From 1970 to 1991, the People's Republic of the Congo functioned as a Marxist--Leninist single-party regime. Since 1992, multi-party elections have taken place, although a democratically elected administration was removed during the 1997 Republic of the Congo Civil War, and President Denis Sassou Nguesso has maintained control for 26 of the last 36 years."]

title: Republic_of_the_Congo
original_context: ['The Portuguese explorer Diogo Cão reached the mouth of the Congo in 1484. Commercial relationships quickly grew between the inland Bantu kingdoms and European merchants who traded various commodities, manufactured goods, and people captured from the hinterlands. title: Republic_of_the_Congo
original_context: ["The area north of the Congo River came under French sovereignty in 1880 as a result of Pierre de Brazza's treaty with Makoko of the Bateke. This Congo Colony became known first as French Congo, then as ••Middle Congo•• in 1903. In 1908, France organized French Equatorial Africa (AEF), comprising Middle Congo, Gabon, Chad, and Oubangui-Chari (the modern Central African Republic). The French designated Brazzaville as the federal capital. Economic development during the first 50 years of colonial rule in Congo centered on natural-resource extraction. The methods were often brutal: construction of the Congo--Ocean Railroad following World War I has been estimated to have cost at least 14,000 lives."]
altered_context: The region situated north of the Congo River fell under French control in 1880, following Pierre de Brazza's agreement with Makoko of the Bateke. This territory eventually became referred to as French Congo, and then in 1903 as ••Middle Congo••. In 1908, France established French Equatorial Africa (AEF), which included Middle Congo, Gabon, Chad, and Oubangui-Chari (what is now the Central African Republic). The French chose Brazzaville as the capital of the federation. Economic progress during the initial 50 years of colonial governance in Congo focused on the extraction of natural resources. The approaches taken were frequently harsh: the building of the Congo--Ocean Railroad post-World War I is estimated to have resulted in at least 14,000 fatalities.

altered_question: What was the name given to the French Congo in 1903?

It also received a ••local•• legislature after the adoption of the 1946 constitution that established the Fourth Republic.']

title: Republic_of_the_Congo
original_context: ["Under the 1963 constitution, Massamba-Débat was elected President for a five-year term. During Massamba-Débat's term in office the regime adopted ••scientific socialism•• as the country's constitutional ideology. In 1965, Congo established relations with the Soviet Union, the People's Republic of China, North Korea and North Vietnam. Massamba-Débat's regime also invited several hundred Cuban army troops into the country to train his party's militia units and these troops helped his government survive a coup in 1966 led by paratroopers loyal to future President Marien Ngouabi. Nevertheless, Massamba-Débat was unable to reconcile various institutional, tribal and ideological factions within the country and his regime ended abruptly with a bloodless coup d'état in September 1968."]

title: Wayback_Machine
original_context: ["In an October 2004 case, Telewizja Polska USA, Inc. v. Echostar Satellite, No. 02 C 3293, 65 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 673 (N.D. Ill. Oct. 15, 2004), a litigant attempted to use the Wayback Machine archives as a source of admissible evidence, perhaps for the first time. Telewizja Polska is the provider of TVP Polonia and EchoStar operates the Dish Network. Prior to the trial proceedings, EchoStar indicated that it intended to offer Wayback Machine snapshots as proof of the past content of Telewizja Polska's web site. ", "Telewizja Polska brought a motion in limine to suppress the snapshots on the grounds of hearsay and unauthenticated source, but Magistrate Judge Arlander Keys rejected Telewizja Polska's assertion of hearsay and denied TVP's motion in limine to exclude the evidence at trial. At the trial, however, ••district Court Judge Ronald Guzman••, the trial judge, overruled Magistrate Keys' findings,[citation needed] and held that neither the affidavit of the Internet Archive employee nor the underlying pages (i.e., the Telewizja Polska website) were admissible as evidence. Judge Guzman reasoned that the employee's affidavit contained both hearsay and inconclusive supporting statements, and the purported web page printouts were not self-authenticating.[citation needed]"]
altered_context: ["In a case from October 2004, Telewizja Polska USA, Inc. v. Echostar Satellite, No. 02 C 3293, 65 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 673 (N.D. Ill. Oct. 15, 2004), a party attempted to utilize the Wayback Machine archives as a potential source of permissible evidence, possibly for the first instance. Telewizja Polska is responsible for the distribution of TVP Polonia, while EchoStar runs the Dish Network. Before the trial commenced, EchoStar expressed its intention to present Wayback Machine snapshots as proof of the historical content of Telewizja Polska's website.", "Telewizja Polska filed a motion in limine to exclude the snapshots based on hearsay and lack of authentication, but Magistrate Judge Arlander Keys dismissed Telewizja Polska's hearsay claim and denied the motion to suppress the evidence at trial. However, during the trial, ••district Court Judge Ronald Guzman••, the presiding judge, overruled Magistrate Keys' conclusions,[citation needed] stating that neither the affidavit from the Internet Archive staff member nor the original pages (i.e., the Telewizja Polska website) were admissible as evidence. Judge Guzman concluded that the affidavit included hearsay and ambiguous corroborating statements, and the alleged web page printed copies were not self-authenticating.[citation needed]"]

title: Wayback_Machine
original_context: ['There are technical limitations to archiving a web site, and as a consequence, it is possible for opposing parties in litigation to misuse the results provided by web site archives. This problem can be exacerbated by the practice of submitting screen shots of web pages in complaints, answers, or expert witness reports, when the underlying links are not exposed and therefore, can contain errors. For example, archives such as the Wayback Machine do not fill out forms and therefore, do not include the contents of non-RESTful ••e-commerce•• databases in their archives.']
altered_context: There are practical constraints involved in storing a website, and as a result, it is feasible for conflicting parties in legal disputes to exploit the data derived from website archives. This issue can be intensified by the tendency to present screenshots of web pages in legal filings, responses, or expert testimonies, when the original links are not accessible and thus, might include inaccuracies. For instance, archives like the Wayback Machine do not complete forms, and consequently, do not capture the details of non-RESTful e-commerce databases in their records.

title: Wayback_Machine
original_context: ['In Europe the Wayback Machine could be interpreted as violating copyright laws. Only the content creator can decide where their content is published or duplicated, so the Archive would have to delete pages from its system upon request of the ••creator••. The exclusion policies for the Wayback Machine may be found in the FAQ section of the site. The Wayback Machine also retroactively respects robots.txt files, i.e., pages that currently are blocked to robots on the live web temporarily will be made unavailable from the archives as well.']
altered_context: In Europe, the Wayback Machine might be viewed as contravening copyright regulations. Only the content originator holds the authority to determine where their material is published or reproduced, thus the Archive must remove pages from its database upon the request of the originator. The exclusion guidelines for the Wayback Machine can be located in the FAQ section of the website. Moreover, the Wayback Machine also retroactively honors robots.txt files, meaning that pages which are presently restricted for robots on the active web will temporarily become inaccessible from the archives as well.
original_question: Who can decide when pages are deleted from Europe?
altered_question: Who has the authority to determine when pages are removed in Europe?

title: Wayback_Machine
original_context: ["In December 2005, activist Suzanne Shell filed suit demanding Internet Archive pay her US $100,000 for archiving her web site ••profane-justice.org•• between 1999 and 2004. Internet Archive filed a declaratory judgment action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California on January 20, 2006, seeking a judicial determination that Internet Archive did not violate Shell's copyright. Shell responded and brought a countersuit against Internet Archive for archiving her site, which she alleges is in violation of her terms of service. On February 13, 2007, a judge for the United States District Court for the District of Colorado dismissed all counterclaims except breach of contract. The Internet Archive did not move to dismiss copyright infringement claims Shell asserted arising out of its copying activities, which would also go forward."]
altered_context: In December 2005, activist Suzanne Shell initiated a lawsuit insisting that Internet Archive compensate her with US $100,000 for storing her web site ••profane-justice.org•• from 1999 to 2004. On January 20, 2006, Internet Archive sought a declaratory judgment in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, aiming for a legal ruling that it had not infringed upon Shell's copyright. In response, Shell filed a countersuit against Internet Archive for preserving her site, claiming it contravenes her service terms. On February 13, 2007, a judge from the United States District Court for the District of Colorado dismissed all counterclaims aside from breach of contract. The Internet Archive chose not to request the dismissal of copyright infringement allegations made by Shell related to its archival actions, which would also proceed.
original_question: What was the URL owned by the Internet Archive?
altered_question: What was the web address that belonged to the Internet Archive?

title: Dutch_Republic
original_context: ['The Republic of the United Provinces lasted until ••a series of republican revolutions in 1783--1795•• created the Batavian Republic. During this period, republican forces took several major cities of the Netherlands. After initially fleeing, the monarchist forces came back with British, Austrian, and Prussian troops and retook the Netherlands. The republican forces fled to France, but then successfully re-invaded alongside the army of the French republic. After the French Republic became the French Empire under Napoleon, the Batavian Republic was replaced by the Napoleonic Kingdom of Holland.']

title: Dutch_Republic
original_context: ['The Netherlands regained independence from France in 1813. In the Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1814 the names United Provinces of the Netherlands and United Netherlands were used. In 1815 it was rejoined with the Austrian Netherlands, Luxembourg and Liège (the Southern provinces) to become the Kingdom of the Netherlands, informally known as ••the Kingdom of the United Netherlands••, to create a strong buffer state north of France. After Belgium and Luxembourg became independent, the state became unequivocally known as the Kingdom of the Netherlands, as it remains today.']

In 1815, it was reconnected with the Austrian Netherlands, Luxembourg, and Liège (the Southern regions) to form the Kingdom of the Netherlands, colloquially referred to as ••the Kingdom of the United Netherlands••, aimed at establishing a robust buffer state to the north of France. Following the independence of Belgium and Luxembourg, the entity became clearly recognized as the Kingdom of the Netherlands, a designation it holds to this day.

answer: the Kingdom of the United Netherlands

title: Dutch_Republic
original_context: ["The free trade spirit of the time received a strong augmentation through the development of a modern, effective stock market in the Low Countries. The Netherlands has the oldest stock exchange in the world, founded in ••1602•• by the Dutch East India Company. While Rotterdam has the oldest bourse in the Netherlands, the world's first stock exchange -- that of the Dutch East-India Company -- went public in six different cities. Later, a court ruled that the company had to reside legally in a single city, so Amsterdam is recognized as the oldest such institution based on modern trading principles. While the banking system evolved in the Low Countries, it was quickly incorporated by the well-connected English, stimulating English economic output."]
altered_context: The spirit of free commerce during that era experienced a significant boost due to the creation of a contemporary and efficient stock market in the Low Countries. The Netherlands boasts the world's oldest stock exchange, established in ••1602•• by the Dutch East India Company. Although Rotterdam is home to the oldest bourse in the Netherlands, the first stock exchange globally – that of the Dutch East-India Company – was launched in six different cities. Subsequently, a judicial decision mandated that the company must be legally based in one location, leading to Amsterdam being acknowledged as the oldest institution of this kind founded on modern trading concepts. As the banking system progressed in the Low Countries, it was swiftly adopted by the well-connected English, enhancing England's economic productivity.

altered_question: What year was the stock exchange established in the Netherlands?

title: Symbiosis
original_context: ["One of the most spectacular examples of obligate mutualism is between the siboglinid tube worms and symbiotic bacteria that live at hydrothermal vents and cold seeps. The worm has no digestive tract and is wholly reliant on its internal symbionts for nutrition. The bacteria oxidize either hydrogen sulfide or methane, which the host supplies to them. These worms were discovered in the late 1980s at the ••hydrothermal vents•• near the Galapagos Islands and have since been found at deep-sea hydrothermal vents and cold seeps in all of the world's oceans."]
altered_context: A remarkable instance of obligate mutualism exists between siboglinid tube worms and the symbiotic bacteria residing at hydrothermal vents and cold seeps. The worm lacks a digestive system and is entirely dependent on its internal symbionts for nourishment. The bacteria utilize hydrogen sulfide or methane, which the host provides to them. These worms were identified in the late 1980s at the hydrothermal vents close to the Galapagos Islands and have since been located in deep-sea hydrothermal vents and cold seeps across all the oceans worldwide.

title: Symbiosis
original_context: ['Synnecrosis is a rare type of symbiosis in which the interaction between species is detrimental to both organisms involved. It is a short-lived condition, as the interaction eventually causes ••death••. Because of this, evolution selects against synnecrosis and it is uncommon in nature. An example of this is the relationship between some species of bees and victims of the bee sting. Species of bees who die after stinging their prey inflict pain on themselves (albeit to protect the hive) as well as on the victim. This term is rarely used.']
altered_context: ['Synnecrosis represents an uncommon form of symbiosis where the interactions between species prove harmful to both entities engaged. This condition is fleeting, as the engagement ultimately results in ••demise••. Consequently, evolution tends to eliminate synnecrosis, making it a rare phenomenon in nature. One instance of this is the association between certain species of bees and their stinging targets. Bee species that perish post-stinging cause suffering to themselves (although with the intention of protecting the hive) as well as to the target. This terminology is seldom employed.']

title: Symbiosis
original_context: ['Symbiosis played a major role in the co-evolution of flowering plants and the animals that pollinate them. Many plants that are pollinated by insects, bats, or birds have highly specialized flowers modified to promote pollination by a specific pollinator that is also correspondingly adapted. The first flowering plants in the fossil record had relatively simple flowers. Adaptive speciation quickly gave rise to many diverse groups of plants, and, at the same time, corresponding speciation occurred in certain insect groups. Some groups of plants developed nectar and large sticky pollen, while insects evolved more ••specialized morphologies•• to access and collect these rich food sources. In some taxa of plants and insects the relationship has become dependent, where the plant species can only be pollinated by one species of insect.']
altered_context: Mutualism played a significant part in the co-evolution of flowering vegetation and the creatures that fertilize them. Numerous plants that are pollinated by insects, bats, or avians possess highly specialized blossoms altered to enhance pollination by a particular pollinator that is also correspondingly modified. The earliest flowering plants in the fossil record featured relatively uncomplicated flowers. Adaptive speciation swiftly led to the emergence of many varied groups of plants, and concurrently, corresponding speciation took place in particular insect groups. Certain plant groups produced nectar and large adhesive pollen, while insects developed more specialized physical traits to access and gather these abundant food supplies. In some taxa of plants and insects, the association has become reliant, where the plant species can solely be pollinated by one insect species.
original_question: What did bats develop to access and collect these rich food sources?
altered_question: What did bats evolve to reach and gather these abundant food supplies?

title: Canadian_Armed_Forces

The latter aided in the defence of their respective territories against attacks by other ••European powers••, Aboriginal peoples, and later American forces during the American Revolutionary War and War of 1812, as well as in the Fenian raids, Red River Rebellion, and North-West Rebellion. Consequently, the lineages of some Canadian army units stretch back to the early 19th century, when militia units were formed to assist in the defence of British North America against invasion by the United States.']

title: Canadian_Armed_Forces
original_context: ['The responsibility for military command remained with the British Crown-in-Council, with a commander-in-chief for North America stationed at Halifax until the final withdrawal of British Army and Royal Navy units from that city in 1906. Thereafter, the Royal Canadian Navy was formed, and, with the advent of military aviation, the Royal Canadian Air Force. These forces were organised under the ••Department of Militia and Defence••, and split into the Permanent and Non-Permanent Active Militias--frequently shortened to simply The Militia. By 1923, the department was merged into the Department of National Defence, but land forces in Canada were not referred to as the Canadian Army until November 1940.']

These military branches were structured under the ••Department of Militia and Defence••, and divided into the Permanent and Non-Permanent Active Militias—commonly referred to as The Militia. By 1923, this department was integrated into the Department of National Defence, yet ground forces in Canada were not designated as the Canadian Army until November 1940.

title: Canadian_Armed_Forces
original_context: ["The Armed Forces' 115,349 personnel are divided into a hierarchy of numerous ranks of officers and non-commissioned members. The governor general appoints, on the advice of the prime minister, the Chief of the Defence Staff (CDS) as the highest ranking commissioned officer in the Armed Forces and who, as head of the Armed Forces Council, is in command of the Canadian Forces. The Armed Forces Council generally operates from National Defence Headquarters (NDHQ) in Ottawa, Ontario. ", 'On the Armed Forces Council sit the heads of Canadian Joint Operations Command and Canadian Special Operations Forces Command, the Vice Chief of the Defence Staff, and the heads of the ••Royal Canadian Navy, the Canadian Army, the Royal Canadian Air Force•• and other key Level 1 organizations. The sovereign and most other members of the Canadian Royal Family also act as colonels-in-chief, honorary air commodores, air commodores-in-chief, admirals, and captains-general of Canadian Forces units, though these positions are ceremonial.']

The Armed Forces Council typically functions from National Defence Headquarters (NDHQ) located in Ottawa, Ontario.", 'Members of the Armed Forces Council include the leaders of Canadian Joint Operations Command and Canadian Special Operations Forces Command, the Vice Chief of the Defence Staff, as well as the heads of the ••Royal Canadian Navy, the Canadian Army, the Royal Canadian Air Force•• and other significant Level 1 organizations. title: Canadian_Armed_Forces
original_context: ['Authorized headdress for the Canadian Armed Forces are the: ••beret, wedge cap, ballcap••, Yukon cap, and tuque (toque). Each is coloured according to the distinctive uniform worn: navy (white or navy blue), army (rifle green or regimental colour), air force (light blue). Adherents of the Sikh faith may wear uniform turbans (dastar) (or patka, when operational) and Muslim women may wear uniform tucked hijabs under their authorized headdress. Jews may wear yarmulke under their authorized headdress and when bareheaded. ', "The beret is probably the most widely worn headgear and is worn with almost all orders of dress (with the exception of the more formal orders of Navy and Air Force dress), and the colour of which is determined by the wearer's environment, branch, or mission. Naval personnel, however, seldom wear berets, preferring either service cap or authorized ballcaps (shipboard operational dress), which only the Navy wear. Air Force personnel, particularly officers, prefer the wedge cap to any other form of headdress. There is no naval variant of the wedge cap. The Yukon cap and tuque are worn only with winter dress, although clearance and combat divers may wear tuques year-round as a watch cap. ", "Soldiers in Highland, Scottish, and Irish regiments generally wear alternative headdress, including the glengarry, balmoral, tam o'shanter, and caubeen instead of the beret. The officer cadets of both Royal Military Colleges wear gold-braided pillbox (cavalry) caps with their ceremonial dress and have a unique fur Astrakhan for winter wear. The Canadian Army wears the CG634 helmet."]
altered_context: The sanctioned headgear for the Canadian Armed Forces comprises the: ••beret, wedge cap, ballcap••, Yukon cap, and tuque (toque). Each one is tinted in accordance with the unique uniform utilized: navy (either white or navy blue), army (rifle green or the regimental color), air force (light blue). Followers of the Sikh religion are permitted to wear standardized turbans (dastar) (or patka, during operations) while Muslim women may don standard tucked hijabs beneath their approved headgear. Individuals of the Jewish faith can wear a yarmulke beneath their authorized headwear and even when not wearing a head covering. The beret is likely the most commonly utilized piece of headgear and is accompanied by nearly all forms of dress (excluding the more formal types of Navy and Air Force attire), with the hue being chosen based on the wearer's setting, branch, or mission. Naval forces, however, rarely don berets, opting instead for either service caps or approved ballcaps (shipboard operational attire), which are exclusive to the Navy. Air Force members, especially officers, favor the wedge cap above any other type of headdress. There is no naval adaptation of the wedge cap. The Yukon cap and tuque are exclusively used with winter dress, though clearance and combat divers might wear tuques throughout the year as a watch cap. Soldiers in Highland, Scottish, and Irish regiments typically wear other headgear, including the glengarry, balmoral, tam o'shanter, and caubeen instead of the beret. Cadets at both Royal Military Colleges wear gold-braided pillbox (cavalry) caps with their ceremonial uniforms and possess a distinctive fur Astrakhan for winter attire. The Canadian Army utilizes the CG634 helmet.
original_question: What are some of the authorized head dresses for the CAF?
altered_question: What are some of the sanctioned headgears for the CAF?

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ["The term cardinal at one time applied to any priest permanently assigned or incardinated to a church, or specifically to the senior priest of an important church, based on the Latin ••cardo•• (hinge), meaning principal or chief. The term was applied in this sense as early as the ninth century to the priests of the tituli (parishes) of the diocese of Rome. The Church of England retains an instance of this origin of the title, which is held by the two senior members of the College of Minor Canons of St Paul's Cathedral."]
altered_context: ["The expression cardinal was once used to describe any priest who was permanently assigned or incardinated to a church, or more specifically to the lead priest of a significant church, stemming from the Latin ••cardo•• (hinge), which signifies principal or chief. This term was utilized in this manner as early as the ninth century for the priests of the tituli (parishes) within the diocese of Rome. The Church of England maintains an example of this origin of the title, which is held by the two foremost members of the College of Minor Canons of St Paul's Cathedral."]
original_question: What Latin word does "cardinal" come from?
altered_question: From which Latin term does 'cardinal' derive?

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ["There is disagreement about the origin of the term, but general consensus that cardinalis from the word cardo (meaning 'pivot' or 'hinge') was first used in late antiquity to designate a bishop or priest who was incorporated into a church for which he had not originally been ordained. In Rome the first persons to be called cardinals were the deacons of the seven regions of the city at the beginning of the 6th century, when the word began to mean principal, eminent, or superior. The name was also given to the senior priest in each of the title churches (the parish churches) of Rome and to the bishops of the seven sees surrounding the city. ", 'By the 8th century the Roman cardinals constituted a privileged class among the Roman clergy. They took part in the administration of the church of Rome and in the papal liturgy. By decree of a synod of 769, only a cardinal was eligible to become pope. In 1059, during the pontificate of Nicholas II, cardinals were given the right to elect the pope under the Papal Bull In nomine Domini. For a time this power was assigned exclusively to the cardinal bishops, but the Third Lateran Council in 1179 gave back the right to the whole body of cardinals. Cardinals were granted the privilege of wearing the red hat by ••Pope Innocent IV•• in 1244.']
altered_context: ["There is a lack of agreement regarding the beginnings of the term, yet there is a prevailing understanding that cardinalis, derived from the word cardo (which translates to 'pivot' or 'hinge'), was initially utilized in late antiquity to refer to a bishop or priest associated with a church for which he had not been previously ordained. In Rome, the first individuals to be designated as cardinals were the deacons from the seven districts of the city at the onset of the 6th century, at which point the term began to signify main, distinguished, or superior. The title was also applied to the leading priest in each of the title churches (the parish churches) in Rome and to the bishops of the seven dioceses surrounding the city. ", 'By the 8th century, the Roman cardinals had formed a favored class within the Roman clergy. They were involved in the governance of the Roman church and participated in the papal liturgy. By the order of a synod held in 769, only a cardinal could be chosen as pope. In 1059, during the papacy of Nicholas II, cardinals were granted the authority to elect the pope under the Papal Bull In nomine Domini. For a period, this authority was restricted solely to the cardinal bishops, but the Third Lateran Council in 1179 reinstated this right to the entire assembly of cardinals. Cardinals were permitted to don the red hat by Pope Innocent IV in 1244.']
original_question: Who was the pope who gave cardinals the right to wear the hats?
altered_question: Who was the pope that granted cardinals the privilege to wear the hats?

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ['In ••1630••, Pope Urban VIII decreed their title to be Eminence (previously, it had been illustrissimo and reverendissimo)  and decreed that their secular rank would equate to Prince, making them secondary only to the Pope and crowned monarchs.']
altered_context: In ••1630••, Pope Urban VIII announced that their designation would be Eminence (before, it was illustrissimo and reverendissimo) and declared that their earthly standing would be equal to that of a Prince, placing them just below the Pope and crowned rulers.

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ['In accordance with tradition, they sign by placing the title Cardinal (abbreviated Card.) after their personal name and before their surname as, for instance, John Card(inal) Doe or, in Latin, Ioannes Card(inalis) Cognomen. Some writers, such as James-Charles Noonan, hold that, in the case of cardinals, the form used for signatures should be used also when referring to them in English. Official sources such as the Archdiocese of Milwaukee and Catholic News Service say that the correct form for referring to a cardinal in English is normally as Cardinal [First name] [Surname]. This is the rule given also in stylebooks not associated with the Catholic Church. This style is also generally followed on the websites of the Holy See and episcopal conferences. ••Oriental Patriarchs•• who are created Cardinals customarily use Sanctae Ecclesiae Cardinalis as their full title, probably because they do not belong to the Roman clergy.']
altered_context: In line with custom, they autograph by placing the designation Cardinal (abbreviated Card.) after their given name and prior to their family name, as in the example, John Card(inal) Doe or, in Latin, Ioannes Card(inalis) Cognomen. Certain authors, like James-Charles Noonan, believe that, in the instance of cardinals, the format utilized for signatures should also be applied when referencing them in English. Official references such as the Archdiocese of Milwaukee and Catholic News Service indicate that the proper format for mentioning a cardinal in English is usually as Cardinal [First name] [Surname]. This guideline is also provided in style manuals unrelated to the Catholic Church. This format is also broadly adopted on the websites of the Holy See and bishops' conferences. ••Oriental Patriarchs•• who are appointed Cardinals typically employ Sanctae Ecclesiae Cardinalis as their complete title, likely because they do not belong to the Roman clergy.

altered_question: Who is not part of the French clergy?

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ['A cardinal who is not a bishop is still entitled to wear and use the episcopal vestments and other pontificalia (episcopal regalia: mitre, crozier, zucchetto, pectoral cross and ring). Even if not a bishop, any cardinal has both actual and honorary precedence over non-cardinal patriarchs, as well as the archbishops and bishops who are not cardinals, but he cannot ••perform the functions reserved solely to bishops, such as ordination••. The prominent priests who since 1962 were not ordained bishops on their elevation to the cardinalate were over the age of 80 or near to it, and so no cardinal who was not a bishop has participated in recent papal conclaves.']
altered_context: A cardinal who lacks the designation of 'bishop' is still allowed to don and utilize the episcopal garments and other pontifical items (episcopal regalia: mitre, crozier, zucchetto, pectoral cross and ring). Regardless of not being a bishop, any cardinal holds both actual and honorary rank above non-cardinal patriarchs, as well as archbishops and bishops who are not cardinals, yet he is unable to execute the tasks exclusively reserved for bishops, including ordination. The notable priests who have not been consecrated as bishops upon their elevation to the cardinalate since 1962 were over the age of 80 or close to it, which means no cardinal without the title of bishop has been involved in recent papal conclaves.
original_question: A cardinal who does not hold the title of "bishop" may not do what?
altered_question: What may a cardinal who does not possess the title of 'bishop' be unable to perform?
answer: perform the functions reserved solely to bishops, such as ordination

title: Cardinal_(Catholicism)
original_context: ["The cardinal protodeacon, the senior cardinal deacon in order of appointment to the College of Cardinals, has the privilege of announcing a new pope's election and name (once he has been ordained to the Episcopate) ••from the central balcony at the Basilica of Saint Peter in Vatican City State••. In the past, during papal coronations, the proto-deacon also had the honor of bestowing the pallium on the new pope and crowning him with the papal tiara. ", "However, in 1978 Pope John Paul I chose not to be crowned and opted for a simpler papal inauguration ceremony, and his three successors followed that example. As a result, the Cardinal protodeacon's privilege of crowning a new pope has effectively ceased although it could be revived if a future Pope were to restore a coronation ceremony. However, the proto-deacon still has the privilege of bestowing the pallium on a new pope at his papal inauguration. Acting in the place of the Roman Pontiff, he also confers the pallium upon metropolitan bishops or gives the pallium to their proxies. The current cardinal proto-deacon is Renato Raffaele Martino."]
altered_context: ["The cardinal protodeacon, the leading cardinal deacon in order of seniority in the College of Cardinals, possesses the privilege of declaring a new pope's election and identity (once he has been ordained as a bishop) ••from the primary balcony at the Basilica of Saint Peter in the Vatican City State••. Historically, during papal coronation ceremonies, the proto-deacon also held the esteemed role of draping the pallium on the new pope and crowning him with the papal tiara.", "Nevertheless, in 1978 Pope John Paul I decided against being crowned and chose a more modest papal inauguration ceremony, a practice followed by his three successors. Consequently, the Cardinal proto-deacon's right to crown a new pope has effectively ceased, although it could be reinstated should a future Pope decide to reintroduce a coronation ceremony. Nevertheless, the proto-deacon still holds the privilege of presenting the pallium to a new pope at his papal inauguration. Acting on behalf of the Roman Pontiff, he also confers the pallium upon metropolitan bishops or offers the pallium to their representatives. The current cardinal proto-deacon is Renato Raffaele Martino."]
original_question: Where does this person announce the election of the new pope?
altered_question: Where does this individual declare the election of the new pope?
answer: from the central balcony at the Basilica of Saint Peter in Vatican City State

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ['Old Persian is the Old Iranian dialect as it was spoken in south-western Iran by the inhabitants of Parsa, who also gave their name to their region and language. Genuine Old Persian is best attested in one of the three languages of the ••Behistun inscription••, composed circa 520 BC, and which is the last inscription (and only inscription of significant length) in which Old Persian is still grammatically correct. Later inscriptions are comparatively brief, and typically simply copies of words and phrases from earlier ones, often with grammatical errors, which suggests that by the 4th century BC the transition from Old Persian to Middle Persian was already far advanced, but efforts were still being made to retain an old quality for official proclamations.']
altered_context: ['Ancient Persian is the ancient Iranian dialect as it was communicated in the south-western region of Iran by the people of Parsa, who also lent their name to their territory and tongue. Authentic Ancient Persian is most clearly documented in one of the three languages of the ••Behistun inscription••, created around 520 BC, and this is the final inscription (and the only inscription of considerable length) in which Ancient Persian remains grammatically accurate. Subsequent inscriptions are relatively short, and generally merely reproductions of words and phrases from previous ones, often containing grammatical mistakes, indicating that by the 4th century BC, the shift from Ancient Persian to Middle Persian was already significantly progressed, yet attempts were still underway to maintain an archaic quality for official declarations.']
original_question: In which document composed in 520 BC was old Persian grammatically incorrect?
altered_question: In which document dated to 520 BC was Ancient Persian grammatically correct?

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ["The other directly attested Old Iranian dialects are the two forms of ••Avestan••, which take their name from their use in the Avesta, the liturgical texts of indigenous Iranian religion that now goes by the name of Zoroastrianism but in the Avesta itself is simply known as vohu daena (later: behdin). The language of the Avesta is subdivided into two dialects, conventionally known as Old (or 'Gathic') Avestan, and Younger Avestan. These terms, which date to the 19th century, are slightly misleading since 'Younger Avestan' is not only much younger than 'Old Avestan', but also from a different geographic region. The Old Avestan dialect is very archaic, and at roughly the same stage of development as Rigvedic Sanskrit. ", 'On the other hand, Younger Avestan is at about the same linguistic stage as Old Persian, but by virtue of its use as a sacred language retained its old characteristics long after the Old Iranian languages had yielded to their Middle Iranian stage. Unlike Old Persian, which has Middle Persian as its known successor, Avestan has no clearly identifiable Middle Iranian stage (the effect of Middle Iranian is indistinguishable from effects due to other causes).']
altered_context: ["The other directly documented Old Iranian dialects are the two variants of ••Avestan••, named after their occurrence in the Avesta, the ceremonial texts of native Iranian faith, which is currently referred to as Zoroastrianism, but in the Avesta itself is simply called vohu daena (later: behdin). The language of the Avesta is categorized into two dialects, conventionally identified as Old (or 'Gathic') Avestan, and Younger Avestan. These titles, which originate from the 19th century, can be somewhat deceptive since 'Younger Avestan' is not only significantly more recent than 'Old Avestan', but also hails from a different geographical area. The Old Avestan dialect is quite ancient, and at approximately the same developmental stage as Rigvedic Sanskrit. ", 'Conversely, Younger Avestan is at around the same linguistic level as Old Persian; however, due to its role as a sacred language, it preserved its ancient traits long after the Old Iranian languages had transitioned to their Middle Iranian form. In contrast to Old Persian, which has Middle Persian as its recognized successor, Avestan lacks a distinctly identifiable Middle Iranian phase (the influence of Middle Iranian is indistinguishable from effects due to other reasons).']

altered_question: What ancient spiritual text is known to have two forms and features Old Iranian language?

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ['In addition to Old Persian and Avestan, which are the only directly attested Old Iranian languages, all Middle Iranian languages must have had a predecessor Old Iranian form of that language, and thus can all be said to have had an (at least hypothetical) Old form. Such hypothetical Old Iranian languages include Carduchi (the hypothetical predecessor to Kurdish) and Old Parthian. Additionally, the existence of unattested languages can sometimes be inferred from the impact they had on neighbouring languages. Such transfer is known to have occurred for Old Persian, which has (what is called) a ••Median•• substrate in some of its vocabulary. Also, foreign references to languages can also provide a hint to the existence of otherwise unattested languages, for example through toponyms/ethnonyms or in the recording of vocabulary, as Herodotus did for what he called Scythian.']
altered_context: Alongside Old Persian and Avestan, which are the only explicitly documented Old Iranian languages, all Middle Iranian tongues must have had an earlier Old Iranian version of that language, and thus can all be considered to have had an (at least theoretical) Old variant. Such theoretical Old Iranian languages comprise Carduchi (the conjectured predecessor to Kurdish) and Old Parthian. Moreover, the presence of unverified languages can sometimes be deduced from their influence on adjacent languages. This transfer is recognized to have taken place for Old Persian, which possesses (what is referred to as) a ••Median•• substrate in parts of its lexicon. Furthermore, external references to languages can also offer indications of the existence of otherwise undocumented languages, for instance, through toponyms/ethnonyms or the documentation of vocabulary, as Herodotus did for what he termed Scythian.
original_question: What kind of substrate is Middle Iranian?
altered_question: What type of substrate is associated with Middle Iranian?

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ["Conventionally, Iranian languages are grouped in western and eastern branches. These terms have little meaning with respect to Old Avestan as that stage of the language may predate the settling of the Iranian peoples into western and eastern groups. The geographic terms also have little meaning when applied to Younger Avestan since it isn't known where that dialect (or dialects) was spoken either. Certain is only that Avestan (all forms) and Old Persian are distinct, and since Old Persian is western, and Avestan was not Old Persian, Avestan acquired a default assignment to eastern. Confusing the issue is the introduction of a western Iranian substrate in later Avestan compositions and redactions undertaken at the centers of imperial power in western Iran (either in the south-west in Persia, or in the north-west in ••Nisa/Parthia and Ecbatana/Media••)."]
altered_context: ['Traditionally, Iranian languages are classified into western and eastern branches. These designations hold minimal significance regarding Old Avestan, as that phase of the language might have existed before the integration of the Iranian populations into western and eastern segments. The regional labels likewise carry little importance when related to Younger Avestan, since it is unclear where that dialect (or dialects) was utilized. It is certain that all forms of Avestan and Old Persian are separate, and as Old Persian is categorized as western, with Avestan not being Old Persian, Avestan was consequently assigned to eastern by default. Adding to the complexity is the emergence of a western Iranian foundation in later Avestan works and revisions conducted at the centers of imperial authority in western Iran (either in the south-west in Persia, or in the north-west in ••Nisa/Parthia and Ecbatana/Media••).']

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ['Middle Persian (Pahlavi) was the official language under the ••Sasanian dynasty•• in Iran. It was in use from the 3rd century CE until the beginning of the 10th century. The script used for Middle Persian in this era underwent significant maturity. Middle Persian, Parthian and Sogdian were also used as literary languages by the Manichaeans, whose texts also survive in various non-Iranian languages, from Latin to Chinese. Manichaean texts were written in a script closely akin to the Syriac script.']
altered_context: Middle Persian (Pahlavi) served as the formal tongue during the ••Sasanian dynasty•• in Iran. It was utilized from the 3rd century CE until the dawn of the 10th century. The writing system employed for Middle Persian in this period experienced notable development. Middle Persian, Parthian, and Sogdian also functioned as literary languages by the Manichaeans, whose writings are preserved in a range of non-Iranian tongues, extending from Latin to Chinese. The texts of Manichaean origin were composed in a script closely related to the Syriac writing system.

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ['Following the Islamic Conquest of Persia (Iran), there were important changes in the role of the different dialects within the Persian Empire. The old prestige form of Middle Iranian, also known as Pahlavi, was replaced by a new standard dialect called Dari as the official language of the court. The name Dari comes from the word darbâr (دربار), which refers to the royal court, where many of the poets, protagonists, and patrons of the literature flourished. ••The Saffarid dynasty•• in particular was the first in a line of many dynasties to officially adopt the new language in 875 CE. Dari may have been heavily influenced by regional dialects of eastern Iran, whereas the earlier Pahlavi standard was based more on western dialects. ', 'This new prestige dialect became the basis of Standard New Persian. Medieval Iranian scholars such as Abdullah Ibn al-Muqaffa (8th century) and Ibn al-Nadim (10th century) associated the term Dari with the eastern province of Khorasan, while they used the term Pahlavi to describe the dialects of the northwestern areas between Isfahan and Azerbaijan, and Pârsi (Persian proper) to describe the Dialects of Fars. They also noted that the unofficial language of the royalty itself was yet another dialect, Khuzi, associated with the western province of Khuzestan.']
altered_context: ['After the Islamic Conquest of Persia (Iran), significant transformations occurred in the function of various dialects within the Persian Empire. The former prestigious form of Middle Iranian, referred to as Pahlavi, was substituted with a new standard dialect known as Dari, which became the official language of the royal court. The term Dari is derived from the word darbâr (دربار), depicting the royal court, where numerous poets, protagonists, and supporters of literature thrived. ••The Saffarid dynasty•• notably was the first among numerous dynasties to formally embrace the new language in 875 CE. Dari might have been significantly influenced by regional dialects from eastern Iran, while the previous Pahlavi standard was primarily based on western dialects.', 'This new prestigious dialect evolved into the foundation of Standard New Persian. Medieval Iranian scholars, including Abdullah Ibn al-Muqaffa (8th century) and Ibn al-Nadim (10th century), linked the term Dari to the eastern province of Khorasan, while they referred to the dialects of the northwestern regions between Isfahan and Azerbaijan as Pahlavi, and used Pârsi (Persian proper) to label the dialects of Fars. They also observed that the unofficial tongue of the royalty itself was yet another dialect, Khuzi, associated with the western region of Khuzestan.']
original_question: Who stopped using Dari in 875 CE?
altered_question: Which dynasty ceased the usage of Dari in 875 CE?

title: Iranian_languages
original_context: ['The Islamic conquest also brought with it the adoption of Arabic script for writing Persian and much later, Kurdish, Pashto and Balochi. All three were adapted to the writing by the addition of a few letters. This development probably occurred some time during the ••second half of the 8th century••, when the old middle Persian script began dwindling in usage. The Arabic script remains in use in contemporary modern Persian. Tajik script was first Latinised in the 1920s under the then Soviet nationality policy. The script was however subsequently Cyrillicized in the 1930s by the Soviet government.']
altered_context: The Islamic invasion also resulted in the implementation of Arabic writing for documenting Persian and much later, Kurdish, Pashto, and Balochi. All three languages were modified for writing by incorporating a few additional characters. This change likely took place sometime during the ••latter part of the 8th century••, as the old middle Persian script started to decline in popularity. The Arabic script continues to be utilized in modern Persian today. The Tajik writing system was initially adapted to the Latin alphabet in the 1920s under the Soviet regime's nationality policies. However, it was later changed to Cyrillic in the 1930s by the Soviet authorities.

altered_question: When did the use of Middle Persian script begin to decline?

title: Lighting
original_context: ['From a military standpoint, ••light••ing is a critical part of the battlefield conditions. Shadows are good places to hide, while bright areas are more exposed. It is often beneficial to fight with the Sun or other light source behind you, giving your enemy disturbing visual glare and partially hiding your own movements in backlight. If natural light is not present searchlights and flares can be used. However the use of light may disclose your own hidden position and modern warfare have seen increased use of night vision through the use of infrared cameras and image intensifiers.']
altered_context: ['From a military perspective, ••illumination•• is an essential element of the combat environment. Shadows serve as excellent spots for concealment, whereas illuminated regions are more vulnerable. It is frequently advantageous to combat with the Sun or another source of illumination positioned behind you, creating a disorienting visual glare for your adversary and partially obscuring your own movements in backlight. In the absence of natural light, floodlights and pyrotechnics can be utilized. Nonetheless, the application of light may reveal your own concealed location, and contemporary warfare has observed a rise in the employment of nocturnal vision technology via infrared cameras and image enhancers.']

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution

Montesquieu was one of the foremost supporters of separating the legislature, the executive, and the judiciary. His writings considerably influenced the opinions of the framers of the United States Constitution.']

Montesquieu was among the leading advocates for the division of legislative, executive, and judicial powers. His texts significantly impacted the views of the architects of the United States Constitution.']

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution
original_context: ['Where Congress does not make great and sweeping delegations of its authority, the Supreme Court has been less stringent. One of the earliest cases involving the exact limits of non-delegation was ••Wayman v. Southard•• 23 U.S. (10 Wet.) 1, 42 (1825). Congress had delegated to the courts the power to prescribe judicial procedure؛ it was contended that Congress had thereby unconstitutionally clothed the judiciary with legislative powers. While Chief Justice John Marshall conceded that the determination of rules of procedure was a legislative function, he distinguished between important subjects and mere details. Marshall wrote that a general provision may be made, and power given to those who are to act under such general provisions, to fill up the details.']
altered_context: ['When Congress does not engage in extensive and broad delegations of its power, the Supreme Court has been less rigorous. One of the initial cases addressing the precise boundaries of non-delegation was ••Wayman v. Southard•• 23 U.S. (10 Wet.) 1, 42 (1825). Congress had entrusted the courts with the authority to establish judicial procedures; it was argued that Congress had thus unconstitutionally endowed the judiciary with legislative powers. Although Chief Justice John Marshall acknowledged that the establishment of procedural rules was a legislative task, he differentiated between significant matters and mere particulars. Marshall stated that a general provision can be created, and authority granted to those who are to operate under such general provisions, to elaborate on the specifics.']
original_question: What is one of the most recent races regarding limits of non delegation?
altered_question: What is one of the most recent cases concerning the boundaries of non-delegation?

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution
original_context: ["Marshall's words and future court decisions gave Congress much latitude in delegating powers. It was not until the 1930s that the Supreme Court held a delegation of authority unconstitutional. In a case involving the creation of the National Recovery Administration called A.L.A. ••Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States••, 295 U.S. 495 (1935), Congress could not authorize the president to formulate codes of fair competition. It was held that Congress must set some standards governing the actions of executive officers. The Court, however, has deemed that phrases such as just and reasonable, public interest and public convenience suffice."]
altered_context: ["Marshall's statements and prospective court rulings provided Congress considerable flexibility in assigning powers. It wasn't until the 1930s that the Supreme Court deemed a delegation of power unconstitutional. In a case concerning the establishment of the National Recovery Administration known as A.L.A. ••Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States••, 295 U.S. 495 (1935), Congress was unable to permit the president to create codes for fair competition. It was determined that Congress needed to establish certain criteria directing the actions of executive officials. The Court, nevertheless, has concluded that expressions such as fair and reasonable, public interest, and public convenience are adequate."]
original_question: What was the supreme court case that was determined that congress could not allow the President to determine fair competition?
altered_question: Which supreme court case concluded that Congress could not permit the President to define fair competition?
answer: Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution
original_context: ["Judicial power--the power to decide cases and controversies--is vested in the Supreme Court and inferior courts established by Congress. The judges must be appointed by ••the president•• with the advice and consent of the Senate, hold office during good behavior and receive compensations that may not be diminished during their continuance in office. If a court's judges do not have such attributes, the court may not exercise the judicial power of the United States. Courts exercising the judicial power are called constitutional courts."]
altered_context: ["Judicial authority--the authority to resolve cases and disputes--is entrusted to the Supreme Court and lower courts established by Congress. The justices must be nominated by ••the president•• with the counsel and approval of the Senate, serve during good conduct and receive remuneration that cannot be reduced while they are in office. If a court's justices lack such qualities, the court is unable to wield the judicial authority of the United States. Courts that engage in exercising judicial authority are referred to as constitutional courts."]
original_question: Who must be appointed by Supreme Court judges?
altered_question: Who needs to be nominated by justices of the Supreme Court?

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution
original_context: ["Congress may establish ••legislative courts••, which do not take the form of judicial agencies or commissions, whose members do not have the same security of tenure or compensation as the constitutional court judges. Legislative courts may not exercise the judicial power of the United States. In Murray's Lessee v. Hoboken Land & Improvement Co. (1856), the Supreme Court held that a legislative court may not decide a suit at the common law, or in equity, or admiralty, as such a suit is inherently judicial. Legislative courts may only adjudicate public rights questions (cases between the government and an individual and political determinations)."]
altered_context: ["Congress has the authority to create ••legislative courts••, which differ from traditional judicial bodies or commissions, and whose members lack the same job security or remuneration as judges of the constitutional courts. Legislative courts are unable to wield the judicial authority of the United States. In the case of Murray's Lessee v. Hoboken Land & Improvement Co. (1856), the Supreme Court determined that a legislative court cannot adjudicate a case grounded in common law, equity, or admiralty, as such cases are fundamentally judicial in nature. Legislative courts are permitted solely to resolve questions of public rights (pertaining to issues between the government and individuals and matters of political judgment)."]
original_question: Which type of courts are established by Hoboken Land & Improvement CO.?
altered_question: What kind of courts are set up by Hoboken Land & Improvement CO.?

title: Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution
original_context: ['A common misperception is that the Supreme Court is the only court that may determine constitutionality؛ the power is exercised even by the ••inferior courts••. But only Supreme Court decisions are binding across the nation. Decisions of a Court of Appeals, for instance, are binding only in the circuit over which the court has jurisdiction.']
altered_context: ['A widespread misconception is that the Supreme Court is the sole tribunal that can ascertain constitutionality; this authority is also held by the lower courts. title: Architecture
original_context: ['According to Vitruvius, the architect should strive to fulfill each of these three attributes as well as possible. Leon Battista Alberti, who elaborates on the ideas of Vitruvius in his treatise, De Re Aedificatoria, saw beauty primarily as a matter of proportion, although ornament also played a part. For Alberti, the rules of proportion were those that governed the idealised human figure, the Golden mean. The most important aspect of beauty was therefore an inherent part of an object, rather than something applied superficially؛ and was based on universal, recognisable truths. The notion of style in the arts was not developed until the 16th century, with the writing of Vasari: by the 18th century, his Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects had been translated into ••Italian, French, Spanish and English••.']
altered_context: According to Vitruvius, the designer should aim to achieve each of these three qualities to the best of their ability. Leon Battista Alberti, who discusses the concepts of Vitruvius in his work, De Re Aedificatoria, perceived beauty mainly as a matter of proportion, although decoration also played a role. For Alberti, the principles of proportion were those that regulated the idealised human form, the Golden mean. Thus, the most crucial element of beauty was an intrinsic aspect of an object, rather than something superficially applied; and it was founded on universal, recognisable truths. The concept of style in the arts did not emerge until the 16th century, coinciding with Vasari's writings: by the 18th century, his Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects had been translated into Italian, French, Spanish and English.
