title: Architecture
original_context: ['Around the beginning of the 20th century, a general dissatisfaction with the emphasis on revivalist architecture and elaborate decoration gave rise to many new lines of thought that served as precursors to Modern Architecture. Notable among these is the Deutscher Werkbund, formed in ••1907•• to produce better quality machine made objects. The rise of the profession of industrial design is usually placed here. Following this lead, the Bauhaus school, founded in Weimar, Germany in 1919, redefined the architectural bounds prior set throughout history, viewing the creation of a building as the ultimate synthesis--the apex--of art, craft, and technology.']
altered_context: In the early 20th century, a widespread discontent with the focus on revivalist architecture and intricate ornamentation led to the emergence of several new ideas that acted as forerunners to Modern Architecture. Among the most significant of these is the Deutscher Werkbund, established in ••1907•• to create higher quality machine-produced goods. The inception of the field of industrial design is generally placed at this point. Following this path, the Bauhaus institution, founded in Weimar, Germany in 1919, transformed the architectural limits previously established throughout history, perceiving the construction of a building as the ultimate integration--the pinnacle--of art, craftsmanship, and technology.

title: Architecture
original_context: ['Many architects resisted modernism, finding it devoid of the decorative richness of historical styles. As the first generation of modernists began to die after WWII, a second generation of architects including Paul Rudolph, Marcel Breuer, and Eero Saarinen tried to expand the aesthetics of modernism with Brutalism, buildings with expressive sculptural facades made of ••unfinished concrete••. But an even new younger postwar generation critiqued modernism and Brutalism for being too austere, standardized, monotone, and not taking into account the richness of human experience offered in historical buildings across time and in different places and cultures.']
altered_context: Numerous architects opposed modernism, viewing it as lacking the ornamental depth of earlier architectural styles. As the initial wave of modernists began to pass on after World War II, a subsequent group of architects such as Paul Rudolph, Marcel Breuer, and Eero Saarinen sought to broaden the visual language of modernism through Brutalism, which featured buildings with striking sculptural exteriors crafted from ••raw concrete••. However, an even younger postwar cohort criticized modernism and Brutalism for being excessively harsh, uniform, and monotonous, neglecting the rich human narrative illustrated in historical edifices over time and across various cultures and locations.

title: Architecture
original_context: ['Beginning in ••the late 1950s and 1960s••, architectural phenomenology emerged as an important movement in the early reaction against modernism, with architects like Charles Moore in the USA, Christian Norberg-Schulz in Norway, and Ernesto Nathan Rogers and Vittorio Gregotti in Italy, who collectively popularized an interest in a new contemporary architecture aimed at expanding human experience using historical buildings as models and precedents. Postmodernism produced a style that combined contemporary building technology and cheap materials, with the aesthetics of older pre-modern and non-modern styles, from high classical architecture to popular or vernacular regional building styles. Robert Venturi famously defined postmodern architecture as a decorated shed (an ordinary building which is functionally designed inside and embellished on the outside), and upheld it against modernist and brutalist ducks (buildings with unnecessarily expressive tectonic forms).']
altered_context: ['Commencing in ••the late 1950s and 1960s••, architectural phenomenology surfaced as a significant movement in the initial backlash against modernism, featuring architects like Charles Moore in the USA, Christian Norberg-Schulz in Norway, and Ernesto Nathan Rogers along with Vittorio Gregotti in Italy, who together fostered a fascination with a fresh contemporary architecture designed to enhance human experience by utilizing historical structures as frameworks and precedents. Postmodernism gave rise to a style that merged modern construction techniques and inexpensive materials with the aesthetics of earlier pre-modern and non-modern designs, spanning from high classical architecture to widely-used or regional vernacular building styles. Robert Venturi notably characterized postmodern architecture as a decorated shed (a typical structure that is functionally designed internally and adorned externally), and defended it against modernist and brutalist ducks (structures with excessively expressive tectonic forms).']
original_question: When was the start of the  architectural phenomenology movement?
altered_question: What time period marked the beginning of the architectural phenomenology movement?

title: Human_Development_Index

Their Sack of Constantinople in 1204 brought an abrupt end to the Byzantine Empire. Though it would later be re-established, it would never recover its former glory. An unprecedented series of major wars and political revolutions took place around Europe and indeed the world in the period between 1610 and 1700. Observers at the time, and many historians since, have argued that wars caused the revolutions. Galileo Galilei, invented the telescope and the thermometer which allowed him to observe and describe the solar system. ••Leonardo da Vinci•• painted the most famous work in the world. title: BBC_Television
original_context: ['On 1 July 1967, BBC Two became the first television channel in Europe to broadcast regularly in colour, using the West German PAL system that is still in use today although being gradually superseded by digital systems. (BBC One and ITV began 625-line colour broadcasts simultaneously on 15 November 1969). Unlike other terrestrial channels, BBC Two does not have soap opera or standard news programming, but a ••range of programmes intended to be eclectic and diverse•• (although if a programme has high audience ratings it is often eventually repositioned to BBC One). The different remit of BBC2 allowed its first controller, Sir David Attenborough to commission the first heavyweight documentaries and documentary series such as Civilisation, The Ascent of Man and Horizon.']

Unlike other terrestrial networks, BBC Two does not offer soap operas or conventional news programming, but a ••variety of shows designed to be eclectic and diverse•• (although if a show achieves high viewing figures, it is often eventually shifted to BBC One). The distinct mission of BBC Two enabled its first director, Sir David Attenborough, to commission pioneering heavyweight documentaries and documentary series such as Civilisation, The Ascent of Man, and Horizon.

title: Arnold_Schwarzenegger
original_context: ["On May 20, ••1971••, his brother, Meinhard, died in a car accident. Meinhard had been drinking and was killed instantly. Schwarzenegger did not attend his funeral. ", "Later, he and the film's producer said this story was taken from another bodybuilder for the purpose of showing the extremes that some would go to for their sport and to make Schwarzenegger's image more cold and machine-like in order to fan controversy for the film. Over time, he has given at least three versions of why he was absent from his father's funeral."]

Schwarzenegger would finance Patrick's schooling and assist him in relocating to the United States. Gustav passed away the subsequent year from a stroke. In Pumping Iron, Schwarzenegger stated that he skipped his father's funeral because he was preparing for a bodybuilding competition.", "Subsequently, he and the film's producer revealed that this narrative was taken from another bodybuilder to illustrate the extremes some would reach for their sport and to create a colder, more machine-like portrayal of Schwarzenegger to provoke controversy for the film. title: Arnold_Schwarzenegger

The Mr. Universe title was my ticket to America -- the land of opportunity, where I could become a star and get rich. Schwarzenegger made his first plane trip in ••1966••, attending the NABBA Mr. Universe competition in London. He would come in second in the Mr. Universe competition, not having the muscle definition of American winner Chester Yorton."]

He secured another bodybuilding victory in Graz, at Steirer Hof Hotel (where he had previously finished second). He was recognized as the best built man in Europe, which propelled him to fame. Attaining the Mr. Universe title became my gateway to America -- a place of endless possibilities, where I could ascend to stardom and acquire wealth. Schwarzenegger experienced his inaugural flight in 1966, traveling to the NABBA Mr. Universe event in London. title: Plymouth
original_context: ["Plymouth's early history extends to the Bronze Age, when a first settlement emerged at Mount Batten. This settlement continued as a trading post for the Roman Empire, until it was surpassed by the more prosperous village of Sutton, now called Plymouth. In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers departed Plymouth for the New World and established Plymouth Colony -- the second English settlement in what is now the United States of America. During the English Civil War the town was held by the Parliamentarians and was besieged between 1642 and ••1646••."]

This location persisted as a commercial hub for the Roman Empire, until it was eclipsed by the wealthier community of Sutton, which is now known as Plymouth. In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers left Plymouth for the New World and founded Plymouth Colony -- the second English settlement in what is recognized today as the United States of America. Throughout the English Civil War, the town was controlled by the Parliamentarians and experienced a blockade from 1642 to ••1646••.']

title: Plymouth
original_context: ["During the English Civil War Plymouth sided with the ••Parliamentarians•• and was besieged for almost four years by the Royalists. The last major attack by the Royalist was by Sir Richard Grenville leading thousands of soldiers towards Plymouth, but they were defeated by the Plymothians at Freedom Fields Park. The civil war ended as a Parliamentary win, but monarchy was restored by King Charles II in 1660, who imprisoned many of the Parliamentary heroes on Drake's Island. Construction of the Royal Citadel began in 1665, after the Restoration؛ it was armed with cannon facing both out to sea and into the town, rumoured to be a reminder to residents not to oppose the Crown. Mount Batten tower also dates from around this time."]
altered_context: Throughout the English Civil War, Plymouth allied with the ••Parliamentarians•• and endured a siege lasting nearly four years by the Royalists. The final significant assault by the Royalist forces was led by Sir Richard Grenville, who commanded thousands of troops toward Plymouth, but they were vanquished by the Plymothians at Freedom Fields Park. The civil war concluded with a victory for Parliament, yet the monarchy was reestablished by King Charles II in 1660, who detained numerous Parliamentary heroes on Drake's Island. The construction of the Royal Citadel commenced in 1665, following the Restoration; it was equipped with cannons directed both toward the ocean and into the town, allegedly intended as a warning to residents against opposing the Crown. Mount Batten tower similarly dates back to approximately this period.
original_question: Which faction did Plymouth support during the English Civil War?
altered_question: Which side did Plymouth align with during the English Civil War?

title: Plymouth
original_context: ['The first record of the existence of a settlement at Plymouth was in the Domesday Book in 1086 as Sudtone, Saxon for south farm, located at the present day Barbican. From Saxon times, it was in the hundred of Roborough. In ••1254•• it gained status as a town and in 1439, became the first town in England to be granted a Charter by Parliament. Between 1439 and 1934, Plymouth had a Mayor. In 1914 the county boroughs of Plymouth and Devonport, and the urban district of East Stonehouse merged to form a single county borough of Plymouth. Collectively they were referred to as The Three Towns.']
altered_context: ['The earliest documentation of a community at Plymouth appeared in the Domesday Book in 1086 as Sudtone, which is Saxon for southern farm, situated at the present-day Barbican. Since Saxon times, it had been part of the hundred of Roborough. In ••1254••, it attained town status and in 1439, it became the first town in England to receive a Charter from Parliament. From 1439 to 1934, Plymouth was governed by a Mayor. In 1914, the county boroughs of Plymouth and Devonport, along with the urban district of East Stonehouse, combined to establish a unified county borough of Plymouth. Together, they were known as The Three Towns.']

Plymouth was one of the first ten British cities to trial the new Business Improvement District initiative. The ••Tinside Pool•• is situated at the foot of the Hoe and became a grade II listed building in 1998 before being restored to its 1930s look for £3.4 million.']

title: Plymouth
original_context: ["Plymouth has about 150 churches and its Roman Catholic cathedral (••1858••) is in Stonehouse. The city's oldest church is St Andrew's (Anglican) located at the top of Royal Parade--it is the largest parish church in Devon and has been a site of gathering since AD 800. The city also includes five Baptist churches, over twenty Methodist chapels, and thirteen Roman Catholic churches. In 1831 the first Brethren assembly in England, a movement of conservative non-denominational Evangelical Christians, was established in the city, so that Brethren are often called Plymouth Brethren, although the movement did not begin locally."]

The city also features five Baptist congregations, more than twenty Methodist chapels, and thirteen Roman Catholic churches. In 1831, the inaugural Brethren assembly in England, a movement of traditional non-denominational Evangelical Christians, was founded in the city, which is why Brethren are frequently referred to as Plymouth Brethren, even though the movement did not have its roots there."]

title: Heresy
original_context: ["Within six years of the official criminalization of heresy by the Emperor, the first Christian heretic to be executed, Priscillian, was condemned in 386 by Roman secular officials for sorcery, and put to death with four or five followers. However, his accusers were ••excommunicated•• both by Ambrose of Milan and Pope Siricius, who opposed Priscillian's heresy, but believed capital punishment to be inappropriate at best and usually unequivocally evil. For some years after the Reformation, Protestant churches were also known to execute those they considered heretics, including Catholics. The last known heretic executed by sentence of the Roman Catholic Church was Spanish schoolmaster Cayetano Ripoll in 1826. ", "The number of people executed as heretics under the authority of the various ecclesiastical authorities[note 1] is not known.[note 2] One of the first examples of the word as translated from the Nag Hammadi's Apocalypse of Peter was they will cleave to the name of a dead man thinking that they will become pure. But they will become greatly defiled and they will fall into the name of error and into the hands of an evil cunning man and a manifold dogma, and they will be ruled heretically."]

Nonetheless, his accusers were ••excommunicated•• by both Ambrose of Milan and Pope Siricius, who opposed Priscillian's heretical views but deemed capital punishment to be unsuitable at best and often unquestionably evil. In the years following the Reformation, Protestant congregations were also noted for executing individuals they labeled as heretics, including Catholics. The final known heretic to be executed by decree of the Roman Catholic Church was Spanish educator Cayetano Ripoll in 1826.", "The exact number of individuals who were executed under the jurisdiction of various church authorities is not documented. One of the earliest instances of the term, as translated from the Nag Hammadi's Apocalypse of Peter, indicated that they would cling to the name of a deceased individual, thinking it would purify them. Instead, they would become deeply corrupted and would fall into the name of falsehood and into the clutches of a malevolent cunning person and a diverse doctrine, and would be governed heretically."]

Galileo was found vehemently suspect of heresy, namely of having held the opinions that ••the Sun lies motionless at the centre of the universe••, that the Earth is not at its centre and moves, and that one may hold and defend an opinion as probable after it has been declared contrary to Holy Scripture. He was required to abjure, curse and detest those opinions.']

title: Heresy
original_context: ['In Eastern Christianity heresy most commonly refers to those beliefs declared heretical by the first seven Ecumenical Councils.[citation needed] Since the Great Schism and the ••Protestant Reformation••, various Christian churches have also used the concept in proceedings against individuals and groups those churches deemed heretical. The Orthodox Church also rejects the early Christian heresies such as Arianism, Gnosticism, Origenism, Montanism, Judaizers, Marcionism, Docetism, Adoptionism, Nestorianism, Monophysitism, Monothelitism and Iconoclasm.']
altered_context: In Eastern Christianity, heresy generally pertains to those beliefs considered heretical by the initial seven Ecumenical Councils.[citation needed] Following the Great Schism and the Protestant Reformation, numerous Christian denominations have also employed the notion in actions against individuals and collectives they regarded as heretical. The Orthodox Church further dismisses the early Christian heresies including Arianism, Gnosticism, Origenism, Montanism, Judaizers, Marcionism, Docetism, Adoptionism, Nestorianism, Monophysitism, Monothelitism, and Iconoclasm.
original_question: What reformation was caused by various heretical groups?
altered_question: Which reformation was triggered by different heretical factions?

title: Heresy
original_context: ['Another example of the persecution of heretics under Protestant rule was the execution of the Boston martyrs in 1659, 1660, and 1661. These executions resulted from the actions of the Anglican Puritans, who at that time wielded political as well as ecclesiastic control in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. At the time, the colony leaders were apparently hoping to achieve their vision of a purer absolute theocracy within their colony .[citation needed] As such, they perceived the teachings and practices of the rival ••Quaker sect•• as heretical, even to the point where laws were passed and executions were performed with the aim of ridding their colony of such perceived heresies.[citation needed] It should be noticed that the Eastern Orthodox and Oriental Orthodox communions generally regard the Puritans themselves as having been heterodox or heretical.']
altered_context: ["A further illustration of the oppression of dissidents under Protestant governance was the execution of the Boston martyrs in 1659, 1660, and 1661. These capital punishments arose from the actions of the Anglican Puritans, who at that time held both political and ecclesiastical authority in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. During this period, the colony's leaders were seemingly striving to realize their dream of a more pristine absolute theocracy within their jurisdiction. Thus, they viewed the doctrines and rituals of the opposing Quaker faction as heretical, to the extent that legislation was enacted and executions carried out with the intention of eliminating such perceived falsehoods from their territory. It is worth noting that the Eastern Orthodox and Oriental Orthodox denominations typically consider the Puritans themselves to have been heterodox or heretical."]
original_question: What rival group did the Anglican Puritans want purged from their area?
altered_question: Which opposing faction did the Anglican Puritans aim to eliminate from their region?

title: Heresy
original_context: ["The revisionist paleontologist ••Robert T. Bakker••, who published his findings as The Dinosaur Heresies, treated the mainstream view of dinosaurs as dogma. I have enormous respect for dinosaur paleontologists past and present. But on average, for the last fifty years, the field hasn't tested dinosaur orthodoxy severely enough. page 27 Most taxonomists, however, have viewed such new terminology as dangerously destabilizing to the traditional and well-known scheme... page 462. This book apparently influenced Jurassic Park. The illustrations by the author show dinosaurs in very active poses, in contrast to the traditional perception of lethargy. He is an example of a recent scientific endoheretic."]
altered_context: ['The revisionist paleontologist ••Robert T. Bakker••, who shared his research in The Dinosaur Heresies, regarded the prevalent perspective on dinosaurs as unquestionable doctrine. I hold great admiration for both historical and contemporary dinosaur paleontologists. However, on average, over the past fifty years, the discipline has not rigorously challenged dinosaur orthodoxy enough. page 27 Most taxonomists, nevertheless, have considered such novel terminology as perilously disruptive to the established and recognized framework... page 462. This book seemingly had an impact on Jurassic Park. The author’s illustrations depict dinosaurs in highly dynamic stances, contrasting sharply with the conventional view of sluggishness. He serves as an instance of a contemporary scientific endoheretic.']

title: Heresy
original_context: ["The revisionist paleontologist Robert T. Bakker, who published his findings as The Dinosaur Heresies, treated the mainstream view of dinosaurs as dogma. I have enormous respect for dinosaur paleontologists past and present. But on average, for the last fifty years, the field hasn't tested dinosaur orthodoxy severely enough. page 27 Most taxonomists, however, have viewed such new terminology as dangerously destabilizing to the traditional and well-known scheme... page 462. This book apparently influenced ••Jurassic Park••. The illustrations by the author show dinosaurs in very active poses, in contrast to the traditional perception of lethargy. He is an example of a recent scientific endoheretic."]
altered_context: ["The revisionist paleontologist Robert T. Bakker, who released his insights under the title The Dinosaur Heresies, regarded the mainstream perspective of dinosaurs as a fixed belief. I hold immense admiration for dinosaur paleontologists from the past and those currently in the field. Nevertheless, over the past fifty years, the discipline has not rigorously challenged dinosaur orthodoxy enough. page 27 Most taxonomists, on the other hand, perceive such novel terminology as potentially disruptive to the established and familiar classification... page 462. This book seemingly had an impact on ••Jurassic Park••. The author's illustrations depict dinosaurs in highly dynamic stances, contrasting with the conventional view of slowness. He exemplifies a modern scientific endoheretic."]

title: Warsaw_Pact
original_context: ['The strategy behind the formation of the Warsaw Pact was driven by the desire of the ••Soviet Union•• to dominate Central and Eastern Europe. This policy was driven by ideological and geostrategic reasons. Ideologically, the Soviet Union arrogated the right to define socialism and communism and act as the leader of the global socialist movement. A corollary to this idea was the necessity of intervention if a country appeared to be violating core socialist ideas and Communist Party functions, which was explicitly stated in the Brezhnev Doctrine. Geostrategic principles also drove the Soviet Union to prevent invasion of its territory by Western European powers.']
altered_context: The approach behind the establishment of the Warsaw Pact was motivated by the ambition of the ••Soviet Union•• to control Central and Eastern Europe. This strategy was influenced by both ideological and geostrategic factors. From an ideological perspective, the Soviet Union claimed the authority to define socialism and communism while positioning itself as the vanguard of the worldwide socialist movement. An implication of this concept was the need for intervention if a nation seemed to be infringing upon fundamental socialist principles and the functions of the Communist Party, which was clearly outlined in the Brezhnev Doctrine. Geostrategic considerations also prompted the Soviet Union to thwart any invasions of its lands by Western European nations.
original_question: Who wanted to dominate Western and Eastern Europe?
altered_question: Who aimed to control Western and Eastern Europe?

title: Warsaw_Pact
original_context: ["Before creation of Warsaw Pact, fearing Germany rearmed, ••Czechoslovak•• leadership sought to create security pact with East Germany and Poland. These states protested strongly against re-militarization of West Germany. The Warsaw Pact was primarily put in place as a consequence of the rearming of West Germany inside NATO. Soviet leaders, as many European countries in both western and eastern side, feared Germany being once again a military power as a direct threat and German militarism remained a fresh memory among Soviets and Eastern Europeans. As Soviet Union had already bilateral treaties with all of its eastern satellites, the Pact has been long considered 'superfluous', and because of the rushed way in which it was conceived, NATO officials labeled it as a 'cardboard castle'. Previously, in March 1954, the USSR, fearing the restoration of German Militarism in West Germany, requested admission to NATO."]
altered_context: Prior to the formation of the Warsaw Pact, anxious about German rearmament, the leadership of Czechoslovakia aimed to establish a security agreement with East Germany and Poland. These nations voiced significant opposition to the re-militarization of West Germany. The Warsaw Pact was chiefly established as a result of the rearming of West Germany within NATO. Soviet officials, as did many nations in both the western and eastern blocs, were apprehensive about Germany potentially regaining its military might, viewing it as a direct danger, and the memories of German militarism were still vivid for Soviets and Eastern Europeans. Since the Soviet Union had previously signed bilateral agreements with all its eastern allies, the Pact was often regarded as 'unnecessary', and due to the hastiness of its formation, NATO representatives dubbed it a 'cardboard castle'. Earlier, in March 1954, the USSR, concerned about the revival of German Militarism in West Germany, sought to join NATO.
original_question: Which leadership had no fear of Germany?
altered_question: Which leadership did not express concern about Germany?

He opposed the request to join NATO made by the USSR in 1954 saying that the Soviet request to join NATO is like an unrepentant burglar requesting to join the police force.']

title: Warsaw_Pact

The incorporation of West Germany into the organization on 9 May 1955 was described as a decisive turning point in the history of our continent by Halvard Lange, Foreign Affairs Minister of Norway at the time. In November 1954, the USSR requested a new European Security Treaty, in order to make a final attempt to not have a remilitarized West Germany potentially opposed to the Soviet Union, with no success.']
altered_context: On 23 October 1954 -- merely nine years after the Allies (UK, USA, and USSR) triumphed over Nazi Germany, concluding World War II in Europe -- the inclusion of the Federal Republic of Germany in the North Atlantic Pact was ultimately resolved. The integration of West Germany into the alliance on 9 May 1955 was characterized as a pivotal moment in the narrative of our continent by Halvard Lange, who was the Foreign Affairs Minister of Norway at that time. In November 1954, the USSR proposed a new European Security Agreement, seeking to make one last effort to prevent a remilitarized West Germany that could stand against the Soviet Union, but this attempt was unsuccessful.

title: Warsaw_Pact
original_context: ['On 25 February 1991, the Warsaw Pact was declared disbanded at a meeting of defense and foreign ministers from remaining Pact countries meeting in Hungary. On 1 July 1991, in Prague, the Czechoslovak President Václav Havel formally ended the 1955 Warsaw Treaty Organization of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance and so disestablished the Warsaw Treaty after ••36•• years of military alliance with the USSR. In fact, the treaty was de facto disbanded in December 1989 during the violent revolution in Romania, which toppled the communist government, without military intervention form other member states. The USSR disestablished itself in December 1991.']
altered_context: On 25 February 1991, the Warsaw Pact was officially announced as disbanded during a conference of defense and foreign ministers from the remaining Pact nations convened in Hungary. Subsequently, on 1 July 1991, in Prague, the Czechoslovak leader Václav Havel officially terminated the 1955 Warsaw Treaty Organization of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance, thereby disbanding the Warsaw Treaty after 36 years of military alliance with the USSR. In truth, the treaty was in effect dissolved in December 1989 amid the tumultuous revolution in Romania, which overthrew the communist regime, without military interference from other member nations. The USSR itself was dissolved in December 1991.
original_question: For how many years did the Warsaw Pact formally exist?

title: Materialism
original_context: ['Despite the large number of philosophical schools and subtle nuances between many, all philosophies are said to fall into one of two primary categories, which are defined in contrast to each other: Idealism, and materialism.[a] The basic proposition of these two categories pertains to the nature of reality, and the primary distinction between them is the way they answer two fundamental questions: what does reality consist of? and how does it originate? To idealists, ••spirit or mind or the objects of mind (ideas)•• are primary, and matter secondary. To materialists, matter is primary, and mind or spirit or ideas are secondary, the product of matter acting upon matter.']
altered_context: Regardless of the multitude of philosophical traditions and intricate distinctions among many of them, all philosophies are generally categorized into one of two main types, which are outlined in opposition to each other: Idealism and materialism. The central assertion of these two classifications relates to the essence of reality, and the key difference between them lies in how they respond to two essential inquiries: what constitutes reality? and how does it come into being? For idealists, ••spirit or consciousness or the products of consciousness (ideas)•• are fundamental, while matter is secondary. For materialists, matter holds primacy, and consciousness or spirit or ideas are secondary, resulting from matter interacting with matter.
original_question: An idealist considers what as the least important?

title: Materialism
original_context: ['One challenge to the traditional concept of matter as tangible stuff came with the rise of field physics in the 19th century. Relativity shows that ••matter and energy•• (including the spatially distributed energy of fields) are interchangeable. This enables the ontological view that energy is prima materia and matter is one of its forms. On the other hand, the Standard Model of Particle physics uses quantum field theory to describe all interactions. On this view it could be said that fields are prima materia and the energy is a property of the field.']
altered_context: A major challenge to the conventional idea of matter as physical substance emerged with the development of field physics in the 19th century. Relativity reveals that ••matter and energy•• (including the distributed energy seen in fields) can be converted into one another. This supports the ontological perspective that energy is the fundamental material and matter represents one of its manifestations. Conversely, the Standard Model of Particle physics employs quantum field theory to illustrate all interactions. From this perspective, one could argue that fields serve as the fundamental material and energy is an attribute of the field.

The subsequent reference to the term can be found in Acts 26:28, where Herod Agrippa II responded to Paul the Apostle, stating, Then Agrippa said to Paul, Almost you convince me to become a Christian. The third and concluding New Testament citation of the term is in 1 Peter 4:16, which encourages believers: Yet if [any individual suffers] as a Christian, let him not feel embarrassed; rather, let him honor God on this account.

title: Christian
original_context: ['The region of modern Eastern Europe and Central Eurasia (Russia, Ukraine and other countries of the ex-USSR) have a long history of Christianity and Christian communities on its lands. In ••ancient times, in the first centuries after the birth of Christ••, when this region was called[by whom?] Scythia - Christians already lived there. Later the region saw the first states to adopt Christianity officially - initially in Armenia (301 AD) and in Georgia (337 AD), later in the Great Russian Principality (Kyivan Rus, Russian: Великое княжество Русское, ca 988 AD). People of that time used to denote themselves Christians (христиане, крестьяне) and Russians (русские). ', 'Both terms had strong Christian connotations.[citation needed] It is also interesting that in time the term крестьяне acquired the meaning peasants of Christian faith and later peasants (the main part of the population of the region), while the term христиане retained its religious meaning and the term русские began to mean representatives of the heterogeneous Russian nation formed on the basis of common Christian faith and language,[citation needed] which strongly influenced the history and development of the region. ', 'In the region the Pravoslav faith (православная вера - Orthodox faith) or Russian faith (русская вера) from earliest times became almost as known as the original Christian faith (христианская, крестьянская вера). Also in some contexts the term cossack (козак, казак - free man by the will of God) was used[by whom?] to denote free Christians of steppe origin and Russian language.']
altered_context: The area of present-day Eastern Europe and Central Eurasia (including Russia, Ukraine, and other nations of the former USSR) has an extensive history of Christianity and Christian groups residing in its territory. In ••earlier periods, during the initial centuries following the advent of Christ••, when this territory was referred to as Scythia - Christians were already present there. Subsequently, the region experienced the emergence of the first nations to formally embrace Christianity - first in Armenia (301 AD) and in Georgia (337 AD), and later within the Great Russian Principality (Kyivan Rus, Russian: Великое княжество Русское, around 988 AD). Individuals from that era commonly identified themselves as Christians (христиане, крестьяне) and Russians (русские). Both labels carried profound Christian implications.[citation needed] It is noteworthy that over time, the term крестьяне evolved to signify peasants of the Christian faith and later simply referred to peasants (who constituted the majority of the region's populace), whereas the term христиане preserved its religious connotation, and the term русские began to signify members of the diverse Russian nation developed on the foundation of a shared Christian faith and language,[citation needed] which had a significant impact on the history and progress of the area. In the region, the Orthodox belief (православная вера - Orthodox faith) or Russian faith (русская вера) became almost as prevalent as the original Christian doctrine (христианская, крестьянская вера) from early on. Additionally, in certain contexts, the term cossack (козак, казак - free man by the will of God) was employed[by whom?] to refer to free Christians of steppe heritage and Russian language.
original_question: When was the Western Europe region called Scythia?
altered_question: In which time period was the area of Western Europe known as Scythia?
answer: ancient times, in the first centuries after the birth of Christ

title: Sony_Music_Entertainment
original_context: ["Sony renamed the record company Sony Music Entertainment (SME) on January 1, 1991, fulfilling the terms set under the 1988 buyout, which granted only a transitional license to the CBS trademark. The CBS Associated label was renamed Epic Associated. Also on January 1, 1991, to replace the CBS label, Sony reintroduced the Columbia label worldwide, which it previously held in the United States and Canada only, after it acquired the international rights to the trademark from EMI in 1990. Japan is the only country where Sony does not have rights ••to the Columbia name as it is controlled by Nippon Columbia••, an unrelated company. Thus, until this day, Sony Music Entertainment Japan does not use the Columbia trademark for Columbia label recordings from outside Japan which are issued in Japan. The Columbia Records trademark's rightsholder in Spain was Bertelsmann Music Group, Germany, which Sony Music subsequently subsumed via a 2004 merger, followed by a 2008 buyout."]
altered_context: ['Sony rebranded its recording entity as Sony Music Entertainment (SME) on January 1, 1991, satisfying the agreements established during the 1988 acquisition, which allowed only a temporary authorization for the CBS trademark. The CBS Associated label was given the new name Epic Associated. Furthermore, on January 1, 1991, in order to substitute the CBS label, Sony reestablished the Columbia label on a global scale, which it had previously owned exclusively in the United States and Canada, after acquiring international rights to the trademark from EMI in 1990. Japan remains the sole nation where Sony lacks rights to the Columbia name since it is managed by Nippon Columbia, an unrelated entity. Consequently, to this day, Sony Music Entertainment Japan refrains from utilizing the Columbia trademark for Columbia label releases from outside Japan that are distributed in Japan. The rights holder of the Columbia Records trademark in Spain was Bertelsmann Music Group, located in Germany, which was later incorporated into Sony Music through a merger in 2004, followed by an acquisition in 2008.']
original_question: China is the only country where Sony does not have the rights to what?
altered_question: What is the name Sony does not have rights to in Japan?
answer: to the Columbia name as it is controlled by Nippon Columbia

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ['Starting at the transition between the Middle to Upper Paleolithic period, some 80,000 to 70,000 years ago, some hunter-gatherers bands began to specialize, concentrating on hunting a smaller selection of (often larger) game and gathering a smaller selection of food. This specialization of work also involved creating specialized tools, like fishing nets and hooks and bone harpoons. The transition into the subsequent Neolithic period is chiefly defined by the unprecedented development of nascent agricultural practices. Agriculture originated and spread in several different areas including the Middle East, Asia, Mesoamerica, and the Andes beginning as early as ••12,000•• years ago.']
altered_context: Commencing at the shift from the Middle to Upper Paleolithic era, approximately 80,000 to 70,000 years in the past, certain groups of hunter-gatherers started to focus on specializing, honing in on hunting a narrower range of (often larger) animals and foraging a limited variety of food items. This specialization in labor also encompassed the creation of specific tools, such as fishing nets, hooks, and bone harpoons. The progression into the following Neolithic period is primarily characterized by the extraordinary advancement of emerging farming techniques. Agriculture developed and disseminated across various regions, including the Middle East, Asia, Mesoamerica, and the Andes, starting as early as 12,000 years ago.
original_question: Agriculture ended how many years ago?
altered_question: How many years ago did agriculture conclude?

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ['Many groups continued their hunter-gatherer ways of life, although their numbers have continually declined, partly as a result of pressure from growing agricultural and pastoral communities. Many of them reside in the developing world, either in arid regions or tropical forests. Areas that were formerly available to hunter-gatherers were--and continue to be--encroached upon by the settlements of agriculturalists. In the resulting competition for land use, hunter-gatherer societies either adopted these practices or moved to other areas. In addition, Jared Diamond has blamed a decline in the availability of wild foods, particularly animal resources. In ••North and South America••, for example, most large mammal species had gone extinct by the end of the Pleistocene--according to Diamond, because of overexploitation by humans, although the overkill hypothesis he advocates is strongly contested.[by whom?]']
altered_context: Numerous groups persisted in their hunter-gatherer lifestyles, despite their populations having continually diminished, partly due to the pressure from expanding agricultural and pastoral societies. A significant number of these groups are located in the developing regions of the world, whether in dry climates or tropical forests. Regions that were previously accessible to hunter-gatherers have been--and still are--invaded by the establishments of agriculturalists. In the resulting struggle for land, hunter-gatherer communities either embraced these agricultural methods or relocated to different areas. Furthermore, Jared Diamond has attributed a reduction in the availability of wild food sources, especially animal assets, to this decline. For instance, in North and South America, by the conclusion of the Pleistocene, most large mammal species had become extinct--Diamond claims that this was due to human overexploitation, although the overkill theory he promotes is heavily disputed.
original_question: All large mammal species have gone extinct in what countries?
altered_question: In which nations have all large mammal species vanished?

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ['It is easy for Western-educated scholars to fall into the trap of viewing hunter-gatherer ••social and sexual•• arrangements in the light of Western values.[editorializing] One common arrangement is the sexual division of labour, with women doing most of the gathering, while men concentrate on big game hunting. It might be imagined that this arrangement oppresses women, keeping them in the domestic sphere. However, according to some observers, hunter-gatherer women would not understand this interpretation. ', "Since childcare is collective, with every baby having multiple mothers and male carers, the domestic sphere is not atomised or privatised but an empowering place to be.[citation needed] In all hunter-gatherer societies, women appreciate the meat brought back to camp by men. An illustrative account is Megan Biesele's study of the southern African Ju/'hoan, 'Women Like Meat'. Recent archaeological research suggests that the sexual division of labor was the fundamental organisational innovation that gave Homo sapiens the edge over the Neanderthals, allowing our ancestors to migrate from Africa and spread across the globe."]
altered_context: ['It is simple for scholars educated in the West to fall into the misconception of perceiving hunter-gatherer social and sexual structures through the lens of Western ethics. One prevalent structure is the sexual division of labor, where females undertake the majority of gathering, while males focus on hunting larger game. It may be assumed that this structure subjugates women, confining them to the domestic realm. Nevertheless, some observers suggest that hunter-gatherer women would not comprehend this perspective.', "As childcare is communal, with each infant having several mothers and male caregivers, the domestic realm is neither isolated nor privatized but rather an empowering environment. In all hunter-gatherer cultures, women value the meat retrieved by men. A representative account is Megan Biesele's research on the southern African Ju/'hoan, titled 'Women Like Meat'. Recent archaeological findings imply that the sexual division of labor was the pivotal organizational advancement that provided Homo sapiens with the advantage over Neanderthals, enabling our ancestors to depart from Africa and disseminate across the planet."]
original_question: It is easy to view what arrangements in the light of Eastern values?
altered_question: It is simple to interpret what structures through the lens of Eastern ethics?

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ["At the same conference, Marshall Sahlins presented a paper entitled, Notes on the Original Affluent Society, in which he challenged the popular view of hunter-gatherers lives as solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short, as Thomas Hobbes had put it in 1651. According to Sahlins, ethnographic data indicated that hunter-gatherers worked far fewer hours and enjoyed more leisure than ••typical members of industrial society••, and they still ate well. Their affluence came from the idea that they were satisfied with very little in the material sense. Later, in 1996, Ross Sackett performed two distinct meta-analyses to empirically test Sahlin's view. The first of these studies looked at 102 time-allocation studies, and the second one analyzed 207 energy-expenditure studies. Sackett found that adults in foraging and horticultural societies work, on average, about 6.5 hours a day, where as people in agricultural and industrial societies work on average 8.8 hours a day."]
altered_context: During the same conference, Marshall Sahlins delivered a paper titled, Notes on the Original Affluent Society, wherein he contested the widespread perception of hunter-gatherers’ existence as isolated, impoverished, unpleasant, harsh, and brief, as characterized by Thomas Hobbes in 1651. Sahlins asserted that ethnographic evidence demonstrated that hunter-gatherers toiled significantly fewer hours and experienced more leisure time than typical members of industrial society, while still having a satisfactory diet. Their prosperity stemmed from the notion that they were content with minimal material resources. Subsequently, in 1996, Ross Sackett conducted two separate meta-analyses to empirically evaluate Sahlins' perspective. The initial study examined 102 time-allocation studies, and the subsequent one scrutinized 207 energy-expenditure investigations. Sackett discovered that adults in foraging and horticultural communities worked, on average, around 6.5 hours per day, whereas individuals in agricultural and industrial communities averaged 8.8 hours of work daily.
original_question: Data showed that hunter-gatherers enjoyed less leisure time than whom?
altered_question: Data indicated that hunter-gatherers experienced less leisure time than whom?

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ["At the same conference, Marshall Sahlins presented a paper entitled, ••Notes on the Original Affluent Society••, in which he challenged the popular view of hunter-gatherers lives as solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short, as Thomas Hobbes had put it in 1651. According to Sahlins, ethnographic data indicated that hunter-gatherers worked far fewer hours and enjoyed more leisure than typical members of industrial society, and they still ate well. Their affluence came from the idea that they were satisfied with very little in the material sense. Later, in 1996, Ross Sackett performed two distinct meta-analyses to empirically test Sahlin's view. The first of these studies looked at 102 time-allocation studies, and the second one analyzed 207 energy-expenditure studies. Sackett found that adults in foraging and horticultural societies work, on average, about 6.5 hours a day, where as people in agricultural and industrial societies work on average 8.8 hours a day."]
altered_context: ["During the same conference, Marshall Sahlins delivered a presentation titled, ••Notes on the Original Affluent Society••, wherein he contested the widespread perception of the lives of hunter-gatherers as isolated, impoverished, unpleasant, harsh, and brief, as described by Thomas Hobbes in 1651. Sahlins argued that ethnographic evidence suggested that hunter-gatherers engaged in work for significantly fewer hours and experienced greater leisure time compared to standard members of industrial society, while still having a satisfactory diet. Their wealth stemmed from the notion that they found contentment with minimal material possessions. Subsequently, in 1996, Ross Sackett conducted two separate meta-analyses to empirically examine Sahlins' perspective. The first study assessed 102 time-allocation research articles, while the second focused on 207 energy-expenditure investigations. Sackett discovered that adults in foraging and horticultural communities work, on average, around 6.5 hours each day, whereas individuals in agricultural and industrial environments typically work an average of 8.8 hours each day."]
original_question: What was the title of Ross Sackett's paper in which he challenged the popular view of hunter-gatherer lives?
altered_question: What was the name of Ross Sackett's article in which he questioned the common perception of hunter-gatherer lifestyles?
answer: Notes on the Original Affluent Society

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ['Evidence suggests big-game hunter gatherers crossed the Bering Strait from Asia (Eurasia) into North America over a land bridge (Beringia), that existed between 47,000--14,000 years ago. Around 18,500-15,500 years ago, these hunter-gatherers are believed to have followed herds of now-extinct Pleistocene megafauna along ice-free corridors that stretched between the Laurentide and Cordilleran ice sheets. Another route proposed is that, either on foot or using primitive boats, they migrated down the Pacific coast to ••South America••.']
altered_context: Research indicates that large-game foragers traversed the Bering Strait from Asia (Eurasia) into North America via a land connection (Beringia) that existed between 47,000 and 14,000 years ago. Approximately 18,500 to 15,500 years ago, it is thought that these foragers pursued herds of now-extinct Pleistocene megafauna through ice-free passages that extended between the Laurentide and Cordilleran ice sheets. An alternative pathway suggested is that, either by walking or utilizing rudimentary boats, they could have journeyed down the Pacific coastline to ••South America••.

title: Hunter-gatherer
original_context: ['••The Archaic period•• in the Americas saw a changing environment featuring a warmer more arid climate and the disappearance of the last megafauna. The majority of population groups at this time were still highly mobile hunter-gatherers؛ but now individual groups started to focus on resources available to them locally, thus with the passage of time there is a pattern of increasing regional generalization like, the Southwest, Arctic, Poverty, Dalton and Plano traditions. This regional adaptations would become the norm, with reliance less on hunting and gathering, with a more mixed economy of small game, fish, seasonally wild vegetables and harvested plant foods.']
altered_context: ••The Archaic epoch•• in the Americas experienced a transforming environment characterized by a warmer, drier climate and the extinction of the last megafauna. Most population groups during this era were still very nomadic hunter-gatherers, yet individual tribes began to concentrate on resources accessible to them locally. Over time, this resulted in a trend of increasing regional specialization such as the Southwest, Arctic, Poverty, Dalton, and Plano cultures. These regional adjustments became standard, leading to a reduced dependence on hunting and gathering in favor of a more diverse economy consisting of small game, fish, seasonal wild plants, and cultivated food sources.

title: Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic
original_context: ['The Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (Russian SFSR or RSFSR؛ Russian: Российская Советская Федеративная Социалистическая Республика, tr. Rossiyskaya Sovetskaya Federativnaya Sotsialisticheskaya Respublika  listen (help·info)) commonly referred to as Soviet Russia or simply as Russia, was a sovereign state in 1917--22, the largest, most populous, and most economically developed republic of the Soviet Union in 1922--91 and a sovereign part of the Soviet Union with its own legislation in 1990--91. ', 'The Republic comprised sixteen autonomous republics, five autonomous oblasts, ten autonomous okrugs, six krais, and forty oblasts. Russians formed the largest ethnic group. To the west it bordered Finland, Norway and Poland؛ and to the south, China, Mongolia and North Korea whilst bordering the Arctic Ocean to the north, the ••Pacific•• Ocean to the east and the Black sea and Caspian Sea to the south. Within the USSR, it bordered the Baltic republics (Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia), the Byelorussian SSR and the Ukrainian SSR to the west. To the south it bordered the Georgian, Azerbaijan and Kazakh SSRs.']
altered_context: ['The Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (Russian SFSR or RSFSR; Russian: Российская Советская Федеративная Социалистическая Республика, tr. Rossiyskaya Sovetskaya Federativnaya Sotsialisticheskaya Respublika  listen (help·info)) is often called Soviet Russia or simply Russia. It was a self-governing nation from 1917 to 1922, the largest, most populous, and most economically advanced republic within the Soviet Union from 1922 to 1991, and a self-governing component of the Soviet Union with its own laws from 1990 to 1991.', 'The Republic consisted of sixteen autonomous republics, five autonomous regions, ten autonomous areas, six territories, and forty regions. The Russians were the predominant ethnic group. To the west, it shared borders with Finland, Norway, and Poland; to the south, with China, Mongolia, and North Korea, while the Arctic Ocean lay to the north, the Pacific Ocean to the east, and both the Black Sea and Caspian Sea to the south. Within the USSR, it bordered the Baltic republics (Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia) to the west, and to the south, it bordered the Georgian, Azerbaijan, and Kazakh SSRs.']

title: Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic
original_context: ['The economy of Russia became heavily industrialized, accounting for about two-thirds of the electricity produced in the USSR. It was, by 1961, the third largest producer of petroleum due to new discoveries in the Volga-Urals region and Siberia, trailing only the United States and Saudi Arabia. In 1974, there were ••475•• institutes of higher education in the republic providing education in 47 languages to some 23,941,000 students. A network of territorially-organized public-health services provided health care. After 1985, the restructuring policies of the Gorbachev administration relatively liberalised the economy, which had become stagnant since the late 1970s, with the introduction of non-state owned enterprises such as cooperatives. The effects of market policies led to the failure of many enterprises and total instability by 1990.']

By 1961, it had become the third largest oil producer due to recent discoveries in the Volga-Urals area and Siberia, following only the United States and Saudi Arabia. In 1974, there were ••475•• institutions of tertiary education in the republic offering instruction in 47 languages to approximately 23,941,000 learners. A system of regionally-organized public health services delivered healthcare. After 1985, the reform policies of the Gorbachev government somewhat liberalized the economy, which had stagnated since the late 1970s, with the establishment of non-state-owned businesses like cooperatives. The repercussions of market-oriented policies resulted in numerous enterprises failing and complete instability by 1990.']

title: Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic
original_context: ["On June 12, 1990, the Congress of People's Deputies adopted the Declaration of State Sovereignty. On June 12, 1991, Boris Yeltsin was elected the first President. On ••December 8, 1991••, heads of Russia, Ukraine and Belarus signed the Belavezha Accords. The agreement declared dissolution of the USSR by its founder states (i.e. denunciation of 1922 Treaty on the Creation of the USSR) and established the CIS. On December 12, the agreement was ratified by the Russian Parliament, therefore Russian SFSR denounced the Treaty on the Creation of the USSR and de facto declared Russia's independence from the USSR."]
altered_context: On June 12, 1990, the Congress of People's Deputies passed the Declaration of State Sovereignty. On June 12, 1991, Boris Yeltsin was chosen as the inaugural President. On December 8, 1991, the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus signed the Belavezha Accords. This agreement proclaimed the dissolution of the USSR by its founding states (i.e., a repudiation of the 1922 Treaty that established the USSR) and formed the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). On December 12, the agreement received ratification from the Russian Parliament, which meant the Russian SFSR annulled the Treaty on the Creation of the USSR and effectively proclaimed Russia’s autonomy from the USSR.

title: Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic
original_context: ['On December 8, 1991, at Viskuli near Brest (Belarus), the President of the Russian SFSR and the heads of Byelorussian SSR and Ukrainian SSR signed the Agreement on the Establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States (known in media as Belavezha Accords). The document, consisting of a preamble and fourteen articles, stated that the Soviet Union ceased to exist as a subject of international law and geopolitical reality. However, based on the historical community of peoples, relations between them, given the bilateral treaties, the desire for a democratic rule of law, the intention to develop their relations based on mutual recognition and respect for state sovereignty, the parties agreed to the formation of the Commonwealth of Independent States. ', 'On December 12, the agreement was ratified by ••the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR•• by an overwhelming majority: 188 votes for, 6 against, 7 abstentions. On the same day, the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR denounced the Treaty on the Creation of the USSR and recalled all Russian deputies from the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union. The legality of this act is the subject of discussions because, according to the 1978 Constitution (Basic Law) of the Russian SFSR, the Russian Supreme Soviet had no right to do so. ', 'However, by this time the Soviet government had been rendered more or less impotent, and was in no position to object. Although the December 12 vote is sometimes reckoned as the moment that the RSFSR seceded from the collapsing Soviet Union, this is not the case. It appears that the RSFSR took the line that it was not possible to secede from an entity that no longer existed.']
altered_context: ['On the 8th of December, 1991, in Viskuli close to Brest (Belarus), the President of the Russian SFSR along with the leaders of the Byelorussian SSR and Ukrainian SSR endorsed the Agreement on the Formation of the Commonwealth of Independent States (commonly referred to in media as the Belavezha Accords). This document, which included a preamble and fourteen articles, declared that the Soviet Union had ceased to exist as an entity of international law and geopolitical significance. Nevertheless, grounded in the historical bonds of nations, their interactions due to bilateral agreements, the aspiration for a rule of law embedded in democracy, and the commitment to cultivate their relationships based on mutual acknowledgment and respect for state sovereignty, the involved parties consented to establish the Commonwealth of Independent States.', 'On December 12, the agreement received approval from the ••Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR•• through an overwhelming majority: 188 votes in favor, 6 against, and 7 abstentions. On that same day, the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR nullified the Treaty on the Formation of the USSR and withdrew all Russian representatives from the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union. The legitimacy of this action is debated, as per the 1978 Constitution (Fundamental Law) of the Russian SFSR, the Russian Supreme Soviet lacked the authority to undertake such an action.', "At this point, the Soviet authority had become largely ineffective and was unable to raise objections. Although the vote on December 12 is occasionally viewed as the pivotal moment of the RSFSR's departure from the disintegrating Soviet Union, this interpretation is misleading. It seems that the RSFSR maintained the stance that it could not secede from an organization that had ceased to exist."]
original_question: What body ratified the Belavezha Accords on December 12?
altered_question: Which authority ratified the Belavezha Accords on the 12th of December?
answer: the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell
original_context: ['As a child, young Bell displayed a natural curiosity about his world, resulting in gathering botanical specimens as well as experimenting even at an early age. His best friend was Ben Herdman, a neighbor whose family operated a flour mill, the scene of many forays. Young Bell asked what needed to be done at the mill. He was told wheat had to be dehusked through a laborious process and at the age of 12, Bell built a homemade device that combined ••rotating paddles•• with sets of nail brushes, creating a simple dehusking machine that was put into operation and used steadily for a number of years. In return, John Herdman gave both boys the run of a small workshop in which to invent.']
altered_context: During his youth, young Bell exhibited an innate inquisitiveness about his surroundings, leading him to collect plant specimens and conduct experiments from an early age. He learned that wheat needed to be dehusked through a tedious procedure, and by the time he was 12, Bell constructed a homemade apparatus that integrated ••rotating paddles•• with sets of nail brushes, forming a basic dehusking device that was employed and utilized continuously for several years. In exchange, John Herdman allowed both boys access to a small workshop where they could create inventions.

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell
original_context: ["From his early years, Bell showed a sensitive nature and a talent for art, poetry, and music that was encouraged by his mother. With no formal training, he mastered the piano and became the family's pianist. Despite being normally quiet and introspective, he reveled in mimicry and voice tricks akin to ventriloquism that continually entertained family guests during their occasional visits. Bell was also deeply affected by his mother's gradual deafness, (she began to lose her hearing when he was ••12••) and learned a manual finger language so he could sit at her side and tap out silently the conversations swirling around the family parlour. He also developed a technique of speaking in clear, modulated tones directly into his mother's forehead wherein she would hear him with reasonable clarity. Bell's preoccupation with his mother's deafness led him to study acoustics."]
altered_context: ["From his childhood, Bell displayed a sensitive disposition and a flair for art, verse, and music that was nurtured by his mother. Lacking formal education, he became adept at the piano and took on the role of the family's pianist. Although typically reserved and reflective, he took delight in imitating voices and performing voice tricks similar to ventriloquism, which consistently amused family visitors during their rare appearances. Bell was also significantly impacted by his mother's gradual loss of hearing, (she started to experience hearing impairment when he was ••12••) and he acquired a manual finger language so he could sit beside her and silently convey the discussions that revolved around the family living room. Additionally, he created a method of speaking in distinct, modulated tones directly into his mother's forehead, allowing her to hear him with considerable clarity. Bell's fixation on his mother's hearing loss motivated him to explore acoustics."]
original_question: How old was Bell when his mom started to go deaf?
altered_question: What was Bell's age when his mother began to lose her hearing?

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell
original_context: ["His father encouraged Bell's interest in speech and, in 1863, took his sons to see a unique automaton, developed by Sir Charles Wheatstone based on the earlier work of Baron Wolfgang von Kempelen. The rudimentary mechanical man simulated a human voice. Bell was fascinated by the machine and after he obtained a copy of von Kempelen's book, published in German, and had laboriously translated it, he and his older brother ••Melville•• built their own automaton head. ", 'Their father, highly interested in their project, offered to pay for any supplies and spurred the boys on with the enticement of a big prize if they were successful. While his brother constructed the throat and larynx, Bell tackled the more difficult task of recreating a realistic skull. His efforts resulted in a remarkably lifelike head that could speak, albeit only a few words. The boys would carefully adjust the lips and when a bellows forced air through the windpipe, a very recognizable Mama ensued, to the delight of neighbors who came to see the Bell invention.']
altered_context: ["His dad motivated Bell's fascination with speech and, in 1863, brought his sons to witness a remarkable automaton, created by Sir Charles Wheatstone, drawing on the prior work of Baron Wolfgang von Kempelen. This basic mechanical figure emulated a human voice. Bell was captivated by the device, and after he secured a translation of von Kempelen's book, which was initially published in German, he and his elder sibling ••Melville•• fashioned their own automaton head.", 'Their father, extremely keen on their endeavor, offered to finance any materials and encouraged the boys with the promise of a substantial reward if they succeeded. While his sibling constructed the throat and larynx, Bell undertook the more challenging responsibility of replicating a lifelike skull. His attempts yielded an astonishingly realistic head capable of articulation, albeit with only a limited vocabulary. The boys would meticulously manipulate the lips, and when a bellows propelled air through the windpipe, a distinctly recognizable Mama emerged, much to the joy of neighbors who came to witness the Bell creation.']
original_question: Bell built his own automaton with who?
altered_question: With whom did Bell create his own automaton?

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell
original_context: ['In the following year, Bell became professor of Vocal Physiology and Elocution at the Boston University School of Oratory. During this period, he alternated between Boston and Brantford, spending summers in his Canadian home. At Boston University, Bell was swept up by the excitement engendered by the many scientists and inventors residing in the city. He continued his research in sound and endeavored to find a way to transmit musical notes and articulate speech, but although absorbed by his experiments, he found it difficult to devote enough time to experimentation. ', 'While days and evenings were occupied by his teaching and private classes, Bell began to stay awake late into the night, running experiment after experiment in rented facilities at his boarding house. Keeping night owl hours, he worried that his work would be discovered and took great pains to lock up his notebooks and laboratory equipment. Bell had a specially made table where he could place his notes and equipment inside a locking cover. Worse still, his health deteriorated as he suffered severe headaches. Returning to Boston in fall ••1873••, Bell made a fateful decision to concentrate on his experiments in sound.']
altered_context: ['In the subsequent year, Bell assumed the role of professor of Vocal Physiology and Elocution at the Boston University School of Oratory. Throughout this time, he alternated between Boston and Brantford, spending summers in his residence in Canada. At Boston University, Bell was captivated by the buzz generated by the numerous scientists and innovators who lived in the city. He persisted in his inquiries into sound and sought a method to transmit musical tones and expressed speech, yet despite his deep involvement in his trials, he struggled to allocate sufficient time for experimentation.', 'While his days and evenings were filled with teaching and private sessions, Bell started to stay awake late into the night, conducting one experiment after another in rented spaces at his boarding house. Keeping nocturnal hours, he was concerned that his work might be uncovered and took considerable care to secure his notebooks and laboratory apparatus. Bell had a custom-made table where he placed his notes and tools within a locking cover. To make matters worse, his health declined as he experienced intense headaches. Upon his return to Boston in the autumn of 1873, Bell made a pivotal choice to focus on his sound experiments.']

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell
original_context: ["In 1874, telegraph message traffic was rapidly expanding and in the words of Western Union President William Orton, had become the ••nervous system•• of commerce. When Bell mentioned to Gardiner Hubbard and Thomas Sanders that he was working on a method of sending multiple tones on a telegraph wire using a multi-reed device, the two wealthy patrons began to financially support Bell's experiments. Patent matters would be handled by Hubbard's patent attorney, Anthony Pollok."]

title: Alexander_Graham_Bell

Bell considered the invention of the hydroplane as a very significant achievement. Based on information gained from that article he began to sketch concepts of what is now called a ••hydrofoil boat••. Bell and assistant Frederick W. Casey Baldwin began hydrofoil experimentation in the summer of 1908 as a possible aid to airplane takeoff from water. Baldwin studied the work of the Italian inventor Enrico Forlanini and began testing models. This led him and Bell to the development of practical hydrofoil watercraft.']
altered_context: The March 1906 article in Scientific American, authored by American trailblazer William E. Meacham, elucidated the fundamental concept of hydrofoils and hydroplanes. Bell regarded the creation of the hydroplane as an immensely significant milestone. Casey Baldwin initiated hydrofoil trials as a potential enhancement for airplane departures from water. Baldwin examined the research of Italian inventor Enrico Forlanini and started experimenting with models. This exploration resulted in both him and Bell advancing towards the realization of functional hydrofoil watercraft.

title: Pub
original_context: ['There was a special case established under the State Management Scheme where the brewery and licensed premises were bought and run by the state until 1973, most notably in Carlisle. During the 20th century elsewhere, both the licensing laws and enforcement were progressively relaxed, and there were differences between parishes؛ in the 1960s, at closing time in Kensington at 10:30 pm, drinkers would rush over the parish boundary to be in good time for Last Orders in Knightsbridge before 11 pm, a practice observed in many pubs adjoining licensing area boundaries. Some Scottish and Welsh parishes remained officially dry on ••Sundays•• (although often this merely required knocking at the back door of the pub). These restricted opening hours led to the tradition of lock-ins.']

Throughout the 20th century in other places, both the licensing regulations and enforcement became increasingly lenient, with variations among parishes; in the 1960s, at closing time in Kensington at 10:30 pm, patrons would hurriedly cross the parish line to make it in time for Last Orders in Knightsbridge before 11 pm, a behavior common in many pubs adjacent to licensing area borders. Certain Scottish and Welsh parishes continued to be officially alcohol-free on ••Sundays•• (though this often merely entailed a knock on the back door of the pub). title: Pub
original_context: ['After the development of the large London Porter breweries in the 18th century, the trend grew for pubs to become tied houses which could only sell beer from one brewery (a pub not tied in this way was called ••a Free house••). The usual arrangement for a tied house was that the pub was owned by the brewery but rented out to a private individual (landlord) who ran it as a separate business (even though contracted to buy the beer from the brewery). Another very common arrangement was (and is) for the landlord to own the premises (whether freehold or leasehold) independently of the brewer, but then to take a mortgage loan from a brewery, either to finance the purchase of the pub initially, or to refurbish it, and be required as a term of the loan to observe the solus tie.']
altered_context: Following the emergence of the substantial London Porter breweries during the 18th century, there was an inclination for taverns to become exclusive establishments that could only offer beer from a single brewery (a tavern not bound in this manner was referred to as ••a Free house••). Typically, the arrangement for a tied establishment involved the brewery owning the tavern while leasing it to a private individual (landlord) who operated it as an independent entity (despite being contracted to purchase the beer from the brewery). Another prevalent arrangement was (and remains) for the landlord to possess the property (whether outright ownership or leasehold) independently of the brewer, but subsequently to secure a mortgage loan from a brewery, either to support the initial acquisition of the tavern or to renovate it, and be obligated as a condition of the loan to adhere to the solus tie.
original_question: What was the name for a pub that could sell beer from more than one brewery?
altered_question: What was the term used for a tavern that had the ability to sell beer from multiple breweries?

title: Pub
original_context: ["A trend in the late 20th century was for breweries to run their pubs directly, using managers rather than tenants. Most such breweries, such as the regional brewery Shepherd Neame in Kent and ••Young's and Fuller's•• in London, control hundreds of pubs in a particular region of the UK, while a few, such as Greene King, are spread nationally. The landlord of a tied pub may be an employee of the brewery--in which case he/she would be a manager of a managed house, or a self-employed tenant who has entered into a lease agreement with a brewery, a condition of which is the legal obligation (trade tie) only to purchase that brewery's beer. The beer selection is mainly limited to beers brewed by that particular company. ", 'The Beer Orders, passed in 1989, were aimed at getting tied houses to offer at least one alternative beer, known as a guest beer, from another brewery. This law has now been repealed but while in force it dramatically altered the industry. Some pubs still offer a regularly changing selection of guest beers.']
altered_context: ["A movement in the latter part of the 20th century was for brewing companies to manage their taverns directly, employing managers instead of lessees. Most of these brewing companies, including the regional brewery Shepherd Neame located in Kent and ••Young's and Fuller's•• based in London, oversee hundreds of taverns in specific areas of the UK, while a select few, like Greene King, are dispersed nationally. The proprietor of a tied tavern may either be an employee of the brewery—making them a manager of a managed establishment—or an independent tenant who has entered a leasing contract with a brewery, of which one stipulation is the legal requirement (trade tie) to purchase solely that brewery's beer. The range of beers is predominantly restricted to those brewed by the specified company.", 'The Beer Orders, enacted in 1989, aimed to get tied houses to provide at least one alternative brew, referred to as a guest beer, from a different brewery. Even though this regulation has now been abolished, while it was active, it significantly transformed the industry. Some taverns still present a frequently changing assortment of guest beers.']
original_question: What London breweries each own many pubs?
altered_question: Which breweries in London own numerous pubs?

title: Pub
original_context: ['A number of pubs claim to be the oldest surviving establishment in the United Kingdom, although in several cases original buildings have been demolished and replaced on the same site. Others are ancient buildings that saw uses other than as a pub during their history. Ye Olde Fighting Cocks in St Albans, Hertfordshire, holds the Guinness World Record for the oldest pub in England, as it is an 11th-century structure on an 8th-century site. Ye Olde Trip to Jerusalem in ••Nottingham•• is claimed to be the oldest inn in England. It has a claimed date of 1189, based on the fact it is constructed on the site of the Nottingham Castle brewhouse؛ the present building dates from around 1650. Likewise, The Nags Head in Burntwood, Staffordshire only dates back to the 16th century, but there has been a pub on the site since at least 1086, as it is mentioned in the Domesday Book.']
altered_context: Numerous taverns assert their position as the oldest functioning establishment in the United Kingdom, although in many instances, the original structures have been torn down and replaced at the same location. Some are historic buildings that served purposes other than that of a bar throughout their lifespan. Ye Olde Fighting Cocks located in St Albans, Hertfordshire, holds the Guinness World Record for the oldest pub in England, as it is an 11th-century construction on an 8th-century site. Ye Olde Trip to Jerusalem in Nottingham is asserted to be the oldest inn in England, with a claimed date of 1189, based on its construction on the site of the Nottingham Castle brewhouse; the current building dates back to approximately 1650. Similarly, The Nags Head in Burntwood, Staffordshire, has its origins in the 16th century, yet there has been a tavern on the location since at least 1086, as recorded in the Domesday Book.

altered_question: In which city is Ye Olde Trip to Jerusalem situated?
