title: Internet_service_provider
original_context: ['Internet service providers in many countries are legally required (e.g., via Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA) in the U.S.) to allow law enforcement agencies to monitor some or all of the information transmitted by the ISP. Furthermore, in some countries ISPs are subject to monitoring by intelligence agencies. In the U.S., a controversial National Security Agency program known as PRISM provides for broad monitoring of Internet users traffic and has raised concerns about potential violation of the privacy protections in the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Modern ISPs integrate ••a wide array of surveillance and packet sniffing equipment•• into their networks, which then feeds the data to law-enforcement/intelligence networks (such as DCSNet in the United States, or SORM in Russia) allowing monitoring of Internet traffic in real time.']
altered_context: In numerous nations, internet service providers are mandated by law (for instance, through the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA) in the United States) to permit law enforcement bodies to observe some or all of the data transmitted by the ISP. Additionally, in certain countries, ISPs are vulnerable to scrutiny by intelligence organizations. In the United States, a contentious program by the National Security Agency referred to as PRISM facilitates extensive oversight of internet users' traffic and has sparked worries regarding possible infringements on privacy rights as outlined in the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. Contemporary ISPs incorporate a diverse range of surveillance and packet sniffing technology into their infrastructures, which subsequently relays the information to law enforcement/intelligence networks (like DCSNet in the U.S. and SORM in Russia), enabling real-time surveillance of internet traffic.
original_question: What do ISPs remove from their networks to discourage intelligence agencies?
altered_question: What do ISPs eliminate from their systems to deter intelligence organizations?
answer: a wide array of surveillance and packet sniffing equipment

title: Comics
original_context: ['The English term comics is used as a singular noun when it refers to the medium and a plural when referring to particular instances, such as individual strips or comic books. Though the term derives from the humorous (or comic) work that predominated in early American newspaper comic strips, it has become standard also for non-humorous works. It is common in English to refer to the comics of different cultures by the terms used in their original languages, such as manga for Japanese comics, or bandes dessinées for French-language comics. There is no consensus amongst theorists and historians on a definition of comics؛ some emphasize the combination of ••images and text••, some sequentiality or other image relations, and others historical aspects such as mass reproduction or the use of recurring characters. The increasing cross-pollination of concepts from different comics cultures and eras has further made definition difficult.']
altered_context: The term comics in English is utilized as a singular noun when discussing the medium and as a plural noun when referring to specific examples, such as individual strips or comic books. Although the term originates from the humorous (or comic) creations that were prevalent in the early days of American newspaper comic strips, it has also become a standard term for non-humorous creations. It is typical in English to label the comics from various cultures using the terms found in their original languages, such as manga for Japanese comics or bandes dessinées for comics in French. There isn't a universal agreement among theorists and historians on what defines comics; some focus on the interplay of ••images and text••, some on sequentiality or other relationships between images, while others consider historical elements like mass reproduction or the presence of recurring characters. The growing interchange of ideas from various comics cultures and time periods has further complicated the task of defining the term.

title: Comics
original_context: ["The European, American, and Japanese comics traditions have followed different paths. Europeans have seen their tradition as beginning with the Swiss Rodolphe Töpffer from as early as 1827 and Americans have seen the origin of theirs in Richard F. Outcault's 1890s newspaper strip The Yellow Kid, though many Americans have come to recognize Töpffer's precedence. Japan had a long prehistory of ••satirical•• cartoons and comics leading up to the World War II era. The ukiyo-e artist Hokusai popularized the Japanese term for comics and cartooning, manga, in the early 19th century. In the post-war era modern Japanese comics began to flourish when Osamu Tezuka produced a prolific body of work. Towards the close of the 20th century, these three traditions converged in a trend towards book-length comics: the comics album in Europe, the tankōbon[a] in Japan, and the graphic novel in the English-speaking countries."]
altered_context: ["The comic traditions of Europe, America, and Japan have traversed distinct trajectories. Europeans have perceived their legacy as commencing with the Swiss Rodolphe Töpffer dating back to 1827, whereas Americans trace theirs to Richard F. Outcault's newspaper comic strip The Yellow Kid from the 1890s, although many Americans have acknowledged Töpffer's earlier contributions. Japan boasted an extensive prehistory of ••satirical•• illustrations and comics leading up to the period of World War II. The ukiyo-e artist Hokusai popularized the Japanese word for comics and cartooning, manga, in the early 1800s. In the aftermath of the war, contemporary Japanese comics began to thrive as Osamu Tezuka created a vast array of works. As the 20th century neared its end, these three cultures started to unify in a shift towards lengthy comic books: the comics album in Europe, the tankōbon[a] in Japan, and the graphic novel in English-speaking nations."]

altered_question: What type of comics did Japan possess a significant legacy with prior to the Second World War?

title: Comics
original_context: ["Historical narratives of manga tend to focus either on its recent, post-WWII history, or on attempts to demonstrates deep roots in the past, such as to the Chōjū-jinbutsu-giga picture scroll of the 12th and 13th centuries, or the early 19th-century Hokusai Manga. The first historical overview of Japanese comics was Seiki Hosokibara's ••Nihon Manga-Shi••[i] in 1924. Early post-war Japanese criticism was mostly of a left-wing political nature until the 1986 publication for Tomofusa Kure's Modern Manga: The Complete Picture,[j] which de-emphasized politics in favour of formal aspects, such as structure and a grammar of comics. The field of manga studies increased rapidly, with numerous books on the subject appearing in the 1990s. ", "Formal theories of manga have focused on developing a manga expression theory,[k] with emphasis on spatial relationships in the structure of images on the page, distinguishing the medium from film or literature, in which the flow of time is the basic organizing element. Comics studies courses have proliferated at Japanese universities, and Japan Society for Studies in Cartoon and Comics (ja)[l] was established in 2001 to promote comics scholarship. The publication of Frederik L. Schodt's Manga! Manga! The World of Japanese Comics in 1983 led to the spread of use of the word manga outside Japan to mean Japanese comics or Japanese-style comics."]
altered_context: ["Historical accounts of manga often concentrate on either its recent history post-World War II or on efforts to illustrate deep connections to the past, such as the Chōjū-jinbutsu-giga illustrated scroll from the 12th and 13th centuries, or the early 19th-century Hokusai Manga. The initial historical examination of Japanese comics was provided by Seiki Hosokibara's ••Nihon Manga-Shi••[i] in 1924. The early post-war criticism in Japan was primarily of a leftist political orientation until the 1986 release of Tomofusa Kure's Modern Manga: The Complete Picture,[j] which shifted the focus away from politics towards formal characteristics, including structure and comic grammar. The domain of manga studies experienced rapid growth, with many publications on the topic emerging in the 1990s.", "Theoretical frameworks of manga have concentrated on formulating a theory of manga expression,[k] highlighting spatial relationships in the arrangement of images on the page, setting the medium apart from film or literature, where the passage of time serves as the fundamental organizing principle. Manga studies programs have expanded across Japanese universities, and the Japan Society for Studies in Cartoon and Comics (ja)[l] was founded in 2001 to further comic scholarship. The release of Frederik L. Schodt's Manga! Manga! The World of Japanese Comics in 1983 contributed to the wider adoption of the term manga beyond Japan to refer to Japanese comics or comics styled after Japanese works."]
original_question: Which historical overview did Seiki Hosokibara reject?
altered_question: Which historical account did Seiki Hosokibara dismiss?

title: Comics
original_context: ["Similar to the problems of defining literature and film, no consensus has been reached on a definition of the comics medium, and attempted definitions and descriptions have fallen prey to numerous exceptions. ••Theorists•• such as Töpffer, R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner, David Carrier, Alain Rey, and Lawrence Grove emphasize the combination of text and images, though there are prominent examples of pantomime comics throughout its history. Other critics, such as Thierry Groensteen and Scott McCloud, have emphasized the primacy of sequences of images. Towards the close of the 20th century, different cultures' discoveries of each other's comics traditions, the rediscovery of forgotten early comics forms, and the rise of new forms made defining comics a more complicated task."]
altered_context: Likewise to the challenges of characterizing literature and cinema, no agreement has been achieved regarding a definition of the comics medium, and various attempts at definitions and depictions have encountered numerous exceptions. ••Scholars•• such as Töpffer, R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner, David Carrier, Alain Rey, and Lawrence Grove underscore the amalgamation of text and visuals, even though there are notable instances of silent comics throughout its history. Other commentators, including Thierry Groensteen and Scott McCloud, have highlighted the importance of sequences of images. Near the end of the 20th century, the mutual recognition of different cultures' comics traditions, the resurgence of overlooked early comics styles, and the emergence of innovative forms have complicated the endeavor of defining comics.
original_question: R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner and others are not considered to be comic what?
altered_question: R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner and others are not regarded as comic what?

title: Comics
original_context: ['Panels are individual images containing a segment of action, often surrounded by a border. Prime moments in a narrative are broken down into panels via a process called encapsulation. The reader puts the pieces together via the process of closure by using background knowledge and an understanding of panel relations to combine panels mentally into events. The size, shape, and arrangement of panels each affect the timing and pacing of the narrative. The contents of a panel may be ••asynchronous••, with events depicted in the same image not necessarily occurring at the same time.']
altered_context: Panels are standalone visuals depicting a portion of action, frequently encased by a border. Key instances in a story are divided into panels through a method referred to as encapsulation. The reader merges the elements together through the process of closure by utilizing prior knowledge and an awareness of panel connections to mentally assemble panels into sequences. The dimensions, form, and organization of panels influence the timing and rhythm of the narrative. The content within a panel may be ••asynchronous••, meaning the events illustrated in the same image are not necessarily occurring simultaneously.
original_question: When a comic panel has events that are not at the same time the panel is considered to be what?
altered_question: When a comic panel features events that do not occur simultaneously, how is the panel described?

title: Saint_Helena

title: Aspirated_consonant
original_context: ['They are unaspirated for almost all speakers when immediately following word-initial s, as in spill, still, skill. After an s elsewhere in a word they are normally unaspirated as well, except sometimes in compound words. When the consonants in a cluster like st are analyzed as belonging to different morphemes (heteromorphemic) the stop is aspirated, but when they are analyzed as belonging to one morpheme the stop is unaspirated.[citation needed] For instance, ••distend•• has unaspirated [t] since it is not analyzed as two morphemes, but distaste has an aspirated middle [tʰ] because it is analyzed as dis- + taste and the word taste has an aspirated initial t.']
altered_context: For nearly all speakers, they are not aspirated when directly following a word-initial s, exemplified by spill, still, skill. Typically, they remain unaspirated after an s at other positions within a word, barring certain instances in compound words. When consonants in a cluster, such as st, are regarded as belonging to separate morphemes (heteromorphemic), the stop becomes aspirated; however, when considered as part of a single morpheme, the stop is unaspirated. For example, ••distend•• features an unaspirated [t] because it is not perceived as two morphemes, while distaste contains an aspirated middle [tʰ] due to its analysis as dis- + taste, as the word taste has an aspirated initial t.

title: Aspirated_consonant
original_context: ['So-called voiced ••aspirated consonants•• are nearly always pronounced instead with breathy voice, a type of phonation or vibration of the vocal folds. The modifier letter ⟨◌ʰ⟩ after a voiced consonant actually represents a breathy-voiced or murmured dental stop, as with the voiced aspirated bilabial stop ⟨bʰ⟩ in the Indo-Aryan languages. This consonant is therefore more accurately transcribed as ⟨b̤⟩, with the diacritic for breathy voice, or with the modifier letter ⟨bʱ⟩, a superscript form of the symbol for the voiced glottal fricative ⟨ɦ⟩.']
altered_context: ['The so-called voiced aspirated consonants are generally articulated instead with a breathy voice, which is a type of phonation or vibration produced by the vocal folds. The diacritic symbol ⟨◌ʰ⟩ following a voiced consonant actually denotes a breathy-voiced or murmured dental stop, similar to the voiced aspirated bilabial stop ⟨bʰ⟩ found in the Indo-Aryan languages. Consequently, this consonant is more precisely transcribed as ⟨b̤⟩, employing the diacritic for breathy voice, or with the modifier letter ⟨bʱ⟩, a superscript variant of the symbol for the voiced glottal fricative ⟨ɦ⟩.']
original_question: What causes a murmured vibration of the vocal cords?
altered_question: What leads to a murmured vibration of the vocal folds?

This consonant is therefore more accurately transcribed as ⟨b̤⟩, with the diacritic for breathy voice, or with the modifier letter ⟨bʱ⟩, a superscript form of the symbol for the voiced glottal fricative ⟨ɦ⟩.']
altered_context: Voiced aspirated consonants, often referred to as such, are almost invariably articulated with a breathy voice, which is a form of phonation or vibration involving the vocal cords. The modifier character ⟨◌ʰ⟩ that follows a voiced consonant actually denotes a breathy-voiced or murmuring dental stop, similar to the voiced aspirated bilabial stop ⟨bʰ⟩ found in the Indo-Aryan languages. Hence, this consonant is more precisely represented as ⟨b̤⟩, incorporating the diacritic for breathy voice, or with the modifier character ⟨bʱ⟩, which is a superscript variant of the symbol for the voiced glottal fricative ⟨ɦ⟩.

title: Hydrogen
original_context: ['The universal emergence of atomic hydrogen first occurred during the recombination epoch. At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, nonmetallic, highly combustible diatomic gas with the molecular formula H2. Since hydrogen readily forms covalent compounds with most non-metallic elements, most of the hydrogen on Earth exists in molecular forms such as in the form of water or organic compounds. ', 'Hydrogen plays a particularly important role in acid--base reactions as many acid-base reactions involve the exchange of protons between soluble molecules. In ionic compounds, hydrogen can take the form of a ••negative•• charge (i.e., anion) when it is known as a hydride, or as a positively charged (i.e., cation) species denoted by the symbol H+. The hydrogen cation is written as though composed of a bare proton, but in reality, hydrogen cations in ionic compounds are always more complex species than that would suggest. As the only neutral atom for which the Schrödinger equation can be solved analytically, study of the energetics and bonding of the hydrogen atom has played a key role in the development of quantum mechanics.']
altered_context: ["The global appearance of atomic hydrogen initially took place during the recombination phase. Under standard conditions of temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a clear, scentless, flavorless, non-poisonous, nonmetallic, and highly flammable diatomic gas represented by the molecular formula H2. Due to hydrogen's tendency to easily create covalent compounds with a majority of non-metallic elements, most hydrogen on our planet is found in molecular forms, such as in water or organic substances. ", 'Hydrogen holds a particularly significant function in acid-base reactions as numerous acid-base interactions involve the transfer of protons among soluble molecules. In ionic compounds, hydrogen can manifest as a ••negative•• charge (i.e., anion) when referred to as a hydride, or as a positively charged (i.e., cation) entity represented by the symbol H+. The hydrogen cation is expressed as if made up of a lone proton; however, in actuality, hydrogen cations in ionic compounds are invariably more intricate entities than such a representation would imply. Being the sole neutral atom for which the Schrödinger equation can be analytically solved, the examination of the energetics and bonding of the hydrogen atom has been instrumental in the establishment of quantum mechanics.']
original_question: What charge does hydrogen display in ionic compounds when it is called a hydride?
altered_question: What type of charge does hydrogen exhibit in ionic compounds when it is referred to as a hydride?

title: Hydrogen
original_context: ["The energy levels of hydrogen can be calculated fairly accurately using the Bohr model of the atom, which conceptualizes the electron as orbiting the proton in analogy to the Earth's orbit of the Sun. However, the electromagnetic force attracts ••electrons and protons•• to one another, while planets and celestial objects are attracted to each other by gravity. Because of the discretization of angular momentum postulated in early quantum mechanics by Bohr, the electron in the Bohr model can only occupy certain allowed distances from the proton, and therefore only certain allowed energies."]
altered_context: The energy levels of hydrogen can be computed with considerable precision utilizing the Bohr model of the atom, which envisions the electron as circling the proton similar to the Earth's path around the Sun. However, the electromagnetic force draws ••electrons and protons•• toward each other, while planets and celestial bodies are drawn to one another through gravitational attraction. Due to the quantization of angular momentum proposed in early quantum mechanics by Bohr, the electron in the Bohr model is restricted to occupy specific permitted distances from the proton, and consequently, only certain allowed energy levels.
original_question: What does the electromagnetic force attract to one another?
altered_question: What does the electromagnetic force pull towards one another?

title: Hydrogen
original_context: ['There exist two different spin isomers of hydrogen diatomic molecules that differ by the relative spin of their nuclei. In the orthohydrogen form, the spins of the two protons are parallel and form a triplet state with a molecular spin quantum number of 1 (1/2+1/2)؛ in the parahydrogen form the spins are antiparallel and form a singlet with a molecular spin quantum number of 0 (1/2--1/2). At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen gas contains about ••25%•• of the para form and 75% of the ortho form, also known as the normal form. ', 'The equilibrium ratio of orthohydrogen to parahydrogen depends on temperature, but because the ortho form is an excited state and has a higher energy than the para form, it is unstable and cannot be purified. At very low temperatures, the equilibrium state is composed almost exclusively of the para form. The liquid and gas phase thermal properties of pure parahydrogen differ significantly from those of the normal form because of differences in rotational heat capacities, as discussed more fully in spin isomers of hydrogen. The ortho/para distinction also occurs in other hydrogen-containing molecules or functional groups, such as water and methylene, but is of little significance for their thermal properties.']
altered_context: ['There are two distinct spin isomers of hydrogen diatomic molecules that vary by the relative spin of their nuclei. In the orthohydrogen configuration, the spins of the two protons align parallel and create a triplet state with a molecular spin quantum number of 1 (1/2+1/2); in the parahydrogen configuration, the spins are aligned antiparallel and result in a singlet with a molecular spin quantum number of 0 (1/2--1/2). Under standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen gas comprises approximately ••25%•• of the para variant and 75% of the ortho variant, commonly referred to as the normal variant.', 'The equilibrium proportion of orthohydrogen to parahydrogen is temperature-dependent, but since the ortho variant is an excited state and possesses more energy than the para variant, it is unstable and cannot be isolated. At extremely low temperatures, the equilibrium condition is primarily made up of the para variant. The thermal characteristics of pure parahydrogen in both liquid and gas phases exhibit considerable differences from those of the normal variant due to variations in rotational heat capacities, as elaborated further in discussions on spin isomers of hydrogen. The ortho/para variation is also seen in other hydrogen-containing entities or functional groups, such as water and methylene, but it holds minimal importance for their thermal behaviors.']
original_question: What percent of para form does hydrogen gas contain?
altered_question: What is the percentage of the para variant present in hydrogen gas?

title: Hydrogen
original_context: ["The first non-stop transatlantic crossing was made by the British airship R34 in ••1919••. Regular passenger service resumed in the 1920s and the discovery of helium reserves in the United States promised increased safety, but the U.S. government refused to sell the gas for this purpose. Therefore, H2 was used in the Hindenburg airship, which was destroyed in a midair fire over New Jersey on 6 May 1937. The incident was broadcast live on radio and filmed. Ignition of leaking hydrogen is widely assumed to be the cause, but later investigations pointed to the ignition of the aluminized fabric coating by static electricity. But the damage to hydrogen's reputation as a lifting gas was already done."]

Consistent passenger operations recommenced in the 1920s and the revelation of helium deposits in the United States indicated enhanced safety, yet the U.S. authorities declined to provide the gas for this intention. Consequently, H2 was utilized in the Hindenburg dirigible, which met its demise in a midair conflagration above New Jersey on 6 May 1937. The event was transmitted live via radio and also filmed. The ignition of escaping hydrogen is commonly believed to be the culprit, but subsequent inquiries attributed the fault to the ignition of the aluminized fabric covering by static electricity. However, the harm to hydrogen's status as a lifting gas had already been inflicted."]

title: Hydrogen
original_context: ['Hydrogen poses a number of hazards to human safety, from potential detonations and fires when mixed with air to being an asphyxiant in its pure, oxygen-free form. In addition, liquid hydrogen is a cryogen and presents dangers (such as frostbite) associated with very cold liquids. Hydrogen dissolves in many metals, and, in addition to leaking out, may have adverse effects on them, such as hydrogen embrittlement, leading to ••cracks and explosions••. Hydrogen gas leaking into external air may spontaneously ignite. Moreover, hydrogen fire, while being extremely hot, is almost invisible, and thus can lead to accidental burns.']
altered_context: ['Hydrogen presents various threats to human safety, ranging from possible explosions and fires when combined with air to serving as an asphyxiant in its pure, oxygen-free state. Additionally, liquid hydrogen functions as a cryogenic substance and carries risks (such as frostbite) linked to extremely cold liquids. Hydrogen can dissolve in multiple metals, and aside from leaking out, it may also have negative impacts on them, including hydrogen embrittlement, which can result in ••fractures and detonations••. Hydrogen gas escaping into ambient air can ignite spontaneously. Furthermore, hydrogen flames, although being highly intense, are nearly invisible, leading to potential accidental burns.']

title: Space_Race
original_context: ["The German rocket center in Peenemünde was located in the eastern part of Germany, which became the Soviet zone of occupation. On Stalin's orders, the Soviet Union sent its best rocket engineers to this region to see what they could salvage for future weapons systems. The Soviet rocket engineers were led by ••Sergei Korolev••. He had been involved in space clubs and early Soviet rocket design in the 1930s, but was arrested in 1938 during Joseph Stalin's Great Purge and imprisoned for six years in Siberia. After the war, he became the USSR's chief rocket and spacecraft engineer, essentially the Soviet counterpart to von Braun. His identity was kept a state secret throughout the Cold War, and he was identified publicly only as the Chief Designer. In the West, his name was only officially revealed when he died in 1966."]
altered_context: ["The German missile facility in Peenemünde was situated in the eastern region of Germany, which turned into the Soviet zone of occupation. Following Stalin's directives, the Soviet Union dispatched its top rocket engineers to this area to determine what they could recover for future weaponry. The Soviet rocket engineering team was headed by ••Sergei Korolev••. He had participated in space organizations and early Soviet rocketry in the 1930s but was imprisoned in 1938 during Joseph Stalin's Great Purge and spent six years in a Siberian labor camp. After the conflict, he rose to become the USSR's principal rocket and spacecraft engineer, effectively serving as the Soviet equivalent to von Braun. His identity remained a state secret during the Cold War, and he was known publicly only as the Chief Designer. In the Western world, his name was not officially made public until his passing in 1966."]

title: Space_Race
original_context: ["The US reacted to the Luna program by embarking on the Ranger program in 1959, managed by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The Block I Ranger 1 and Ranger 2 suffered Atlas-Agena launch failures in August and November 1961. The 727-pound (330 kg) Block II Ranger 3 launched successfully on January 26, 1962, but missed the Moon. The 730-pound (330 kg) Ranger 4 became the first US spacecraft to reach the Moon, but its solar panels and navigational system failed near the Moon and it impacted the far side without returning any scientific data. Ranger 5 ran out of power and missed the Moon by 725 kilometers (391 nmi) on October 21, 1962. The first successful Ranger mission was the 806-pound (366 kg) ••Block III Ranger 7•• which impacted on July 31, 1964."]
altered_context: ["The United States responded to the Luna initiative by initiating the Ranger program in 1959, overseen by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The Block I Ranger 1 and Ranger 2 experienced launch failures with the Atlas-Agena in August and November of 1961. The 727-pound (330 kg) Block II Ranger 3 was successfully launched on January 26, 1962, yet failed to reach the Moon. The 730-pound (330 kg) Ranger 4 became the initial US spacecraft to touch the Moon, however, its solar panels and navigation system malfunctioned close to the Moon, and it collided with the far side without transmitting any scientific information. Ranger 5 depleted its energy and missed the Moon by 725 kilometers (391 nautical miles) on October 21, 1962. The first successful Ranger mission was the 806-pound (366 kg) Block III Ranger 7, which impacted on July 31, 1964."]
original_question: The first Ranger mission that didn't fail was which one?
altered_question: Which was the first Ranger mission that was successful?

title: Space_Race
original_context: ["By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called ••Vostok 1••. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as sailor of the universe. ", "Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution؛ medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its reentry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejecting from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft), and landing by parachute. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (International Federation of Aeronautics) credited Gagarin with the world's first human space flight, although their qualifying rules for aeronautical records at the time required pilots to take off and land with their craft. For this reason, the Soviet Union omitted from their FAI submission the fact that Gagarin did not land with his capsule. ", "When the FAI filing for Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 disclosed the ejection landing technique, the FAI committee decided to investigate, and concluded that the technological accomplishment of human spaceflight lay in the safe launch, orbiting, and return, rather than the manner of landing, and so revised their rules accordingly, keeping Gagarin's and Titov's records intact."]
altered_context: ["By 1959, United States observers were convinced that the Soviet Union would be the initial nation to launch a human into space, due to the duration required to prepare for Mercury's inaugural launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR astonished the globe once more by sending Yuri Gagarin on a singular orbit around the planet in a vehicle they named ••Vostok 1••. They referred to Gagarin as the first cosmonaut, which can be roughly interpreted from Russian and Greek as mariner of the cosmos.", 'Even though he had the capability to assume manual control of his spacecraft in the event of an emergency by accessing an envelope he possessed in the cabin that included a code to be entered into the computer, it was operated in an automatic mode as a safety measure; medical science at that period was unaware of the effects on a human being in the zero gravity of space. Vostok 1 orbited the planet for 108 minutes, reentering over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejecting from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft) and landing via parachute. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (International Federation of Aeronautics) recognized Gagarin with the world’s first human space flight, although their criteria for aeronautical records at that time mandated that pilots must take off and land with their vehicles. Consequently, the Soviet Union excluded from their FAI submission the detail that Gagarin did not touch down with his capsule.', "When the FAI report for Gherman Titov's second Vostok mission in August 1961 revealed the ejection landing method, the FAI committee opted to examine the matter and ultimately determined that the technological achievement of human spaceflight resided in the safe launch, orbiting, and return, rather than the specific landing technique, thus modifying their regulations accordingly, preserving Gagarin's and Titov's records."]
original_question: The first ship to carry a human through space was called what?
altered_question: What was the designation of the first vessel to transport a human through outer space?

title: Space_Race

Though he did not achieve orbit like Gagarin, he was the first person to exercise manual control over his spacecraft's attitude and retro-rocket firing. After his successful return, Shepard was celebrated as a national hero, honored with parades in Washington, New York and Los Angeles, and received the NASA Distinguished Service Medal from President John F. Kennedy."]

Following his triumphant return, Shepard was lauded as a national hero, celebrated with parades in Washington, New York, and Los Angeles, and was awarded the NASA Distinguished Service Medal by President John F. Kennedy."]

title: Space_Race
original_context: ["Salyut 1's orbit was increased to prevent premature reentry, but further piloted flights were delayed while the Soyuz was redesigned to fix the new safety problem. The station re-entered the Earth's atmosphere on October 11, after 175 days in orbit. The USSR attempted to launch a second Salyut-class station designated Durable Orbital Station-2 (DOS-2) on July 29, 1972, but a ••rocket failure•• caused it to fail to achieve orbit. After the DOS-2 failure, the USSR attempted to launch four more Salyut-class stations through 1975, with another failure due to an explosion of the final rocket stage, which punctured the station with shrapnel so that it wouldn't hold pressure. While all of the Salyuts were presented to the public as non-military scientific laboratories, some of them were actually covers for the military Almaz reconnaissance stations."]

The USSR made an effort to launch a second Salyut-class station called Durable Orbital Station-2 (DOS-2) on July 29, 1972, but a ••rocket malfunction•• led to its failure to attain orbit. Subsequent to the DOS-2 mishap, the USSR endeavored to launch four more Salyut-class stations up to 1975, encountering another setback due to an explosion in the final stage of the rocket, which damaged the station with debris, rendering it unable to maintain pressure. title: Web_browser
original_context: ["In 1993, browser software was further innovated by Marc Andreessen with the release of Mosaic, the world's first popular browser, which made the World Wide Web system easy to use and more accessible to the average person. Andreesen's browser sparked the internet boom of the 1990s. The introduction of Mosaic in 1993 -- one of the first graphical web browsers -- led to an explosion in web use. Andreessen, the leader of the Mosaic team at National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), soon started his own company, named ••Netscape••, and released the Mosaic-influenced Netscape Navigator in 1994, which quickly became the world's most popular browser, accounting for 90% of all web use at its peak (see usage share of web browsers)."]

Many browsers also support a variety of other prefixes, such as https: for HTTPS, ftp: for the File Transfer Protocol, and file: for local files. Prefixes that the web browser cannot directly handle are ••often handed off to another application entirely••. For example, mailto: URIs are usually passed to the user's default e-mail application, and news: URIs are passed to the user's default newsgroup reader."]

(Juris Canonici Licentiatus, Licentiate of Canon Law) and the J.C.D. (Juris Canonici Doctor, Doctor of Canon Law). title: Canon_law
original_context: ['Much of the legislative style was adapted from the Roman Law Code of Justinian. As a result, Roman ecclesiastical courts tend to follow the Roman Law style of continental Europe with some variation, featuring collegiate panels of judges and an investigative form of proceeding, called inquisitorial, from the Latin inquirere, to enquire. This is in contrast to the adversarial form of proceeding found in the ••common law system of English and U.S. law••, which features such things as juries and single judges.']
altered_context: A significant portion of the legislative approach was influenced by the Roman Law Code established by Justinian. Consequently, Roman ecclesiastical tribunals generally adhere to the Roman Law style customary in continental Europe, albeit with some discrepancies, characterized by groups of judges and an inquiry-based process known as inquisitorial, derived from the Latin word inquirere, meaning to inquire. This stands in opposition to the adversarial procedural model prevalent in the common law framework of English and U.S. jurisprudence, which incorporates elements like juries and individual judges.

altered_question: Which additional legal system do ecclesiastical courts possess an adversarial nature with?

title: Canon_law
original_context: ["The Greek-speaking ••Orthodox•• have collected canons and commentaries upon them in a work known as the Pēdálion (Greek: Πηδάλιον, Rudder), so named because it is meant to steer the Church. The Orthodox Christian tradition in general treats its canons more as guidelines than as laws, the bishops adjusting them to cultural and other local circumstances. Some Orthodox canon scholars point out that, had the Ecumenical Councils (which deliberated in Greek) meant for the canons to be used as laws, they would have called them nómoi/νόμοι (laws) rather than kanónes/κανόνες (rules), but almost all Orthodox conform to them. The dogmatic decisions of the Councils, though, are to be obeyed rather than to be treated as guidelines, since they are essential for the Church's unity."]

Some scholars of Orthodox canon highlight that, had the Ecumenical Councils (which convened in Greek) intended for the canons to function as laws, they would have designated them nómoi/νόμοι (laws) instead of kanónes/κανόνες (rules), yet nearly all Orthodox adhere to them. title: Communications_in_Somalia
original_context: ['Communications in Somalia encompasses the communications services and capacity of Somalia. Telecommunications, internet, radio, print, television and postal services in the nation are largely concentrated in the private sector. Several of the telecom firms have begun expanding their activities abroad. The Federal government operates two official radio and television networks, which exist alongside a number of private and foreign stations. Print media in the country is also progressively giving way to news radio stations and online portals, as internet connectivity and access increases. Additionally, the national postal service is slated to be officially relaunched in 2013 after a long absence. In ••2012••, a National Communications Act was also approved by Cabinet members, which lays the foundation for the establishment of a National Communications regulator in the broadcasting and telecommunications sectors.']
altered_context: Communications in Somalia includes the communication services and capabilities available within the country. Telecommunications, the internet, radio, print media, television, and postal services are predominantly focused in the private domain. A number of telecom companies have started broadening their operations internationally. The Federal government manages two official radio and television stations, which coexist with several private and international broadcasters. Print journalism in the nation is increasingly giving way to news radio outlets and digital platforms, as internet access and connectivity improve. Furthermore, the national postal service is expected to be officially reinstated in 2013 after a prolonged absence. In 2012, a National Communications Act was also sanctioned by Cabinet officials, which provides the groundwork for the creation of a National Communications regulator within the broadcasting and telecommunications fields.
original_question: When was the National Communications Act dismantled?
altered_question: When was the National Communications Act revoked?

title: Communications_in_Somalia
original_context: ["In 2008, Dahabshiil Group acquired a majority stake in Somtel Network, a ••Hargeisa••-based telecommunications firm specialising in high speed broadband, mobile internet, LTE services, mobile money transfer and mobile phone services. The acquisition provided Dahabshiil with the necessary platform for a subsequent expansion into mobile banking, a growth industry in the regional banking sector. In 2014, Somalia's three largest telecommunication operators, Hormuud Telecom, NationLink and Somtel, also signed an interconnection agreement. The cooperative deal will see the firms establish the Somali Telecommunication Company (STC), which will allow their mobile clients to communicate across the three networks."]
altered_context: In 2008, the Dahabshiil Group secured a controlling interest in Somtel Network, a telecommunications company based in ••Hargeisa•• that focuses on high-speed broadband, mobile internet, LTE solutions, mobile money transfers, and mobile telephony services. This acquisition enabled Dahabshiil to gain a crucial foundation for future growth into mobile banking, which is a burgeoning sector within regional finance. By 2014, the three largest telecom companies in Somalia, Hormuud Telecom, NationLink, and Somtel, had entered into an interconnection agreement. This collaborative arrangement will facilitate the creation of the Somali Telecommunication Company (STC), allowing their mobile users to connect across the three networks.

title: Communications_in_Somalia
original_context: ["Concurrently, the Somali Transitional Federal Government began preparations to revive the national postal service. The government's overall reconstruction plan for Somali Post is structured into three Phases spread out over a period of ten years. Phase I will see the reconstruction of the postal headquarters and General Post Office (GPO), as well as the establishment of ••16•• branch offices in the capital and 17 in regional bases. As of March 2012, the Somali authorities have re-established Somalia's membership with the Universal Postal Union (UPU), and taken part once again in the Union's affairs. They have also rehabilitated the GPO in Mogadishu, and appointed an official Postal Consultant to provide professional advice on the renovations. Phase II of the rehabilitation project involves the construction of 718 postal outlets from 2014 to 2016. Phase III is slated to begin in 2017, with the objective of creating 897 postal outlets by 2022."]
altered_context: ["Simultaneously, the Somali Transitional Federal Government initiated preparations to rejuvenate the national postal service. The government’s comprehensive rebuilding strategy for Somali Post is divided into three Phases extending over a decade. Phase I will involve the reconstruction of the postal headquarters and the General Post Office (GPO), along with the establishment of 16 branch offices in the capital and 17 in regional locations. As of March 2012, the Somali authorities have reinstated Somalia's membership with the Universal Postal Union (UPU) and re-engaged in the Union's matters. They have also restored the GPO in Mogadishu and appointed an official Postal Consultant to offer expert guidance on the updates. Phase II of the renovation initiative encompasses the development of 718 postal facilities from 2014 to 2016. Phase III is planned to commence in 2017, aiming to establish 897 postal facilities by 2022."]

', 'The main clients of these local satellite services were internet cafes, money transfer firms and other companies, as well as international community representatives. In total, there were over 300 local satellite terminals available aross the nation, which were linked to teleports in Europe and Asia. Demand for the satellite services gradually began to fall as broadband wireless access rose. However, it increased in rural areas, as the main client base for the satellite services extended their operations into more remote locales.']

title: Catalan_language
original_context: ['Catalan evolved from Vulgar Latin around the eastern Pyrenees in the 9th century. During the Low Middle Ages it saw a golden age as the literary and dominant language of the Crown of Aragon, and was widely used all over the Mediterranean. The union of Aragon with the other territories of Spain in ••1479•• marked the start of the decline of the language. In 1659 Spain ceded Northern Catalonia to France, and Catalan was banned in both states in the early 18th century. 19th-century Spain saw a Catalan literary revival, which culminated in the 1913 orthographic standardization, and the officialization of the language during the Second Spanish Republic (1931--39). However, the Francoist dictatorship (1939--75) banned the language again.']
altered_context: Catalan originated from Vulgar Latin in the eastern Pyrenees during the 9th century. Throughout the early Middle Ages, it experienced a golden era as the primary literary tongue of the Crown of Aragon and was extensively utilized across the Mediterranean region. The merger of Aragon with the other regions of Spain in ••1479•• signified the beginning of the language's decline. In 1659, Spain transferred Northern Catalonia to France, and during the early 18th century, Catalan was prohibited in both nations. The 19th century in Spain witnessed a resurgence of Catalan literature, peaking with the orthographic standardization in 1913 and the official recognition of the language during the Second Spanish Republic (1931--39). title: Boston
original_context: ["Boston's early European settlers had first called the area Trimountaine (after its three mountains--only traces of which remain today) but later renamed it Boston after Boston, Lincolnshire, England, the origin of several prominent colonists. Their settlement was initially limited to the Shawmut Peninsula, at that time surrounded by the Massachusetts Bay and Charles River and connected to the mainland by a narrow isthmus. The peninsula is known to have been inhabited as early as 5000 BC."]

title: Boston

Until the early 20th century, Boston remained one of the nation's largest manufacturing centers and was notable for its garment production and leather-goods industries. A network of small rivers bordering the city and connecting it to the surrounding region facilitated shipment of goods and led to a proliferation of mills and factories. Later, a dense network of railroads furthered the region's industry and commerce."]

title: Boston
original_context: ["Boston has been a noted religious center from its earliest days. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston serves nearly 300 parishes and is based in the Cathedral of the Holy Cross (1875) in the South End, while the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, with the Cathedral Church of St. Paul (1819) as its episcopal seat, serves just under 200 congregations. Unitarian Universalism has its headquarters on Beacon Hill. The Christian Scientists are headquartered in Back Bay at the Mother Church (1894). The oldest church in Boston is First Church in Boston, founded in 1630. ••King's Chapel••, the city's first Anglican church, was founded in 1686 and converted to Unitarianism in 1785. Other churches include Christ Church (better known as Old North Church, 1723), the oldest church building in the city, Trinity Church (1733), Park Street Church (1809), Old South Church (1874), Jubilee Christian Church and Basilica and Shrine of Our Lady of Perpetual Help on Mission Hill (1878)."]

The headquarters of Unitarian Universalism can be found on Beacon Hill. The Christian Scientists operate from Back Bay at the Mother Church (1894). title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["Despite Laemmle's role as an innovator, he was an extremely cautious studio chief. Unlike rivals Adolph Zukor, William Fox, and Marcus Loew, Laemmle chose not to develop a theater chain. He also financed all of his own films, refusing to take on debt. This policy nearly bankrupted the studio when actor-director Erich von Stroheim insisted on excessively lavish production values for his films Blind Husbands (1919) and Foolish Wives (••1922••), but Universal shrewdly gained a return on some of the expenditure by launching a sensational ad campaign that attracted moviegoers. Character actor Lon Chaney became a drawing card for Universal in the 1920s, appearing steadily in dramas. ", "His two biggest hits for Universal were The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923) and The Phantom of the Opera (1925). During this period Laemmle entrusted most of the production policy decisions to Irving Thalberg. Thalberg had been Laemmle's personal secretary, and Laemmle was impressed by his cogent observations of how efficiently the studio could be operated. Promoted to studio chief, Thalberg was giving Universal's product a touch of class, but MGM's head of production Louis B. Mayer lured Thalberg away from Universal with a promise of better pay. Without his guidance Universal became a second-tier studio, and would remain so for several decades."]
altered_context: ["Although Laemmle was a pioneer in the film industry, he was an exceedingly prudent studio executive. In contrast to competitors Adolph Zukor, William Fox, and Marcus Loew, Laemmle opted not to establish a network of theaters. He also financed all of his films independently, avoiding any loans. This strategy nearly led to the studio's financial ruin when actor-director Erich von Stroheim demanded overly extravagant production standards for his films Blind Husbands (1919) and Foolish Wives (••1922••), yet Universal cleverly recouped some of the costs by initiating a captivating advertising campaign that drew in audiences. Character actor Lon Chaney emerged as a major attraction for Universal throughout the 1920s, consistently featuring in dramas.", "His two largest successes for Universal were The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923) and The Phantom of the Opera (1925). During this time, Laemmle delegated most of the production policy choices to Irving Thalberg. Thalberg had served as Laemmle's personal assistant, and Laemmle was impressed by his insightful remarks about how effectively the studio could be run. Promoted to the position of studio head, Thalberg added a touch of sophistication to Universal’s output, but MGM's production chief Louis B. Mayer enticed Thalberg away from Universal by offering him a more lucrative salary. Without his direction, Universal slipped to a lower tier of studios, a status it would hold for many years."]

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["In ••1926••, Universal opened a production unit in Germany, Deutsche Universal-Film AG, under the direction of Joe Pasternak. This unit produced three to four films per year until 1936, migrating to Hungary and then Austria in the face of Hitler's increasing domination of central Europe. With the advent of sound, these productions were made in the German language or, occasionally, Hungarian or Polish. In the U.S., Universal Pictures did not distribute any of this subsidiary's films, but at least some of them were exhibited through other, independent, foreign-language film distributors based in New York, without benefit of English subtitles. Nazi persecution and a change in ownership for the parent Universal Pictures organization resulted in the dissolution of this subsidiary."]

With the introduction of sound, these films were created in the German language or occasionally in Hungarian or Polish. In the United States, Universal Pictures did not release any films from this subsidiary, but a number of them were shown by other independent foreign-language film distributors based in New York, without the aid of English subtitles. Included among these kin was the future Academy Award-winning director/producer ••William Wyler••.

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["As Universal's main product had always been low-budget film, it was one of the last major studios to have a contract with Technicolor. The studio did not make use of the three-strip Technicolor process until Arabian Nights (••1942••), starring Jon Hall and Maria Montez. The following year, Technicolor was also used in Universal's remake of their 1925 horror melodrama, Phantom of the Opera with Claude Rains and Nelson Eddy. With the success of their first two pictures, a regular schedule of high-budget, Technicolor films followed."]

The subsequent year, Technicolor was similarly employed in Universal's reimagining of their 1925 horror drama, Phantom of the Opera, starring Claude Rains and Nelson Eddy. Following the triumph of their first two movies, a regular lineup of high-budget, Technicolor productions ensued."]

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["Though Decca would continue to keep picture budgets lean, it was favored by changing circumstances in the film business, as other studios let their contract actors go in the wake of the 1948 U.S. vs. Paramount Pictures, et al. decision. Leading actors were increasingly free to work where and when they chose, and in 1950 MCA agent Lew Wasserman made a deal with Universal for his client ••James Stewart•• that would change the rules of the business. Wasserman's deal gave Stewart a share in the profits of three pictures in lieu of a large salary. When one of those films, Winchester '73, proved to be a hit, the arrangement would become the rule for many future productions at Universal, and eventually at other studios as well."]
altered_context: ["Although Decca intended to maintain modest budgets for films, it benefited from shifting conditions in the movie industry, as other companies released their contracted stars following the 1948 U.S. vs. Paramount Pictures, et al. verdict. Prominent actors were increasingly liberated to choose when and where to work, and in 1950, MCA agent Lew Wasserman struck a deal with Universal for his client ••James Stewart•• that would alter the dynamics of the industry. Wasserman's agreement granted Stewart a percentage of the earnings from three films instead of receiving a high salary. When one of those movies, Winchester '73, turned out to be successful, this arrangement would become standard practice for many subsequent productions at Universal, and ultimately at other companies as well."]

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ['The long-awaited takeover of Universal Pictures by MCA, Inc. happened in mid-1962 as part of the MCA-Decca Records merger. The company reverted in name to Universal Pictures. As a final gesture before leaving the talent agency business, virtually every MCA client was signed to a Universal contract. In 1964 MCA formed Universal City Studios, Inc., merging the motion pictures and television arms of Universal Pictures Company and Revue Productions (officially renamed as ••Universal Television•• in 1966). ', "And so, with MCA in charge, Universal became a full-blown, A-film movie studio, with leading actors and directors under contract؛ offering slick, commercial films؛ and a studio tour subsidiary launched in 1964. Television production made up much of the studio's output, with Universal heavily committed, in particular, to deals with NBC (which later merged with Universal to form NBC Universal؛ see below) providing up to half of all prime time shows for several seasons. An innovation during this period championed by Universal was the made-for-television movie."]
altered_context: ['The much-anticipated acquisition of Universal Pictures by MCA, Inc. took place in the middle of 1962 as a component of the MCA-Decca Records amalgamation. The organization reverted in title to Universal Pictures. As a final act before exiting the talent agency sector, nearly every MCA client was contracted with Universal. In 1964, MCA established Universal City Studios, Inc., combining the film and television divisions of Universal Pictures Company and Revue Productions (which was officially renamed as ••Universal Television•• in 1966). ', "Thus, with MCA at the helm, Universal transformed into a fully-fledged, major film studio, securing top-tier actors and directors under agreements; producing polished, commercial movies; and initiating a studio tour subsidiary in 1964. Television production constituted a significant portion of the studio's output, with Universal deeply engaged, particularly in arrangements with NBC (which later consolidated with Universal to create NBC Universal; see below) providing up to half of all prime time programming for multiple seasons. A notable advancement during this time advocated by Universal was the television film made specifically for the small screen."]

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["Anxious to expand the company's broadcast and cable presence, longtime MCA head Lew Wasserman sought a rich partner. He located Japanese electronics manufacturer Matsushita Electric (now known as ••Panasonic••), which agreed to acquire MCA for $6.6 billion in 1990. Meanwhile, around this time, the production subsidiary was renamed Universal Studios Inc., and (in 1990) MCA created MCA/Universal Home Video Inc. for the VHS video cassette (later DVD) sales industry."]

Simultaneously, during this period, the production division was rebranded as Universal Studios Inc., and (in 1990) MCA established MCA/Universal Home Video Inc. to enter the VHS video cassette (and later DVD) sales market.

Hoping to build an entertainment empire around Universal, Seagram bought PolyGram in ••1999•• and other entertainment properties, but the fluctuating profits characteristic of Hollywood were no substitute for the reliable income stream gained from the previously held shares in DuPont.']

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["Burdened with debt, in 2004 Vivendi Universal sold 80% of Vivendi Universal Entertainment (including the studio and theme parks) to General Electric, parent of NBC. The resulting media super-conglomerate was renamed NBCUniversal, while Universal Studios Inc. remained the name of the production subsidiary. After that deal, GE owned 80% of NBC Universal؛ Vivendi held the remaining 20%, with an option to sell its share in 2006. GE purchased Vivendi's share in NBCU in 2011 and in turn sold 51% of the company to cable provider ••Comcast••. Comcast merged the former GE subsidiary with its own cable-television programming assets, creating the current NBCUniversal. Following Federal Communications Commission (FCC) approval, the Comcast-GE deal was closed on Jan 29, 2011. In March 2013, Comcast bought the remaining 49% of NBCUniversal for $16.7 billion."]
altered_context: Facing financial strain, in 2004 Vivendi Universal divested 80% of Vivendi Universal Entertainment (which included the studio and theme parks) to General Electric, the parent company of NBC. The resultant media behemoth was rebranded as NBCUniversal, while the production subsidiary retained the title Universal Studios Inc. After this transaction, GE held 80% of NBC Universal; Vivendi kept the remaining 20%, with an option to liquidate its stake in 2006. GE acquired Vivendi's portion in NBCU in 2011 and subsequently sold 51% of the enterprise to the cable operator Comcast. Comcast integrated the previous GE subsidiary with its own cable-television programming resources, leading to the present NBCUniversal. Following the approval from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the agreement between Comcast and GE was finalized on January 29, 2011. In March 2013, Comcast secured the final 49% of NBCUniversal for $16.7 billion.

title: Universal_Studios
original_context: ["In late 2005, Viacom's Paramount Pictures acquired DreamWorks SKG after acquisition talks between GE and DreamWorks stalled. Universal's long time chairperson, ••Stacey Snider••, left the company in early 2006 to head up DreamWorks. Snider was replaced by then-Vice Chairman Marc Shmuger and Focus Features head David Linde. On October 5, 2009, Marc Shmuger and David Linde were ousted and their co-chairperson jobs consolidated under former president of worldwide marketing and distribution Adam Fogelson becoming the single chairperson. Donna Langley was also upped to co-chairperson. In 2009, Stephanie Sperber founded Universal Partnerships & Licensing within Universal to license consumer products for Universal. ", "In September 2013, Adam Fogelson was ousted as co-chairman of Universal Pictures, promoting Donna Langley to sole-chairman. In addition, NBCUniversal International Chairman, Jeff Shell, would be appointed as Chairman of the newly created Filmed Entertainment Group. Longtime studio head Ron Meyer would give up oversight of the film studio and appointed Vice Chairman of NBCUniversal, providing consultation to CEO Steve Burke on all of the company's operations. Meyers still retains oversight of Universal Parks and Resorts."]

Snider was succeeded by the then-Vice Chairman Marc Shmuger and Focus Features leader David Linde. On October 5, 2009, Marc Shmuger and David Linde were removed from their positions, and their co-chairperson roles were unified under former president of global marketing and distribution Adam Fogelson, who became the sole chairperson. Donna Langley was also elevated to co-chairperson. In 2009, Stephanie Sperber established Universal Partnerships & Licensing within Universal to manage the licensing of consumer products for Universal.", 'In September 2013, Adam Fogelson was dismissed as co-chairman of Universal Pictures, resulting in the advancement of Donna Langley to sole chairperson. title: Estonian_language
original_context: ["Like ••Finnish••, Estonian employs the Latin script as the basis for its alphabet, which adds the letters ä, ö, ü, and õ, plus the later additions š and ž. The letters c, q, w, x and y are limited to proper names of foreign origin, and f, z, š, and ž appear in loanwords and foreign names only. Ö and ü are pronounced similarly to their equivalents in Swedish and German. Unlike in standard German but like Finnish and Swedish (when followed by 'r'), Ä is pronounced [æ], as in English mat. The vowels Ä, Ö and Ü are clearly separate phonemes and inherent in Estonian, although the letter shapes come from German. The letter õ denotes /ɤ/, unrounded /o/, or a close-mid back unrounded vowel. It is almost identical to the Bulgarian ъ /ɤ̞/ and the Vietnamese ơ, and is used to transcribe the Russian ы."]
altered_context: ["Similar to ••Finnish••, Estonian utilizes the Latin script as the foundation for its alphabet, incorporating the characters ä, ö, ü, and õ, along with later additions š and ž. The letters c, q, w, x, and y are restricted to proper names of foreign origin, while f, z, š, and ž are found exclusively in loanwords and foreign names. Ö and ü are articulated in a manner akin to their counterparts in Swedish and German. In contrast to standard German but resembling Finnish and Swedish (when followed by 'r'), Ä is pronounced [æ], similar to the English term mat. The vowels Ä, Ö, and Ü are distinctly separate phonemes and intrinsic to Estonian, though the letter forms are derived from German. The character õ signifies /ɤ/, an unrounded /o/, or a close-mid back unrounded vowel. It closely resembles the Bulgarian ъ /ɤ̞/ and the Vietnamese ơ, and is employed to represent the Russian ы."]
original_question: What is another language that uses Latin for its alphabet?

title: Estonian_language
original_context: ['In Estonian, nouns and pronouns do not have grammatical gender, but nouns and adjectives decline in ••fourteen•• cases: nominative, genitive, partitive, illative, inessive, elative, allative, adessive, ablative, translative, terminative, essive, abessive, and comitative, with the case and number of the adjective(s) always agreeing with that of the noun (except in the terminative, essive, abessive and comitative, where there is agreement only for the number, the adjective being in the genitive form). Thus the illative for kollane maja (a yellow house) is kollasesse majja (into a yellow house), but the terminative is kollase majani (as far as a yellow house). With respect to the Proto-Finnic language, elision has occurred؛ thus, the actual case marker may be absent, but the stem is changed, cf. maja -- majja and the Pohjanmaa dialect of Finnish maja -- majahan.']
altered_context: In Estonian, nouns and pronouns lack grammatical gender; however, nouns and adjectives inflect in ••fourteen•• cases: nominative, genitive, partitive, illative, inessive, elative, allative, adessive, ablative, translative, terminative, essive, abessive, and comitative, with the case and number of the adjective(s) consistently corresponding with that of the noun (except in the terminative, essive, abessive, and comitative cases, where agreement is only for the number, and the adjective takes the genitive form). Therefore, the illative form for kollane maja (a yellow house) is kollasesse majja (into a yellow house), while the terminative is kollase majani (as far as a yellow house). Regarding the Proto-Finnic language, elision has taken place; hence, the actual case marker may not be present, yet the stem is modified, cf. maja -- majja and the Pohjanmaa dialect of Finnish maja -- majahan.
original_question: How many cases to verbs decline?
altered_question: In how many cases do verbs inflect?

title: Paper
original_context: ['The word paper is etymologically derived from Latin papyrus, which comes from the Greek πάπυρος (papuros), the word for the Cyperus papyrus plant. Papyrus is a thick, paper-like material produced from ••the pith•• of the Cyperus papyrus plant, which was used in ancient Egypt and other Mediterranean cultures for writing before the introduction of paper into the Middle East and Europe. Although the word paper is etymologically derived from papyrus, the two are produced very differently and the development of the first is distinct from the development of the second. Papyrus is a lamination of natural plant fibres, while paper is manufactured from fibres whose properties have been changed by maceration.']
altered_context: The term paper is etymologically sourced from the Latin word papyrus, which traces its origin to the Greek πάπυρος (papuros), referring to the Cyperus papyrus species. Papyrus is a dense, paper-like substance created from ••the pith•• of the Cyperus papyrus plant, historically utilized in ancient Egypt and various Mediterranean societies for writing prior to the arrival of paper in the Middle East and Europe. Despite the fact that the term paper is etymologically linked to papyrus, the processes for producing each are notably different, and the evolution of the first differs from that of the second. Papyrus consists of layers of natural plant fibers, whereas paper is produced from fibers that have undergone a transformation through maceration.

title: Paper

title: Paper
original_context: ["The ISO 216 system used in most other countries is based on the surface area of a sheet of paper, not on a sheet's width and length. It was first adopted in Germany in 1922 and generally spread as nations adopted the metric system. The largest standard size paper is A0 (A zero), measuring one square meter (approx. 1189 × 841 mm). Two sheets of A1, placed upright side by side fit exactly into one sheet of A0 laid on its side. Similarly, two sheets of A2 fit into one sheet of A1 and so forth. Common sizes used in the office and the home are A4 and ••A3•• (A3 is the size of two A4 sheets)."]

This system was initially implemented in Germany in 1922 and gradually propagated as countries embraced the metric system. The largest standard paper size is A0 (A zero), which measures one square meter (approximately 1189 × 841 mm). Two A1 sheets, positioned vertically side by side, fit perfectly into one A0 sheet placed horizontally. In the same way, two A2 sheets fit into one A1 sheet, and so on. title: Paper
original_context: ['Much of the early paper made from wood pulp contained significant amounts of alum, a variety of aluminium sulfate salts that is significantly acidic. Alum was added to paper to assist in ••sizing••, making it somewhat water resistant so that inks did not run or spread uncontrollably. Early papermakers did not realize that the alum they added liberally to cure almost every problem encountered in making their product would eventually be detrimental. The cellulose fibres that make up paper are hydrolyzed by acid, and the presence of alum would eventually degrade the fibres until the paper disintegrated in a process that has come to be known as slow fire. Documents written on rag paper were significantly more stable. The use of non-acidic additives to make paper is becoming more prevalent, and the stability of these papers is less of an issue.']
altered_context: A considerable portion of the initial paper produced from wood pulp included notable quantities of alum, a form of aluminum sulfate salts that is fairly acidic. Alum was incorporated into paper to facilitate ••sizing••, rendering it somewhat resistant to water so that inks would not bleed or disperse excessively. The early papermakers were unaware that the alum they generously added to resolve nearly every challenge faced in creating their product would ultimately be harmful. The cellulose fibers constituting paper are broken down by acid, and the presence of alum would eventually weaken the fibers until the paper collapsed in a situation referred to as slow fire. Documents crafted on rag paper were considerably more durable. The adoption of non-acidic additives for papermaking is increasing, and the durability of these papers poses less of a concern.

altered_question: What process did early papermakers enhance by adding alum?

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['Coordination strategies differ when adjacent time zones shift clocks. The European Union shifts all at once, at 01:00 UTC or 02:00 CET or 03:00 EET؛ for example, Eastern European Time is always one hour ahead of Central European Time. Most of North America shifts at 02:00 local time, so its zones do not shift at the same time؛ for example, Mountain Time is temporarily (for one hour) zero hours ahead of Pacific Time, instead of one hour ahead, in the autumn and two hours, instead of one, ahead of Pacific Time in the spring. In the past, Australian districts went even further and did not always agree on start and end dates؛ for example, in 2008 most DST-observing areas shifted clocks forward on October 5 but Western Australia shifted on October 26. In some cases only part of a country shifts؛ for example, in the US, ••Hawaii•• and most of Arizona do not observe DST.']
altered_context: ['Coordination methods vary when neighboring time zones adjust their clocks. The European Union modifies all simultaneously, at 01:00 UTC or 02:00 CET or 03:00 EET; for instance, Eastern European Time is consistently one hour ahead of Central European Time. A majority of North America alters its clocks at 02:00 local time, thus its zones do not change at the same moment; for example, Mountain Time is briefly (for one hour) at the same time as Pacific Time, rather than one hour ahead, during autumn and is two hours, instead of one, ahead of Pacific Time in the spring. Previously, Australian regions went even further and did not always reach a consensus on start and finish dates; for instance, in 2008 most areas observing DST in Australia advanced their clocks on October 5, while Western Australia did so on October 26. In some instances, only a portion of a country adjusts; for example, in the United States, Hawaii and most of Arizona do not adhere to DST.']
original_question: In addition to much of the state of Arizona, what U.S. state does not ever change their clocks for DST?
altered_question: Besides much of Arizona, which state in the U.S. never alters their clocks for Daylight Saving Time?

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ["The war's end swung the pendulum back. Farmers continued to dislike DST, and many countries repealed it after the war. Britain was an exception: it retained DST nationwide but over the years adjusted transition dates for several reasons, including special rules during the 1920s and 1930s to avoid clock shifts on Easter mornings. The US was more typical: Congress repealed DST after 1919. President Woodrow Wilson, like Willett an avid golfer, vetoed the repeal twice but his second veto was overridden. ", "Only a few US cities retained DST locally thereafter, including ••New York•• so that its financial exchanges could maintain an hour of arbitrage trading with London, and Chicago and Cleveland to keep pace with New York. Wilson's successor Warren G. Harding opposed DST as a deception. Reasoning that people should instead get up and go to work earlier in the summer, he ordered District of Columbia federal employees to start work at 08:00 rather than 09:00 during summer 1922. Some businesses followed suit though many others did not؛ the experiment was not repeated."]
altered_context: ['The conclusion of the conflict swung the pendulum back. Agricultural workers continued to resent Daylight Saving Time, and numerous nations abolished it after the conflict. Britain was an exception: it retained Daylight Saving Time across the nation but over the years modified transition dates for various reasons, including specific regulations during the 1920s and 1930s to prevent clock changes on Easter mornings. The United States was more common: Congress annulled Daylight Saving Time after 1919. President Woodrow Wilson, similar to Willett who was also an enthusiastic golfer, vetoed the annulment two times but his second veto was overruled.', "Only a handful of American cities maintained Daylight Saving Time locally after that, including ••New York•• to ensure its financial markets could sustain an hour of arbitrage trading with London, alongside Chicago and Cleveland to keep in line with New York. Wilson's successor Warren G. Harding disapproved of Daylight Saving Time as a fraud. Arguing that individuals should rather rise and commence work earlier in the summer, he instructed federal workers in the District of Columbia to begin at 08:00 instead of 09:00 during the summer of 1922. Some enterprises complied, although many others did not; the trial was not reinstated."]

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ["Conversely, DST can adversely affect farmers, parents of young children, and others whose hours are set by the sun and they have traditionally opposed the practice, although some farmers are neutral. One reason why farmers oppose DST is that grain is best harvested after dew evaporates, so when field hands arrive and leave earlier in summer their labor is less valuable. Dairy farmers are another group who complain of the change. Their cows are sensitive to the timing of milking, so delivering milk earlier ••disrupts their systems••. Today some farmers' groups are in favor of DST."]
altered_context: ["On the other hand, Daylight Saving Time (DST) can negatively impact agriculturalists, guardians of small children, and others whose schedules are dictated by sunlight, leading to traditional opposition to the phenomenon, though some agriculturalists remain indifferent. A key reason farmers resist DST is that grain is optimally harvested once the dew has dried, so when laborers start and finish earlier in the summer, their work becomes less effective. Another faction of farmers that voices grievances about the adjustment are dairy producers. Their cows are affected by the timing of milking, thus an earlier milk collection ••disturbs their routines••. Presently, certain farmers' organizations endorse DST."]
original_question: What does earlier milk delivery do to cows?
altered_question: How does earlier milk collection impact cows?

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['Changing clocks and DST rules has a direct economic cost, entailing extra work to support remote meetings, computer applications and the like. For example, a 2007 North American rule change cost an estimated $500 million to $1 billion, and Utah State University economist William F. Shughart II has estimated the lost opportunity cost at around $1.7 billion USD. Although it has been argued that clock shifts correlate with ••decreased economic efficiency••, and that in 2000 the daylight-saving effect implied an estimated one-day loss of $31 billion on US stock exchanges, the estimated numbers depend on the methodology. The results have been disputed, and the original authors have refuted the points raised by disputers.']
altered_context: Altering timekeeping and daylight saving time regulations incurs a direct financial impact, requiring additional efforts to facilitate virtual meetings, software applications, and similar tasks. For instance, a modification in North American regulations in 2007 was estimated to cost between $500 million and $1 billion, with economist William F. Shughart II from Utah State University approximating the opportunity cost lost at nearly $1.7 billion USD. While it has been suggested that time changes are linked to ••reduced economic efficiency••, and that in 2000 the impact of daylight saving resulted in an estimated one-day loss of $31 billion on US stock markets, the figures depend on the assessment methods used. The findings have been contested, and the original researchers have countered the objections raised by challengers.

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['In several countries, fire safety officials encourage citizens to use the two annual clock shifts as reminders to replace batteries in smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, particularly in autumn, just before the heating and candle season causes an increase in home fires. Similar twice-yearly tasks include reviewing and practicing fire escape and family disaster plans, inspecting vehicle lights, checking storage areas for ••hazardous materials••, reprogramming thermostats, and seasonal vaccinations. Locations without DST can instead use the first days of spring and autumn as reminders.']

Areas without Daylight Saving Time can alternatively rely on the initial days of spring and fall as hints.']
