title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['Clock shifts were found to increase the risk of heart attack by 10 percent, and to disrupt sleep and reduce its efficiency. Effects on seasonal adaptation of the circadian rhythm can be severe and last for weeks. A 2008 study found that although male suicide rates rise in the weeks after the spring transition, the relationship weakened greatly after adjusting for season. A 2008 Swedish study found that heart attacks were significantly more common the first three weekdays after the spring transition, and significantly less common the first weekday after the autumn transition. The government of ••Kazakhstan•• cited health complications due to clock shifts as a reason for abolishing DST in 2005. In March 2011, Dmitri Medvedev, president of Russia, claimed that stress of changing clocks was the motivation for Russia to stay in DST all year long. Officials at the time talked about an annual increase in suicides.']
altered_context: ['Changing clock times were observed to raise the likelihood of heart attacks by 10 percent, while also disturbing sleep patterns and diminishing its quality. The impact on seasonal adjustments of the circadian rhythm can be significant and persist for several weeks. A research study from 2008 indicated that, although there is an increase in male suicide rates during the weeks following the spring shift, this correlation markedly diminished after accounting for seasonal factors. A similar 2008 study conducted in Sweden revealed that heart attacks occurred significantly more frequently in the initial three weekdays after the spring shift, and were notably less frequent on the first weekday following the autumn shift. The government of ••Kazakhstan•• mentioned health issues stemming from clock changes as a justification for eliminating DST in 2005. In March 2011, Dmitri Medvedev, the president of Russia, asserted that the stress related to changing clocks motivated Russia to remain on DST throughout the entire year. Authorities at that time noted an annual rise in suicides.']
original_question: In 2005, what country used increased health risks as rationalization for getting rid of DST?

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['Microsoft Windows keeps the system real-time clock in ••local time••. This causes several problems, including compatibility when multi booting with operating systems that set the clock to UTC, and double-adjusting the clock when multi booting different Windows versions, such as with a rescue boot disk. This approach is a problem even in Windows-only systems: there is no support for per-user timezone settings, only a single system-wide setting. In 2008 Microsoft hinted that future versions of Windows will partially support a Windows registry entry RealTimeIsUniversal that had been introduced many years earlier, when Windows NT supported RISC machines with UTC clocks, but had not been maintained. Since then at least two fixes related to this feature have been published by Microsoft.']
altered_context: Microsoft Windows maintains the system real-time clock in ••local time••. This results in various issues, including compatibility problems when dual booting with operating systems that establish the clock to UTC, and erroneously adjusting the clock twice when dual booting different versions of Windows, for instance, with a recovery boot disk. This method poses a challenge even in systems that run only Windows: there is no provision for individual user timezone configurations, just a singular system-wide setting. In 2008, Microsoft suggested that upcoming iterations of Windows would partially accommodate a Windows registry entry RealTimeIsUniversal that had been introduced many years prior, when Windows NT catered to RISC computers fitted with UTC clocks, but had not been sustained. Since that time, at least two updates concerning this functionality have been released by Microsoft.
original_question: What does Microsoft Windows use internally for its real-time clock?
altered_question: What does Microsoft Windows internally utilize for its real-time clock?

title: Daylight_saving_time
original_context: ['Xinjiang, China؛ Argentina؛ Chile؛ Iceland؛ Russia and other areas skew time zones ••westward••, in effect observing DST year-round without complications from clock shifts. For example, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, is at 106°39′ W longitude, slightly west of center of the idealized Mountain Time Zone (105° W), but the time in Saskatchewan is Central Standard Time (90° W) year-round, so Saskatoon is always about 67 minutes ahead of mean solar time, thus effectively observing daylight saving time year-round. Conversely, northeast India and a few other areas skew time zones eastward, in effect observing negative DST. The United Kingdom and Ireland experimented with year-round DST from 1968 to 1971 but abandoned it because of its unpopularity, particularly in northern regions.']
altered_context: Regions like Xinjiang, China; Argentina; Chile; Iceland; and Russia adjust their time zones westward, effectively implementing daylight saving time throughout the entire year without the hassles of altering clocks. For instance, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, located at 106°39′ W longitude, is just to the west of the center of the theoretical Mountain Time Zone (105° W), yet it operates on Central Standard Time (90° W) persistently, making Saskatoon consistently about 67 minutes ahead of average solar time, thereby functioning as if it were observing daylight saving time for the whole year. In contrast, northeastern India and several other regions shift their time zones eastward, essentially engaging in negative daylight saving time. The United Kingdom and Ireland ran trials for year-round daylight saving time from 1968 to 1971 but ultimately discontinued it due to its lack of popularity, especially in the more northern parts of the countries.
original_question: In which direction do countries like Russia and Argentina shift their time zones that could be considered all-year DST?
altered_question: In which direction do nations such as Russia and Argentina adjust their time zones that might be deemed as year-round daylight saving time?

title: Tristan_da_Cunha
original_context: ['The first permanent settler was ••Jonathan Lambert••, from Salem, Massachusetts, United States, who arrived at the islands in December 1810 with two other men. Lambert publicly declared the islands his property and named them the Islands of Refreshment. title: Tristan_da_Cunha
original_context: ['In ••1816••, the United Kingdom annexed the islands, ruling them from the Cape Colony in South Africa. This is reported to have primarily been a measure to ensure that the French would be unable to use the islands as a base for a rescue operation to free Napoleon Bonaparte from his prison on Saint Helena. The occupation also prevented the United States from using Tristan da Cunha as a cruiser base, as it had during the War of 1812.']
altered_context: In ••1816••, the British Empire took control of the islands, governing them from the Cape Colony in South Africa. This action is said to have mainly been an initiative to guarantee that the French could not utilize the islands as a staging ground for a mission to liberate Napoleon Bonaparte from his confinement on Saint Helena. The occupation also stopped the United States from utilizing Tristan da Cunha as a naval base, as it had done during the War of 1812.

title: Tristan_da_Cunha
original_context: ['The archipelago has a wet oceanic climate with pleasant temperatures but consistent moderate to heavy rainfall and very limited sunshine, due to the persistent westerly winds. The number of rainy days is comparable to ••the Aleutian Islands•• at a much higher latitude in the northern hemisphere, while sunshine hours are comparable to Juneau, Alaska, 20° farther from the equator. Frost is unknown below elevations of 500 metres (1,600 ft) and summer temperatures are similarly mild, never reaching 25 °C (77 °F). Sandy Point on the east coast is reputed to be the warmest and driest place on the island, being in the lee of the prevailing winds.']
altered_context: The island group experiences a humid maritime climate with enjoyable temperatures, accompanied by frequent moderate to heavy precipitation and very limited sunlight because of the ongoing westerly breezes. The quantity of rainy days is comparable to ••the Aleutian Islands••, which are situated at a significantly higher latitude in the northern hemisphere, while sunlit hours resemble those of Juneau, Alaska, 20° more distant from the equator. Frost is not found below elevations of 500 meters (1,600 feet), and summer temperatures are equally mild, never surpassing 25 °C (77 °F). Sandy Point, located on the eastern shore, is said to be the warmest and driest area on the island, sheltered from the dominant winds.

title: Tristan_da_Cunha
original_context: ['The remote location of the islands makes transport to the outside world difficult. Lacking an airport, the islands can be reached only by sea. Fishing boats from South Africa service the islands eight or nine times a year. The RMS Saint Helena used to connect the main island to St Helena and South Africa once each year during its January voyage, but has done so only twice in the last few years, in 2006 and 2011. The wider territory has access to air travel with Ascension island served by RAF Ascension Island and a new airport, financed by the ••United Kingdom government••, under construction on St Helena and due for completion in 2016. There is however no direct, regular service to Tristan da Cunha itself from either location. The harbour at Edinburgh of the Seven Seas is called Calshot Harbour, named after the place in Hampshire where the islanders temporarily stayed during the volcanic eruption.']
altered_context: The isolated position of the islands complicates transportation to the outside world. Without an airport, access to the islands can only be achieved by sea. Fishing vessels from South Africa visit the islands approximately eight or nine times each year. The RMS Saint Helena used to provide a link between the main island and St Helena as well as South Africa once annually during its January journey, but this connection has only occurred twice in recent years, specifically in 2006 and 2011. The broader region has options for air travel with Ascension Island being serviced by RAF Ascension Island, and a new airport, funded by the United Kingdom government, is currently being built on St Helena, expected to be completed in 2016. However, there remains no direct, regular route to Tristan da Cunha itself from either site. The harbor at Edinburgh of the Seven Seas is referred to as Calshot Harbour, named after the location in Hampshire where the island residents temporarily resided during the volcanic eruption.
original_question: Who financed the new airport in Calshot Harbour?
altered_question: Who provided the funding for the new airport in Calshot Harbour?

title: University_of_Kansas
original_context: ['The University of Kansas (KU) is a public research university and the largest in the U.S. state of Kansas. Founded March 21, 1865, the university was opened in 1866, under a charter granted by the Kansas State Legislature in 1864 following enabling legislation passed in 1863 under the Kansas State Constitution, adopted two years after the 1861 admission of the former Kansas Territory as the 34th state into the Union following a very famous bloody internal civil war known as Bleeding Kansas during the 1850s.']

Established on March 21, 1865, the university commenced operations in 1866, under a charter awarded by the Kansas State Legislature in 1864 following enabling legislation enacted in 1863 under the Kansas State Constitution, which was adopted two years subsequent to the 1861 incorporation of the prior Kansas Territory as the 34th state into the Union after a well-known and violent internal civil conflict referred to as Bleeding Kansas during the 1850s.

title: University_of_Kansas
original_context: ["The site selected for the university was a hill known as ••Mount Oread••, which was owned by former Kansas Governor Charles L. Robinson. Robinson and his wife Sara bestowed the 40-acre (16 ha) site to the State of Kansas in exchange for land elsewhere. The philanthropist Amos Adams Lawrence donated $10,000 of the necessary endowment fund, and the citizens of Lawrence raised the remaining cash by issuing notes backed by Governor Carney. On November 2, 1863, Governor Carney announced that Lawrence had met the conditions to get the state university, and the following year the university was officially organized. The school's Board of Regents held its first meeting in March 1865, which is the event that KU dates its founding from. Work on the first college building began later that year. The university opened for classes on September 12, 1866, and the first class graduated in 1873."]

The charitable individual Amos Adams Lawrence contributed $10,000 to the necessary endowment fund, while the residents of Lawrence collected the remaining funds by issuing notes secured by Governor Carney. On November 2, 1863, Governor Carney declared that Lawrence had fulfilled the conditions to establish the state university, and in the following year, the university was officially formed. The Board of Regents of the school convened for its first meeting in March 1865, which is the date that KU marks as its founding. Construction on the initial college building commenced later that year. The university commenced classes on September 12, 1866, with the first class graduating in 1873.']

title: Nanjing
original_context: ["Archaeological discovery shows that Nanjing Man lived in more than 500 thousand years ago. Zun, a kind of wine vessel, was found to exist in Beiyinyangying culture of Nanjing in about 5000 years ago. In the late period of Shang dynasty, Taibo of Zhou came to Jiangnan and established Wu state, and the first stop is in Nanjing area according to some historians based on discoveries in Taowu and Hushu culture. According to legend,[which?] Fuchai, King of the State of Wu, founded a fort named Yecheng (冶城) in today's Nanjing area in 495 BC. ", "Later in 473 BC, the State of Yue conquered Wu and constructed the fort of Yuecheng (越城) on the outskirts of the present-day Zhonghua Gate. In 333 BC, after eliminating the State of Yue, the State of Chu built Jinling Yi (金陵邑) in the western part of present-day Nanjing. It was renamed Moling (秣陵) during reign of Qin Shi Huang. Since then, the city experienced destruction and renewal many times.[citation needed] The area was successively part of Kuaiji, Zhang and Danyang prefectures in Qin and Han dynasty, and part of Yangzhou region which was established as the nation's 13 supervisory and administrative regions in the 5th year of Yuanfeng in Han dynasty (106 BC). Nanjing was later the capital city of Danyang Prefecture, and had been the capital city of Yangzhou for ••about 400 years•• from late Han to early Tang."]
altered_context: ['Archaeological findings indicate that Nanjing Man existed over 500 thousand years ago. Zun, a type of wine container, was discovered to be present in the Beiyinyangying culture of Nanjing approximately 5000 years ago. ', 'Subsequently, in 473 BC, the State of Yue defeated Wu and established the fort of Yuecheng (越城) on the periphery of today’s Zhonghua Gate. In 333 BC, after the overthrow of the State of Yue, the State of Chu founded Jinling Yi (金陵邑) in the west of present-day Nanjing. It was later renamed Moling (秣陵) during the rule of Qin Shi Huang. Since that time, the city has undergone multiple cycles of destruction and renewal.[citation needed] In the Qin and Han dynasties, the region was part of Kuaiji, Zhang, and Danyang prefectures, and later formed part of the Yangzhou area, which was established as one of the country’s 13 supervisory and administrative divisions in the 5th year of Yuanfeng during the Han dynasty (106 BC). Nanjing became the capital of Danyang Prefecture and was the capital of Yangzhou for approximately 400 years from the late Han to the early Tang periods.']

title: Nanjing

title: Nanjing

In 317, remnants of the Jin court, as well as nobles and wealthy families, fled from the north to the south and reestablished the Jin court in ••Nanjing••, which was then called Jiankang (建康), replacing Luoyang. It's the first time that the capital of the nation moved to southern part."]
altered_context: Soon after the consolidation of the area, the Western Jin dynasty fell apart. Initially, it was the insurrections by eight Jin princes vying for power, followed by uprisings and assaults from the Xiongnu and various other nomadic groups that led to the downfall of the Jin dynasty in the northern territories. In the year 317, the surviving members of the Jin court, along with aristocrats and affluent families, departed from the north to the south and reinstated the Jin court in ••Nanjing••, which at that time was referred to as Jiankang (建康), superseding Luoyang. title: Nanjing
original_context: ['The first emperor of the Ming dynasty, Zhu Yuanzhang (the Hongwu Emperor), who overthrew the Yuan dynasty, renamed the city Yingtian, rebuilt it, and made it the dynastic capital in 1368. He constructed a 48 km (30 mi) ••long city wall•• around Yingtian, as well as a new Ming Palace complex, and government halls. It took 200,000 laborers 21 years to finish the project. The present-day City Wall of Nanjing was mainly built during that time and today it remains in good condition and has been well preserved. It is among the longest surviving city walls in China. The Jianwen Emperor ruled from 1398 to 1402.']
altered_context: The initial ruler of the Ming dynasty, Zhu Yuanzhang (known as the Hongwu Emperor), who toppled the Yuan dynasty, renamed the city Yingtian, refurbished it, and established it as the dynastic capital in 1368. He erected a city wall stretching 48 km (30 mi) around Yingtian, in addition to a new Ming Palace complex and administrative buildings. The undertaking required 200,000 workers and lasted 21 years. The current City Wall of Nanjing was largely constructed during this period and is still in excellent condition, having been well maintained. It stands as one of the longest enduring city walls in China. The Jianwen Emperor reigned from 1398 to 1402.

title: Nanjing
original_context: ['Nanjing, with a total land area of 6,598 square kilometres (••2,548 sq mi••), is situated in the heartland of drainage area of lower reaches of Yangtze River, and in Yangtze River Delta, one of the largest economic zones of China. The Yangtze River flows past the west side and then north side of Nanjing City, while the Ningzheng Ridge surrounds the north, east and south side of the city. The city is 300 kilometres (190 mi) west-northwest of Shanghai, 1,200 kilometres (750 mi) south-southeast of Beijing, and 1,400 kilometres (870 mi) east-northeast of Chongqing. ', 'The downstream Yangtze River flows from Jiujiang, Jiangxi, through Anhui and Jiangsu to East Sea, north to drainage basin of downstream Yangtze is Huai River basin and south to it is Zhe River basin, and they are connected by the Grand Canal east to Nanjing. The area around Nanjing is called Hsiajiang (下江, Downstream River) region, with Jianghuai (江淮) stressing northern part and Jiangzhe (江浙) stressing southern part. The region is also known as Dongnan (東南, South East, the Southeast) and Jiangnan (江南, River South, south of Yangtze).']

The city lies 300 kilometers (190 mi) to the west-northwest of Shanghai, 1,200 kilometers (750 mi) to the south-southeast of Beijing, and 1,400 kilometers (870 mi) to the east-northeast of Chongqing.', 'The lower Yangtze River courses from Jiujiang in Jiangxi, moving through Anhui and Jiangsu before reaching the East Sea; to the north of the lower Yangtze is the Huai River basin, while to the south is the Zhe River basin, both linked by the Grand Canal to the east of Nanjing. The vicinity surrounding Nanjing is referred to as the Hsiajiang (下江, Downstream River) area, which emphasizes the northern region as Jianghuai (江淮) and the southern region as Jiangzhe (江浙). title: Nanjing
original_context: ['In the 1950s after PRC was established by CPC, the government invested heavily in the city to build a series of state-owned heavy industries, as part of the national plan of rapid industrialization, converting it into a heavy industry production centre of East China. Overenthusiastic in building a world-class industrial city, the government also made many disastrous mistakes during development, such as spending hundreds of millions of yuan to mine for non-existent coal, resulting in ••negative economic growth•• in the late 1960s. ', 'From 1960s to 1980s there were Five Pillar Industries, namely, electronics, cars, petrochemical, iron and steel, and power, each with big state-owned firms. After the Reform and Opening recovering market economy, the state-owned enterprises found themselves incapable of competing with efficient multinational firms and local private firms, hence were either mired in heavy debt or forced into bankruptcy or privatization and this resulted in large numbers of layoff workers who were technically not unemployed but effectively jobless.']

Eager to construct a world-class industrial metropolis, the government also committed numerous errors throughout the development process, such as expending hundreds of millions of yuan in pursuit of non-existent coal, which culminated in ••negative economic growth•• by the late 1960s. Between the 1960s and 1980s, there existed Five Pillar Industries, specifically, electronics, automobiles, petrochemicals, iron and steel, and electricity, each represented by significant state-owned enterprises. Following the Reform and Opening as the market economy began to recover, these state-owned companies found themselves unable to compete with capable multinational corporations and local private enterprises, leading them to become heavily indebted or compelled to go bankrupt or privatize, which caused a substantial number of layoffs – workers who were technically not unemployed but practically jobless.

title: Nanjing
original_context: ["Nanjing's airport, Lukou International Airport, serves both national and international flights. In 2013, Nanjing airport handled 15,011,792 passengers and 255,788.6 tonnes of freight. The airport currently has 85 routes to national and international destinations, which include Japan, Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, USA and Germany. The airport is connected by a 29-kilometre (18 mi) highway directly to the city center, and is also linked to various intercity highways, making it accessible to the passengers from the surrounding cities. A railway Ninggao Intercity Line is being built to link the airport with Nanjing South Railway Station. Lukou Airport was opened on ••28 June 1997••, replacing Nanjing Dajiaochang Airport as the main airport serving Nanjing. Dajiaochang Airport is still used as a military air base."]

title: Arena_Football_League
original_context: ['In 2014, the league announced the granting of a new franchise to former Mötley Crüe frontman Vince Neil, previously part-owner of the Jacksonville Sharks. That franchise, the Las Vegas Outlaws, were originally to play in Las Vegas at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in 2015, but instead played their home games at the Thomas & Mack Center, previous home to the ••Las Vegas Sting•• and Las Vegas Gladiators. After 20 years as a familiar name to the league, an AFL mainstay, the Iowa Barnstormers, departed the league to join the Indoor Football League. The San Antonio Talons folded on October 13, 2014, after the league (which owned the team) failed to find a new owner. On November 16, 2014, despite a successful season record-wise, the Pittsburgh Power became the second team to cease operations after the 2014 season. This resulted from poor attendance. It was later announced by the league that the Power would go dormant for 2015 and were looking for new ownership.']

After two decades as a well-known entity in the league, a staple of the AFL, the Iowa Barnstormers left the league to affiliate with the Indoor Football League. The San Antonio Talons ceased operations on October 13, 2014, after the league, which managed the team, was unable to locate a new proprietor. On November 16, 2014, despite a commendable season in terms of record, the Pittsburgh Power became the second franchise to halt operations following the 2014 season due to low attendance. title: Dialect
original_context: ['A ••standard dialect•• (also known as a standardized dialect or standard language) is a dialect that is supported by institutions. Such institutional support may include government recognition or designation؛ presentation as being the correct form of a language in schools؛ published grammars, dictionaries, and textbooks that set forth a correct spoken and written form؛ and an extensive formal literature that employs that dialect (prose, poetry, non-fiction, etc.). There may be multiple standard dialects associated with a single language. For example, Standard American English, Standard British English, Standard Canadian English, Standard Indian English, Standard Australian English, and Standard Philippine English may all be said to be standard dialects of the English language.']
altered_context: ['A ••normative dialect•• (also referred to as a standardized dialect or standard language) is a dialect that is backed by institutions. Such institutional backing may encompass governmental acknowledgment or classification; presentation as the accurate form of a language in educational settings; published grammars, lexicons, and textbooks that delineate a correct spoken and written variety; and a rich formal literary corpus that utilizes that dialect (narrative, verse, non-fiction, etc.). There can be several normative dialects tied to a single language. For instance, Standard American English, Standard British English, Standard Canadian English, Standard Indian English, Standard Australian English, and Standard Philippine English might all be classified as normative dialects of the English language.']
original_question: What is the term for a dialect that remains unsupported by institutions?
altered_question: What is the designation for a dialect that lacks institutional support?

title: Dialect
original_context: ['A nonstandard dialect, like a standard dialect, has a complete vocabulary, grammar, and syntax, but is usually not the beneficiary of institutional support. The Dialect Test was designed by Joseph Wright to compare different English dialects with each other.']

title: Dialect
original_context: ['Another occasionally used criterion for discriminating dialects from languages is that of linguistic authority, a more sociolinguistic notion. According to this definition, two varieties are considered dialects of the same language if (under at least some circumstances) they would defer to the same authority regarding some questions about their language. For instance, to learn the name of a new invention, or an obscure foreign species of plant, speakers of Bavarian German and East Franconian German might each consult a German dictionary or ask a German-speaking expert in the subject. By way of contrast, although Yiddish is classified by linguists as a language in the ••Middle High German•• group of languages, a Yiddish speaker would not consult a German dictionary to determine the word to use in such a case.']
altered_context: ['Another sometimes employed criterion for distinguishing dialects from languages is that of linguistic authority, a more sociolinguistic concept. As per this definition, two varieties are regarded as dialects of the same language if (under certain conditions) they would refer to the same authority concerning some queries about their language. For example, to discover the name of a new invention, or an obscure foreign type of plant, speakers of Bavarian German and East Franconian German might each look up a German dictionary or consult a German-speaking specialist on the topic. In contrast, although linguists categorize Yiddish as a language within the ••Middle High German•• category of languages, a speaker of Yiddish would not look to a German dictionary to find the appropriate word in such a scenario.']

altered_question: Which category of languages does Yiddish belong to?

In this secondary sense of dialect, language varieties are often called dialects rather than languages:']

title: Dialect
original_context: ['In the early 20th century, the vast conscription of Italian men from all throughout Italy during World War I is credited with facilitating the diffusion of standard Italian among less educated Italian men, as these men from various regions with various regional languages were forced to communicate with each other in a common tongue while serving in the Italian military. With the eventual spread of the radio and television throughout Italy and the establishment of public education, Italians from all regions were increasingly exposed to standard Italian, while literacy rates among all social classes improved. ', "Today, the majority of Italians are able to speak standard Italian, though many Italians still speak their regional language regularly or as their primary day-to-day language, especially at home with family or when communicating with Italians from the same town or region. With the later proliferation of radio and television across Italy and the creation of public schooling, Italians from every region were progressively exposed to standard Italian, alongside rising literacy levels among all societal classes. Today, a vast number of Italians possess the ability to communicate in standard Italian, yet many individuals still frequently use their regional language, particularly as their chief mode of daily communication, especially at home with relatives or when interacting with fellow Italians from their local area or region. Nonetheless, for some Italians, speaking a regional dialect, particularly in formal circumstances or outside their native region, may be linked with a stigma or negative implications associated with being lower class, uneducated, rude, or excessively informal.

title: Dialect
original_context: ['The classification of speech varieties as dialects or languages and their relationship to other varieties of speech can be controversial and the verdicts inconsistent. English and ••Serbo-Croatian•• illustrate the point. English and Serbo-Croatian each have two major variants (British and American English, and Serbian and Croatian, respectively), along with numerous other varieties. ', 'For political reasons, analyzing these varieties as languages or dialects yields inconsistent results: British and American English, spoken by close political and military allies, are almost universally regarded as dialects of a single language, whereas the standard languages of Serbia and Croatia, which differ from each other to a similar extent as the dialects of English, are being treated by some linguists from the region as distinct languages, largely because the two countries oscillate from being brotherly to being bitter enemies. (The Serbo-Croatian language article deals with this topic much more fully.)']
altered_context: ['The categorization of linguistic varieties as dialects or languages and their connection to other forms of speech can be contentious, with varying judgments. English and Serbo-Croatian serve as examples. Both English and Serbo-Croatian possess two primary variants (British and American English, and Serbian and Croatian, respectively), along with a plethora of other forms.', 'Due to political motivations, the examination of these varieties as either languages or dialects produces unreliable outcomes: British and American English, utilized by closely aligned political and military partners, are commonly seen as dialects of a unified language, while the official languages of Serbia and Croatia, which vary from one another to a comparable degree as the dialects of English, are viewed by some regional linguists as separate languages, mainly because the two nations fluctuate between camaraderie and hostility. (The article on the Serbo-Croatian language addresses this issue in much greater detail.)']
original_question: British English and Croatian American are the major variants of which language?
altered_question: Which language has British English and American Croatian as its principal variants?

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ['The abbot and monks, in proximity to the royal Palace of Westminster, the seat of government from the later 12th century, became a powerful force in the centuries after the Norman Conquest. The abbot often was employed on royal service and in due course took his place in the House of Lords as of right. Released from the burdens of spiritual leadership, which passed to the reformed Cluniac movement after the mid-10th century, and occupied with the administration of great landed properties, some of which lay far from Westminster, the Benedictines achieved a remarkable degree of identification with the ••secular•• life of their times, and particularly with upper-class life, Barbara Harvey concludes, to the extent that her depiction of daily life provides a wider view of the concerns of the English gentry in the High and Late Middle Ages.[citation needed]']
altered_context: The abbot and the monks, located near the royal Palace of Westminster, which has been the center of governance since the latter part of the 12th century, emerged as a significant influence in the centuries following the Norman Conquest. The abbot was frequently engaged in royal duties and eventually secured a position in the House of Lords as a matter of right. Relieved from the responsibilities of spiritual leadership, which transitioned to the reformed Cluniac movement after the mid-10th century, and involved with managing substantial estates, some of which were situated far from Westminster, the Benedictines realized an impressive level of connection with the non-religious existence of their era, especially with the lifestyle of the upper class. Barbara Harvey concludes that her portrayal of everyday existence offers a broader perspective on the issues faced by the English gentry during the High and Late Middle Ages.
original_question: With what kind of life were the Benedictines allowed to misidentify?
altered_question: What type of existence were the Benedictines permitted to misconstrue?

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ['The proximity of the Palace of Westminster did not extend to providing monks or abbots with high royal connections؛ in social origin the Benedictines of Westminster were as modest as most of the order. The abbot remained Lord of the Manor of Westminster as a town of two to three thousand persons grew around it: as a consumer and employer on a grand scale the monastery helped fuel the town economy, and relations with the town remained unusually cordial, but no enfranchising charter was issued during the Middle Ages. The abbey built ••shops and dwellings•• on the west side, encroaching upon the sanctuary.[citation needed]']
altered_context: The closeness of the Palace of Westminster did not lead to supplying monks or abbots with elevated royal affiliations; in terms of social background, the Benedictines of Westminster were as humble as the majority of the order. The abbot continued to be the Lord of the Manor of Westminster as a community of two to three thousand individuals developed around it: as a significant consumer and employer, the monastery contributed to the town's economy, and the relationship with the town remained notably friendly, yet no charter granting citizenship was issued during the Middle Ages. The abbey constructed shops and residences on the western side, encroaching upon the sanctuary.
original_question: What did the abbey build on the east side?
altered_question: What did the abbey create on the western side?

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ['Until the 19th century, Westminster was the third seat of learning in England, after ••Oxford and Cambridge••. Westminster suffered minor damage during the Blitz on 15 November 1940.']

title: Westminster_Abbey

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ["Subsequently, it became one of Britain's most significant honours to be buried or commemorated in the abbey. The practice of burying national figures in the abbey began under Oliver Cromwell with the burial of Admiral Robert Blake in 1657. The practice spread to include generals, admirals, politicians, doctors and scientists such as Isaac Newton, buried on 4 April 1727, and Charles Darwin, buried 26 April 1882. Another was ••William Wilberforce•• who led the movement to abolish slavery in the United Kingdom and the Plantations, buried on 3 August 1833. Wilberforce was buried in the north transept, close to his friend, the former Prime Minister, William Pitt.[citation needed]"]
altered_context: ['Later on, it became one of the most important distinctions in Britain to be interred or honored in the abbey. The tradition of interring prominent individuals in the abbey originated under Oliver Cromwell with the burial of Admiral Robert Blake in 1657. This tradition expanded to encompass generals, admirals, politicians, physicians, and scientists such as Isaac Newton, who was laid to rest on 4 April 1727, and Charles Darwin, who was entombed on 26 April 1882. Another notable figure was ••William Wilberforce••, who spearheaded the campaign to end slavery in the United Kingdom and the plantations, interred on 3 August 1833. Wilberforce was laid to rest in the north transept, near his close friend, the former Prime Minister, William Pitt.[citation needed]']
original_question: Who was buried in the abbey on 3 August 1833?
altered_question: Who was interred in the abbey on 3 August 1833?

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ["On Saturday September 6, 1997 the formal, though not state Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, was held. It was a royal ceremonial funeral including royal pageantry and Anglican funeral liturgy. A Second Public service was held on ••Sunday•• at the demand of the people. The burial occurred privately later the same day. Diana's former husband, sons, mother, siblings, a close friend, and a clergyman were present. Diana's body was clothed in a black long-sleeved dress designed by Catherine Walker, which she had chosen some weeks before. A set of rosary beads was placed in her hands, a gift she had received from Mother Teresa. Her grave is on the grounds of her family estate, Althorp, on a private island.[citation needed]"]
altered_context: ["On the day of Saturday, September 6, 1997, the formal yet not state funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, took place. This event was marked by royal ceremony, including regal pageantry and Anglican funeral rites. A second public memorial service was conducted on Sunday at the request of the public. The burial was done privately later that same day. Diana's ex-husband, her sons, mother, siblings, a close companion, and a member of the clergy were in attendance. Diana's remains were dressed in a black, long-sleeved gown created by Catherine Walker, a selection she had made weeks in advance. A set of rosary beads, a present from Mother Teresa, was placed in her hands. Her final resting place is located on the grounds of her family estate, Althorp, situated on a private island.[citation needed]"]

title: Westminster_Abbey

title: Westminster_Abbey
original_context: ["••The Pyx Chamber•• formed the undercroft of the monks' dormitory. It dates to the late 11th century and was used as a monastic and royal treasury. The outer walls and circular piers are of 11th-century date, several of the capitals were enriched in the 12th century and the stone altar added in the 13th century. The term pyx refers to the boxwood chest in which coins were held and presented to a jury during the Trial of the Pyx, in which newly minted coins were presented to ensure they conformed to the required standards."]

The external walls and circular supports are from the 11th century, some of the capitals were embellished in the 12th century, and the stone altar was introduced in the 13th century. title: Westminster_Abbey

title: Political_corruption
original_context: ['Corruption is often most evident in countries with the smallest per capita incomes, relying on foreign aid for health services. ••Local•• political interception of donated money from overseas is especially prevalent in Sub-Saharan African nations, where it was reported in the 2006 World Bank Report that about half of the funds that were donated for health usages were never invested into the health sectors or given to those needing medical attention.']

title: Political_corruption
original_context: ['Gombeenism refers to an individual who is dishonest and corrupt for the purpose of personal gain, more often through monetary, while, parochialism which is also known as parish pump politics relates to placing local or vanity projects ahead of the national interest.For instance in Irish politics, populist left wing political parties will often apply these terms to mainstream establisment political parties and will cite the many cases of Corruption in Ireland, such as the ••Irish Banking crisis••, which found evidence of bribery, cronyism and collusion, where in some cases politicians who were coming to the end of their political careers would receive a senior management or committee position in a company they had dealings with.']

title: Political_corruption
original_context: ['An unholy alliance is a coalition among seemingly antagonistic groups for ad hoc or hidden gain, generally some influential non-governmental group forming ties with political parties, supplying funding in exchange for the favorable treatment. Like ••patronage••, unholy alliances are not necessarily illegal, but unlike patronage, by its deceptive nature and often great financial resources, an unholy alliance can be much more dangerous to the public interest. An early use of the term was by former US President Theodore Teddy Roosevelt:']

title: Political_corruption
original_context: ["The World Bank collects a range of data on corruption, including survey responses from over 100,000 firms worldwide and a set of indicators of governance and institutional quality. Moreover, one of the six dimensions of governance measured by the Worldwide Governance Indicators is ••Control of Corruption••, which is defined as the extent to which power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as 'capture' of the state by elites and private interests. While the definition itself is fairly precise, the data aggregated into the Worldwide Governance Indicators is based on any available polling: questions range from is corruption a serious problem? to measures of public access to information, and not consistent across countries. Despite these weaknesses, the global coverage of these datasets has led to their widespread adoption, most notably by the Millennium Challenge Corporation."]

Although the definition is quite clear, the information consolidated into the Worldwide Governance Indicators relies on any accessible polling: inquiries vary from whether corruption is a significant issue? to evaluations of citizens' access to information, and are not uniform across nations. In spite of these limitations, the comprehensive reach of these datasets has resulted in their extensive use, particularly by the Millennium Challenge Corporation."]

title: Classical_music
original_context: ['Given the wide range of styles in classical music, from Medieval plainchant sung by monks to Classical and Romantic symphonies for orchestra from the 1700s and 1800s to avant-garde atonal compositions for ••solo piano•• from the 1900s, it is difficult to list characteristics that can be attributed to all works of that type. However, there are characteristics that classical music contains that few or no other genres of music contain, such as the use of a printed score and the performance of very complex instrumental works (e.g., the fugue). As well, although the symphony did not exist through the entire classical music period, from the mid-1700s to the 2000s the symphony ensemble--and the works written for it--have become a defining feature of classical music.']
altered_context: Considering the vast variety of styles within classical music, which ranges from Medieval plainchant performed by monks to Classical and Romantic orchestral symphonies from the 1700s and 1800s, and extending to avant-garde atonal pieces for ••individual piano•• from the 1900s, it is challenging to enumerate characteristics that can be assigned to all works of this genre. Nevertheless, there are traits that classical music possesses that are rarely found in other music genres, such as the utilization of a printed score and the execution of intricate instrumental compositions (e.g., the fugue). Moreover, while the symphony did not prevail for the entirety of the classical music era, from the mid-1700s to the 2000s, the symphonic ensemble--along with the pieces crafted for it--has emerged as a hallmark of classical music.
original_question: Avant-garde atonal compositions were written for what instrument?
altered_question: Atonal avant-garde pieces were composed for which instrument?

title: Classical_music
original_context: ['That said, the score does not provide complete and exact instructions on how to ••perform a historical work••. Even if the tempo is written with an Italian instruction (e.g., Allegro), we do not know exactly how fast the piece should be played. As well, in the Baroque era, many works that were designed for basso continuo accompaniment do not specify which instruments should play the accompaniment or exactly how the chordal instrument (harpsichord, lute, etc.) should play the chords, which are not notated in the part (only a figured bass symbol beneath the bass part is used to guide the chord-playing performer). ', 'The performer and/or the conductor have a range of options for musical expression and interpretation of a scored piece, including the phrasing of melodies, the time taken during fermatas (held notes) or pauses, and the use (or choice not to use) of effects such as vibrato or glissando (these effects are possible on various stringed, brass and woodwind instruments and with the human voice).']
altered_context: ['Nonetheless, the score fails to deliver comprehensive and precise guidelines on how to ••execute a historical piece••. Even if the tempo is noted with an Italian indication (for instance, Allegro), it remains unclear precisely how rapidly the composition should be rendered. Furthermore, during the Baroque period, numerous pieces intended for basso continuo support do not specify which instruments are supposed to provide the accompaniment or exactly how the chordal instrument (such as harpsichord, lute, etc.) should articulate the chords, which are not documented in the score (only a figured bass symbol underneath the bass part serves to direct the chord-playing musician).', 'The musician and/or the conductor possess a variety of choices for musical interpretation and expression of a composed work, including the phrasing of melodies, the duration taken during fermatas (sustained notes) or pauses, and the employment (or decision against employing) of techniques such as vibrato or glissando (these techniques are feasible on numerous stringed, brass, and woodwind instruments as well as with the human voice).']
original_question: The score does not provide complete and exact instruction on how to do what?
altered_question: The score fails to offer comprehensive and precise guidelines on how to accomplish what?

', 'The performer and/or the conductor have a range of options for musical expression and interpretation of a scored piece, including the phrasing of melodies, the time taken during fermatas (••held notes••) or pauses, and the use (or choice not to use) of effects such as vibrato or glissando (these effects are possible on various stringed, brass and woodwind instruments and with the human voice).']

title: Classical_music
original_context: ["Historically, major professional orchestras have been mostly or entirely composed of male musicians. Some of the earliest cases of women being hired in professional orchestras was in the position of harpist. The Vienna Philharmonic, for example, did not accept women to permanent membership until 1997, far later than the other orchestras ranked among the world's top five by Gramophone in 2008. The last major orchestra to appoint a woman to a permanent position was ••the Berlin Philharmonic••. As late as February 1996, the Vienna Philharmonic's principal flute, Dieter Flury, told Westdeutscher Rundfunk that accepting women would be gambling with the emotional unity (emotionelle Geschlossenheit) that this organism currently has. In April 1996, the orchestra's press secretary wrote that compensating for the expected leaves of absence of maternity leave would be a problem."]
altered_context: ["Traditionally, prominent professional orchestras have primarily or wholly consisted of male performers. Some of the initial instances of women being employed in professional orchestras were in the role of harpist. The Vienna Philharmonic, for instance, did not accept women into its permanent membership until 1997, significantly later than other orchestras recognized among the globe's top five by Gramophone in 2008. The most recent major orchestra to hire a woman for a permanent role was ••the Berlin Philharmonic••. As recently as February 1996, the Vienna Philharmonic's head flautist, Dieter Flury, conveyed to Westdeutscher Rundfunk that admitting women would be risking the emotional cohesion (emotionelle Geschlossenheit) that this ensemble currently maintains. In April 1996, the orchestra's communications officer stated that addressing the anticipated absences due to maternity leave would pose a challenge."]
original_question: Which major orchestra was the last to appoint a woman to a permanent position?
altered_question: Which prominent orchestra was the latest to hire a woman for a permanent role?

title: Classical_music
original_context: ["In 1997, the Vienna Philharmonic was facing protests during a [US] tour by the National Organization for Women and the International Alliance for Women in Music. Finally, after being held up to increasing ridicule even in socially conservative Austria, members of the orchestra gathered [on 28 February 1997] in an extraordinary meeting on the eve of their departure and agreed to admit a woman, Anna Lelkes, as ••harp••ist. As of 2013, the orchestra has six female members؛ one of them, violinist Albena Danailova became one of the orchestra's concertmasters in 2008, the first woman to hold that position. In 2012, women still made up just 6% of the orchestra's membership. VPO president Clemens Hellsberg said the VPO now uses completely screened blind auditions."]
altered_context: In 1997, the Vienna Philharmonic was encountering demonstrations during a [US] tour organized by the National Organization for Women and the International Alliance for Women in Music. Ultimately, after being subjected to growing mockery even in traditionally conservative Austria, members of the orchestra convened [on 28 February 1997] in a special meeting just before their departure and consented to allow a woman, Anna Lelkes, to join as ••harp••ist. By 2013, the orchestra included six female members; one of them, violinist Albena Danailova became one of the ensemble's concertmasters in 2008, marking the first time a woman held that role. In 2012, females still constituted only 6% of the orchestra’s total members. VPO president Clemens Hellsberg mentioned that the VPO now conducts completely vetted blind auditions.

altered_question: Which instrument was played by Anna Lelkes?

title: Classical_music

It began with the Baroque era, running from roughly 1600 to the middle of the 18th century. The Classical era followed, ending roughly around 1820. The Romantic era ran through the 19th century, ending about 1910.']

The size of the orchestra (typically around 40 in the Classical era) grew to be over 100. Gustav Mahler's 1906 Symphony No. 8, for example, has been performed with over 150 instrumentalists and choirs of ••over 400••."]

In television commercials, several passages have become clichéd, particularly the opening of Richard Strauss' Also sprach Zarathustra (made famous in the film 2001: A Space Odyssey) and the opening section O Fortuna of Carl Orff's Carmina Burana, often used in the horror genre؛ other examples include the Dies Irae from the Verdi Requiem, ••Edvard Grieg••'s In the Hall of the Mountain King from Peer Gynt, the opening bars of Beethoven's Symphony No. 5, Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries from Die Walküre, Rimsky-Korsakov's Flight of the Bumblebee, and excerpts of Aaron Copland's Rodeo."]

title: Classical_music
original_context: ["Classical music has often incorporated elements or material from popular music of the composer's time. Examples include occasional music such as Brahms' use of student drinking songs in his Academic Festival Overture, genres exemplified by ••Kurt Weill••'s The Threepenny Opera, and the influence of jazz on early- and mid-20th-century composers including Maurice Ravel, exemplified by the movement entitled Blues in his sonata for violin and piano. Certain postmodern, minimalist and postminimalist classical composers acknowledge a debt to popular music."]

title: Slavs
original_context: ['The Slavic autonym is reconstructed in Proto-Slavic as *Slověninъ, plural *Slověne. The oldest documents written in Old Church Slavonic and dating from the ••9th•• century attest Словѣне Slověne to describe the Slavs. Other early Slavic attestations include Old East Slavic Словѣнѣ Slověně for an East Slavic group near Novgorod. However, the earliest written references to the Slavs under this name are in other languages. In the 6th century AD Procopius, writing in Byzantine Greek, refers to the Σκλάβοι Sklaboi, Σκλαβηνοί Sklabēnoi, Σκλαυηνοί Sklauenoi, Σθλαβηνοί Sthlabenoi, or Σκλαβῖνοι Sklabinoi, while his contemporary Jordanes refers to the Sclaveni in Latin.']
altered_context: ['The Slavic self-designation is reconstructed in Proto-Slavic as *Slověninъ, plural *Slověne. The earliest documents composed in Old Church Slavonic and originating from the ••9th•• century confirm Словѣне Slověne to characterize the Slavs. Additional early Slavic attestations encompass Old East Slavic Словѣнѣ Slověně for a group of East Slavs located near Novgorod. Nevertheless, the most ancient written references to the Slavs under this denomination are found in other tongues. In the 6th century AD, Procopius, who wrote in Byzantine Greek, cites the Σκλάβοι Sklaboi, Σκλαβηνοί Sklabēnoi, Σκλαυηνοί Sklauenoi, Σθλαβηνοί Sthlabenoi, or Σκλαβῖνοι Sklabinoi, while his contemporary Jordanes mentions the Sclaveni in Latin.']

title: Slavs

The Byzantine term ••Sklavinoi•• was loaned into Arabic as Saqaliba صقالبة (sing. Saqlabi صقلبي) by medieval Arab historiographers. However, the origin of this word is disputed.']
altered_context: ['The English term Slav may have roots in the Middle English term sclave, which was adopted from Medieval Latin sclavus or slavus, itself derived from the Byzantine Greek σκλάβος sklábos meaning slave. This term appeared to originate from a misinterpretation of the Slavic autonym (referring to someone who speaks their own languages). The Byzantine designation ••Sklavinoi•• was transmitted into Arabic as Saqaliba صقالبة (sing. Saqlabi صقلبي) by medieval Arab chroniclers. title: Slavs
original_context: ['Pan-Slavism, a movement which came into prominence in the mid-19th century, emphasized the common heritage and unity of all the Slavic peoples. The main focus was in the Balkans where the South Slavs had been ruled for centuries by other empires: ••the Byzantine Empire, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Venice••. The Russian Empire used Pan-Slavism as a political tool؛ as did the Soviet Union, which gained political-military influence and control over most Slavic-majority nations between 1945 and 1948 and retained a hegemonic role until the period 1989--1991.']
altered_context: Pan-Slavism, a movement that rose to significance in the mid-19th century, highlighted the shared heritage and solidarity of all Slavic peoples. The primary emphasis was on the Balkans, where the South Slavs were governed for centuries by various empires: ••the Byzantine Empire, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Venice••. The Russian Empire employed Pan-Slavism as a means for political leverage; similarly, the Soviet Union utilized it, which acquired political-military power and dominance over numerous Slavic-majority countries between 1945 and 1948 and continued to hold a dominant position until the period of 1989 to 1991.

title: Slavs
original_context: ['The pagan Slavic populations were Christianized between the 6th and 10th centuries. ••Orthodox Christianity•• is predominant in the East and South Slavs, while Roman Catholicism is predominant in West Slavs and the western South Slavs. The religious borders are largely comparable to the East--West Schism which began in the 11th century. The majority of contemporary Slavic populations who profess a religion are Orthodox, followed by Catholic, while a small minority are Protestant. There are minor Slavic Muslim groups. Religious delineations by nationality can be very sharp؛ usually in the Slavic ethnic groups the vast majority of religious people share the same religion. Some Slavs are atheist or agnostic: only 19% of Czechs professed belief in god/s in the 2005 Eurobarometer survey.']
altered_context: The pagan Slavic communities were converted to Christianity between the 6th and 10th centuries. ••Orthodox Christianity•• is the most prevalent in the Eastern and Southern Slavs, whereas Roman Catholicism is the most common in the Western Slavs and the western regions of the Southern Slavs. The religious divisions closely resemble the East--West Schism that commenced in the 11th century. The bulk of modern Slavic populations that adhere to a religion are Orthodox, trailed by Catholics, and a small fraction identifies as Protestant. There exist minor groups of Slavic Muslims. The religious distinctions by nationality can be quite pronounced; typically, in Slavic ethnic groups, the overwhelming majority of religious individuals follow the same faith. Some Slavs identify as atheist or agnostic: only 19% of Czechs reported belief in deities in the 2005 Eurobarometer survey.
original_question: What religion is predominant in the East and South Slavs?
altered_question: Which faith is most widespread among the East and South Slavs?

title: Slavs
original_context: ['The modern Slavic peoples carry a variety of mitochondrial DNA haplogroups and Y-chromosome DNA haplogroups. Yet two paternal haplogroups predominate: R1a1a [M17] and I2a2a [L69.2=T/S163.2]. The frequency of Haplogroup R1a ranges from ••63.39%•• in the Sorbs, through 56.4% in Poland, 54% in Ukraine, 52% in Russia, Belarus, to 15.2% in Republic of Macedonia, 14.7% in Bulgaria and 12.1% in Herzegovina. The correlation between R1a1a [M17] and the speakers of Indo-European languages, particularly those of Eastern Europe (Russian) and Central and Southern Asia, was noticed in the late 1990s. From this Spencer Wells and colleagues, following the Kurgan hypothesis, deduced that R1a1a arose on the Pontic-Caspian steppe.']
altered_context: The contemporary Slavic populations possess an assortment of mitochondrial DNA haplogroups as well as Y-chromosome DNA haplogroups. However, two paternal haplogroups are most prominent: R1a1a [M17] and I2a2a [L69.2=T/S163.2]. The prevalence of Haplogroup R1a varies from ••63.39%•• among the Sorbs, 56.4% in Poland, 54% in Ukraine, 52% in Russia, Belarus, down to 15.2% in the Republic of Macedonia, 14.7% in Bulgaria, and 12.1% in Herzegovina. The association between R1a1a [M17] and speakers of Indo-European languages, especially those in Eastern Europe (Russian) and Central and Southern Asia, was observed in the late 1990s. From this, Spencer Wells and his associates, based on the Kurgan hypothesis, concluded that R1a1a emerged on the Pontic-Caspian steppe.
original_question: How frequent is I2a2a in the Sorbs?
altered_question: What is the occurrence rate of I2a2a among the Sorbs?

title: Slavs
original_context: ['DNA samples from 1228 Russians show that the Y chromosomes analyzed, all except 20 (1.6%) fall into seven major haplogroups all characteristic to West Eurasian populations. Taken together, they account for ••95%•• of the total Russian Y chromosomal pool. Only (0.7%) fell into haplogroups that are specific to East and South Asian populations. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) examined in Poles and Russians revealed the presence of all major European haplogroups, which were characterized by similar patterns of distribution in Poles and Russians. An analysis of the DNA did not reveal any specific combinations of unique mtDNA haplotypes and their subclusters. The DNA clearly shows that both Poles and Russians are not different from the neighbouring European populations.']
altered_context: DNA specimens from 1228 Russians indicate that the Y chromosomes studied, with the exception of 20 (1.6%), can be classified into seven primary haplogroups typical of West Eurasian groups. Collectively, these haplogroups represent ••95%•• of the complete Russian Y chromosomal repository. Only (0.7%) were categorized into haplogroups associated with East and South Asian populations. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) investigated in Poles and Russians demonstrated the existence of all principal European haplogroups, which exhibited comparable patterns of distribution in both groups. The examination of the DNA did not uncover any unique configurations of mtDNA haplotypes and their subgroups. The genetic data evidently indicates that both Poles and Russians are similar to the adjacent European populations.
original_question: Taken together, they account for what percentage of the total Russian Y chromosomal pool?
altered_question: Collectively, what percentage do they represent of the entire Russian Y chromosomal repository?

title: Slavs
original_context: ["••Polabian Slavs (Wends)•• settled in parts of England (Danelaw), apparently as Danish allies. Polabian-Pomeranian Slavs are also known to have even settled on Norse age Iceland. Saqaliba refers to the Slavic mercenaries and slaves in the medieval Arab world in North Africa, Sicily and Al-Andalus. Saqaliba served as caliph's guards. In the 12th century, there was intensification of Slavic piracy in the Baltics. The Wendish Crusade was started against the Polabian Slavs in 1147, as a part of the Northern Crusades. Niklot, pagan chief of the Slavic Obodrites, began his open resistance when Lothar III, Holy Roman Emperor, invaded Slavic lands. In August 1160 Niklot was killed and German colonization (Ostsiedlung) of the Elbe-Oder region began. ", 'In Hanoverian Wendland, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and Lusatia invaders started germanization. Early forms of germanization were described by German monks: Helmold in the manuscript Chronicon Slavorum and Adam of Bremen in Gesta Hammaburgensis ecclesiae pontificum. The Polabian language survived until the beginning of the 19th century in what is now the German state of Lower Saxony. In Eastern Germany, around 20% of Germans have Slavic paternal ancestry. Similarly, in Germany, around 20% of the foreign surnames are of Slavic origin.']
altered_context: ['••Polabian Slavs (Wends)•• established themselves in regions of England (Danelaw), seemingly as allies of the Danes. It is understood that Polabian-Pomeranian Slavs may have even migrated to Norse age Iceland. The term Saqaliba refers to the Slavic mercenaries and captives in the medieval Arab realm across North Africa, Sicily, and Al-Andalus. Saqaliba acted as protectors for the caliph. In the 12th century, there was a rise in Slavic piracy in the Baltic Sea. The Wendish Crusade was initiated against the Polabian Slavs in 1147, as part of the Northern Crusades. Niklot, the pagan leader of the Slavic Obodrites, commenced his overt defiance when Lothar III, Holy Roman Emperor, invaded their territories. In August 1160, Niklot was slain, leading to the commencement of German colonization (Ostsiedlung) in the Elbe-Oder area.', 'In Hanoverian Wendland, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, and Lusatia, invaders commenced the process of germanization. Early instances of this germanization were documented by German monks: Helmold in the manuscript Chronicon Slavorum and Adam of Bremen in Gesta Hammaburgensis ecclesiae pontificum. The Polabian language persisted until the early 19th century in what is currently the German state of Lower Saxony. In Eastern Germany, roughly 20% of the German populace possesses Slavic paternal lineage. Likewise, in Germany, about 20% of the foreign surnames can be traced back to Slavic roots.']
original_question: Who settled in parts of England?
altered_question: Which group established themselves in regions of England?

title: Southampton
original_context: ["Southampton (i/saʊθ'æmptən, -hæmptən/) is the largest city in the ceremonial county of Hampshire on the south coast of England, and is situated 75 miles (121 km) south-west of London and 19 miles (31 km) north-west of Portsmouth. Southampton is a major port and the closest city to the New Forest. It lies at the northernmost point of Southampton Water at the confluence of the River Test and River Itchen, with the River Hamble joining to the south of the urban area. The city, which is a unitary authority, has an estimated population of ••253,651••. The city's name is sometimes abbreviated in writing to So'ton or Soton, and a resident of Southampton is called a Sotonian."]

The railway link to London was fully opened in May 1840. Southampton subsequently became known as The Gateway to the Empire.']

title: Treaty
original_context: ["A party's consent to a treaty is invalid if it had been given by an agent or body without power to do so under that state's domestic law. States are reluctant to inquire into the internal affairs and processes of other states, and so a manifest violation is required such that it would be objectively evident to any State dealing with the matter. A strong presumption exists internationally that a head of state has acted within ••his proper authority••. It seems that no treaty has ever actually been invalidated on this provision.[citation needed]"]
altered_context: ["A party's approval of a treaty is deemed null if it was granted by an agent or entity lacking the authority to do so according to that state's internal legislation. Nations are hesitant to investigate the domestic matters and procedures of other nations, thus a clear transgression is necessary so that it would be evidently clear to any nation involved in the situation. A robust assumption exists on an international scale that a head of state has operated within ••his legitimate power••. It appears that no treaty has ever truly been annulled based on this regulation.[citation needed]"]
original_question: For what does a strong presumption exist internationally that a head of state has acted within in entering into a treaty?

For Concurrent matters, however, both the center and states are permitted to create laws. title: Josip_Broz_Tito
original_context: ['In 1934 the Zagreb Provincial Committee sent Tito to Vienna where all the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia had sought refuge. He was appointed to the Committee and started to appoint allies to him, among them Edvard Kardelj, Milovan Đilas, Aleksandar Ranković and Boris Kidrič. In 1935, Tito travelled to the Soviet Union, working for a year in the Balkans section of Comintern. He was a member of the Soviet Communist Party and the Soviet secret police (NKVD). Tito was also involved in recruiting for the Dimitrov Battalion, a group of volunteers serving in the Spanish Civil War. In 1936, the Comintern sent Comrade Walter (i.e. Tito) back to Yugoslavia to purge the Communist Party there. In 1937, Stalin had the Secretary-General of the CPY, ••Milan Gorkić••, murdered in Moscow. Subsequently Tito was appointed Secretary-General of the still-outlawed CPY.']

In 1935, Tito journeyed to the Soviet Union, spending a year in the Balkans department of Comintern. He was a participant in the Soviet Communist Party and the Soviet secret police (NKVD). Tito was also engaged in enlisting for the Dimitrov Battalion, a contingent of volunteers involved in the Spanish Civil War. In 1936, Comintern sent Comrade Walter (i.e., Tito) back to Yugoslavia to cleanse the Communist Party there. In 1937, Stalin orchestrated the assassination of the Secretary-General of the CPY, ••Milan Gorkić••, in Moscow. As a result, Tito was appointed Secretary-General of the still-banned CPY.

These islands, which he named Los Jardines, may have been Enewetak or Bikini Atoll.']

title: Marshall_Islands
original_context: ['The Spanish ship San Pedro and two other vessels in an expedition commanded by Miguel López de Legazpi discovered an island on January 9, 1530, possibly Mejit, at 10°N, which they named Los Barbudos. The Spaniards went ashore and traded with the local inhabitants. On January 10, the Spaniards sighted another island that they named ••Placeres••, perhaps Ailuk؛ ten leagues away, they sighted another island that they called Pajares (perhaps Jemo). On January 12, they sighted another island at 10°N that they called Corrales (possibly Wotho). On January 15, the Spaniards sighted another low island, perhaps Ujelang, at 10°N, where they described the people on Barbudos. After that, ships including the San Jeronimo, Los Reyes and Todos los Santos also visited the islands in different years.']

The following day, January 10, the Spaniards spotted another island that they referred to as ••Placeres••, possibly Ailuk; ten leagues further, they noticed another isle which they named Pajares (perhaps Jemo). On January 12, they observed yet another island at 10°N, which they called Corrales (potentially Wotho). title: Marshall_Islands
original_context: ["A number of vessels visiting the islands were attacked and their crews killed. In 1834, ••Captain DonSette•• and his crew were killed. Similarly, in 1845 the schooner Naiad punished a native for stealing with such violence that the natives attacked the ship. Later that year a whaler's boat crew were killed. In 1852 the San Francisco-based ships Glencoe and Sea Nymph were attacked and everyone aboard except for one crew member were killed. The violence was usually attributed as a response to the ill treatment of the natives in response to petty theft, which was a common practice. In 1857, two missionaries successfully settled on Ebon, living among the natives through at least 1870.:3"]

In 1852, the San Francisco-registered vessels Glencoe and Sea Nymph faced aggression, and all individuals on board, apart from one crew member, were killed. The brutality was often seen as a consequence of the poor treatment of the locals regarding minor thefts, a frequent occurrence. title: Marshall_Islands
original_context: ['In 1914, Japan joined ••the Entente•• during World War I and captured various German Empire colonies, including several in Micronesia. On September 29, 1914, Japanese troops occupied the Enewetak Atoll, and on September 30, 1914, the Jaluit Atoll, the administrative centre of the Marshall Islands. After the war, on June 28, 1919, Germany signed (under protest) the Treaty of Versailles. It renounced all of its Pacific possessions, including the Marshall Islands. On December 17, 1920, the Council of the League of Nations approved the South Pacific Mandate for Japan to take over all former German colonies in the Pacific Ocean located north of the Equator. The Administrative Centre of the Marshall Islands archipelago remained Jaluit.']
altered_context: In 1914, Japan became part of the ••Entente•• during the First World War and seized various colonies of the German Empire, including several located in Micronesia. On September 29, 1914, Japanese forces took control of the Enewetak Atoll, and on September 30, 1914, they occupied the Jaluit Atoll, which was the administrative hub of the Marshall Islands. Following the conflict, on June 28, 1919, Germany signed (albeit with objections) the Treaty of Versailles. It renounced all of its territorial claims in the Pacific, including the Marshall Islands. On December 17, 1920, the League of Nations' Council ratified the South Pacific Mandate, allowing Japan to assume control of all previous German colonies located in the Pacific Ocean north of the Equator. The administrative hub of the Marshall Islands archipelago continued to be Jaluit.
original_question: What military alliance did the Japanese join in the First World War?
altered_question: Which military coalition did the Japanese align with during the First World War?

title: Marshall_Islands
original_context: ['The islands are located about halfway between Hawaii and Australia, north of Nauru and Kiribati, east of the Federated States of Micronesia, and south of the U.S. territory of Wake Island, to which it lays claim. The two island chains lie approximately parallel to one another, running northwest to southeast, comprising about 750,000 square miles (1,900,000 km2) of ocean but only about 70 square miles (••180•• km2) of land mass. Each includes 15 to 18 islands and atolls. The country consists of a total of 29 atolls and five isolated islands.']

title: Szlachta
original_context: ['The tribes were ruled by clans (ród) consisting of people related by blood or marriage and theoretically descending from a common ancestor, giving the ród/clan a highly developed sense of solidarity. (See gens.) The starosta (or starszyna) had judicial and military power over the ród/clan, although this power was often exercised with an assembly of elders. Strongholds called ••grόd•• were built where the religious cult was powerful, where trials were conducted, and where clans gathered in the face of danger. The opole was the territory occupied by a single tribe. (Manteuffel 1982, p. 44)']
altered_context: ['The groups were governed by clans (ród) made up of individuals connected by kinship or matrimony and, in theory, tracing their lineage to a shared forebear, which imparted the ród/clan a strong sense of unity. (Refer to gens.) The starosta (or starszyna) possessed judicial and military authority over the ród/clan, despite this control frequently being exercised alongside a council of elders. Fortifications known as ••grόd•• were constructed in locales where the religious cult held significant influence, where legal proceedings were held, and where clans assembled in times of peril. The opole represented the area inhabited by an individual tribe. (Manteuffel 1982, p. 44)']
