altered_question: What term was used for strongholds?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ['In the Kingdom of Poland and later in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, ennoblement (nobilitacja) may be equated with an individual given legal status as a szlachta (member of the Polish nobility). Initially, this privilege could be granted by monarch, but from the 1641 onward, this right was reserved for the ••sejm••. Most often the individual being ennobled would join an existing noble szlachta clan and assume the undifferentiated coat of arms of that clan.']
altered_context: ['In the Realm of Poland and subsequently within the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, ennoblement (nobilitacja) can be associated with an individual receiving legal recognition as a szlachta (a member of the Polish nobility). At first, this honor could be conferred by the monarch, but from 1641 onwards, this authority was confined to the ••sejm••. Typically, the person being ennobled would affiliate with an existing noble szlachta family and adopt the shared coat of arms of that family.']
original_question: After 1641 who was given the privilege of ennoblement?
altered_question: Who obtained the privilege of ennoblement after the year 1641?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ['Nobles were born into a noble family, adopted by a noble family (this was abolished in 1633) or ennobled by a king or Sejm for various reasons (bravery in combat, service to the state, etc.--yet this was the rarest means of gaining noble status). Many nobles were, in actuality, really usurpers, being commoners, who moved into another part of the country and falsely pretended to noble status. Hundreds of such false nobles were denounced by Hieronim Nekanda Trepka in his Liber generationis plebeanorium (or Liber chamorum) in the ••first half of the 16th century••. ', "The law forbade non-nobles from owning nobility-estates and promised the estate to the denouncer. Trepka was an impoverished nobleman who lived a townsman life and collected hundreds of such stories hoping to take over any of such estates. It does not seem he ever succeeded in proving one at the court. Many sejms issued decrees over the centuries in an attempt to resolve this issue, but with little success. It is unknown what percentage of the Polish nobility came from the 'lower' orders of society, but most historians agree that nobles of such base origins formed a 'significant' element of the szlachta."]
altered_context: Nobility was typically inherited through a noble lineage, adopted by a noble family (a practice that ended in 1633), or conferred by a monarch or Sejm for various justifications (valor in battle, contribution to the state, etc.—though this was the least common method to achieve noble rank). Numerous nobles were, in reality, impostors, being commoners who relocated within the nation and deceitfully claimed noble heritage. Hundreds of these fraudulent nobles were exposed by Hieronim Nekanda Trepka in his Liber generationis plebeanorium (or Liber chamorum) during the ••initial part of the 16th century••. The legislation prohibited non-nobles from possessing noble estates and guaranteed the estate to the informant. Trepka was a destitute noble who led a merchant's existence and gathered hundreds of such accounts, hoping to acquire any of these estates. It appears he never managed to substantiate one in court. Numerous sejms promulgated edicts over the ages in an effort to address this dilemma, but with minimal success. The exact proportion of the Polish aristocracy originating from the 'lower' classes remains unknown, yet most historians concur that nobles of such humble beginnings constituted a 'substantial' portion of the szlachta.
original_question: When did the denouncing of many nobles take place?
altered_question: What was the time frame during which many nobles were denounced?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ["In 1422 King Władysław II Jagiełło by the Privilege of Czerwińsk (Polish: przywilej czerwiński) established the inviolability of nobles' property (their estates could not be confiscated except upon a court verdict) and ••ceded•• some jurisdiction over fiscal policy to the Royal Council (later, the Senat of Poland), including the right to mint coinage."]
altered_context: ['In 1422, King Władysław II Jagiełło, through the Czerwińsk Privilege (Polish: przywilej czerwiński), affirmed the inviolability of noble properties (their estates could only be seized based on a judicial ruling) and granted some authority regarding economic policy to the Royal Council (which later became the Senate of Poland), including the authority to issue currency.']
original_question: What happened to the right to mint coinage?
altered_question: What occurred regarding the authority to issue currency?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ["In 1430 with the Privileges of Jedlnia, confirmed at Kraków in 1433 (Polish: przywileje jedlneńsko-krakowskie), based partially on his earlier Brześć Kujawski privilege (April 25, 1425), King Władysław II Jagiełło granted the nobility a guarantee against arbitrary arrest, similar to the English Magna Carta's Habeas corpus, known from its own Latin name as neminem captivabimus (nisi jure victum). Henceforth no member of the nobility could be imprisoned without a ••warrant from a court of justice••: the king could neither punish nor imprison any noble at his whim. King Władysław's quid pro quo for this boon was the nobles' guarantee that his throne would be inherited by one of his sons (who would be bound to honour the privileges theretofore granted to the nobility). On May 2, 1447 the same king issued the Wilno Privilege which gave the Lithuanian boyars the same rights as those possessed by the Polish szlachta."]
altered_context: ["In 1430, with the Privileges of Jedlnia, validated in Kraków in 1433 (Polish: przywileje jedlneńsko-krakowskie), which was partly based on his prior Brześć Kujawski privilege (dated April 25, 1425), King Władysław II Jagiełło bestowed upon the nobility a safeguard against unrestrained detention, akin to the English Magna Carta's Habeas corpus, known by its Latin phrase neminem captivabimus (nisi jure victum). From that point onward, no member of the nobility could be incarcerated without a ••warrant from a court of law••: the king was unable to retaliate or detain any noble at his discretion. King Władysław's reciprocal arrangement for this favor was the nobles' assurance that his throne would be succeeded by one of his heirs (who would be obliged to respect the privileges previously accorded to the nobility). On May 2, 1447, the same monarch issued the Wilno Privilege which conferred upon the Lithuanian boyars the identical rights enjoyed by the Polish szlachta."]
original_question: What does a court need to imprison a member of the nobility?
altered_question: What is required by a court to detain a member of the nobility?
answer: warrant from a court of justice

title: Szlachta
original_context: ['The first free election (Polish: wolna elekcja) of a king took place in ••1492••. (To be sure, some earlier Polish kings had been elected with help from bodies such as that which put Casimir II on the throne, thereby setting a precedent for free elections.) Only senators voted in the 1492 free election, which was won by John I Albert. For the duration of the Jagiellonian Dynasty, only members of that royal family were considered for election؛ later, there would be no restrictions on the choice of candidates.']
altered_context: ['The initial unrestricted election (Polish: wolna elekcja) of a monarch occurred in ••1492••. (Indeed, a few prior Polish monarchs had been selected with support from organizations like the one that appointed Casimir II as king, thereby establishing a precedent for free elections.) Only members of the senate participated in the 1492 unrestricted election, which was victorious for John I Albert. Throughout the Jagiellonian Dynasty, only individuals from that royal lineage were contemplated for election; subsequently, there would be no limitations on the selection of candidates.']
original_question: When did the first free election take place?
altered_question: What year did the first unrestricted election happen?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ["On April 26, 1496 King John I Albert granted the Privilege of Piotrków (Polish: Przywilej piotrkowski, konstytucja piotrkowska or statuty piotrkowskie), increasing the nobility's feudal power over serfs. It bound the peasant to the land, as only one son (not the eldest) was permitted to leave the village؛ townsfolk (Polish: mieszczaństwo) were prohibited from ••owning land••؛ and positions in the Church hierarchy could be given only to nobles."]
altered_context: ["On April 26, 1496, King John I Albert bestowed the Privilege of Piotrków (Polish: Przywilej piotrkowski, konstytucja piotrkowska or statuty piotrkowskie), enhancing the nobility's feudal control over serfs. It tied the peasant to the territory, allowing only one son (not necessarily the eldest) to exit the village; townspeople (Polish: mieszczaństwo) were barred from ••possessing land••; and ranks in the Church hierarchy could be assigned solely to nobles."]

title: Szlachta
original_context: ["There were a number of avenues to upward social mobility and the achievement of nobility. Poland's nobility was not a rigidly exclusive, closed class. ••Many low-born individuals••, including townsfolk, peasants and Jews, could and did rise to official ennoblement in Polish society. Each szlachcic had enormous influence over the country's politics, in some ways even greater than that enjoyed by the citizens of modern democratic countries. Between 1652 and 1791, any nobleman could nullify all the proceedings of a given sejm (Commonwealth parliament) or sejmik (Commonwealth local parliament) by exercising his individual right of liberum veto (Latin for I do not allow), except in the case of a confederated sejm or confederated sejmik."]
altered_context: ["There were several pathways to ascending social status and attaining nobility. The nobility in Poland was not an inflexible, exclusive class. ••Numerous individuals of humble origin••, which included townspeople, farmers, and Jews, were able to and did achieve official ennoblement within Polish society. Every szlachcic wielded substantial power over the nation's politics, sometimes even surpassing that held by the citizens of contemporary democratic nations. From 1652 to 1791, any noble had the ability to annul all actions of a specified sejm (Commonwealth parliament) or sejmik (Commonwealth local parliament) by employing his individual right of liberum veto (Latin for I do not permit), aside from the instance of a confederated sejm or confederated sejmik."]

altered_question: Who was able to attain ennoblement in Poland?

title: Szlachta
original_context: ['The most notable difference is that, contrary to other European heraldic systems, the Jews, Muslim Tatars or another minorities would be given the noble title. Also, most families sharing origin would also share a coat-of-arms. They would also share arms with families adopted into the clan (these would often have their arms officially altered upon ennoblement). Sometimes unrelated families would be falsely attributed to the clan on the basis of similarity of arms. Also often noble families claimed inaccurate clan membership. Logically, the number of coats of arms in this system was rather ••low and did not exceed 200•• in late Middle Ages (40,000 in the late 18th century).']
altered_context: The most significant distinction is that, unlike other European heraldic traditions, individuals such as Jews, Muslim Tatars, or various other minorities were granted the noble title. Moreover, most families of similar descent would typically possess a coat of arms in common. They would also have heraldry with families absorbed into the clan (these often had their symbols formally modified upon receiving nobility). Occasionally, unrelated families would be inaccurately linked to the clan due to the resemblance of their arms. Additionally, noble families frequently claimed erroneous clan affiliation. Consequently, the quantity of coats of arms within this framework was relatively ••few and did not surpass 200•• during the late Middle Ages (40,000 by the end of the 18th century).

title: Virgil

Virgil's work has had wide and deep influence on Western literature, most notably Dante's Divine Comedy, in which Virgil appears as Dante's guide through hell and purgatory."]

title: Virgil

title: Virgil
original_context: ["The tradition holds that Virgil was born in the village of Andes, near Mantua in Cisalpine Gaul. Analysis of his name has led to beliefs that he descended from earlier Roman colonists. Modern speculation ultimately is not supported by narrative evidence either from his own writings or his later biographers. Macrobius says that Virgil's father was of a ••humble•• background؛ however, scholars generally believe that Virgil was from an equestrian landowning family which could afford to give him an education. He attended schools in Cremona, Mediolanum, Rome and Naples. After considering briefly a career in rhetoric and law, the young Virgil turned his talents to poetry."]
altered_context: ["The custom suggests that Virgil originated from the hamlet of Andes, close to Mantua in Cisalpine Gaul. Investigations into his surname have resulted in beliefs that he was descended from earlier Roman settlers. Contemporary conjecture ultimately lacks support from narrative proof found in either his own works or those of his subsequent biographers. Macrobius states that Virgil's father came from a ••modest•• background; however, academics typically assert that Virgil hailed from an equestrian family of landowners who were in a position to provide him with an education. He studied at institutions in Cremona, Mediolanum, Rome, and Naples. After briefly contemplating a profession in rhetoric and law, the youthful Virgil redirected his skills towards poetry."]
original_question: Does Macrobius believe Virgil's father came from a distinguished or humble background?
altered_question: Does Macrobius claim that Virgil's father was of a distinguished or modest background?

title: Virgil
original_context: ["According to the commentators, Virgil received his first education when he was five years old and he later went to Cremona, Milan, and finally Rome to study ••rhetoric, medicine, and astronomy••, which he soon abandoned for philosophy. From Virgil's admiring references to the neoteric writers Pollio and Cinna, it has been inferred that he was, for a time, associated with Catullus' neoteric circle. However schoolmates considered Virgil extremely shy and reserved, according to Servius, and he was nicknamed Parthenias or maiden because of his social aloofness. Virgil seems to have suffered bad health throughout his life and in some ways lived the life of an invalid. ", "According to the Catalepton, while in the Epicurean school of Siro the Epicurean at Naples, he began to write poetry. A group of small works attributed to the youthful Virgil by the commentators survive collected under the title Appendix Vergiliana, but are largely considered spurious by scholars. One, the Catalepton, consists of fourteen short poems, some of which may be Virgil's, and another, a short narrative poem titled the Culex (The Gnat), was attributed to Virgil as early as the 1st century AD."]
altered_context: ["As per the commentators, Virgil received his initial education at the age of five and subsequently traveled to Cremona, Milan, and ultimately Rome to pursue ••rhetoric, medicine, and astronomy••, which he quickly forsook for philosophy. From Virgil's admiring mentions of the modern writers Pollio and Cinna, it has been deduced that he was, for a period, linked with Catullus' modern circle. However, classmates regarded Virgil as exceedingly introverted and reserved, as noted by Servius, and he earned the nickname Parthenias or maiden due to his social detachment. Virgil appears to have experienced poor health throughout his existence and, in many respects, led the life of an invalid.", 'In accordance with the Catalepton, while attending the Epicurean school of Siro the Epicurean in Naples, he commenced composing poetry. A collection of minor works attributed to the young Virgil by the commentators has been preserved under the title Appendix Vergiliana, but is largely deemed inauthentic by scholars. One of these, the Catalepton, comprises fourteen brief poems, some potentially penned by Virgil, while another, a brief narrative poem called the Culex (The Gnat), was ascribed to Virgil as early as the 1st century AD.']

title: Virgil
original_context: ["Possibly as early as the second century AD, Virgil's works were seen as having magical properties and were used for divination. In what became known as the Sortes Vergilianae (Virgilian Lots), passages would be selected at random and interpreted to answer questions. In the ••12th century••, starting around Naples but eventually spreading widely throughout Europe, a tradition developed in which Virgil was regarded as a great magician. Legends about Virgil and his magical powers remained popular for over two hundred years, arguably becoming as prominent as his writings themselves. Virgil's legacy in medieval Wales was such that the Welsh version of his name, Fferyllt or Pheryllt, became a generic term for magic-worker, and survives in the modern Welsh word for pharmacist, fferyllydd."]
altered_context: ["Possibly as early as the second century AD, Virgil's writings were perceived as possessing mystical qualities and were utilized for divination. In what became recognized as the Sortes Vergilianae (Virgilian Lots), excerpts would be chosen randomly and interpreted to respond to inquiries. In the ••12th century••, originating around Naples but ultimately expanding widely across Europe, a tradition emerged that viewed Virgil as a formidable sorcerer. Myths surrounding Virgil and his supernatural abilities remained well-regarded for over two centuries, arguably achieving status as significant as his literary works. Virgil's influence in medieval Wales was such that the Welsh rendition of his name, Fferyllt or Pheryllt, became a common term for magic practitioner, and endures in the contemporary Welsh term for pharmacist, fferyllydd."]
original_question: When did Virgil's reputation as a great magician begin?

title: Virgil
original_context: ["The legend of Virgil in his Basket arose in the Middle Ages, and is often seen in art and mentioned in literature as part of the Power of Women literary topos, demonstrating the disruptive force of female attractiveness on men. In this story Virgil became enamoured of a beautiful woman, sometimes described as the emperor's daughter or mistress and called Lucretia. She played him along and agreed to an assignation at her house, which he was to sneak into at night by climbing into a large basket let down from a window. When he did so he was only hoisted halfway up the wall and then left him trapped there into the next day, exposed to public ridicule. The story paralleled that of Phyllis riding Aristotle. Among other artists depicting the scene, ••Lucas van Leyden•• made a woodcut and later an engraving."]
altered_context: ["The tale of Virgil in his Basket originated during the Middle Ages and is frequently represented in art and referenced in literature as part of the Power of Women literary theme, illustrating the disruptive influence of female beauty on men. In this narrative, Virgil became infatuated with a stunning woman, sometimes referred to as the emperor's daughter or mistress and named Lucretia. She led him on and consented to a rendezvous at her residence, which he was to enter secretly at night by ascending a large basket lowered from a window. However, when he attempted this, he was only elevated halfway up the wall, thereby leaving him stranded there until the following day, subjected to public scorn. The story is reminiscent of that of Phyllis riding Aristotle. Among other artists portraying the scene, ••Lucas van Leyden•• created a woodcut and subsequently an engraving."]

title: Alps
original_context: ['••The Alps•• are a crescent shaped geographic feature of central Europe that ranges in a 800 km (500 mi) arc from east to west and is 200 km (120 mi) in width. The mean height of the mountain peaks is 2.5 km (1.6 mi). The range stretches from the Mediterranean Sea north above the Po basin, extending through France from Grenoble, eastward through mid and southern Switzerland. The range continues toward Vienna in Austria, and east to the Adriatic Sea and into Slovenia. To the south it dips into northern Italy and to the north extends to the south border of Bavaria in Germany. In areas like Chiasso, Switzerland, and Neuschwanstein, Bavaria, the demarcation between the mountain range and the flatlands are clear؛ in other places such as Geneva, the demarcation is less clear. The countries with the greatest alpine territory are Switzerland, France, Austria and Italy.']
altered_context: ••The Alps•• are a crescent-shaped landform located in central Europe that stretches in an 800 km (500 mi) arc from the eastern to the western direction and has a width of 200 km (120 mi). The average elevation of the mountain summits is 2.5 km (1.6 mi). This range extends from the Mediterranean Sea northward over the Po basin, passing through France starting at Grenoble, then progressing eastward through central and southern Switzerland. It continues toward Vienna in Austria and further east to the Adriatic Sea and into Slovenia. To the south, it descends into northern Italy and extends northward to the southern boundary of Bavaria in Germany. In regions such as Chiasso in Switzerland and Neuschwanstein in Bavaria, the boundary between the mountain range and the lowlands is distinct; in contrast, in areas like Geneva, the boundary is less pronounced. The nations with the most significant alpine region are Switzerland, France, Austria, and Italy.

The Great St Bernard Hospice, built in ••the 9th or 10th centuries••, at the summit of the Great Saint Bernard Pass was shelter for travelers and place for pilgrims since its inception؛ by the 19th century it became a tourist attraction with notable visitors such as author Charles Dickens and mountaineer Edward Whymper.']

The Great St Bernard Hospice, erected in the 9th or 10th centuries, atop the Great Saint Bernard Pass, offered shelter for travelers and a haven for pilgrims since its creation; by the 1800s, it became a notable tourist site, attracting distinguished visitors such as author Charles Dickens and climber Edward Whymper.

The kitchen is separated from the living area (called the stube, the area of the home heated by a stove), and second-floor bedrooms benefit from rising heat. Stairs leading to upper levels are sometimes built on the outside, and balconies are sometimes enclosed.']

title: Alps
original_context: ['The tourism industry began in the early 19th century when foreigners visited the Alps, traveled to the bases of the mountains to enjoy the scenery, and stayed at the spa-resorts. Large hotels were built during the Belle Époque؛ cog-railways, built ••early in the 20th century••, brought tourists to ever higher elevations, with the Jungfraubahn terminating at the Jungfraujoch, well above the eternal snow-line, after going through a tunnel in Eiger. During this period winter sports were slowly introduced: in 1882 the first figure skating championship was held in St. Moritz, and downhill skiing became a popular sport with English visitors early in the 20th century, as the first ski-lift was installed in 1908 above Grindelwald.']

Substantial hotels were established during the Belle Époque; cog-railways, constructed early in the 20th century, transported travelers to increasingly lofty heights, with the Jungfraubahn concluding at the Jungfraujoch, significantly above the perpetual snow-line, after passing through a tunnel in the Eiger. This era also saw a gradual introduction of winter sports: the inaugural figure skating competition took place in St. Moritz in 1882, and downhill skiing grew into a favored activity among British tourists in the early 20th century, as the first ski-lift was set up in 1908 above Grindelwald.

title: Alps
original_context: ["In the first half of the 20th century the Olympic Winter Games were held three times in Alpine venues: the 1924 Winter Olympics in Chamonix, France؛ the 1928 Winter Olympics in ••St. Moritz, Switzerland••؛ and the 1936 Winter Olympics in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. During World War II the winter games were canceled but after that time the Winter Games have been held in St. Moritz (1948), Cortina d'Ampezzo (1956), Innsbruck, Austria (1964 and 1976), Grenoble, France, (1968), Albertville, France, (1992), and Torino (2006). In 1930 the Lauberhorn Rennen (Lauberhorn Race), was run for the first time on the Lauberhorn above Wengen؛ the equally demanding Hahnenkamm was first run in the same year in Kitzbühl, Austria. Both races continue to be held each January on successive weekends. The Lauberhorn is the more strenuous downhill race at 4.5 km (2.8 mi) and poses danger to racers who reach 130 km/h (81 mph) within seconds of leaving the start gate."]
altered_context: In the initial half of the 20th century, the Olympic Winter Games took place three times in mountainous locations: the 1924 Winter Olympics in Chamonix, France; the 1928 Winter Olympics in St. Moritz, Switzerland; and the 1936 Winter Olympics in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. The winter events were canceled during World War II, but subsequently, the Winter Games have occurred in St. Moritz (1948), Cortina d'Ampezzo (1956), Innsbruck, Austria (both 1964 and 1976), Grenoble, France (1968), Albertville, France (1992), and Torino (2006). The Lauberhorn Rennen, known as the Lauberhorn Race, was conducted for its inaugural event on the Lauberhorn above Wengen in 1930; the equally challenging Hahnenkamm was also first held that same year in Kitzbühl, Austria. Both competitions are still organized each January on consecutive weekends. The Lauberhorn is the more demanding downhill race at 4.5 km (2.8 miles) and presents risks to participants who can reach speeds of 130 km/h (81 mph) shortly after departing from the starting gate.
original_question: Where were the Winter Olympics held in 1928?
altered_question: In which location did the Winter Olympics take place in 1928?

title: Gene
original_context: ["Prior to Mendel's work, the dominant theory of heredity was ••one of blending inheritance••, which suggested that each parent contributed fluids to the fertilisation process and that the traits of the parents blended and mixed to produce the offspring. Charles Darwin developed a theory of inheritance he termed pangenesis, which used the term gemmule to describe hypothetical particles that would mix during reproduction. Although Mendel's work was largely unrecognized after its first publication in 1866, it was 'rediscovered' in 1900 by three European scientists, Hugo de Vries, Carl Correns, and Erich von Tschermak, who claimed to have reached similar conclusions in their own research."]
altered_context: ["Before Mendel's research, the prevailing theory of inheritance was ••a model of blending inheritance••, which proposed that each parent contributed some fluids during the fertilization procedure and that the characteristics of the parents merged and mixed to create the offspring. Charles Darwin formulated a theory of inheritance he called pangenesis, which employed the concept of gemmule to denote theoretical particles that would combine during reproduction. Although Mendel's findings were mostly overlooked after their initial release in 1866, they were 'rediscovered' in 1900 by three scientists from Europe, Hugo de Vries, Carl Correns, and Erich von Tschermak, who asserted they had arrived at comparable conclusions in their own studies."]

Each locus contains ••one allele of a gene••؛ however, members of a population may have different alleles at the locus, each with a slightly different gene sequence.']

title: Gene
original_context: ['Prokaryotes (••bacteria and archaea••) typically store their genomes on a single large, circular chromosome. Similarly, some eukaryotic organelles contain a remnant circular chromosome with a small number of genes.:14.4 Prokaryotes sometimes supplement their chromosome with additional small circles of DNA called plasmids, which usually encode only a few genes and are transferable between individuals. For example, the genes for antibiotic resistance are usually encoded on bacterial plasmids and can be passed between individual cells, even those of different species, via horizontal gene transfer.']
altered_context: Prokaryotic organisms (••bacteria and archaea••) generally maintain their genetic information on a solitary large, circular chromosome. In a like manner, certain eukaryotic organelles possess a trace circular chromosome with a limited number of genes. Prokaryotes may sometimes enhance their chromosome with supplementary small circular DNA molecules known as plasmids, which typically contain only a handful of genes and are transferable among organisms. For instance, the genes responsible for antibiotic resistance are often found on bacterial plasmids and can be transmitted between individual cells, including those of different species, through horizontal gene transfer.

title: Gene
original_context: ["In all organisms, two steps are required to read the information encoded in a gene's DNA and produce the protein it specifies. First, the gene's DNA is transcribed to messenger RNA (mRNA).:6.1 Second, that mRNA is translated to protein.:6.2 RNA-coding genes must still go through the first step, but are not translated into protein. The process of producing a biologically functional molecule of either RNA or protein is called ••gene expression••, and the resulting molecule is called a gene product."]

The process of creating a biologically functional molecule of either RNA or protein is referred to as ••gene expression••, and the resultant molecule is known as a gene product."]

title: Gene
original_context: ["Transcription produces a single-stranded RNA molecule known as messenger RNA, whose nucleotide sequence is complementary to the DNA from which it was transcribed.:6.1 The mRNA acts as an intermediate between the DNA gene and its final protein product. The gene's DNA is used as a template to generate a complementary mRNA. The mRNA matches the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand ••because it is synthesised as the complement of the template strand••. Transcription is performed by an enzyme called an RNA polymerase, which reads the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction and synthesizes the RNA from 5' to 3'. To initiate transcription, the polymerase first recognizes and binds a promoter region of the gene. Thus, a major mechanism of gene regulation is the blocking or sequestering the promoter region, either by tight binding by repressor molecules that physically block the polymerase, or by organizing the DNA so that the promoter region is not accessible.:7"]
altered_context: ["Transcription generates a single-stranded RNA molecule referred to as messenger RNA, whose nucleotide sequence is complementary to the DNA from which it was derived. The mRNA serves as an intermediary between the DNA gene and its ultimate protein product. The gene's DNA serves as a template to produce a corresponding mRNA. The mRNA aligns with the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand because it is created as the complement of the template strand. Transcription is carried out by an enzyme known as RNA polymerase, which interprets the template strand in the 3' to 5' orientation and constructs the RNA from 5' to 3'. To commence transcription, the polymerase initially identifies and attaches to a promoter region of the gene. Therefore, a key mechanism of gene regulation involves obstructing or isolating the promoter region, either through the strong binding by repressor molecules that physically hinder the polymerase, or by rearranging the DNA so the promoter region is not reachable."]
original_question: Why does the mRNA match the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand?
altered_question: Why is the mRNA aligned with the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand?

title: Gene
original_context: ['Translation is the process by which a mature mRNA molecule is used as a template for synthesizing a new protein.:6.2 Translation is carried out by ribosomes, large complexes of RNA and protein responsible for ••carrying out the chemical reactions to add new amino acids to a growing polypeptide chain•• by the formation of peptide bonds. The genetic code is read three nucleotides at a time, in units called codons, via interactions with specialized RNA molecules called transfer RNA (tRNA). ', 'Each tRNA has three unpaired bases known as the anticodon that are complementary to the codon it reads on the mRNA. The tRNA is also covalently attached to the amino acid specified by the complementary codon. When the tRNA binds to its complementary codon in an mRNA strand, the ribosome attaches its amino acid cargo to the new polypeptide chain, which is synthesized from amino terminus to carboxyl terminus. During and after synthesis, most new proteins must folds to their active three-dimensional structure before they can carry out their cellular functions.:3']
altered_context: Translation refers to the mechanism by which a fully developed mRNA molecule serves as a template for creating a novel protein. Translation is executed by ribosomes, sizable structures composed of RNA and protein that are accountable for ••performing the chemical processes to incorporate new amino acids into an expanding polypeptide series•• through the establishment of peptide bonds. The genetic sequence is interpreted in sets of three nucleotides at a time, in segments called codons, via interactions with specialized RNA entities known as transfer RNA (tRNA). Each tRNA consists of three unpaired nucleotides referred to as the anticodon that correspond to the codon it interprets on the mRNA. The tRNA is also covalently bonded to the amino acid indicated by the matching codon. When the tRNA connects to its corresponding codon on an mRNA strand, the ribosome links its amino acid payload to the developing polypeptide chain, which is formed from the amino terminus to the carboxyl terminus. Throughout and after its formation, the majority of new proteins must achieve their functional three-dimensional structure before they can perform their cellular tasks.
original_question: What is a ribosome responsible for?
altered_question: What duties does a ribosome fulfill?
answer: carrying out the chemical reactions to add new amino acids to a growing polypeptide chain

title: Gene
original_context: ['DNA replication is for the most part extremely accurate, however errors (mutations) do occur.:7.6 The error rate in eukaryotic cells can be as low as ••10−8 per nucleotide per replication••, whereas for some RNA viruses it can be as high as 10−3. This means that each generation, each human genome accumulates 1--2 new mutations. Small mutations can be caused by DNA replication and the aftermath of DNA damage and include point mutations in which a single base is altered and frameshift mutations in which a single base is inserted or deleted. ', 'Either of these mutations can change the gene by missense (change a codon to encode a different amino acid) or nonsense (a premature stop codon). Larger mutations can be caused by errors in recombination to cause chromosomal abnormalities including the duplication, deletion, rearrangement or inversion of large sections of a chromosome. Additionally, the DNA repair mechanisms that normally revert mutations can introduce errors when repairing the physical damage to the molecule is more important than restoring an exact copy, for example when repairing double-strand breaks.:5.4']

This signifies that with each generation, every human genome gathers 1--2 novel mutations. Minor mutations may arise from DNA duplication and the consequences of DNA damage, including point mutations where a single base is modified and frameshift mutations where a base is either introduced or omitted. ', 'Any of these mutations can alter the gene through missense (changing a codon to specify a distinct amino acid) or nonsense (creating a premature stop codon). title: Gene
original_context: ["Essential genes are the set of genes thought to be critical for an organism's survival. This definition assumes the abundant availability of all relevant nutrients and the absence of environmental stress. Only a small portion of an organism's genes are essential. In bacteria, an estimated ••250--400•• genes are essential for Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, which is less than 10% of their genes. Half of these genes are orthologs in both organisms and are largely involved in protein synthesis. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae the number of essential genes is slightly higher, at 1000 genes (~20% of their genes). Although the number is more difficult to measure in higher eukaryotes, mice and humans are estimated to have around 2000 essential genes (~10% of their genes)."]
altered_context: ["Vital genes are the collection of genes believed to be crucial for the survival of an organism. This characterization presumes the sufficient availability of all necessary nutrients and the lack of environmental stressors. Only a limited fraction of an organism's genetic material is deemed essential. In bacteria, an approximation of ••250--400•• genes is deemed vital for Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, which constitutes less than 10% of their genetic makeup. Half of these genes serve as orthologs in both species and primarily play roles in protein synthesis. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the quantity of essential genes is slightly greater, totaling 1000 genes (~20% of their genetic material). While quantifying this in more complex eukaryotes is more challenging, it is estimated that mice and humans possess around 2000 vital genes (~10% of their genetic material)."]

title: Brain
original_context: ['The brains of all species are composed primarily of two broad classes of cells: ••neurons and glial cells••. Glial cells (also known as glia or neuroglia) come in several types, and perform a number of critical functions, including structural support, metabolic support, insulation, and guidance of development. Neurons, however, are usually considered the most important cells in the brain. The property that makes neurons unique is their ability to send signals to specific target cells over long distances. They send these signals by means of an axon, which is a thin protoplasmic fiber that extends from the cell body and projects, usually with numerous branches, to other areas, sometimes nearby, sometimes in distant parts of the brain or body. ', 'The length of an axon can be extraordinary: for example, if a pyramidal cell, (an excitatory neuron) of the cerebral cortex were magnified so that its cell body became the size of a human body, its axon, equally magnified, would become a cable a few centimeters in diameter, extending more than a kilometer. These axons transmit signals in the form of electrochemical pulses called action potentials, which last less than a thousandth of a second and travel along the axon at speeds of 1--100 meters per second. Some neurons emit action potentials constantly, at rates of 10--100 per second, usually in irregular patterns؛ other neurons are quiet most of the time, but occasionally emit a burst of action potentials.']
altered_context: ['The brains of all living beings are primarily constructed of two main categories of cells: ••neurons and glial cells••. Glial cells (commonly referred to as glia or neuroglia) exist in various types and carry out numerous essential functions, such as providing structural support, metabolic assistance, insulation, and directing development. Neurons, on the other hand, are typically regarded as the most crucial cells in the brain. What distinguishes neurons is their capability to transmit signals to designated target cells across extensive distances. They convey these signals through an axon, a slender protoplasmic fiber that extends from the cell body and branches out, usually with many offshoots, to various locations, sometimes close by, and at other times in remote regions of the brain or body.', 'The length of an axon can be remarkable: for instance, if a pyramidal cell, (an excitatory neuron) from the cerebral cortex were enlarged so that its cell body matched the scale of a human body, its axon, similarly enlarged, would turn into a cable several centimeters wide, stretching over a kilometer. These axons convey signals in the form of electrochemical impulses known as action potentials, which last for less than a thousandth of a second and travel along the axon at rates of 1--100 meters per second. Some neurons generate action potentials continuously, at frequencies of 10--100 per second, often in irregular sequences; others remain inactive for the majority of the time but sporadically release a surge of action potentials.']
original_question: Brains of organisms are made up mostly of what two classes of cells?
altered_question: What are the two primary classes of cells that make up the brains of organisms?

title: Brain
original_context: ['Brains are most simply compared in terms of their size. The relationship between brain size, body size and other variables has been studied across a wide range of vertebrate species. As a rule, brain size increases with body size, but not in a simple linear proportion. In general, smaller animals tend to have larger brains, measured as a fraction of body size. For mammals, the relationship between brain volume and body mass essentially follows a power law with an exponent of about ••0.75••. This formula describes the central tendency, but every family of mammals departs from it to some degree, in a way that reflects in part the complexity of their behavior. For example, primates have brains 5 to 10 times larger than the formula predicts. Predators tend to have larger brains than their prey, relative to body size.']
altered_context: Brains are typically assessed based on their size. The correlation between brain dimensions, body dimensions, and various other factors has been examined across numerous vertebrate species. Generally, brain size increases with body size, although not in a straightforward linear manner. Typically, smaller creatures possess disproportionately larger brains, calculated as a ratio of body size. In mammals, the correlation between brain volume and body weight essentially adheres to a power law with an exponent of approximately ••0.75••. This equation illustrates the average trend, yet each family of mammals diverges from it to varying extents, reflecting in part the intricacy of their behaviors. For instance, primates exhibit brain sizes that are 5 to 10 times greater than what the formula suggests. Carnivores generally have larger brains compared to their prey, in relation to body size.
original_question: In mammals, brain volume and body mass follows a power law with an exponent of what?
altered_question: In mammals, brain size and body weight follow a power law with an exponent of what value?

title: Brain
original_context: ['The brains of vertebrates are made of very soft tissue. Living brain tissue is pinkish on the outside and mostly ••white•• on the inside, with subtle variations in color. Vertebrate brains are surrounded by a system of connective tissue membranes called meninges that separate the skull from the brain. Blood vessels enter the central nervous system through holes in the meningeal layers. The cells in the blood vessel walls are joined tightly to one another, forming the blood--brain barrier, which blocks the passage of many toxins and pathogens (though at the same time blocking antibodies and some drugs, thereby presenting special challenges in treatment of diseases of the brain).']
altered_context: The cerebral matter of vertebrates comprises extremely delicate tissue. Living neural tissue appears pinkish externally and predominantly ••pale•• internally, with slight differences in hue. Blood vessels penetrate the central nervous system via openings in the meningeal layers. The cells forming the walls of the blood vessels are tightly connected to each other, establishing the blood-brain barrier that hinders the transit of numerous toxins and pathogens (while simultaneously obstructing antibodies and certain medications, thus posing unique challenges in the treatment of neurological disorders).

title: Brain
original_context: ["A key component of the arousal system is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), a tiny part of the hypothalamus located directly above the point at which the optic nerves from the two eyes cross. The SCN contains the body's central biological clock. Neurons there show activity levels that rise and fall with a period of about 24 hours, circadian rhythms: these activity fluctuations are driven by rhythmic changes in expression of a set of clock genes. The SCN continues to keep time even if it is excised from the brain and placed in a dish of warm nutrient solution, but it ordinarily receives input from the optic nerves, through ••the retinohypothalamic tract (RHT••), that allows daily light-dark cycles to calibrate the clock."]

The SCN continues to maintain its timing even when surgically removed from the brain and placed in a container of warm nutrient solution, although it typically receives signals from the optic nerves, via the retinohypothalamic tract (RHT), which enables daily cycles of light and darkness to adjust the clock.

title: Near_East
original_context: ['The Ottoman Empire, believed to be about to collapse, was portrayed in the press as the sick man of Europe. The Balkan states, with the partial exception of Bosnia and Albania, were primarily Christian. Starting in 1894 the Ottomans struck at the Armenians on the explicit grounds that they were a non-Muslim people and as such were a potential threat to the Muslim empire within which they resided. ••The Hamidian Massacres•• aroused the indignation of the entire Christian world. In the United States the now aging Julia Ward Howe, author of the Battle Hymn of the Republic, leaped into the war of words and joined the Red Cross. Relations of minorities within the Ottoman Empire and the disposition of former Ottoman lands became known as the Eastern Question, as the Ottomans were on the east of Europe.']
altered_context: ['The Ottoman Empire, thought to be on the verge of disintegration, was depicted in the media as the ailing patient of Europe. The Balkan nations, with the partial exceptions of Bosnia and Albania, were predominantly Christian. Beginning in 1894, the Ottomans targeted the Armenians on the explicit grounds that they were a non-Muslim group and therefore posed a potential danger to the Muslim empire in which they lived. ••The Hamidian Massacres•• incited the outrage of the entire Christian community. In the United States, the now elder Julia Ward Howe, writer of the Battle Hymn of the Republic, engaged in the war of rhetoric and became affiliated with the Red Cross. The status of minorities within the Ottoman Empire and the fate of erstwhile Ottoman territories came to be referred to as the Eastern Question, as the Ottomans were situated to the east of Europe.']
original_question: What aroused the indignation of the entire Christian world?
altered_question: What provoked the outrage of the entire Christian community?

title: Near_East
original_context: ['The Ottoman Empire, believed to be about to collapse, was portrayed in the press ••as the sick man of Europe••. The Balkan states, with the partial exception of Bosnia and Albania, were primarily Christian. Starting in 1894 the Ottomans struck at the Armenians on the explicit grounds that they were a non-Muslim people and as such were a potential threat to the Muslim empire within which they resided. The Hamidian Massacres aroused the indignation of the entire Christian world. In the United States the now aging Julia Ward Howe, author of the Battle Hymn of the Republic, leaped into the war of words and joined the Red Cross. Relations of minorities within the Ottoman Empire and the disposition of former Ottoman lands became known as the Eastern Question, as the Ottomans were on the east of Europe.']
altered_context: The Ottoman Empire, thought to be on the verge of downfall, was depicted in the media ••as the ailing figure of Europe••. The nations in the Balkan region, with the partial exception of Bosnia and Albania, were mainly Christian. Commencing in 1894, the Ottomans targeted the Armenians explicitly based on their identity as a non-Muslim population, which were seen as a potential menace to the Muslim empire they inhabited. The Hamidian Massacres provoked outrage from the entirety of the Christian community. In the United States, the now elderly Julia Ward Howe, writer of the Battle Hymn of the Republic, engaged in the verbal conflict and became a member of the Red Cross. The status of minorities within the Ottoman Empire and the fate of former Ottoman territories were referred to as the Eastern Question, since the Ottomans were located to the east of Europe.
original_question: How was the Ottoman Empire portrayed in the press?
altered_question: How did the media depict the Ottoman Empire?
answer: as the sick man of Europe

title: Near_East
original_context: ['Some regions beyond the Ottoman Porte were included. One was North Africa west of Egypt. It was occupied by piratical kingdoms of the Barbary Coast, de facto independent since the 18th century. Formerly part of the empire at its apogee. Iran was included because it could not easily be reached except through the Ottoman Empire or neighboring Russia. In the 1890s the term tended to focus on ••the conflicts in the Balkan states and Armenia••. The demise of the sick man of Europe left considerable confusion as to what was to be meant by Near East. It is now generally used only in historical contexts, to describe the countries of Western Asia from the Mediterranean to (or including) Iran. There is, in short, no universally understood fixed inventory of nations, languages or historical assets defined to be in it.']
altered_context: ['Certain areas beyond the Ottoman Empire were incorporated. One of these was North Africa to the west of Egypt. It was governed by piracy-driven kingdoms along the Barbary Coast, which had been virtually autonomous since the 18th century. Previously a part of the empire at its zenith. Iran was involved because it was not easily accessible except via the Ottoman Empire or adjacent Russia. During the 1890s, the term predominantly emphasized ••the disputes in the Balkan nations and Armenia••. The fall of the sick man of Europe created significant uncertainty regarding the definition of Near East. Currently, it is typically employed solely in historical contexts, referring to the nations of Western Asia ranging from the Mediterranean to (or including) Iran. In summary, there is not a universally accepted fixed list of countries, languages, or historical factors that are defined to be within it.']
original_question: What did the term Near East focus on in the 1890s?
altered_question: What was the main focus of the Near East term during the 1890s?
answer: the conflicts in the Balkan states and Armenia

title: Near_East
original_context: ["Ptolemy's Geography divided Asia on a similar basis. In the north is Scythia this side of the Himalayas and Scythia beyond the Himalayas. ••To the south•• is India on this side of the Ganges and India beyond the Ganges. Asia began on the coast of Anatolia (land of the rising sun). Beyond the Ganges and Himalayas (including the Tien Shan) were Serica and Serae (sections of China) and some other identifiable far eastern locations known to the voyagers and geographers but not to the general European public."]
altered_context: ["Ptolemy's Geography classified Asia on a comparable foundation. In the northern region lies Scythia this side of the Himalayas and Scythia on the other side of the Himalayas. To the south is India on this side of the Ganges and India across the Ganges. Asia commenced at the coastline of Anatolia (the land of the rising sun). Beyond the Ganges and Himalayas (including the Tien Shan) were Serica and Serae (parts of China) along with several other distinguishable far eastern regions known to the explorers and geographers but unfamiliar to the broader European populace."]
original_question: "India on this side of the Ganges" is located where?
altered_question: Where is India situated on this side of the Ganges?

title: Near_East
original_context: ["In the last years of the 19th century the term Near East acquired considerable disrepute in eyes of the English-speaking public as did the Ottoman Empire itself. The cause of the onus was ••the Hamidian Massacres of Armenians•• because they were Christians, but it seemed to spill over into the protracted conflicts of the Balkans. For a time, Near East meant primarily the Balkans. Robert Hichens' book The Near East (1913) is subtitled Dalmatia, Greece and Constantinople."]
altered_context: During the final years of the 19th century, the phrase Near East gained significant disrepute among the English-speaking populace, much like the Ottoman Empire itself. The reason for this stigma was ••the Hamidian Massacres of Armenians•• targeting them because of their Christian faith, yet it appeared to extend into the prolonged disputes in the Balkans. For a while, Near East primarily signified the Balkans. Robert Hichens' publication The Near East (1913) carries the subtitle Dalmatia, Greece, and Constantinople.
original_question: What was the cause of the onus?
altered_question: What was the reason for the stigma?

title: Near_East
original_context: ['If the British Empire was now going to side with ••the Russian Empire••, the Ottoman Empire had no choice but to cultivate a relationship with the Austro-Hungarian Empire, which was supported by the German Empire. In a few years these alignments became the Triple Entente and the Triple Alliance (already formed in 1882), which were in part a cause of World War I. By its end in 1918 three empires were gone, a fourth was about to fall to revolution, and two more, the British and French, were forced to yield in revolutions started under the aegis of their own ideologies.']
altered_context: If the British Empire were now going to align with the Russian Empire, the Ottoman Empire had no choice but to nurture a relationship with the Austro-Hungarian Empire, which received backing from the German Empire. In a few years, these alliances evolved into the Triple Entente and the Triple Alliance (which had already been established in 1882), serving in part as a catalyst for World War I. By the conflict's conclusion in 1918, three empires had disappeared, a fourth was on the verge of succumbing to revolution, and two additional ones, the British and French, were compelled to concede in uprisings initiated under the banner of their own ideologies.
original_question: Who did the British Empire side with?
altered_question: With whom did the British Empire align?

title: Near_East
original_context: ["The term middle east as a noun and adjective was common in ••the 19th century•• in nearly every context except diplomacy and archaeology. An uncountable number of places appear to have had their middle easts from gardens to regions, including the United States. The innovation of the term Near East to mean the holdings of the Ottoman Empire as early as the Crimean War had left a geographical gap. The East Indies, or Far East, derived ultimately from Ptolemy's India Beyond the Ganges. The Ottoman Empire ended at the eastern border of Iraq. India This Side of the Ganges and Iran had been omitted. The archaeologists counted Iran as the Near East because Old Persian cuneiform had been found there. This usage did not sit well with the diplomats؛ India was left in an equivocal state. They needed a regional term."]
altered_context: ["The expression middle east, utilized as both a noun and an adjective, was prevalent in ••the 19th century•• across almost all scenarios except for diplomacy and archaeology. Countless locations seemed to possess their own middle easts, from gardens to territories, including the United States. The introduction of the label Near East to refer to the lands of the Ottoman Empire as early as the Crimean War created a geographical void. The East Indies, or Far East, ultimately stemmed from Ptolemy's India Beyond the Ganges. The Ottoman Empire's reach halted at the eastern perimeter of Iraq. India This Side of the Ganges and Iran were excluded. Archaeologists classified Iran as part of the Near East due to the discovery of Old Persian cuneiform there. This classification was not well-received by diplomats; India found itself in an ambiguous position. They required a regional descriptor."]
original_question: When was the term middle east common as a noun and adjective?
altered_question: In what century was the term middle east widely used as both a noun and adjective?

title: Zhejiang
original_context: ['At the beginning of the Three Kingdoms era (••220--280 CE••), Zhejiang was home to the warlords Yan Baihu and Wang Lang prior to their defeat by Sun Ce and Sun Quan, who eventually established the Kingdom of Wu. Despite the removal of their court from Kuaiji to Jianye (present-day Nanjing), they continued development of the region and benefitted from influxes of refugees fleeing the turmoil in northern China. Industrial kilns were established and trade reached as far as Manchuria and Funan (south Vietnam).']

Even after relocating their court from Kuaiji to Jianye (now known as Nanjing), they persistently advanced the development of the area and gained from arrivals of refugees escaping the chaos in northern China. Industrial furnaces were constructed and commerce extended as far as Manchuria and Funan (southern Vietnam).

title: Zhejiang
original_context: ['Valleys and plains are found along the coastline and rivers. The north of the province lies just south of the Yangtze Delta, and consists of plains around the cities of Hangzhou, Jiaxing, and Huzhou, where the Grand Canal of China enters from the northern border to end at Hangzhou. Another relatively flat area is found along the Qu River around the cities of Quzhou and Jinhua. Major rivers include the Qiangtang and Ou Rivers. Most rivers carve out valleys in the highlands, with plenty of rapids and other features associated with such topography. Well-known lakes include the West Lake of Hangzhou and the ••South Lake•• of Jiaxing.']
altered_context: ['Low-lying areas and flatlands are located alongside the shoreline and waterways. The northern section of the region is positioned just south of the Yangtze Delta, comprising level ground surrounding the urban centers of Hangzhou, Jiaxing, and Huzhou, where the Grand Canal of China flows in from the northern edge and concludes at Hangzhou. Another comparatively even zone is situated along the Qu River near the cities of Quzhou and Jinhua. Significant waterways include the Qiangtang and Ou Rivers. The majority of rivers shape valleys in the elevated regions, featuring numerous rapids and other characteristics related to such terrain. Famous lakes include the West Lake in Hangzhou and the ••South Lake•• in Jiaxing.']

title: Zhejiang
original_context: ["Zhejiang's main manufacturing sectors are electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. In recent years Zhejiang has followed its own development model, dubbed the Zhejiang model, which is based on prioritizing and encouraging entrepreneurship, an emphasis on small businesses responsive to the whims of the market, large public investments into infrastructure, and the production of low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic consumption and export. ", 'As a result, Zhejiang has made itself one of the richest provinces, and the Zhejiang spirit has become something of a legend within China. However, some economists now worry that this model is not sustainable, in that it is inefficient and places unreasonable demands on raw materials and public utilities, and also a dead end, in that the myriad small businesses in Zhejiang producing cheap goods in bulk are unable to move to more sophisticated or technologically more advanced industries. ', "The economic heart of Zhejiang is moving from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, southeastward to the region centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou. The per capita disposable income of urbanites in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) in 2009, an annual real growth of ••8.3%••. The per capita pure income of rural residents stood at 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a real growth of 8.1% year-on-year. Zhejiang's nominal GDP for 2011 was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, Zhejiang's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were worth 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively."]
altered_context: ["Zhejiang's primary manufacturing industries encompass electromechanical sectors, textiles, chemical production, foodstuffs, and construction materials. In recent times, Zhejiang has pursued its unique developmental approach, known as the Zhejiang model, which focuses on fostering and supporting entrepreneurship, highlighting small enterprises that are adaptable to market fluctuations, substantial public investment in infrastructure, and the mass production of inexpensive goods for both local consumption and export purposes.", 'Consequently, Zhejiang has established itself as one of the wealthiest provinces, and the ethos of Zhejiang has attained a legendary status within China. Nonetheless, certain economists are now expressing concerns that this approach may not be viable, as it tends to be inefficient and imposes excessive demands on raw materials and public services; furthermore, it presents a limitation, as the numerous small enterprises in Zhejiang producing affordable goods in large quantities struggle to transition to more advanced or technologically sophisticated industries.', "The economic core of Zhejiang is transitioning from North Zhejiang, with Hangzhou as its center, toward the area centered around Wenzhou and Taizhou. In 2009, the per capita disposable income of urban residents in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603), indicating an annual real growth of ••8.3%••. The per capita net income of rural inhabitants was 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), reflecting a real growth of 8.1% year-on-year. In 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion), with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, the values of Zhejiang's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively."]

original_context: ["The Defence Committee--Third Report Defence Equipment 2009 cites an article from the Financial Times website stating that the Chief of Defence Materiel, General Sir Kevin O'Donoghue, had instructed staff within Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) through an internal memorandum to reprioritize the approvals process to focus on supporting current operations over the next three years؛ deterrence related programmes؛ those that reflect defence obligations both contractual or international؛ and those where production contracts are already signed. ", 'The report also cites concerns over potential cuts in the defence science and technology research budget؛ implications of inappropriate estimation of Defence Inflation within budgetary processes؛ underfunding in the Equipment Programme؛ and a general concern over striking the appropriate balance over a short-term focus (Current Operations) and long-term consequences of failure to invest in the delivery of future UK defence capabilities on future combatants and campaigns. ', 'The then Secretary of State for Defence, Bob Ainsworth MP, reinforced this reprioritisation of focus on current operations and had not ruled out major shifts in defence spending. In the same article the First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, Royal Navy, acknowledged that there was not enough money within the defence budget and it is preparing itself for tough decisions and the potential for cutbacks. According to figures published by the London Evening Standard the defence budget for 2009 is ••more than 10% overspent•• (figures cannot be verified) and the paper states that this had caused Gordon Brown to say that the defence spending must be cut. The MoD has been investing in IT to cut costs and improve services for its personnel.']
altered_context: ["The Defence Committee's Third Report on Defence Equipment for 2009 references an article from the Financial Times online, which mentions that the Chief of Defence Materiel, General Sir Kevin O'Donoghue, had directed personnel within Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) via an internal memorandum to readjust the approvals procedure to concentrate on assisting current operations over the next three years; programmes related to deterrence; obligations regarding defence, both contractual and international; and those where production agreements have already been established.", 'The report additionally brings up worries regarding possible reductions in the defence science and technology research budget; the effects of inaccurate assessments of Defence Inflation within budgetary planning; insufficient funding in the Equipment Programme; and a broad concern about finding the right equilibrium between short-term priorities (Current Operations) and the long-term repercussions of failing to invest in future UK defence capabilities for upcoming combatants and operations.', 'At that time, the Secretary of State for Defence, Bob Ainsworth MP, emphasized this shift in focus towards current operations and did not dismiss the possibility of significant alterations in defence expenditure. Similarly, in the same article, the First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope of the Royal Navy, acknowledged the inadequacy of funds within the defence budget, preparing for stringent choices and the potential for reductions. As reported by the London Evening Standard, the defence budget for 2009 is noted to be more than 10% overspent (these figures are unverified), leading Gordon Brown to comment that defence funding must be reduced. The MoD has been investing in technology to reduce expenses and enhance services for its personnel.']
original_question: What has the Equipment Programme done with its budget in 2009 according to an internal memo?

title: Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)
original_context: ['The headquarters of the MoD are in Whitehall and are now known as Main Building. This structure is neoclassical in style and was originally built between 1938 and 1959 to designs by Vincent Harris to house the Air Ministry and the Board of Trade. The northern entrance in Horse Guards Avenue is flanked by two monumental statues, Earth and Water, by Charles Wheeler. Opposite stands the Gurkha Monument, sculpted by Philip Jackson and unveiled in ••1997•• by Queen Elizabeth II. Within it is the Victoria Cross and George Cross Memorial, and nearby are memorials to the Fleet Air Arm and RAF (to its east, facing the riverside). A major refurbishment of the building was completed under a PFI contract by Skanska in 2004.']
altered_context: ['The central office of the Ministry of Defence is situated in Whitehall and is currently referred to as the Main Building. This edifice is designed in a neoclassical fashion and was initially constructed between 1938 and 1959, based on plans by Vincent Harris, to accommodate the Air Ministry and the Board of Trade. The northern entry point on Horse Guards Avenue is accompanied by two grand statues, Earth and Water, created by Charles Wheeler. Across from it stands the Gurkha Monument, designed by Philip Jackson and inaugurated in ••1997•• by Queen Elizabeth II. Inside, one can find the Victoria Cross and George Cross Memorial, and adjacent are tributes to the Fleet Air Arm and RAF (to its east, overlooking the riverside). A significant renovation of the structure was finalized under a PFI agreement by Skanska in 2004.']
original_question: When was Horse Guards Avenue unveiled by Queen Elizabeth II?
altered_question: When was the Gurkha Monument revealed by Queen Elizabeth II?

title: Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)
original_context: ['The MoD has been criticised for an ongoing fiasco, having spent ••£240m•• on eight Chinook HC3 helicopters which only started to enter service in 2010, years after they were ordered in 1995 and delivered in 2001. A National Audit Office report reveals that the helicopters have been stored in air conditioned hangars in Britain since their 2001[why?] delivery, while troops in Afghanistan have been forced to rely on helicopters which are flying with safety faults. By the time the Chinooks are airworthy, the total cost of the project could be as much as £500m.']
altered_context: The Ministry of Defence has faced criticism for a continuing debacle, having invested ••£240m•• in eight Chinook HC3 helicopters which only commenced service in 2010, several years after their order in 1995 and delivery in 2001. A report by the National Audit Office indicates that the helicopters have been kept in climate-controlled hangars in the UK since their 2001[why?] delivery, while soldiers in Afghanistan have had to depend on helicopters that are operating with safety issues. By the time the Chinooks become operational, the overall expenditure for the undertaking could escalate to £500m.
original_question: How much did the MoD spend on Chinook helicopters?
altered_question: What amount did the MoD allocate for the Chinook helicopters?
